text:
We are in an ice age and have been for millions of years. We are in an interglacial period and that will not end for 5000 year or so. What caused the ice age was Antarctica moving over the south pole AND the Indian and Eurasian plates crashing together to create the Himalayans, disrupting air patterns, and¬†increasing the albedo of the planet. What causes the interglacial period is the changes in the earth orbit, processing, and the position of the earth in the orbit during the season.

There is no evidence that the atmosphere is sensitive to a change in co2 levels. That is because co2 is not the trigger that some people claim it is. Look at the second graph of this page.https://www.geocraft.com/WVFossils/Carboniferous_climate.html
You will see that there is no link between co2 levels and co2. 

The alarmist spend hundreds of billions to spread fake information because of two reasons. First they are trying to destroy capitalism so that they can create a one world government. Secondly, some of them are using it to get rich. Its all about power and money.

Animals have been able to handle much greater rates of change than has happen in the last century. In the late 1500 to early 1600, the temperature dropped by over 3¬∞c in little more than a century.¬†IF they can handle a drop that drastically, they can easily handle a rise of 1¬∞c per century.

text:
¬†@ZigSputnik¬† this is going to be a long reply, first some definitions and disclaimers, global warming is different than, climate change .. you can have climate change with global warming, but not the other way around.  does man impact and cause climate change .. absolutely .... but the term climate change is such a broad term that it literally is applied to EVERYTHING, if you build a house that is personal climate change, the changing of the season is ... climate change, .. one is man made the other is not.  cruise ships dumping garbage into the oceans is climate change, just as when you plant a tree or forest... 

global warming is completely different, although it impacts climate change dramatically, first is global warming happening, yes.. to a small degree, over the past 120 years the temperature has risen about 1C ( 0.9C or 1.62F) with most of this change happening over the past 35 years, ... was the cause for this rise CO2... most likely yes. (I say most likely because its not 100%.. but more like 90% proven, close enough for me, I say that because we didn't have the means to measure a lot of things back then)

ok, so now we come to the heart of the problem, CO2 does not act in the way that most people believes it does, CO2 absorbs only very specific wavelengths, 2.7, 4.3, and 15 microns, once absorbed it then radiates them in every direction almost instantly (this happens in 83 femtoseconds) in completely different wavelength that fluctuates but the average is about 25 microns, meaning they are not re absorbed by other CO2 molecules, with the current amount of CO2 this all happens in about 10 meters, meaning that those 3 wavelengths never make it to the ground... then once IR reflects off the ground... those three wavelengths make it about 10M off the ground before they are all absorbed and changed into another wavelength... thus  all of the suns energy absorbed during the day leaves through the atmosphere during the night.

if we where to double the amount of CO2 the same process would happen in about 5M instead of 10M I can explain this mathematically if you wish.  what does this really mean?  CO2 does not act in the way that the media says it does, and there is nothing about global warming that is alarming, also no change we do to impact CO2 (increase or decrease) will have any real impact to global warming, (there is an exception to this... but would mean we would need to see a HUGE increase in plant life, thus increasing the water vapor that is constantly in the atmosphere) ... I can expound on anything you want ... let me know.

text:
¬†@Sentient #6¬† That still doesn't make it the greatest issue, friend. And stating, "well it is" doesn't prove your point either. I could just say, "Well it isn't," and that has just as much validity as your statement. But with a hypothetical, I'll show you why it's not the worst thing that could happen to humans. 

If a war were to break out that is so massive most governments stop functioning properly and crime is the norm, from torture to murder and so forth. And this lasts for generations. Would you prefer that reality or extinction? Choosing extinction means you agree extinction is not the worst possible scenario for humans. 

And to actually detail my point originally, it's not to diminish Climate Change's importance and our job to stop it, but that it could take quite awhile for it to actually become a critical extinction danger for humans, though of course other animals like polar bears are already affected much more and will be extinct far sooner than us, and that is definitely something worth stopping but doesn't make it such a critical danger (yet) for humans. 

Though also, the most significant impact any individual can have on climate change, is to have a plant-based / Vegan diet. The last time I checked (about a year or two ago) Animal Agriculture is the LEADING cause of green-house gas emissions, even more than all the world's transportation combined. Veganism is when you care for the animals and that's why you don't eat animal products, but even if you don't care about them, being plant-based (which is the same as Veganism but without you caring for animals) is beneficial to you and the world because it is the best thing any individual can do if you really want to stop or slow down climate change. And plant-based diets have been proven healthy for all stages of life, from pregnancy to adulthood.

text: ok So most normal people believe that the earth is warming, You loose some people when you say that we are the cause, although most normal people will say we at least contribute to the problem. You loose more when you say if we get rid of fossil fuels the problem is solved, because most normal scientist will tell you they can't guarantee that it will stop global warming. As mentioned the earth was a lot warmer before humans were even alive. I have no issues with moving towards cleaner air and water, however I do not go along with the green new deal who do not take into account for money, jobs and poor planning. Because if you don't plan properly and you don't test ideas in small areas, you can do more harm than good. The easiest would example would be to go back to the 80's when we were all told that plastic bags were going to save the planet. That paper bags and packaging were causing irreputable harm to the environment due to deforestation. It was scientist who told us this along with conservationist. How did that work out? I don't think most of you realize how bad the chemicals are that go into solar panels. Electric cars are really Coal burning cars at this point in time. So let's all not panic, Work hard to find good solutions. Test them in small areas until we sure they won't do more harm and go forward. By the way you don't need the government to do anything, for you to use less fossil fuels. Get a small car or motor cycle or better yet rid a peddle bike. Switch to LED lighting. Shut off your cable box because it uses more electricity than any other appliance in your house.(unless you have a 1970's fridge). Use reusable bags. Take public transportation.  There are a million little things all of us can do to use less energy. If your not than you are part of the problem. Be the solution. Be an inspiration to others to use less energy. Don't be someone on a pedestal preaching to others. You catch more bees with honey than vinegar.

text:
One recent survey says only 13% of Americans don‚Äôt believe the climate is changing because of humans.  Only 5% believe the climate isn‚Äôt changing.  These are not small numbers I know but I say ‚Äúonly‚Äù because the overwhelming majority believe we are causing climate change. So the issue isn‚Äôt so much denial anymore as what to do about it.   It certainly seems to me that humans are causing climate change. My issue with the climate crusaders side of this argument is the insistence that renewable energy sources that don‚Äôt work or even do more environment harm are going to solve our problems.  

Solar produces CO2 free energy (kinda), but what happens when they are used up, obsolete, or damaged?  Off to China with the rest of the e-waste.  That‚Äôs just ONE simple example of many that shows what‚Äôs wrong with current renewable energy technology. 

Point is these are complex problems that aren‚Äôt easy to solve and many of the climate crusaders as guilty as of putting on blinders to the facts as the climate deniers.  We can‚Äôt just blindly push for renewable so we can feel good over solving one issue while simultaneously creating equally negative consequences.

text:
IPCC¬†:¬†
Doubling current¬† co2 would cause 1¬∞ of warming.
The¬†ipcc models predicting global temp ¬†used speculative secondary forcing projections based on this observation.
Let's do¬†the¬†math:
Atmospheric co2, appx 2.3 billion tons
co2 makes up 27% of carbon based fuels
Half of human produced co2 is reabsorbed by the ocean etc.

The Lambert-Beer law states that radiant energy absorption decreases with saturation, meaning the more co2 there is the less forcing effect.

Das¬†Lambert-Beer'sche¬†Gesetz¬†oder Bouguer-Lambert-Beer'sche¬†Gesetz¬†beschreibt die Abschw√§chung der Intensit√§t einer Strahlung in Bezug zu deren Anfangsintensit√§t bei dem Durchgang durch ein Medium mit einer absorbierenden Substanz, in Abh√§ngigkeit von der Konzentration der absorbierenden Substanz und der Schichtdicke.

We need to produce about 2000 million tons of co2 to alter the temperature according to the assumption that co2 could drive the climate.
That would take us a few hundred years
However there is only so much to burn on the planet:
Coal - 900 million tons¬†
Oil - 300 million tons
Petrol - 100 million tons

Also...
Co2 absorbs energy in only 2 radiant frequencies: 4, and 10 micrometers. 
How is a trace gas with such a low absorption rate going to drive global temperatures?

Also:
2nd law of thermodynamics:
No open system can heat itself or maintain its temperature. 
The air in a greenhouse does not heat up because of radiative forcing, it heats up because it is trapped by the glass and cannot radiate the heat out or mix with other air. The earth's atmosphere however is losing heat constantly to outer space.

text:
¬†@Scott Koontz¬† that's math extrapolated from the IPCC's own assessment. The sun is obviously the largest energy contributor, aside from cosmic rays,  volcanoes, orbital distances and inclinations etc. The total co2 budget for the planet is less than half of one percent of the atmosphere, and the human contribution is 3 to 4 percent of that.  This is just the science. Co2 is a vital aspect of our ability to digest, among other fundamental functions. In any case, co2 has been out of lock-step with the temperature for thousands of years at a time and there have been much more rapid warming phases in the past. Here is an overview of a few hundred data points (30yr trend cycles): 
We live in an interglacial ice age:¬† the Holocene. The current interglacial period is older than other similar periods. If there is a trend we are due for more cooling.
20th century rates of warming:
1910-1940¬†- 0.5¬∞ per 30 yrs
1940 to 1980 there was cooling
1980-2000¬†- 0.4¬∞ per 30 yrs (lower rate)
Previous rates were much higher:
1326 bc global warming rate: 1.4¬∞ per century
6440 bc global warming rate: 1.9¬∞ per century
9620 bc global warming rate 100¬∞ per century. This is the start of the Holocene interglacial. The rate was more than 111x that of late 20th century rate.
1817 bc 50¬∞ per century

Medieval Warm Period¬†
1100's to 1300's¬†
The MGWP was 0.25¬∞ warmer than today
Vikings grew crops in Greenland and had settlements on the coast of northern Canada.

text:
Statisticulation (statistical manipulation) 
97 percent consensus?
The Studies ask Different Questions and have different parameters. Not a basis for agglomerated consent. Many scientists who do not agree with catastrophic AGW are listed in with those who do agree. Their objections are ignored, even if they publicly reject the results of studies that claim to prove the consensus.
Actual study results
Naomi Oreskes 2004
Study was published 4 days before the Kyoto Conference, before it was peer reviewed. It is always cited as a peer reviewed paper.
there was Global Cooling noted by 2006
Al Gore claimed broadly, citing the Orensky study, that zero scientists disagreed w the AGW

B. Pizer in England did same study as Orensky with very different results
13 explicit endorsement of CAGW
322 endorse but focus on impacts
89 mitigation proposals
67 reject or doubt consensus
470 no position at all‚Ä¶ they just mentioned CC in their papers
unrelated to climate change
44 natural factors
87 focus on methods

Doran and Zimmerman 2009
Margaret Kendall Zimmermans thesis
The consensus on the consensus
10257 earth scientists
3246 responded
79 selected themselves to represent the study‚Ä¶ they publish papers on climate

Questions Asked:
compared to pre 80s do you think mean temp has gone up or down?
do you think humans are causing the uptick?
opinion poll‚Ä¶ not empirical data

Data Base - 79 Scientists
38 objected‚Ä¶ its the Sun
5 said humans have a nominal effect
1 said its HDCC
77 out of 79 agreed with one of the questions 
and 78 out of 79 agreed with the other‚Ä¶ 

Anderegg et al - student paper
published in the National Academy of Science Journal -not peer reviewed 
wrangled in by Steven Schneider 
‚Äúcontributed articles‚Äù - scientific op ed,
Angderegg went through the IPPC list and found out that 34 percent of scientists in the IPPC disagree with the notion of Catastrophic AGW.
However, Andereeg chose to narrow the study to only the IPPC members who publish. They only make up 5 percent of the IPPC scientist staff. 97 percent of those who publish are with the ADGCC.

One of the most cited studies: John Cook
Australian Climate Communications Officer
Definition Question/Statement : Humans Cause Warming 12 or 13,000 articles, many were not representative of the discipline of the whole, and included opinion pieces. They only read the abstracts.
67 percent had no position
.5 percent endorsed AGW
Many authors who are included in the study publicly objected to how their work was characterized. One article was only about media coverage of Climate Change.When several scientists demanded to review the data, Cook dissimulated. 
A hacker got to the data. He then waffled on time-stamps. When the time-stamps were found you could see that they processed an unrealistic number of articles in too little time to be able to actually evaluate them. Investigators discovered that Cook classified articles that are in disagreement as supportive of the Catastrophic AGW hypothesis.
He later admitted that the data was not processed well.

Actual Percentages of endorsements for Catastrophic AGW:
Orensky 1.2 percent
Doran and Zimmermann 2.38  percent
Anderegg 66 percent
Cook and al 0.54 percent

Yes plants absorb CO2, and if they die and fossilize, they‚Äôre compacted into fossil fuels. Since we use those broken down fossil fuels as a source of energy to power vehicles, Its released into the atmosphere. When the suns energy comes in through the atmosphere, most is able to escape back into space once it reaches the earths surface, but some of that heat is held in by CO2 and other greenhouse gases (which has and is slowly heating up the atmosphere). So yes it does contribute to climate change, it‚Äôs just not too noticeable because 90% of that heat is absorbed by the ocean, and water expands when heated, plus the additional melting ice from the poles. It‚Äôs a threat, and a very real one, if we don‚Äôt find a way to slow the process it‚Äôs going to have some devastating impact.

text: ¬†@Scott Koontz¬† The data demonstrates the opposite, at least where catastrophic AGW is concerned. The polls were done badly. There are several parts to the question, parts of which are and parts of which are not controversial. Climate Change is an obvious thing and no scientist disputes that. The greenhouse effect is already disputed by some scientists. The human contribution to co2 is undisputed, but co2's forcing effect is disputed widely. Very few scientists think that humans are driving climate, although all think there might be some contribution. I follow scientific conferences in four languages, so I see a fair amount of data gathering results and hear quite a range of opinions. The climate alarmist camp is funded to the teeth, so I think it's difficult to find a party without a conflict of interest at this point.

1970-1999 is 29 years, and from 0.03¬∞C to 0.40¬∞C is a 0.37¬∞C increase. 0.37/29*10 ‚âà 0.13¬∞C increase per decade.
1999-2019 is 20 years, and from 0.40¬∞C to 0.82¬∞C is a 0.42¬∞C increase. 0.42/20*10 ‚âà 0.21¬∞C increase per decade.

Which one is the larger number? 0.13 or 0.21. Take your time.

text: I have a fond memories in my mind. Back in 2007, I was swimming in the pool and a very familiar scent hit my nose. It was the scent that rain carries with it. I love it a lot. Suddenly the grey clouds arrived and it started raining cats and dogs. I left but thunder and lightning followed and it rained like that for almost 3 months. That was my last good memory of a proper rain pattern. It would always come on time, either the first week of April or the last week of May. Last year, I saw very little rain. It would rain for 3 days a week and then it would be dry again. I miss the scent of rain clouds. It almost never rains during the day time anymore here. Only during night. This is a literal example of climate change and people still don't believe in it.

text:
Fact: Glaciers are not permanent snow cover. 

Fact: Melting glaciers are melting from below, due to pressure melting of compressed snow not increased atmospheric temperatures.

Fact: Climate is not global. Climate is local or regional.

Fact: Weather is not local, it is transitory. Moving along upper air currents like the Jet Stream.

Fact: Every year since 1957 a medallion has been placed on the exact south pole. It moves several hundred feet per year. This is due to the Antarctic ice cap being a giant glacier and moving to sea level elevation.

Fact: Those "growth rings" in ice cores are not years, they are snow storms. 

Fact: Polar Bear numbers have increased sizably since the 1950s.

text: Joe, for being a PhD you included an awful lot of spin in this video. I implore you to be more honest in the future + 2 address your bias so that you can have a more open mind. I too am a college professor. I was like you for a while and assumed my position. But as I was working day and night on a series of patents to address global warming I looked at the data more closely. I can tell you I hate being lied to. The first thing I discovered was there is no empirical data showing that CO2 has increased temperatures. There is however significant data showing that increasing temperatures have generated a significant positive correlation With CO2 levels. That my friend it's just the tip of the iceberg. You either know the truth and don't care or you don't know the truth and don't care. Because, if you did care you would begin pointing out the large number of inconsistencies and inaccuracies not to mention the huge number of lies and fraud. Such as the fact that ocean levels are not accelerating, there is no increase in extreme weather according to virtually every reputable scientist, glaciers have been melting since the mid-1800s, NASA manipulation of surface temperatures, etc etc etc! You seem to be very good at YouTube so I implore you to address your biases and be more comprehensive in certain areas. God bless you and I wish you and yours well.

text:
¬†@P Mason¬† I don't understand your last comment, needs clarification please. Otherwise, I think we're capable of spontaneously wanting to do good. It's just that it's a lot easier etc. if the systems of human interaction, such as economics or politics, are set up to encourage it. In other words, to get deep change in human behaviour, it really helps strategically to have the law on your side. So political organisation is required for effective change. But that won't click in, I pessimistically think, until the reptures in life around the industrialised world due to CC etc mean that we know we have more to gain than to lose by changing those systems. And by then, of course, it will be too late.¬†But if you can be more optimistic than me, more power to you, buddy.
Personally I think we need to break our economic dependence on industry. This means society learning to live without needing to economically expand. And since capitalism requires expansion in order for its economics to work (as result of the profit motive), that means things will get really bad before changing industrialised economics will obviously be less damaging to those economies than not changing it.¬†
The degree of future damage is mitigated by all the good actions we do now. However, I don't think non-law-affecting action can stop the eventual collapse of the global economy, and a century or so of bloody global chaos as a result. It's even more regretable due to the fact that we can see the collapse coming but not clearly enough to make enough of us want to change enough of our behaviour to stop it. But again, that's why we need law on our side. (Once the political aspect clicks in you're well into the cycle of political revolution. That's another story. I've written a book about that, and someone actually published it.)
author: Grant Bartley

text: I mean, I don't understand your last sentence

text:
¬†@P Mason¬† I like the quote. I read it a different way, but can see that aspects of the controversy may easily make an unnecessarily divisive stimulus in the sort of way you cite.¬†
The truth is scary enough, surely. Cultural collapses cost lives. In particular, global trading network collapses (in revolutions and world wars etc) have always been disturbing to the people caught in the falling net. Social paradigm shifts are destructive, and we're heading for a big one; and although we can't say how big, the less we do to swerve to avoid it, the bigger the destruction.
author: Grant Bartley

text:

 I'm thinking, if we could manage to produce and maintain a zero percent inflaiion economy, that would stop economic growth in its tracks; maybe first the unnecessary stuff. But maybe a zero inflation economy is as difficult to achieve as absolute zero K. And about as much fun to live in.

text:
I‚Äôm confused.....and maybe someone out there can lend insight.  He stated (at 3:44) that from 1900 until today that the average temperature in the world has increased 1 degree. And then concluded that within the next 100 years we will see a temperature increase from 2.4 to 4.8%, and a subsequent increase in sea level by 1 meter.  Politically I‚Äôm ‚Äúindependent‚Äù so I don‚Äôt have a dog in the political fight - but rather I‚Äôm seeking the truth.

Because I‚Äôm over 50 years old, I‚Äôve been around long enough to see a lot of scientific ‚Äúfacts‚Äù turn out to be wrong.  And while I love science, I also am enamored with the study of human behavior.  That being said, I‚Äôve seen waaaaay too many scientists start off with the conclusion, and then try and prove what they already believe to be true.  I just found out that there‚Äôs actually a term for it, ‚Äúconfirmation bias‚Äù. (It‚Äôs when you form an opinion and then you create a theory. And then you work hard to prove it).  Does anyone remember when ‚Äúkiller bees‚Äù were going to wipe out North America, and it was a sure thing?  Or when it was determined as fact that the ‚Äúwalking catfish‚Äù in Florida bodies of water were going to wipe out the entire fish ecosystem throughout the U.S.?  I‚Äôm not doubting some of these facts, especially the CO2 situation.......but can someone point me to a better source of information that does more than leap from the 1 degree historical temperature change, to the 2.5 - 5% that is ‚Äúcertainly‚Äù coming our way? (While I do have a skeptical eye, I am teachable and want to know the science of what we know and don‚Äôt know about the future climate change situation........and help is GREATLY appreciated!!).  Thanks!

text: This video is condescending and Full of lies. The warmest decade was in the 30s but of course the climate change people ignore that information so they can make their little models work, well we know how good the models are because they have missed the mark on every model they produced.  Their models are all made by academics who have no idea what they‚Äôre doing. If you build a model that has garbage going into it you get garbage going out. That‚Äôs the way of models. For any model to be working properly and it needs to be validated. The correlations they put in for CO2 versus temperature are basically created out of nothing.  If CO2 was driving temperature and the CO2 has doubled why has there not been a sharper increase in temperature. The temperature is been rising almost at the same rate since 1950 after a declining Before that. Yet  these liars will tell you that it‚Äôs jumping at 10 times normal. So they agreed temperature was rising that it‚Äôs just about how fast. Using the scientific principle you change one variable to see how the other responds. Well we‚Äôve been fortunate in the case of CO2 because it has doubled and yet the temperature is almost flat in relative terms. Why is it not doubling in fact if you look back in the ice record You do see a correlation between temperature and CO2. Some might say the temperature is leading and other say CO2. But this is the first time there‚Äôs been a dramatic departure and we know CO2 is leading. What else do you need to know if CO2 was driving the temperature it should be off the scale. But it‚Äôs not. He starts off by mentioning polar bears yet the polar bear population is thriving and has reached its highest in Decades.  Perfect example of anecdotal data they used to try and scare people thinking the planet is coming to an end or at least life on the planet. They are the climate change pug who cried Wolf and soon it will all come crashing down as they‚Äôre running out of time to steal your money in the name of saving the planet from global catastrophe. Yes it is about global catastrophe because the globalist on the planet want to eliminate borders and the only way they can do it is to find a cause that everybody can get behind. Don‚Äôt give up your sovereignty to the united nation clowns. The real sad part here is they want to dedicate resources that could go to feeding people housing people and making clean air. Travel to some of the poorest countries in the world and you can‚Äôt see across the street. Much of it comes from the burning of organics such as wood and whatever else they can get their hands on. That‚Äôs not CO2 in the air. It costs millions of lives every year and yet they want to focus on a gas that has no affect on health. This behaviour is verging on criminal. He also states that the Oceans are more acidic. The oceans are not acidic, They are basic about 8.2. He refers to the Arctic ice is shrinking but then makes an extremely revealing confession that 1400 years ago the ice was the same as it is now. So how is it that if it‚Äôs so extremely warm now that the Arctic ice was in the same condition 1400 years ago yes you get to see the picture this is not an unusual thing on the planet to have the Arctic ice recede. He does talk about sea level rising .1 inches a year. Wow like that hasn‚Äôt happened before. The oceans have risen 300 m since the last Ice Age .1 inches a year doesn‚Äôt seem that a normal does it. He throws in a comment about how icebergs seem to be disappearing or at least the ice shelves are disappearing. Last time I checked That was a natural process where the icebergs flow off the continents into the water where they disappear. What he fails to mention is that all of those ice sheets that are supposedly going to cause the oceans to rise are already floating. And the last time I checked when floating ice melts it doesn‚Äôt increase the level of the water. And guess what folks the average temperature at the South Pole is minus 56 deg f so it‚Äôs not going to melt. He finishes off with A wild statement that the ocean is going to rise a metre which is catastrophic to people on the earth. Well I would say that‚Äôs a huge overstatement in that very few people are going to be affected by an ocean rise of a metre even if it did happen. And right now people in Miami are betting against that because it‚Äôs some of the most expensive property in the world. People don‚Äôt believe it because it‚Äôs BS.

text:
Global warming does not exist that is created by man. Do you seriously contend that our little gases compete with the drive of the sun and our seas? How you all sound (but a couple comments are in the know). The earth's climate changes...that's a fact. The earth's warming and cooling cycles are actually tract and we have been much warmer in previous centuries (surprise) when there was no CO2, etc. If any are really curious about the truth and are interested in educating yourselves go watch the youtube video "The Dark Winter 640" by Dr. John Casey a former NASA climatologist who has been ringing the hoax bell for decades. Oh yes, the change from global warming to climate change (how convenient). At first, I think the UN's scientists (the UN is where all the climate change computers are kept) was sincere though driven by greed. When it was obvious to them the warming period was coming to an end they started parameterizing the data into the software of the climate change computers. In other words, they fudge the numbers to get the results they want and switched the fear mongering cry from global warming to climate change. This reminds me of when the French sold the idea of bottled water to the Americans. What a concept, now thousands liter our earth with plastics unintentionally yearly and poison themselves with mini plastic from regular use of drinking from plastic containers.

What we really need to do is clean up our planet. That doesn't mean we have to throw our gas cars away either. If climate change was so very real; eating meat would be outlawed (all the clearcutting and animal factory farms give off more greenhouse gases then all of the factories and all of the vehicles on the earth combined (surprised?). Anyway, for instance, the warming of the oceans are blamed on the coral bleaching that is destroying our reefs around the world. This is a natural process that happens to corral all the time but the thing that is actually killing them is the pollution created by us. All the reefs are estimated to be saturated/covered with plastics measuring an average of 5cm long with the coral harvesting, ocean pollution, and bad fishing practices adding to the problem. Corral is a live animal and can't breathe when covered in plastic that 'we' put in the ocean:  it's such a shame that we don't seem to care anymore.

We have gotten away from the average person recycling and don't dry your clothes in a dryer and don't buy anything in plastic; covering the whole realm up to cleaning up environmental sprays etc, etc... The garbage of the world is created by us and here we are embracing climate change which has nothing to do with how we are destroying this planet. The climate changes, that's it. You see, the globalist elite cannot make money with just cleaning up the planet: there's no money in it. But with man-made climate change, they can force mass migration, build electric cars and plants when fusion energy would have been so cheap and so convenient. author: Not a Persona

text:
1. You weaken your argument when you admit that high levels of CO2 existed before, but humans did not even exist.  If your cause is absent, yet your effect is present, then your causal argument is weak.  

2.  Even if we accept your premises as accurate, a question of quantity is still unanswered: how do you we know that the amount of increase in global temperature caused by CO2 equals the amount of CO2 produced by humans?  This quantity is especially important because your own data proves that the current CO2 level existed when humans did not exist; therefore, the same natural conditions as before could produce the same effects today.

3.  You constantly cherry pick the evidence: your timeline starts at 1770, then 1870, and then 1970.  You must show the data from all years to be accurate because there could be drops in global temperature when CO2 levels were high.  This video is an insult to basic statistics.

text:
"There are solar cycles and earth orbital cycles." As if the mere existance of them could explain the way climate changes now? 
"They both have more of an effect on weather and climate than man does" Unsupported assertion.
"Was that caused by CO2?" Why would it mean everything is caused by CO2? 
"It certainly was warmer in the US in the 1930's" You mean one year in the 30s in one part of the world? 
"Any chart that claims it was colder in the 30's is based on fudged proxy data" Because everything that doesn't support your conclusion is faked, naturally. 
"Besides, Global average temperature is not a very accurate number anyway" So you admit they couldn't know it was warmer in the 30s by this logic? Consistency, please.
"Do they really measure the total global temperature with widely scattered data point?" Therefore all temperature readings are invalid? Wonder how we get an upward trend in the first place?

It is absurd on it's face to think a trace gas like CO2, which has been much higher in the past according to ice cores, is controlling our climate like these alarmist are trying to say it does.  Ice is starting to grow again in the arctic and what if we start having very severe winters and short summers in the Northern Hemisphere? "trace gas" So is ozone, yet nobody says that isn't important. There's 0,04% of CO2, yet there's 0,000007% of ozone to protect us from lethal solar radiation. There's 78% nitrogen and it's worthless as a greenhouse gas.
"which has been much higher in the past" So what? They don't contradict with anything. Why would they?
"Ice is starting to grow again in the arctic" You mean one year fluctuation? Try 3 decade long down trend.
"what if" What if spiderman fought batman?
"solar physicist are saying the next 10 years will be colder" No, they say the sun will be colder. The Earth's climate is affected by multible things, not just sun. Temperatures might not even drop.

"Some are even predicting a little ice age" Peer reviewed scientific paper published in respected scientific journal is needed to verify your claims.

text: Yes, we have warming but mostly as a natural cycle as is easy to see in all data. The alleged speed is not real. The ice core data show that the CO2 lags the temperature.  On the NASA website they cite the IPCC report as proof and IPCC cites NASA as proof. In the IPCC references there is also no other relevant proof for the CO2 thesis. The temperature data only comes from two US government agency sources (NASA and NOAA) so they report as required. The data are modified each year to 'adjust' for biases. Unbiased data do not show anywhere near the warming and the manmade component is most likely minimal but exists. Supposedly 15 degrees is the optimal average temperature (which is nonsense in itself) and we are at 14.8. text:
Renewables are falling in cost dramatically each year along with storage costs.  Utility-scale solar costs declined nearly 30% last year, commercial scale by 15%, while residential solar costs fell 6%.  Renewables are now among the least costly ways to generate electricity, so they can‚Äôt be horribly inefficient.  Add another half a penny for electrical energy storage and you are looking at $0.035 a kilowatt hour for solar and a bit less for wind by mid-next decade.  Fossil fuels can‚Äôt touch this kind of low cost.

Nuclear power has a role to play in electricity generation (at $0.095 a kilowatt hour) but it can‚Äôt practically get to more than a 30% solution (it‚Äôs 15% now globally).  

We waste more energy than we actually use so efficiency gains would be an important direction to pursue.

Methane is a secondary issue compared to the huge amount of carbon dioxide being emitted.  Livestock is about 2% of the overall methane effect at most and methane itself is causing 20% of the warming that carbon dioxide is causing.

Latest costs I could find (three years old, from the US government).

Wind Offshore $.197/kWh
Wind Onshore $.074/kWh (but as low as $.032)

Solar Thermal $.240/kWh (but $.100 to $.120 this year for molten salt version)
Residential Solar PV $.125/kWh
Community Solar PV $.110/kWh
Commercial Solar PV $.092/kWh
Utility Solar PV $.050/kWh ($.044 with sun tracking)

Natural Gas Conv Combined Cycle $.142/kWh
Natural Gas Adv Combined Cycle $.073/kWh (still in play)
Peaking Gas Combustion Turbine $.156/kWh (almost obsolete)
IGCC (coal gas) $.116/kWh

Nuclear $.095/kWh (but increased to $.112 to $.183 this year, not sure why)
Coal $.095/kWh ($.060 to $.143 this year, triple this for GHGs & health consequences)
Hydro $.084/kWh
Geothermal $.048/kWh (cheapest option where available)
Biomass $.101/kWh

Some interesting statistics

Global Nuclear Capacity 1987 = 300 GW and 2017 = 351 GW (30 years, 17% increase)

Global Solar PV Capacity 2016 = 302 GW and 2017 = 405 GW (1 year, 34% increase)

Solar PV Capacity Projections for 2020 = 500 GW and 2050 = 4,600 GW

I‚Äôd bet on solar rather than nuclear, but even solar will be just part of the solution.

text:
Sorry but natural cycles have been absolutely ruled out.  It's us.  

Climate data is regularly collected independently by at least 5 agencies and 3 satellite services plus reanalyzed from original data source in peer-reviewed literature occasionally and they all agree.  Even skeptical sources like BEST agree.  

And, of course, FIVE BILLION dollars are NOT paid to climate change researchers EACH YEAR by governments.  Most climate research is performed by private institutions and it is done for free (as a requirement of teaching positions or completing doctoral degrees).  At most governments toss in some grant money for hiring students or lab space.  It is expressly forbidden for scientists to financially benefit from their research in a direct way, just to keep them unbiased.  For the same reason, the IPCC is an all volunteer organization.

At this point it should be clear to any reader that you have no knowledge about the climate topic so there's little point addressing all the the other falsehoods in your comment.

text:
Climate change is absolutely real. The
problem is people do not understand the cause¬†of global warming. The
planet has been warming for the last 100 years because we have been in a solar
maximum for the last¬†100¬†years, since the last solar minimum called
the Centennial Minimum which ended at solar cycle 14. The last seven solar
cycles have been especially high in amplitude with average amplitude of 200.05
resulting in an even more rapid warming of the planet. But the Grand Solar
Maximum ended with solar cycle 23;¬†solar cycle 24¬†started in 2009
with an extremely low and long minima, two very low peaks (2012 and 2014),
and¬†since has nose-dived back to minima levels.¬†Cycle 24 will
be¬†amplitude 116.4, the lowest since the aforementioned cycle 14 which
came in at amplitude¬†107.1, and cycle 25 will be at least¬†30% lower
putting us back to Dalton Minimum levels. Many expect cycle 26 to be low also
and if that happens we will experience Maunder Minimum conditions. GCR's will
continue to increase due to the solar minimum and these cause¬†increasing
cloud nucleation, seismic activity and volcanism. Cloud nucleation and
volcanism will increase the albedo¬†effect¬†and¬†the planet will
cool for the next 20-50 years (or longer if we are unlucky). By then we should
have burned up all of the carbon trying not to freeze and still heat our
greenhouses so we can feed ourselves. Problem solved, remember: stay calm and
carry on. Climate change is real but humans do not need to and should not try
to avert it, we will fail. What we need to and will have no choice but to do is
adapt to the changing climate like we always have, if we can. Sincerely Jess W
Fulbright¬† June 2, 2018.

text:
We know WHY Climate Change happens, as it has happened for millions of years.  Climate Change is a part of our planet's cycle and involves gravitational pulls from the sun, moon and other forces we can't control.
.
We can also see a correlation between human activity and Climate Change.  Correlation does not equal causation, which is why a lot of ancient beliefs and sacrifices were not accurate or helpful.  Just because it might rain once in a while, after someone did a "rain dance", doesn't mean the dancer made it rain.
.
I live in a desert which was once lush with greenery and before that, it was underwater.  Humans cannot speed up, slow down nor prevent Climate Change.  
.
We SHOULD, however, be better stewards of our environment:  Clean-up trash in your neighborhoods and if you live near a beach, participate in regularly scheduled beach cleanups to keep plastics and other trash from joining those massive trash islands we have in our oceans.

text:
+1dir

"In greenhouse gas discussions, why is it Methane is generally ignored relative to Carbon Dioxide when Methane is 30 times more potent as a greenhouse gas and compounds Carbon Dioxide levels in its conversion into Carbon Dioxide during its decaying process?"

Though an individual methane molecule has more of a warming impact than an individual CO2 molecule, CO2 is a more important greenhouse gas than methane for a number of reasons. For example:

1) CO2 is more abundant in the atmosphere.
2) Bacteria break down much of the methane to form CO2. 
3) CO2 has a longer atmospheric residence time than methane, since methane readily reacts with other molecules higher in the atmosphere.
4) Methane levels, and methane's impact energy balance, have begun leveling off, while CO2 levels and impact continue to increase.
5) Methane ends up being responsible for a minority of the anthropogenic impact on energy balance, with CO2 making up the majority. 


I cite some scientific evidence for each of these points right before figure 4 in section 2.3 of:

"+Myth: Attributing Warming to CO2 Involves the Fallaciously Inferring Causation from a Mere Correlation"
http://blamethenoctambulantjoycean.blogspot.ca/2018/04/myth-attributing-warming-to-co2.html


Also see:

"Methane is the second most abundant GHG after carbon dioxide (CO2), accounting for 14 percent of global emissions. Though methane is emitted into the atmosphere in smaller quantities than CO2 , its global warming potential (i.e., the ability of the gas to trap heat in the atmosphere) is 25 times greater.  As a result, methane emissions currently contribute more than one-third of today‚Äôs anthropogenic warming."
https://www.globalmethane.org/documents/analysis_fs_en.pdf 

"Methane is a powerful greenhouse gas, with a global warming potential that is far greater than that of carbon dioxide, particularly over the time horizon of the first few decades following emission.
[...]
Methane is a far more potent GHG than is CO2, but methane also has a tenfold shorter residence time in the atmosphere, so its effect on global warming attenuates more rapidly (IPCC 2007)."
http://www.jlcny.org/site/attachments/article/561/Howarth%20Report%202.pdf

text:
+Atomsk's Sanakan
A researched response is appreciated. My comment could have been better focused had I included that it is more likely that American Government and sponsored Special Interest organizations research statistics often ignore Methane impact on global climate change. Here is a quote from: onegreenplanet.org

"Focusing on carbon emissions is only half the battle ‚Äì or 74 percent of total emissions to be exact ‚Äì but, focusing on the percentage of total emissions is extremely misleading because it ignores global warming potential altogether.

We‚Äôve seen that methane, which accounts for only 14 percent of emissions worldwide, traps up to 100 times more heat than carbon dioxide over a 5-year period. This means that even though carbon dioxide molecules outnumber methane 5 to 1, this comparatively smaller amount of methane is still 19 times greater a problem for climate change over a 5 year period, and 4 times greater over a 100 year period.

To put it another way, any methane molecule released today is 100 times more heat-trapping than a molecule of carbon dioxide, or potentially even higher according to NASA‚Äôs Goddard Institute for Space Studies.

With the UN establishing various tipping points for irreversible climate change damage on the horizon, it‚Äôs time that methane enters mainstream consideration. And better yet, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) estimates that livestock production is responsible for 14.5 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions, while other organizations like the Worldwatch Institute have estimated it could be as much as 51 percent ‚Äì it‚Äôs time that we look beyond our gas tanks and on to our plates."

text:
Lost me at the "more than the past MILLION years" part. CO2 levels have reached way higher in the past 1,000 years. They've always been fluctuating rapidly through time, so seriously, why are humans the only ones to blame, when we've had cars and factories for like 300 years? Couldn't natural processes be a big part of the latest surge of CO2? Not to be skeptical or anything... 

Another thing, why can't people be skeptical about this? Personally, I have heard my teachers and experts all saying, "There's tons of evidence..." yet I've never seen the evidence. That's why people are being skeptical about it. Some authorities can throw numbers around like "the past million years", and others can say "400 ppm", but that doesn't register with open-minded thinkers until they know how exactly scientists have come to that conclusion. 

I'm so bad because I want to know truth. I'm so bad because I won't accept what "the science" is saying until I read their instruments. If I were to believe this kind of stuff on a whim, I would be in trouble because I don't know what the sea levels were in 1901, and this guy could be trying to take advantage of my ignorance, so thanks, but no thanks.

author: Dn Zach

text:
In the 1990's, I believed 100% in Global Warming.  I thought we needed to do whatever we could to stop it. But many of the predictions of doom were SO overblown that the idea totally lost credibility with me.  I read one article that said the US and Canada would be like the tropics by 2020 and poison ivy would have leaves that were 10 inches across.  I don't think any of that is going to happen in the next two years.  I read that Florida would soon be underwater.  Also not happening. 

So, I stopped believing and thought it was all nonsense. But I still believed humans should use renewable energy and recycle and use less energy.  Doing better for the Earth is always a good idea, whether Global Warming was real or not.

Now, I do believe in Climate Change.  I believe humans are contributing to it.  I believe we need to change.  I don't believe all the overblown doom..."it's the biggest threat ever" sort of stuff...nah.  It's happening, it's causing problems, the problems will worsen...we need to act.  But I do think trying to make people care by using dramatic claims of impending doom will backfire.

text: The chemical makeup of the atmosphere on Venus is 95% carbon dioxide and it is extremely hot.  The chemical makeup of the atmosphere on Mars is also 95% carbon dioxide and it is cold.  If carbon dioxide has such a huge impact on the temperature of a planet, why do these two planets differ so drastically in temperature?  This proves that carbon dioxide is not a major contributor to temperature increase of our planet.  Side note: For those of you who are going to say that Venus is closer and therefore, it is hotter... then explain to me why the surface of Jupiter is significantly hotter than Earth (Earth is closer to the sun when compared to Jupiter).

text:
So, did you really think that no one would actually fact check your evidence? And, just remember, you asked what we thought, so here's my critique.
I stopped checking your work half-way through item 10. I found that I had already taken up too much of my own time and too much space with the writing of what I had checked to that point, so I gave up on the rest. I just don't think that I should have to spend more hours fixing your work.  
In response to your preamble, I'd like to say that what scientists do or do not agree on or believe should be of little consequence anymore than when politicians want to disagree with facts. Most scientists of their day didn't believed Galileo, Pastuer, or Alfred Wegener. What science can PROVE, IS important.
Psychological statements like, "The climate ship has left the dock," inferring that those who disagree are left behind those who are so much more enlightened is, to be frank, insulting. You will get no one to listen to your arguments except those who have already been indoctrinated. You change nothing, nor change anyone's mind using this technique. Maybe I should re-phase that to no will change their mind to your way.  
Using words like 'could happen' or 'might happen' throughout your presentation does not give me a clear sense of your absolute knowledge of the science. Nor does not predicting larger hurricanes beforehand, but adding them after-the-fact to your repertoire of justifications.  
Item 3. Since CO2 levels have only been measured since 1958, how does the WMO know what levels were before 1790? It's a SWAG (scientific wild a$$ guess). The fine print on page 2 admits that they are making an assumption. And we all know what ASS-U-ME means, right? This is not the science fact that you promised. Item 6-same problem.  
Item 7- CO2 levels haven't been this high (>400 ppm) since before humans existed. And your point is.....? I could say that it hasn't been this dark since last night. What does my statement prove? The bottom line is that there was a time that CO2 levels were this high and human intervention was definitely not to blame. It's been 70-80 times that amount of time since that last real dinos roamed the earth. One million years is nothing, when compared to the life of this planet.  I could easily deduce that the cycle for this higher concentration is 1 million years and that this is normal. Yes, I know that this is most likely not true. I recognize the human hand of destruction to our environment. But, I also don't recognize how your statement is an absolute proof in yours or anyone's theory. You've basically stated that there are times that CO2 is high and humans had nothing to do with it.
Item 10- You show that, worldwide, all volcanoes are only responsible for 0.2 gigatons, or 200 megatons (million tons) of CO2. But, the same source that you, yourself used clearly states that just one volcano, Mt. Pinatubo, is thought to have injected more than 250 megatons of gas into the upper atmosphere on A SINGLE DAY. It also states that in an AVERAGE year, volcanoes release between about 180 and 440 million tonnes of carbon dioxide. I'd say 200 was low-balling the estimates since we don't even know what an average year looks like. Yes, we've been measuring CO2 for 70 years. Compare that with the Earths 5 billion year age and the solar and earth tilt cycles that can take millions. We can't have a real average of volcanic output, just another rough SWAG.  
You wouldn't normally use two languages to write one argument, so don't use two measuring systems. In 18 you state that ocean levels are rising by 1/10th inch per year. At the end of your video you state that with the current trend, ocean levels will be up 1 Meter by the end of the century. 0.1 inch = 2.5 mm x 100 (years)= 250mm. That's 1/4 of a meter (did you see how I used your trick of cross measurement there?) And with the fact that electric vehicles and alternative energy sources are in their infancy, this means things will get better without the hype. But, still, if you're going to exaggerate your numbers, try to keep your answers the same throughout your argument. And no, I didn't fact check either of these numbers. I just found an inconsistency in your statement.  
For the record, I would like to say that I thought I was a believer in climate change. I certainly was more of one before I watched this video. I would love to believe that we humans have the power within our grasp to lower ocean levels, acid levels, and stop mass extinctions, hurricanes or any other natural disasters. But, what I want and what I get are not always the same. I certainly want to believe that our scientists wouldn't collude in emails and texts to make sure that they get their facts correc........the same. I would also like to believe that they are considering all the facts. But, I am beginning to believe that climate scientists are deliberately avoiding some very important points.   
Even I know about Milankovitch Cycles. I also know that the billions of square kilometers of land that were buried under 3-5 km thick ice sheets, were compressed by all that weight.I know that even today it continues to rise (an estimated 1 km so far) since the ice melted, back to it's normal height. This has led to more water shedding off into the oceans.  
I know that the drying up of the Great Salt Lake (think Lake Superior emptying into the ocean), the Caspian and Aral Seas, and other trapped inland waters, along with the emptying of the prehistoric aquifers, both under the U.S. and Canada, and the Sahara desert being pumped dry means that these water displacements have to go somewhere and be accounted for. This planet is a closed loop system. No one seems to be taking these facts into account when measuring the height of the rising oceans. How do we stop the Great Salt Lake and others from evaporating? Do we tell the Russians and Africans that they are not allowed fresh water to drink and grow their food? Maybe we should tell North Americans to conserve their dwindling aquifer by not growing corn for ethanol or eating so much? OK, forget that last one. That's actually a good idea.  
And I haven't even gotten into the Gulf of Mexico coastal erosion caused by the US army corps of engineers, or the Gulfs dead zone, or the assumption (note the word assume) that the Sahara is covered in green for thousands of years due only to a minor shift in the Earths tilt in one of those previously described cycles, Possibly every 30-40,000 years. And we have no control over this, either.
In conclusion, we non-scientist outsiders don't have a problem believing REAL science. Pythagoras's theorem can be proven again and again. Einstein's theory of relativity can be shown to be accurate the same as Darwin's theory can be. Yet, despite your best selling methods, what few climate control predictions there are appear to be failing almost as badly as Y2K and 2012. One degree rise over decades does not evidence give. Especially if, as one real scientist, with a Nobel prize points out, your data is flawed. And maligning his reputation proves more about who you are than countering his argument.  Also, that rise in temperature can be explained with other facts that are out of our control.
Now, can we move on to the real science? Watching the ozone layer closing back up because of the direct efforts of scientists and nations working together; this is real science. There's plenty of evidence for humans polluting the earth and her oceans. THIS can be shown in video and documentation. THIS can be proven to be true to those who want to see real, honest data. Fix THIS and maybe your climate predictions will also be proven; or not. What matters most to me is that we are able to pass on a clean (cleaner?) environment to our children. I think we can all agree on this.

text:
Jupiter's hotter than Earth because of its extremely thick gas atmosphere.
Mars and Venus aren't good comparisons. Mars' orbit is actually more elliptical, making it colder for longer in the year.
Venus has also had more time to heat up because its year is shorter than its day, which means their days would be boiling hot due to the sun giving it even more heat to trap inside itself.
Mars has a very thin atmosphere, which allows more heat to escape (thus making it much colder), meanwhile Venus has active volcanoes that make its already hot surface even hotter as the thick atmosphere traps heat.
We need to stop hiding our heads and do something about this horrible mess we have created on this planet. This planet is currently our only home. Do not take that for granted, and do try to help save yourself and the rest of the human race and all the animals here before it is too late and we must face the facts. Time is limited.

text:
I used this video for follow-along notes and a reflection for my science class.  I hope this helps someone looking for content.

Climate Science: What You Need To Know (STUDENT VERSION)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ffjIyms1BX4 
 
Let‚Äôs not beat around the rapidly melting iceberg here: climate change is happening, and we‚Äôre causing it. The evidence is overwhelming. 

Scientists usually reserve this level of agreement for claims like ‚ÄúEarth is a planet‚Äù and ‚Äúair is real‚Äù yet here we are, the climate change ship has now left the dock, and lots of people on shore are still debating whether boats can actually float. 

BUT, maybe you‚Äôre a person who trusts and accepts what climate scientists are telling us, it‚Äôs just sometimes it‚Äôs hard to explain why. I mean we‚Äôve all been there‚Ä¶ 

‚ÄúI mean I care about the environment. I figure with the polar bears and everything we might 
as well try electric cars. What do we have to lose?‚Äù 

And then they go CAPS LOCK SERIOUS saying they have proof that climate change is a hoax 
perpetuated by scientists paid off by the Polar Bear Lobby as part of a plan to install Al Gore as supreme world polar bear emperor. WAKE UP SHEEPLE! 

To keep that from happening, we put together this handy reference. 

1. The _____ is the source of warmth on Earth, so thanks for that, Sun. Ice and clouds reflect some of its light away, and the rest is absorbed by land and water and re-emitted as heat. 

2. Some heat escapes to space, and some is held in by the atmospheric _______________ effect. 

3. The insulating effect of Earth‚Äôs greenhouse gases are the reason that life exists as we know it, but human activities have increased the concentration of one of them, carbon dioxide, _____% since the Industrial Revolution. 

4. We know the sun‚Äôs output has varied during history, but since 1970s, the period when global temperatures increased in the fastest, temperature and solar activity have moved in _______________ directions. 

5. If the sun was to blame, it would cook the upper and lower layers of atmosphere together. Instead, we only see warming in the ________ layers, the same place that human greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide are piling up. 

6. Since 1870, with fossil fuels, cement production, and land use combined, humans have put about 2,000 gigatons of _______ into the atmosphere, that's two million million tons, and about 40% has stayed there. 

7. Studying gases trapped in ____  ________ have let us see what Earth‚Äôs atmosphere was like in the past. At more than 400 parts per million, today‚Äôs CO2 levels are the highest they‚Äôve been for almost a million years. That‚Äôs before humans even existed, totally uncharted territory for us. 

8. More carbon dioxide in atmosphere means average temperatures across the globe are ______________, and fast. Right now, Earth is warming about ten times faster than at the end of an ice age. 
 
Ok, so CO2 is increasing. How do we know it's our fault? 
The best evidence comes from looking at what isotopes, or different kinds of carbon, are in the atmosphere. 

9. Fossil fuels come mainly from old __________. Plants prefer to use the lighter isotope carbon-12 over the heavier carbon-13, so they contain a higher ratio of 12 to 13 than the atmosphere does. When more fossil fuels get burned, the percentage of carbon-12 in the atmosphere should go up, and that's exactly what we see. 

10. And it's not because of volcanic activity. Volcanoes only emit about ___% as much CO2 as we do. 

11. Normally that CO2 is balanced and exchanged between the atmosphere, plants, and animals, BUT eliminating carbon ______ has released centuries worth (of CO2) in just a few years. 

12. Other greenhouse gases are also increasing, like _________ from farm animals and natural gas processing, or nitrous oxide from fertilizers. 
 
13. If we run simulations just using natural causes of climate change, they predict ___ change, or even cooling in 20th century and that is not what‚Äôs happening. 

14. It's still gonna get cold in some places, but in 2000s there were twice as many record highs as record lows. Each of the past three decades has been __________ than any other decade since we started measuring in 1850. 

15. Since 1900, actual temperatures around the world increased almost a full degree, and most of that has happened since the ________'s. 

16. Looking at data from tree rings and ice cores, the past 30 years is probably the warmest 
in eight centuries. Of course, not every place on Earth warms equally. 

17. Oceans cover more than 70% of Earth, and they absorb more than _____% of the heat added to the planet. Naturally, that‚Äôs where we see most extreme changes. 

18. Around the world, oceans are rising a tenth of inch per year, and they‚Äôre up _ inches since 1901. 

19. This is because water expands as it warms; 

20. and when ice sheets and glaciers melt in Greenland and Antarctica, water that‚Äôs normally on frozen land gets put in the ocean. 

21. The oceans are Earth's largest carbon sink. As more CO2 enters atmosphere, more of it dissolves in the ocean, which makes the water more __________. 

22. This doesn‚Äôt mean that the oceans will be made of acid, but animals with calcium shells are super-sensitive to pH. We‚Äôre on course for the oceans to hit pH 7.8 in 100 years, which could wipe out one-third of species in the ocean. 

23. We also know that levels of summer sea ice in the Arctic have decreased ____% since 1978, they might be the lowest levels in 1400 years. 

24. That white sea ice usually __________ the sun‚Äôs energy back into atmosphere (albedo effect), BUT the dark ocean is soaking it up like a black shirt on a sunny day, which feeds the cycle forward. 

If CO2 emissions continue on their current trends, Earth is on course to be 2.5-5 degrees ¬∞C (4.7-8.6 ¬∞F)
warmer, and the oceans could be up to a meter higher, by the end of this century.

Is that a big deal? Yeah! It's the biggest deal. This is by far the greatest issue facing our species. The last time the Earth averaged a few degrees colder, most of North America was covered in a mile-thick sheet of ice. That many degrees warmer? We're gonna have a bad time. 

So now you're armed with the facts. Why we know climate change is happening, and why we‚Äôre causing it. Please, share this information with the people you know, and let me know: 

Did it change any minds? Did it change your mind? I mean, are facts enough? If not, then why do so many people continue to NOT believe in climate science? We'll answer that question in our next video. 
Stay curious. 
~ END

Reflection Questions (Please answer on a separate sheet of paper and turn it in.):
1. If you already accepted Climate Change, how did this video help you understand it better?  If you did not accept the science of Climate Change, did this video change your mind? Why or Why Not?

2. What is a question about Climate Change you still have (list at least one)?

3. How high may the oceans get by the end of this century if CO2 emissions follow the current trend AND how may that affect coastal communities?

4. By burning Fossil Fuels, what percent of Carbon Dioxide have we added to the atmosphere AND how does that upset the natural Carbon Cycle? 

5. Explain how the above disruption of the Carbon Cycle leads to the warming of earth‚Äôs temperatures AND where do we see the most warming (land, atmosphere, oceans)?

text: Apparently people, including this paid speaker, do not realize what the word "climate" actually refers to. Climate is not weather, it is not today's weather, not an average of this week, this month, this year, not even this decade. A century mark is getting somewhat closer. Climate is based on the average temperature and climate for thousands of years. Using the period of time these guys do is akin to going fishing and just because you did not catch a single fish that day you claim  the lake is completely empty of fish! The Earth has been through "climate change" long before we were here (and worse). As far as I can tell, the planet is still here. There are still animals and plants. They may not be what was here 65 million years ago or even 12, 000 years ago but since WE weren't here maybe... MAYBE... climate change occurs naturally. Humans are SO arrogant as to think we know what's best for this planet when we have only been here a few thousand years. Perhaps what is best for the planet is not the same as what we want, that being the best for us.

text:
Why do you not mention water vapor?  It comprises over 90% of all greenhouse gases.  You are only giving part of the climate change story (yes - it's real).   You are hiding behind CO2 graphs that are misleading at best.   Climate change is a natural process. We are climbing out of the Pleistocene Ice Age, where the CO2 was reduced to dangerously low levels, almost to the point (150ppm) which can not sustain photosynthesis.   Now CO2 is climbing back to reasonable levels for plant life.     
Before you believe the 97% fairy tale, check into the study on which it is based. (Cook et al 2013).   Look into what was excluded and why - and watch the 97% number shrink down to the .3% of climate paper abstracts that actually stated that climate change is caused by humans.

text:
The reason for the contrast in views on climate change between Sweden and the US is primarily down to two things: Education and culture. Swedish education is very progressive whereas in the US it is compromised by pressure groups trying to mould education to their world view. 
The Swedes (and Scandinavians in general), by and large, are quite collectivist in their outlook. They generally subscribe to the idea that everyone is better off when we work for collective gains. This is why Scandinavians are far more relaxed about paying high taxes than others: They are confident that well-invested taxes provide exponential results. Americans are far more individualistic. They don't take kindly to being told what to do or how to think, and the White House hates the idea of being subjugated to international bodies such as the UN, the ICC or the IPCC. Since America is so corrupt, they have no faith in their governments disbursing tax receipts constructively. Big industry, in particular big pharma, the fossil fuel industry and the military industrial cartel, are the big winners from US tax spending.  
You could also add that the very religious Americans are kinda gullible and prone to latching onto any viewpoints that accord with their own world view, whereas the more pragmatic Swedes place their faith in scientists.

text:
There's definitely something weird about the climate where I live (Utah) in the last decade or so...it seems BOTH extreme seasons have been getting, well, more extreme.  And closer together!  I kid you not, two weeks ago we had an end-of-summer wildfire so close to my town we had trouble with coughing and stinging eyes for a week...and as I write this, it's been raining all night and _there is frost vapor on my window_.

IT'S NOT EVEN OCTOBER YET!
I mean, sure, this doesn't mean that every day from now on is just gonna get colder and colder, but c'mon, frost on the windows only a WEEK after the last SUMMER wildfire finally got under control?  Even in a quickly-changing-weather biome like a desert (we had an Arizona-like summer this year, too) or mountain ("Greatest Snow on Earth!"--don't look at me like that.  It's a phrase on our license plates) doesn't normally change THAT fast.

Summer this year contained like two weeks in a row where the high of the day didn't fall below 100 (Fahrenheit, I'm an American and this is about a place in America--I'm not saying it was literally BOILING! :P) and yet I feel fairly certain that winter this year will do similarly as it did last year, after a just-as-hot summer:  contain entire weeks where the high of the day doesn't break into two digits.  (For you metric users: That's DEFINITELY colder than 0 C.)  It seems odd (and kinda unfair) to have both hot summers AND cold winters; you'd think that the warmer summers would mean milder winters or the colder winters would mean cooler summers.  NOPE! 

I guess what I'm trying to say is that I have empirical evidence, gathered from my own real-life experience of living in the same place for decades, that SOMEthing funky is going on with the weather.  And if it's not us?  As many below me have said, couldn't hurt to switch to renewables as soon as comfortably and profitably possible anyway.
author: Robin Chesterfield

text:
While I accept that Global Warming has occurred from 1880 to 1998, the efforts to switch to renewables leaves VERY MUCH to be desired. 
First, renewables are more expensive, and that expense is passed along to the energy consumer. You think solar and wind are cheap? Solar is only cheap because it's subsidized  by enormous amounts of Tax dollars, which means the Taxpayer ends up paying more in the long-term. Also, solar panels are complicated to manufacture, and require extremely dangerous chemicals like Hydrogen Sulfide, which destroys bone. Or Cadmium, which has problems of it's own. AND, they wear out from sun-exposure.
Secondly, Wind turbines are also expensive to manufacture, and in California, they've had a bad history of wearing out bearings and catching fire.
Lastly, most solar and wind is manufactured in China, which has looser Regulations on pollution, so they GET all/most of the money. Do we WANT to send more money to China?

Alternatively, there are arguments that say CO2 is only a small part, about 4%, of the greenhouse gases that hold the Sun's warmth, and thus cause Global Warming. Water vapor is 95%. 
No one I know knows how to control water vapor, which is mostly from sea-water evaporation. It's why the Paris Accord only promised to LIMIT the PROJECTED temp rise of 3 to 7 degrees, by .05 degrees! And cost US 2 Trillion dollars! Such a DEAL!

That said....why not approach the problem from a Technical viewpoint? Like, say, setting up a Space Umbrella to shield the Earth from 5% of sunlight? We could do that by using a mile-long railgun to fire 5mm ball-bearings into the L1 Earth/Sun balance point. They would just STAY there.
The CERN accelerator is basically a several miles long railgun, so we know how to do that.

text: So, there was this period between 3-5 million years BC where the average world temperature was constantly, except for a few exceptions, between zero and two degrees Celsius, whereas 2016, the average temperature was only 0.99¬∞C (which was described as "hottest year in recorded history). About 300 years ago, the last "Ice Age" ended and since then, the temperature started going up. The Climatic Optimum (250 BC-400 AC) was a warm period (around 2¬∞C) warmer than today's climate. The Thermal Maximum (about 55 Mio. years ago) was so hot (between 14 and 16 degrees Celsius), palm trees could grow on the poles.  Climate is far too complex and has too many factors to be ascribed to just carbon oxide emissions (which still is a factor of climate). Nonetheless, if we keep burning fossil fuels, someday, there are none left and that is, in my humble opinion, the reason we should work on an alternative.

text:
Global Warming is real, according even to Skeptic scientists.
The CAUSE is what is in question. The only proposed solution-set does basically NOTHING to address the problem EFFECTIVELY.
The Paris Accord, for instance, says IF every Country fulfills it's commitments, it will SLOW NOT PREVENT the rise in Warming by -0.2 to -0.5 degrees. That STILL leaves a 'PROJECTED' rise of +3 to +7 degrees!

That said,
Why not approach the issue in a preventative way(since the stake is human survival)?
For instance, I'm an Engineer. When it's VERY HOT and SUNNY out, in California, I usually carry an Umbrella.
I devised an Macro-Engineering project to set up a HUMONGOUS Space Umbrella at the L1 near-Earth Orbit point. Just set up a mile-long rail-gun at the Equator, to fire a constant stream of 3-5mm ball-bearings into the L1 point. Doable with current technology. That would shade our Earth from 3 to 5% of the Sun's heat. The SUN is the actual SOURCE of Global Warming. CO2 is just part of what forms the Greenhouse trap that holds the Solar heat.
I submitted it to various Scientific and Engineering journals, POTUS, NASA, and various News Agencies. 
All I heard back were crickets.

text: Wow, this guy is a moron.  The last 20 years the earth is actually been cooler.  The earth did warm from 1978 to 1988, but it also cooled from the 1939 until 1977 and guess what back then they were blaming human activity for the cooling.  But, in all actuallity humans have little to no effect on global temperatures, all you have to do is study the temperatures of the Pacific Ocean to understand why the climate changes.  When the eastern part of the ocean is warmer than the western part, like it was from the early 1900s to 1938 and from 1978 to 1998, the earth warms.  When it is the other way around, like it was from 1939 to 1977 and from 1998 until present, you get cooling.  Also, the 1930s was the warmest decade on record.  CO2 may be at the highest it has been since humans have been on the planet, but it is nowhere near the highest it has ever been. about 570 million years ago it was 20 times higher than it was today.  Then there is also the fact that the average temperature of earth has varied from 12 degrees celcius to 22 degrees celcius at all levels of CO2.  The fact of the matter is that the earth is still has one of lowest levels of CO2 than it has had since the planet was formed over 600 billion years ago.

text:
Personally, I think one of the biggest issues with climate change is that saying that temperature has risen by "OMG, one full degree!" fails to impress most people -- especially Americans, who are using Fahrenheit. On a warm day, here, it's 90 degrees. You're telling me, instead it'll be 91? Big freaking deal!

So what's missing is a very real explanation for just how dramatic one degree is. Sure, you mentioned the ice caps melting, and losing ocean species, but for the majority of us who aren't fishermen, the ocean is this annoying giant puddle that gets in the way of people living in other places, and is sometimes nice to swim in. What's missing here is a real connection between what this means to us -- land-dwelling creatures -- and not a hundred years from today. Tell us what it means NOW. Tell us what it will do during our own lifetime. And tell it to us in ways that we're actually likely to care about.

Because one degree? Meh. It's already about 300 kelvin.

text:
Several of his "facts" are completely wrong.

#1.  Yes, the sun is the source of the majority of Earth's "warmth" - thanks for that, captain obvious.

#2.  Yes, the Greenhouse Effect does trap some of the heat that would otherwise be re-emitted into space.  But it is interesting that he never actually explains how much...   Not so bad in #2 but very bad for #3 as you'll see.  It is also incorrect to say that the Sun's output hasn't changes.   The thermal output hasn't changed much - at least not in a way that would explain the temperature increase but its magnetic output has increased.   This causes a reduction in cloud creation.  Fewer clouds means warming.  In fact, according to scientists like Svensmark (see a documentary on him called the "Cloud Mystery" for more information).  You'll see that changes is the Sun's magnetic output better explain the warming we've seen than CO2.

#3 .  There is where the wheels really begin to come off this ridiculous wagon.  Saying that CO2 has increased 40% since the Industrial Revolution sounds like a lot.  However, a more honest way to describe the increase would be from ~280 parts per million by volume to about 400 ppmv.   Again, that sounds like a lot expressed as a percentage increase or even as the raw increase of ~120ppmv but what is it as a percentage of the whole?  100ppmv is another way of saying 0.01%.  Also, prior to the 1900s (or 1960s, depending on who you ask) humans didn't increase CO2 enough to affect climate in any way.  Even though the Industrial Revolution began in the 1700s, it is important to remember that it was a very localized phenomenon for most of that time.  Only in the 1900s did it become a global event.  So how do you explain the warming that happened prior to the 1900s?

#4.  This is totally wrong.   The temperatures didn't "increase the fastest" in the 1970s and neither did CO2 concentration.  Part of the problem with the hypothesis that anthropogenic CO2 has driven the warming since the end of the Little Ice Age is that the correlation between CO2 levels and temperature from the 1700s to present is so poor.  Sometimes they rise at the same time, sometimes they go in opposite direction.   Look at the cooling period in the mid 20th century where, despite record increases in CO2, the average global temperature actually fell - to the point that, in the 1970s, scientists were predicting a possible ice-age.

#5.  He's actually shooting himself in the foot here.  If CO2 were the primary driver, we'd see warming in the troposphere that we're simply not seeing.  The warming we are seeing is not consistent with being driven primarily by CO2.

#6...  Ok, that's it.  I'm done with this nonsense.   The instant they start talking about CO2 in gigatons, you know you're being had.
author: Jonathan Gwynne
