author: Jeremy D

text:
+Trevor W

"For example: the average temperature on earth has remained relatively constant for the past 17 or so years."

potholer54 has a good discussion of this in his Youtube video: 
"Why global temperatures never go up in straight lines" (especially from 5:22 - 11:22)


Anyway, there's been global warming over the past couple of decades, as observed in ocean warming, surface warming, warming of the troposphere (with the associated stratospheric cooling typical of greenhouse-gas-induced warming), and Earth's energy balance (i.e. comparing the amount of energy the Earth takes up vs. the amount of energy the Earth releases). Radiative forcing from CO2 has continued, as it did during earlier periods of global warming:

Atmospheric warming (tropospheric warming and stratospheric cooling): 
"Comparing tropospheric warming in climate models and satellite data"
"Sensitivity of Satellite-Derived Tropospheric Temperature Trends to the Diurnal Cycle Adjustment"
"Evidence for an earlier greenhouse cooling effect in the stratosphere before 1980 over the Northern Hemisphere"
"Assessing atmospheric temperature data sets for climate studies"

Surface warming: 
"Global Temperature in 2015" http://mahb.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/20160120_Temperature2015.pdf
"On the definition and identifiability of the alleged ‚Äúhiatus‚Äù in global warming"

Surface warming / ocean warming: 
"Possible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus"
"Assessing the impact of satellite-based observations in sea surface temperature trends"

Ocean warming: 
‚ÄúAssessing recent warming using instrumentally homogeneous sea surface temperature records‚Äù
"Tracking ocean heat uptake during the surface warming hiatus"
"A review of global ocean temperature observations: Implications for ocean heat content estimates and climate change"
http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf ["Ocean warming dominates the increase in energy stored in the climate system, accounting for more than 90% of the energy accumulated between 1971 and 2010 (high confidence).[...] On a global scale, the ocean warming is largest near the surface, and the upper 75 m warmed by 0.11 [0.09 to 0.13] ¬∞C per decade over the period 1971 to 2010."]

Energy balance:
"The Earth's energy balance" [ http://lecuyer.aos.wisc.edu/publications/2015_stephens_lecuyer_EEB_ar.pdf ]
"Insights into Earth‚Äôs Energy Imbalance from Multiple Sources"
"Anthropogenic and natural warming inferred from changes in Earth‚Äôs energy balance"
"An update on Earth‚Äôs energy balance in light of the latest global observations"

CO2 Radiative forcing:
"Observational determination of surface radiative forcing by CO2 from 2000 to 2010"
"Increases in greenhouse forcing inferred from the outgoing longwave radiation spectra of the Earth in 1970 and 1997"


This has led to many scientists saying that there's been no "pause" or "hiatus" in global warming in a literal sense; instead heat is re-distributed on the planet, while global warming continues:

"The global warming hiatus: Slowdown or redistribution?"
"Has there been a hiatus?"
"Debunking the climate hiatus"
"An apparent hiatus in global warming?"
"Change points of global temperature"


Michael Mann himself feels uncomfortable with the term "pause", since it leads to denialists pretending AGW has stopped, when it actually hasn't. Mann also admits that global warming has continued:

"The rate at which the earth‚Äôs temperature has been rising eased slightly in the past decade, but temperature is still increasing; calling the slowdown a ‚Äúpause‚Äù is false."
http://www.meteo.psu.edu/holocene/public_html/Mann/articles/articles/MannSciAmApr14.pdf

"Making sense of the early-2000s warming slowdown
[...]
We do not believe that warming has ceased [...]
A point of agreement we have with Lewandowsky et al. 26 concerns the unfortunate way in which the recent changes have been framed in terms of GMST having ‚Äú'stalled', 'stopped', 'paused', or entered a 'hiatus'‚Äù. Just exactly how such changes should be referred to is open to debate. Possible choices include 'reduced rate of warming', 'decadal fluctuation' or 'temporary slowdown' ‚Äî all try to convey the primary mechanism involved, which in the recent example is likely to be internal decadal variability."
https://courses.eas.ualberta.ca/eas570/warming_slowdown.pdf



"I am curious why it is that many predictions made by scientists including the "hockey stick" Al Gore Model don't appear to be accurate today."

See the following Youtube video:
"23 -- Medieval Warm Period -- fact vs. fiction"

In that video (from about 2:10), potholer54 discussed the hockey stick pattern, in which recent global warming occurs at a much faster rate than warming during the MWP [medieval warm period]. potholer54 also discusses the multiple lines of research supporting this hockey stick pattern. And figure 4 of the following paper again confirms the hockey stick pattern by comparing different temperature constructions: 
"Continental-scale temperature variability during the last two millennia"

The hockey stick pattern also shows up in the following papers:
"Medieval Warm Period, Little Ice Age and 20th century temperature variability from Chesapeake Bay"
"Inter-hemispheric temperature variability over the past millennium"

The following paper addresses, and rebuts, criticism of the hockey stick pattern:
"Robustness of the Mann, Bradley, Hughes reconstruction of Northern Hemisphere surface temperatures: Examination of criticisms based on the nature and processing of proxy climate evidence"

Mann even showed the same hockey stick pattern without the tree ring proxies that many people had objected to:
"Proxy-based reconstructions of hemispheric and global surface temperature variations over the past two millennia"

Also, the following paper compares recent warming to Northern Hemisphere temperatures back to 1000AD. This data seems to suggest modern warming stronger than that seen in the medieval periods displayed (see figure 2):
"Ensemble reconstruction constraints on the global carbon cycle sensitivity to climate"

Furthermore, see the following for an alternative account, where recent modern temperatures were warmer than the vast majority of the Holocene, reversing a long-term cooling trend:
"A Reconstruction of Regional and Global Temperature for the Past 11,300 Years"

For further discussion of this at a laymen's level, see:
https://www.skepticalscience.com/broken-hockey-stick.htm



"Please, don't assume that everyone who is skeptical of climate change is "denying the facts" or is paid off by big oil companies."

Skepticism is not denialism; we shouldn't conflate the two. What we're dealing with here is denialism, not skepticism, from people who are trying to avoid facts that they find inconvenient.

author: Patrick Williams

text:
To me the main problem with this video is the conclusion.  "Is that a big deal? Yeah, it's the biggest deal.  This is by far the greatest issue facing our species.  The last time the earth averaged a few degrees colder, most of North America was covered in a mile-thick sheet of ice.  That many degrees warmer?  We're going to have a bad time.  Now you're armed with the facts..."

It appears to me that most of the client scientists who are in the "skeptic" camp don't so much disagree with whether warming is occurring (the last two decades notwithstanding), but on the "greatest issue facing our species" part.  Even if you ignore the problems with the oft-quoted 97% statistic, it only applies to the idea that our prolific CO2 emissions generally will result in warming--without any details about how much warming or what the consequences will be.  

Five minutes of facts, figures, charts, graphs, etc., but when it came time to address that most important part of this issue, all you give us is a conclusory "We're going to have a bad time"?  If you're going to say this is "the greatest" issue, you're saying it's worse than war, hunger, disease, and nuclear proliferation.  The phrase "existential threat" gets tossed around.  Why end the video right where you get to the part that actually matters?

text:
Ok first - alright you proved climate is changing, NO ONE has denied that, in fact we all say climate is changing that's not the problem here, the earth is constantly changing temperature, since FOREVER, and THAT'S a fact, the thing you need to prove is if humans are accelerating that process.

Second - you say earth has been the hottest in 8 centuries ... Thats very convenient, because you don't mention the fact that it hasnt been the hottest in 2000 years, when it was FAR warmer than today, before that we had multiple climates, including the ice age, and between that peak the temperatures have came down to way less than today (The Little Ice Age that drove the vikings out of Greenland) and then back up until today. So there are a lot of huge changes, and none of them have to do with men.

Third - saying the amount of ice in the artic decreased 40% in 1978 is also pretty useless information, since the amount of ice in the artic also INCREASED 50% since 2012 .. so, there's not much of a consistent change here right? You can't just say something is real and be positive of it when there's no proof and the facts that you show are completely manipulated in your favor...

Forth - you mention the fact that CO2 has been the highest, but you didn't mention the fact that average temperature levels have been flat since 1997 ... There's no obvious and direct connection here, you can't just assume something is happening by connecting 2 facts .. A is true, B is true .. If SOMETIMES A causes B, that doesn't mean A is THE CAUSE for all the B .. You get what Im saying?

Now, I could go on and on, but just let me tell you something, climate IS changing, there's no denying, can I prove that men have nothing to do with it? No I can't. Can I prove that all the arguments you and a lot of people give are invalid? Yes. And since that is the case, decisions shouldn't be taken without no real proof or reasoning, decisions can't be made out of pure theory and concepts.. Thats all

text:
+zzebowa

"Since 1990 sun spot activity (not solar activity, there is more to the sun than just sun spots)  has decreased, but it is still MUCH higher than in 1900. Another solar metric, TSI, thats how strongly it shines,  is also up in the last century, and has stayed up."

The sun does not account for recent global warming (since about the 1970s).

Here's NASA dumbing it down for you:

"Is the sun causing global warming?
No. The sun can influence the Earth‚Äôs climate, but it isn‚Äôt responsible for the warming trend we‚Äôve seen over the past few decades. The sun is a giver of life; it helps keep the planet warm enough for us to survive. We know subtle changes in the Earth‚Äôs orbit around the sun are responsible for the comings and goings of the ice ages. But the warming we‚Äôve seen over the last few decades is too rapid to be linked to changes in Earth‚Äôs orbit, and too large to be caused by solar activity. In fact, recently (2005-2010) the sun has become less active, while temperatures have marched upwards.
One of the ‚Äúsmoking guns‚Äù that tells us the sun is not causing global warming comes from looking at the amount of the sun‚Äôs energy that hits the top of the atmosphere. Since 1978, scientists have been tracking this using sensors on satellites and what they tell us is that there has been no upward trend in the amount of the sun‚Äôs energy reaching Earth.
A second smoking gun is that if the sun were responsible for global warming, we would expect to see warming throughout all layers of the atmosphere, from the surface all the way up to the upper atmosphere (stratosphere). But what we actually see is warming at the surface and cooling in the stratosphere. This is consistent with the warming being caused by a build-up of heat-trapping gases near the surface of the Earth, and not by the sun getting ‚Äúhotter.‚Äù"
http://climate.nasa.gov/faq/?


And here are some scientific papers showing that the sun did not cause most of the recent global warming:

"Cosmic rays, solar activity and the climate"
"Causes of the Global Warming Observed since the 19th Century"
"Evidence of recent causal decoupling between solar radiation and global temperature"
"Solar trends and global warming"
"Small influence of solar variability on climate over the past millennium"
"Quantifying the role of solar radiative forcing over the 20th century"
"Unusual activity of the Sun during recent decades compared to the previous 11,000 years"
"Solar variability and global warming: a statistical comparison since 1850"
"Can solar variability explain global warming since 1970?" 



"oceans absorb 90% of the heat added to the climate.  This is completely bogus."

Nope:

"Ocean warming dominates the increase in energy stored in the climate system, accounting for more than 90% of the energy accumulated between 1971 and 2010 (high confidence).[...] On a global scale, the ocean warming is largest near the surface, and the upper 75 m warmed by 0.11 [0.09 to 0.13] ¬∞C per decade over the period 1971 to 2010."
http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf



"Loss of arctic  sea ice is a net NEGATIVE feedback for two reasons"

Nope. The melting ice decreases Earth's albedo, promoting warming. This positive feedback is discussed in sources such as:

"Observational determination of albedo decrease caused by vanishing Arctic sea ice"
"Estimating the global radiative impact of the sea ice‚Äìalbedo feedback in the Arctic"
"The central role of diminishing sea ice in recent Arctic
temperature amplification"



"In summary, we do know it is getting warmer, we do know we are contributing to that, but the effect is small and therefore entirely beneficial"

Nope. Numerous scientists know the following (hence the scientific consensus these):

A1) There has been global warming since the mid-20th century.
A2) Humans (largely via anthropogenic greenhouse gases) caused most of this recent warming.
A3) Most of the recent (or near future) climate change is (or will be) caused by humans.
A4) Climate change is a serious problem and/or a danger to humanity.

The consensus on A1 and A2 is discussed in:
"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"

The consensus on A3 and A4 is discussed in:
http://www.pewinternet.org/2015/07/23/elaborating-on-the-views-of-aaas-scientists-issue-by-issue/
"The Bray and von Storch 5th International Survey of Climate Scientists 2015/2016"


The following sources provide scientific evidence on A1 and A2 (there are at least 50 scientific papers providing evidence on A2):

"Causes of the Global Warming Observed since the 19th Century"
"Attribution of observed historical near-surface temperature variations to anthropogenic and natural causes using CMIP5 simulations"
"Anthropogenic and natural warming inferred from changes in Earth‚Äôs energy balance"
"Attributing Observed SST Trends and Subcontinental Land Warming to Anthropogenic Forcing during 1979‚Äì2005"
"Sensitivity of the attribution of near surface temperature warming to the choice of observational dataset"
"A probabilistic quantification of the anthropogenic component of twentieth century global warming"
"Identifying human influences on atmospheric temperature"
"Quantifying anthropogenic influence on recent near-surface temperature change"
"Evidence for external forcing on 20th-century climate from combined ocean-atmosphere warming patterns"
"Observed 21st century temperatures further constrain likely rates of future warming"


And the reason for the consensus on A4, is that there's abundant scientific research showing that anthropogenic climate change has caused (or will cause):
- increased heat-related mortality (which outweighs any decreases in cold-related mortality)
- increased drought intensity
- economic losses from sea level rise
- increased hurricane intensity
- ocean acidification (which results in things such as loss of marine crops and marine food)
- reduced crop yields
and so on.

Here's some research on this, to get you started:

"A meta-analysis of crop yield under climate change and adaptation"
"Climate Change: Impact on Agriculture and Costs of Adaptation"
"Ocean Acidification: The Other CO2 Problem"
"Nutrition and income from molluscs today imply vulnerability to ocean acidification tomorrow"
"Economic impacts of climate change in Europe: sea-level rise"
"Economic losses from US hurricanes consistent with an influence from climate change"
"Tropical cyclones and climate change"
"Anthropogenic warming has increased drought risk in California"
"Contribution of anthropogenic warming to California drought during 2012‚Äì2014"
"Increasing drought under global warming in observations and models"
"Global warming and changes in drought"
"Climate warming will not decrease winter mortality"
"Winter season mortality: will climate warming bring benefits?"
"Winter mortality in a warming climate: a reassessment"
"Heat-Related Mortality and Adaptation to Heat in the United States"
"Projecting Future Heat-Related Mortality under Climate Change Scenarios: A Systematic Review"
"Climate change effects on human health: projections of temperature-related mortality for the UK during the 2020s, 2050s and 2080s"
"Comparative Assessment of the Effects of Climate Change on Heat and Cold-Related Mortality in the United Kingdom and Australia"

author: zzebowa

text:
+zzebowa

"Far too long to bother reading."

Like some many other denialists, you find excuses not to address evidence that shows you're wrong...

"It is, however, important not to confuse denialism with genuine scepticism, which is essential for scientific progress. Sceptics are willing to change their minds when confronted with new evidence; deniers are not."
http://www.bmj.com/content/341/bmj.c6950.full



"So to take your first point, there is more  behind surface shortwave flux than just the sun. If you look at the NCEP RE2 data there is a clear short wave flux peak at 2003."

You've failed to show that this solar forcing caused global warming. Now, you might be claiming that changes in cloud cover affected  shortwave flux, and these changes caused the warming. The problem with that is that the changes in cloud covered are a feedback resulting from (and augmenting) the effect of anthropogenic greenhouse gases. Basically, CO2 caused warming, which augments atmospheric water vapor levels since warmer air can hold more water vapor. This leads to the formation of more clouds. These clouds can act as fast positive feedback or as negative feedback, depending on how high those clouds are in the atmosphere. The scientific evidence suggests that the clouds are a net positive feedback. This has been shown in a number of climate models and has been confirmed by observational data. For example:


"An Analysis of the Short-Term Cloud Feedback Using MODIS Data
[...]
Low clouds provide a strong negative cloud feedback, mainly because of their impact in the shortwave (SW) portion of the spectrum. Midlevel clouds provide a positive net cloud feedback that is a combination of a positive SW feedback partially canceled by a negative feedback in the longwave (LW). High clouds have only a small impact on the net cloud feedback because of a close cancellation between large LW and SW cloud feedbacks."

"A net decrease in the Earth‚Äôs cloud, aerosol, and surface 340 nm reflectivity during the past 33 yr (1979‚Äì2011)
[...]
The amount of the longwave offset plus changes in atmospheric absorption determine whether the cloud plus aerosol change represents a net positive or negative feedback. The correlated increase in surface temperature suggests a net positive feedback."

"Evidence for climate change in the satellite cloud record
[...]
Our results suggest that radiative forcing by a combination of anthropogenic greenhouse gases and volcanic aerosol has produced observed cloud changes during the past several decades that exert positive feedbacks on the climate system."

"Thermodynamic control of anvil cloud amount
[...]
Compelling physical arguments, with varying degrees of observational support, suggest that cloud changes with warming constitute a net positive feedback on radiative forcing (6). Two main contributors to this positive feedback are an expected reduction of low-level cloud amount (7‚áì‚áì‚Äì10) and a rise of high-level clouds (11, 12). Some arguments have also been advanced for negative feedbacks that would reduce the sensitivity of Earth‚Äôs temperature to perturbations, through for instance a greater preponderance of liquid in clouds at warmer temperatures (13) or, for reasons that are unclear, a reduction in the relative area of the wet, vs. dry, tropics with warming (14, 15)."

Neither TSI nor sunspots nor cosmic rays caused most of the global warming since the mid-20th centuries. Anthropogenic greenhouse gases did. Do your homework, denialist.


Climate scientists know that the sun did not cause the recent global warming, while anthropogenic greenhouse gases did cause the recent warming.

Here's NASA dumbing it down for you:

"Is the sun causing global warming?
No. The sun can influence the Earth‚Äôs climate, but it isn‚Äôt responsible for the warming trend we‚Äôve seen over the past few decades. The sun is a giver of life; it helps keep the planet warm enough for us to survive. We know subtle changes in the Earth‚Äôs orbit around the sun are responsible for the comings and goings of the ice ages. But the warming we‚Äôve seen over the last few decades is too rapid to be linked to changes in Earth‚Äôs orbit, and too large to be caused by solar activity. In fact, recently (2005-2010) the sun has become less active, while temperatures have marched upwards.
One of the ‚Äúsmoking guns‚Äù that tells us the sun is not causing global warming comes from looking at the amount of the sun‚Äôs energy that hits the top of the atmosphere. Since 1978, scientists have been tracking this using sensors on satellites and what they tell us is that there has been no upward trend in the amount of the sun‚Äôs energy reaching Earth.
A second smoking gun is that if the sun were responsible for global warming, we would expect to see warming throughout all layers of the atmosphere, from the surface all the way up to the upper atmosphere (stratosphere). But what we actually see is warming at the surface and cooling in the stratosphere. This is consistent with the warming being caused by a build-up of heat-trapping gases near the surface of the Earth, and not by the sun getting ‚Äúhotter.‚Äù"
http://climate.nasa.gov/faq/?

"But several lines of evidence show that current global warming cannot be explained by changes in energy from the sun:
- Since 1750, the average amount of energy coming from the sun either remained constant or increased slightly.
- If the warming were caused by a more active sun, then scientists would expect to see warmer temperatures in all layers of the atmosphere. Instead, they have observed a cooling in the upper atmosphere, and a warming at the surface and in the lower parts of the atmosphere. That's because greenhouse gases are trapping heat in the lower atmosphere.
- Climate models that include solar irradiance changes can‚Äôt reproduce the observed temperature trend over the past century or more without including a rise in greenhouse gases."
http://climate.nasa.gov/causes/


And here are some scientific papers showing that the sun did not cause most of the recent global warming:

"Causes of the Global Warming Observed since the 19th Century"
"Evidence of recent causal decoupling between solar radiation and global temperature"
"Solar trends and global warming"

"Unusual activity of the Sun during recent decades compared to the previous 11,000 years"
"Solar variability and global warming: a statistical comparison since 1850"
"Can solar variability explain global warming since 1970?"


Though cosmic rays likely influenced climate in the past, cosmic rays did not cause the recent global warming period, i.e. the global warming since the mid-20th century. This is discussed in scientific sources you're ignorant of, such as:

"Cosmic rays, solar activity and the climate"
"Dynamical evidence for causality between galactic cosmic rays and interannual variation in global temperature"
"Reply to Luo et al.: Robustness of causal effects of galactic cosmic rays on interannual variation in global temperature"
"Global atmospheric particle formation from CERN CLOUD measurements"



"As for what you say, the theory that WV increase at 7%/K is just a theory, and has not actually happened.  If you look at all data sets there has been no SH increase associated with the recent warming."

Bertie Blue and I already corrected your fabrications on this long ago. Stop repeating your distortions. Try to address Bertie Blue's point in an intellectually honest manner:

"The only claims for 7% have nothing to do with specific humidity."
"Link 4 (Google book): This says that the SATURATION VAPOUR PRESSURE increases at a rate of 7% per Kelvin, NOT the specific humidity. This is NOT a claim of global warming - it is an experimentally verified fact. If you place water in a sealed container, the vapour pressure in the sealed space above the water will rise at 7% per Kelvin. It is the MAXIMUM vapour pressure - the actual vapour pressure will only equal that when the relative humidity is 100%. The saturation vapour pressure is used to calculate the RELATIVE humidity. It is the WATER HOLDING CAPACITY which increases at 7% per Kelvin, NOT the actual quantity of water in the atmosphere. Yes, if relative humidity were to remain the same under warming, then that would mean specific humidity would also increase by 7%. But the prediction is that relative humidity will DECREASE under warming. The predicted increase for SPECIFIC humidity is 1-3%."
"So you refuse to learn the difference between "saturation vapour pressure" and "specific humidity". Trenbath's paper: " water holding capacity of air increases by about 7% per 1¬∞C warming" (your 4th link uses the same teminology).
As I already explained, water holding capacity is the ability of the atmosphere to hold water vapour, NOT the amount of water vapour it actually holds. As average relative humidity FALLS (as predicted), the actual quantity of water vapour in the air will rise by LESS than 7%." 


Anyway, the expected changes in water vapor occurred. AGW began predominantly in the mid-to-late 1970s, and was preceded by global cooling from the 1940s to the 1970s. Scientists observed the expected increase in atmospheric moisture over the relevant time-frame of 1980 - 2010, when the warming is most pronounced:

"Increasing evidence from observations and climate models indicates that anthropogenic activity is increasing atmospheric moisture (Boucher et al. 2004; Willett et al. 2007; Santer et al. 2007; Min et al. 2008).
[...]
Most studies of global atmospheric moisture indicate that recent warming is associated with an increase in specific humidity and little change in relative humidity (Dai 2006; Trenberth et al. 2007; Willett et al. 2008). A more recent analysis suggests that reductions in relative humidity have occurred because of a lack of increase in oceanic moisture being supplied to warming land surfaces (Simmons et al. 2010).
[...]
Hourly temperatures in the United States have warmed since 1930, with much of this warming occurring since 1980. [...] There have been no long-term changes in dewpoint temperatures or specific humidity but rather there has been a decreasing (1947‚Äì79) and then an increasing (1980‚Äì2010) trend in both variables."
http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/full/10.1175/JAMC-D-12-035.1



"And no, clouds are not  a net +ve feedback,  you are wrong"

Stop being in denialist of the evidence. Clouds can act as positive feedback or negative feddback, though on the whole they are a net positive feedback:

"Evidence for climate change in the satellite cloud record
[...]
Our results suggest that radiative forcing by a combination of anthropogenic greenhouse gases and volcanic aerosol has produced observed cloud changes during the past several decades that exert positive feedbacks on the climate system."

"A net decrease in the Earth‚Äôs cloud, aerosol, and surface 340 nm reflectivity during the past 33 yr (1979‚Äì2011)
[...]
The amount of the longwave offset plus changes in atmospheric absorption determine whether the cloud plus aerosol change represents a net positive or negative feedback. The correlated increase in surface temperature suggests a net positive feedback."

"Thermodynamic control of anvil cloud amount
[...]
Compelling physical arguments, with varying degrees of observational support, suggest that cloud changes with warming constitute a net positive feedback on radiative forcing (6). Two main contributors to this positive feedback are an expected reduction of low-level cloud amount (7??‚Äì10) and a rise of high-level clouds (11, 12). Some arguments have also been advanced for negative feedbacks that would reduce the sensitivity of Earth‚Äôs temperature to perturbations, through for instance a greater preponderance of liquid in clouds at warmer temperatures (13) or, for reasons that are unclear, a reduction in the relative area of the wet, vs. dry, tropics with warming (14, 15)."

+ucsdsnsd4

"This video doesn't really cover much on explaining how it is CO2's fault. It kinda goes over it but mostly it just assumes it's bc of CO2. But the problem I have is when people argue against it they say that we assume that the co2 is the significant reason for climate change."

It's a well-evidenced fact that humans (largely via anthropogenic greenhouse gases) caused most of the global warming that occurred since the mid-20th century. Arguing about this point, is like arguing over whether HIV causes AIDS or whether smoking causes cancer.


There are at least 50 scientific papers showing this. These papers use various techniques, including:

- model-based prediction, where those models were tested against previous data, including paleoclimatological data, akin to how one can predict the generate astronomical models that explain the motion of planets/satellites and then use those models to predict the motion of other planets/satellites; the models predict how much warming would result from solar forcing, CO2 release, etc. based on how much warming resulted from these factors in the past

- examining warming patterns in different layers of the atmosphere (since different forcings produce different patterns of atmospheric warming, with greenhouse gases having a particular atmospheric warming pattern).

So different methods have yielded much the same conclusion. That is a hallmark of good science: consilience of different results on the same, accurate conclusion. That way, the strengths of one methods can compensate for the weaknesses in another method, and you know that your result is not just due to the flaws of one particular methods.

Here are some of the 50+ scientific papers on this:

"Causes of the Global Warming Observed since the 19th Century"

"Anthropogenic and natural warming inferred from changes in Earth‚Äôs energy balance"

As an admittedly uninformed skeptic, I find the staw-man at 0:51 off-putting. The companion piece to this "Why people don't believe in Climate Change"  Was equally condescending and snarky basically saying that my brain is stuck in cave-man mode.  Apparently you guys have no idea why otherwise rational people don't trust the conclusions of climate science.  There are actual rational reasons.  It would have been nice if those reasons could have been addressed. 

3:26  There's one reason why I'm skeptical.  Simulations. So much of this rides on the trustworthiness of simulations written by people who went into the climate field, very likely BECAUSE they believed the climate was changing and that man was responsible.  How do I know that this bias is not being programmed into the simulation.  "Opps!  Looks like the simulation is not working right, we are not getting the "right" answer, tweak those numbers a bit."

In the 80's they told us (in elementary school, through a program called CARE), that by 2001 we'd all have to wear protective suits to be able to go outside. Also we were supposed to have used up all the oil by 2001 (or maybe it was 2010).  They told us a lot of stuff that wasn't true.  So forgive me for not trusting these people, they have a bad track record that they have NEVER addressed.  Why were they wrong in the 80's, and why are they right now?  The kids who were brainwashed in the 80's are they heading up these climate science research projects?

I don't trust climate scientists because they are living in an echo chamber where the only acceptable answer to any question is the popular one.  That isn't science.  Science is about skepticism, when skepticism dies, so does scientific inquiry.  I'm not denying anything, I'm still skeptical, that's all.
