text:
+Queleimporta Pene

"Climate change is a fact, but I am not yet sure we are causing it."

It's a well-evidenced fact that humans (largely via anthropogenic greenhouse gases) caused most of the global warming that occurred since the mid-20th century. Arguing about this point, is like arguing over whether HIV causes AIDS or whether smoking causes cancer.

There are at least 50 scientific papers showing this. These papers use various techniques, including:

- model-based prediction, where those models were tested against previous data, including paleoclimatological data, akin to how one can predict the generate astronomical models that explain the motion of planets/satellites and then use those models to predict the motion of other planets/satellites; the models predict how much warming would result from solar forcing, CO2 release, etc. based on how much warming resulted from these factors in the past

- examining warming patterns in different layers of the atmosphere (since different forcings produce different patterns of atmospheric warming, with greenhouse gases having a particular atmospheric warming pattern).

So different methods have yielded much the same conclusion. That is a hallmark of good science: consilience of different results on the same, accurate conclusion. That way, the strengths of one methods can compensate for the weaknesses in another method, and you know that your result is not just due to the flaws of one particular methods.

Here are some of the 50+ scientific papers on this:

"Causes of the Global Warming Observed since the 19th Century"
"Attribution of observed historical near-surface temperature variations to anthropogenic and natural causes using CMIP5 simulations"
"Anthropogenic and natural warming inferred from changes in Earth‚Äôs energy balance"
"Attributing Observed SST Trends and Subcontinental Land Warming to Anthropogenic Forcing during 1979‚Äì2005"
"Sensitivity of the attribution of near surface temperature warming to the choice of observational dataset"
"A probabilistic quantification of the anthropogenic component of twentieth century global warming"
"Identifying human influences on atmospheric temperature"
"Quantifying anthropogenic influence on recent near-surface temperature change"
"Evidence for external forcing on 20th-century climate from combined ocean-atmosphere warming patterns"



"The only argument is the carbon isotopes argument, could you develope more on that please?"

There are quite a number of ways we can confirm that the recent CO2 increase is anthropogenic. For example, we can:

1) use carbon isotope ratios in atmospheric CO2
2) show that the oceans likely aren't a net releaser of CO2, since the oceans are acidifying (indicative of net CO2 uptake, not net CO2 release) and CO2 levels are increasing in the ocean
3) measure emissions from other non-anthropogenic sources (such as volcanoes), and see that anthropogenic emissions outweigh those sources
4) observe the decreased atmospheric O2 levels that one would expect from burning of fossils fuels as a contributor to CO2 emissions
5) observe the correlation between increased anthropogenic CO2 emissions and increased atmospheric CO2
6) the radiative forcing and temperature response changed from before to after the industrial revolution, consistent with anthropogenic CO2 emissions resulting in warming (as opposed to it just being non-anthropogenic)

And here are some background sources on these points:

Point 1:
https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/outreach/isotopes/
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2011JD017048/full
https://journals.uair.arizona.edu/index.php/radiocarbon/article/viewFile/16286/pdf

Points 1, 2, 4, and 5:
http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.713.6770&rep=rep1&type=pdf

Point 2:
ftp://oce.orst.edu/dist/OMEL/Diazo_CO2/Doneyetal2009.pdf
https://eprints.soton.ac.uk/363195/

Point 3:
http://minsocam.org/MSA/RIM/RiMG075/RiMG075_Ch11.pdf
http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/volcanowatch/archive/2007/07_02_15.html

Point 6:
https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Theologos_Dergiades/publication/287372610_Long-Run_Changes_in_Radiative_Forcing_and_Surface_Temperature_The_Effect_of_Human_Activity_over_the_Last_Five_Centuries/links/568d515008aead3f42ed982b.pdf


SkepticalScience discusses some other lines of evidence as well:
http://www.skepticalscience.com/anthrocarbon-brief.html
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text:
The distinction you are making between denialists and skeptics is way too involved for my money.  I'm just using the term in the common manner.  I'm skeptical.  When I say I'm skeptical, I don't mean "professionally,"  I mean I'm not sure I believe the claims of climate science and I have various reasons which keep me from completely buying into the idea.

If I was going to make a convenient distinction to serve my argument, I would make one between Climate Alarmists and climate scientists.  A climate scientist has to wait for the result of his prediction to empirically confirm his theory.  You don't have that with Climate Alarmists.  Climate Alarmists do not wait for data that confirms their prediction, and they are willing to suppress data  which refutes their prediction.  Climate Alarmism is belief in an unproven prediction that human carbon dioxide emissions will catastrophically alter the Earth's environment.

Climate Alarmists have staked entire reputations on these predictions.  I don't know much about climate science, but I do know a lot about human nature, and scientists are like all other people.  They do not merely make mistakes, they are capable of deluding themselves.  If one's immediate superior is a Climate Alarmist, there are many and diverse sociological motives which will effect the gathering and interpretation of data.

I have a book called Forbidden Archaeology, which documents cases where members of the scientific community have suppressed evidence and destroyed the careers of colleagues who threatened to undermine consensus on subjects on which prominent community members  have built their careers and reputations.  

"Because the models/simulations are compared to data to make sure they are accurate."  

The models are only accurate to the available experimental data.  The source of experimental data is the actual climate.  There is no data to tell us what a transition from our current climate to runaway global warming would look like.   Most of the data used to compare with the models is the data gathered "so far."  So the predictive reliability of these models is still questionable and could be way off due to yet unknown factor or programing error. 

None of the predictions of these models are empirical.  So when people say 97% of Climate Scientists agree on global warming, I'd like to know just exactly what they are agreeing about.  Do they all agree with the dire and unconfirmed predictions of these models?  

One of the most important aspects of science is experimentation.  Experiments have to be repeatable so that results can be confirmed.  We don't properly have that with climate science.  All we have is a simulation which keeps getting run, over and over, and the scientific nature of that simulated reality is perfectly reasonable to doubt.  

The climate is a very big thing to study,  I'm not convinced that we have come so far that  we know all the factors involved and that our simulations are replicating reality.  For instance, in chemistry, some reactions have limitations in a given environment.  Does the effect plateau?  And the degree and nature of the change caused by rising CO2 levels is a question for which we do not have empirical answers. 

The point of saying that is not to say, "THEREFORE!  Climate Change is a Hoax!"  I'm not saying that.   When I hear appeals to authority and to consensus and see great social pressure being used to push a point,  I instinctively dig in my heels.  That's just my nature. I frequently play devil's advocate to myself in my own head and try on different ideas.  Just going with the crowd is not in my DNA. 

I understand we can't afford to run the experiment of climate change.  In fact, the point of climate alarmism is to force human society to change, using the power of the state, in order to avoid climate change, is it not?  

So, there are some intense pressures here.  If the Climate Alarmists fail to change human activity, and little or no climate change occurs, then the Climate Scientists and Alarmists alike are going to seem more and more like chicken little and will fall into disrepute.  

On the other hand, if Climate Alarmists succeed in changing government policy, and little or no climate change occurs, they will have succeeded in seizing great power and influence for themselves 
without having had to prove that any of there predictions were experimentally valid.  

If they are right, and catastrophic climate change does occur, that is a price no one wants to pay.  Even so, if true, the process is not likely to be reversed due to social forces.  I recall learning that the last time a single species came to dominate the world it led to a mass extinction (I do not recall if the two were related).  Mass extinctions are part of life and death on planet earth.  

I don't wish to become extinct or to watch the natural world become less rich. But the destruction of one epoch gives rise to another.  According to the fossil and geological records, mass extinctions open up new opportunities for new life forms.  If the former inhabitants of the earth had never died off, we never would have come to be.  We cling to the earth as it currently exists, but it is going to change, whether because of our activity, or because of external factors.  Gradually, or suddenly, it will change and various life forms will perish, and new life will emerge, or perhaps, finally, death will reign. That's also a strong consensus opinion out there.

OK, that is a very fatalistic view. So, I want to ask, what if there is only marginal climate change?  What if the changes in the climate are not catastrophic, but just generally "bad?"  And by "bad" I mean that the changes cause smaller extinctions and disturbances to the environment.  How small?  How about small enough that people will willingly pay the price? 

Global warming is a bit of a catch-all phrase.  How much global warming do all these scientists agree on?  Because the amount makes a big difference.  Personally, I think that is what causes Climate Alarmists to make dire predictions instead of conservative ones. Climate Alarmists use fear because they know that if we had to sacrifice all the polar bears, so that every human could live that first-world lifestyle, that we would get a solid worldwide majority who would vote to let the polar bears die, and deal with the regret later.  

That's what I think drives the fear among climate alarmists.  They need to use the power of the state to force changes on people before those people realize that climate change may involve prices they are willing to pay in order to live with modern conveniences.  Without the fear of catastrophic changes, most humans would be willing to make a devil's bargain to obtain prosperity at the price of environmental degradation.  That is what drives Climate Alarmism.  There is not enough data to justify Climate Alarmism.  

That is the outcome I actually find reasonable, because in spite of being skeptical about the claims of climate science,   I instinctively feel that having so many people doing so many things is bound to have at least SOME impact.  I just question the dire nature of the predictions.  I feel that the masses are being manipulated towards panic in order to make them agree to societal changes they would not agree to if they believed the coming climate changes were more minor. 

I don't mis-remember CARE.  I might have their predictive dates off, but it was coming early this (21st) century.  This was not some rogue teacher, this was (at least) a district wide program, and probably much larger. I remember the information because it came in the form of worksheets that had some very nice artwork and well crafted propaganda.  The information was presented in the form of a letter from the future.  A future student was writing back to the 11 year old me in 1984 to tell me what life was like in 20xx). It was striking and haunting. 

When I said "There's one reason I'm skeptical"  that was not a very well written sentence.  I should have said "Here's one reason,"  because I have a number of reasons for being skeptical, none of them very strong, but all joined together they prevent me from believing the claims of climate alarmists.  Some more rational than others, but as I said, all uninformed (in terms of climate science).  General suspicion is one reason I remain skeptical of the claims of climate alarmists.

 When I saw, "An Inconvenient Truth,"  I was somewhat swayed, and seriously considered what the impact of skyrocketing carbon dioxide might be on the environment.  The exponential growth on Al Gore's chart was so visibly alarming but when I considered the implications I came to believe that whatever the results are, they are inevitable.

In regards to the echo chamber claim.  The claim (not mine) that 99% (97%?) of climate scientists agree means that they are indeed in an echo chamber. What comes from their mouths is what they hear from their colleagues, and they may be right, but they are living in an echo chamber.  This happens in science all the time.  You really need to study scientists from a sociological point of view.  Science is empirical, scientists are human.  

Fantastic claims require fantastic proof.  Fantastic claims offered by people living in echo chambers can be reasonably questioned (especially when the evidence is a computer program they all worked on together).  If they say global warming is an urgent and existential threat to the earth and that 97% of scientists agree on "climate change"  (though it is rarely stated HOW MUCH climate change they agree on)  I think it is entirely reasonable to suspect that there are more sociological forces than empirical science at work.

I tried posting this earlier but it wouldn't show up.  So if this ends up duplicating a post I apologize, I can't see my earlier post.
author: Paul Stringini

text:
+Paul Stringini

"A climate scientist has to wait for the result of his prediction to empirically confirm his theory.  You don't have that with Climate Alarmists.  [...] Climate Alarmism is belief in an unproven prediction that human carbon dioxide emissions will catastrophically alter the Earth's environment. [...] I think that is what causes Climate Alarmists to make dire predictions instead of conservative ones. "

You're attacking a straw man with this who "catastrophic" idea, and your clams about "alarmists" hold no merit:

"Climate Change Skepticism and Denial: An Introduction
[...]
A constant refrain coming from the denial campaign is that climate scientists are ‚Äúalarmists‚Äù who exaggerate the degree and threat of global warming to enhance their status, funding, and influence with policy makers. The contribution by William Freudenburg and Violetta Muselli provides an insightful empirical test of this charge and finds it to lack support."

"Polluted Discourse: Communication and Myths in a Climate of Denial
[...]
Additionally, we find that catastrophic anthropogenic global warming [CAGW] is essentially a term that is never used in the relevant scientific literature by mainstream sources. Furthermore, in the press it appears to be used exclusively by climate contrarians. The term is typically neither defined nor attributed to a mainstream scientific source. Our conclusion is therefore that CAGW is simply a straw man used by climate contrarians to criticize the mainstream position (50)."



"The models are only accurate to the available experimental data"

No. For example, take the following paper:
"Evidence for climate change in the satellite cloud record"

That paper compares cloud data, to the cloud predictions made by climate models. The climate models were made before this cloud data analysis was done. So the cloud data (presented in the analysis discussed in the paper) had not yet been fed into the models. Instead, the models were made/published, the cloud data was then analyzed, and then the models were compared to the data.

Another example of this is the IPCC first consensus prediction. It fit the data that followed it did rather well, as discussed in the following paper:
"Assessment of the first consensus prediction on climate change"



"So when people say 97% of Climate Scientists agree on global warming, I'd like to know just exactly what they are agreeing about."

There's a scientific consensus that:

A1) There has been global warming since the mid-20th century.
A2) Humans (largely via anthropogenic greenhouse gases) caused most of this recent warming.
A3) Most of the recent (or near future) climate change is (or will be) caused by humans.
A4) Climate change is a serious problem and/or a danger to humanity.

The following paper documents that consensus on A1 and A2:
"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"

For the consensus on A3 and A4, among AAAS (American Academy for the Advancement of Science) scientists with relevant expertise, there's a 95% consensus that climate change was a serious problem and a 93% consensus that recent warming is mostly caused by humans:

"Earth Scientists Views on Climate Change"
http://www.pewinternet.org/2015/07/23/elaborating-on-the-views-of-aaas-scientists-issue-by-issue/

And in another survey, ~87% of climate researchers thought that humans caused (or will cause) most of the recent (or near future) climate change, while ~86% of climate researchers thought that climate change poses a very serious problem and a threat to humanity:

Figures 88 (v043) and 2 (v007) of "The Bray and von Storch 5th International Survey of Climate Scientists 2015/2016"
https://www.hzg.de/imperia/md/content/hzg/zentrale_einrichtungen/bibliothek/berichte/hzg_reports_2016/hzg_report_2016_2.pdf



"None of the predictions of these models are empirical."

Nonsense, since the models make empirical predictions that can be compared to the empirical data.



" I'm not convinced that we have come so far that  we know all the factors involved"

We don't need to know all the factors involved in order to know what caused most of the recent warming, just like I don't need to know all the factors involved in a murder to know that the defendant killed the victim.



"One of the most important aspects of science is experimentation.  Experiments have to be repeatable so that results can be confirmed.  We don't properly have that with climate science."

That makes no sense. For example, various astronomical events are not repeatable, yet these astronomical events still count as evidence for various astronomical theories. Similarly, climate science does not need to repeat various event,s in order to have evidence.



"There is no data to tell us what a transition from our current climate to runaway global warming would look like."

You're attacking a straw man again, since not even the IPCC thinks runaway global warming is likely:

"For instance, a ‚Äúrunaway greenhouse effect‚Äù‚Äîanalogous to Venus--appears to have virtually no chance of being induced by anthropogenic activities."
http://www.ipcc.ch/meetings/session31/inf3.pdf



"When I hear appeals to authority and to consensus and see great social pressure being used to push a point,  I instinctively dig in my heels.  That's just my nature."

That's contrarianism and pseudoskepticism. That is not a good thing.

"When scientific consensus is rejected by non-experts who naively consider themselves more scientifically astute than the collective scientific community, it is appropriately labeled pseudoskepticism."
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/tops.12179/full
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text:
You did a neat job of avoiding or dismissing every sociological argument I made.

When you called my reference to catastrophic global warming a straw man, you actually made a straw man of my argument.  What qualifies as a catastrophe?  This is what I'm talking about.  Out of one side of your mouth you say, I quote, "~86% of climate researchers thought that climate change poses a very serious problem and a threat to humanity:" That sounds catastrophic to me. 

By the way, the whole "Climate Alarmists vs Climate Scientists" was merely a "tit for tat" ad hominem attack on the motives of scientists.  Just as you have essentially been attacking the motives of anyone who dares question their unsupported claim that their observations predict a THREAT to humanity.  You denied the validity of skeptics you don't agree with.  Do you realize how incredibly childish that is?   "They're deniers, not skeptics!"  It becomes an essentially sociological argument at that point.  It's a "no true Scotsman" fallacy. 

The globe has undergone many changes while humans have inhabited it.  These Climate scientists are obviously no anthropologists.  There once was a place called Doggerland, it was swallowed by the sea during a period of global warming, humanity survived.

I made no reference to a Venus situation, but I don't know why that would be ruled out in any case.  As the most resilient of the large mammals, anything that threatens humans threatens most mammals.  Perhaps most chordates.  I really don't know because the threat is unspecified.

Starting at "a threat to humanity," most humans would consider things that can threaten all of humanity with.... extinction?  Sunburns?  What is the threat?  That's why you people come off as preachy zealots.  Amorphous threats are the tools of despots. 

Cloud predictions?  A model that predicts clouds is not a model that predicts that clouds are going to threaten humanity.  How are the clouds going to kill us?  Are the models predicting consecutive months or years of total cloud cover?  That would indeed be a threat.

A predictive model has to be relevant to the prediction you are making.  We are talking about a humanity threatening change in the earth's climate.  Exactly which model predicts that, and exactly what data goes into that.

I reassert that any models that predict "a threat to humanity" are not empirical, and probably do not exist.  What is happening is that scientists are looking at models that tell them the earth is warming and they make the judgment THEMSELVES that it is a threat to humanity.  And what is much more likely is that the global temperature change is a threat to specialized animals in certain cold environments.

Here is something for you to think about.  If the industrial revolution never happened.  And humanity was limited to half a billion people living a sustainable lifestyle.  Can you guarantee the climate would never change?  Of course not.  

You made a bad analogy here "We don't need to know all the factors involved in order to know what caused most of the recent warming, just like I don't need to know all the factors involved in a murder to know that the defendant killed the victim."

That is a bad analogy.  We are not trying to solve a murder, we are trying to predict the future.  Those two operations are NOT analogous.  Predictive models which lack critical elements will give bad predictions.  That is something I should not have to argue.   

It makes no sense that experiments have to be repeatable?  It's called the scientific method. You really ought to Google that.  If the climate scientists you are listening to think that experimental data does not need to be confirmed by repeated experimentation and observation, those are not scientists.  

An hypothesis generated as the result of a single astronomical event would be considered an UNCONFIRMED HYPOTHESIS.  An observation is made, an hypothesis is made, more observations, perhaps a prediction.  Confirmed predictions from observations of similar events are observed, the hypothesis may be considered confirmed or perhaps plausible.  If you see something once, an hypothesis about the observation would not be considered confirmed and any prediction based on those observations would be greeted with natural skepticism.

Right now,  the "threat to humanity" claim is an unconfirmed hypothesis, not based on observation, but based on conjecture.  It is not scientific.  Not every statement made by a scientist is a statement of science.

I said  "There is no data to tell us what a transition from our current climate to runaway global warming would look like."

You said" You're attacking a straw man again, since not even the IPCC thinks runaway global warming is likely:"

Ok, I told you I was ignorant.  I didn't realize the term "runaway global warming" specifically referred to a Venus situation.  I thought it just meant irreversible and  humanity threatening global warming.

I'll restate my argument: 
There is no data to tell us what a transition from our current climate to one in which humanity is seriously threatened would look like.  

How bad does the climate have to get in order to threaten one of the most the most adaptable species to ever exist?  Catastrophically bad?  

See, that is what I'm talking about.  You are making a distinction without a difference.  How bad do the models say it is going to get?  How does that compare with changes in global temperature in the past?  Climate scientists are attempting to use fear and threats to manipulate human behavior according to their beliefs about how humanity should live.  I don't trust them at all.

I said, "When I hear appeals to authority and to consensus and see great social pressure being used to push a point,  I instinctively dig in my heels.  That's just my nature."

To which you replied, "That's contrarianism and pseudoskepticism. That is not a good thing."

Bullshit. Willingness to yield to social pressure and consensus is how you authoritarians manipulate people.  I will never consider my initial reflex to reject majority opinion a liability.  It is not to say I don't come around.  But I think before I join a crowd.  I guess that is because my background is in History.
author: Paul Stringini

text:
+Paul Stringini

"Out of one side of your mouth you say, I quote, "~86% of climate researchers thought that climate change poses a very serious problem and a threat to humanity:" That sounds catastrophic to me."

A "serious problem" need not be catastrophic. For instance, diabetes, automobile accidents, allergic reactions to peanuts, etc. are serious problems that don't end the world, lead to humanity-ending catastrophe, etc. Similarly, anthropogenic climate change can be a serious problem with serious negative consequences, without collapsing human society, ending the world, etc.



"The globe has undergone many changes while humans have inhabited it.  These Climate scientists are obviously no anthropologists."

You're making a very silly argument here. Past non-anthropogenic climate change doesn't change the fact that most of the recent global warming was caused by humans through the production of anthropogenic greenhouse gases. To say otherwise is as ridiculous as saying that humans can't cause forest fires now, since humans didn't cause a forest fire that occurred hundreds of years ago:

"These examples illustrate that different climate changes in the past had different causes. The fact that natural factors caused climate changes in the past does not mean that the current climate change is natural. By analogy, the fact that forest fires have long been caused naturally by lightning strikes does not mean that fires cannot also be caused by a careless camper."
https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-6-1.html

"Critics have argued that, if temperatures were as warm or warmer than current conditions before the onset of anthropogenic forcing, this would provide evidence that ‚Äúnatural‚Äù fluctuations alone could explain current conditions, since greenhouse gases were only ~280 ppmv during Medieval time (versus 400 ppmv today).
[...]
With the increase in irradiance and a decline in explosive volcanism in the early 20th century, global temperatures might then have returned to an unperturbed level similar to that of the MQP [Medieval Quiet Period], but *the rapid rise in anthropogenic greenhouse gases propelled temperatures well beyond that level, as positive anthropogenic radiative forcing overwhelmed natural variability (Myhre et al., 2013).*"
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/291523102_The_Medieval_Quiet_Period



"Cloud predictions?  A model that predicts clouds is not a model that predicts that clouds are going to threaten humanity."

Stop moving the goal-posts. You claimed that the models made no accurate empirical predictions. I showed you that they made accurate predictions of cloud cover. So you were wrong. Deal with it.



"It makes no sense that experiments have to be repeatable?  It's called the scientific method. You really ought to Google that."

I already dealt with this mistake of your's:
That makes no sense. For example, various astronomical events are not repeatable, yet these astronomical events still count as evidence for various astronomical theories. Similarly, climate science does not need to repeat various events in order to have evidence.

So, once again, one does not need repeatable events in order to have scientific evidence. For example, we have evidence on human evolution from non-human animals, even though we have no repeated that event. We can have a forensic evidence on a murder, even though we have no repeated the murder.



"We are not trying to solve a murder, we are trying to predict the future.  Those two operations are NOT analogous." of climate change."

Climate scientists are trying to figure out the causes of climate change, which is analogous to figure out who caused a death. Climate scientists even use terms like "fingerprinting" to discuss trying to figure out the causes of climate change, even different causes of climate change have a distinct pattern or "fingerprint" that can different them from other causes of climate change:

"Application of regularised optimal fingerprinting to attribution. Part II: application to global near-surface temperature"
"Adaptation of the optimal fingerprint method for climate change detection using a well-conditioned covariance matrix estimate"



"I'll restate my argument: There is no data to tell us what a transition from our current climate to one in which humanity is seriously threatened would look like."

You don't read the peer-reviewed scientific literature, so you have no clue what the data shows. You're just making stuff up. You're like a creationist who claims that there's no evidence of hominid evolution, yet refuses to read any of the scientific research on hominid evolution. You're saying what you want to be true, not what you have evidence for.


There's abundant scientific research showing that anthropogenic climate change has caused (or will cause):
- increased heat-related mortality (which outweighs any decreases in cold-related mortality)
- increased drought intensity
- economic losses from sea level rise
- increased hurricane intensity
- ocean acidification (which results in things such as loss of marine crops and marine food)
- reduced crop yields
and so on.

Here's some research on this, to get you started:

"Ice Melt, Sea Level Rise and Superstorms: Evidence from Paleoclimate Data, Climate Modeling, and Modern Observations that 2C Global Warming Could Be Dangerous"
"A meta-analysis of crop yield under climate change and adaptation"
"Climate Change: Impact on Agriculture and Costs of Adaptation"
"Ocean Acidification: The Other CO2 Problem"
"Nutrition and income from molluscs today imply vulnerability to ocean acidification tomorrow"
"Economic impacts of climate change in Europe: sea-level rise"
"Economic losses from US hurricanes consistent with an influence from climate change"
"Tropical cyclones and climate change"
"Anthropogenic warming has increased drought risk in California"
"Contribution of anthropogenic warming to California drought during 2012‚Äì2014"
"Increasing drought under global warming in observations and models"
"Global warming and changes in drought"
"Climate warming will not decrease winter mortality"
"Winter season mortality: will climate warming bring benefits?"
"Winter mortality in a warming climate: a reassessment"
"Heat-Related Mortality and Adaptation to Heat in the United States"
"Projecting Future Heat-Related Mortality under Climate Change Scenarios: A Systematic Review"
"Climate change effects on human health: projections of temperature-related mortality for the UK during the 2020s, 2050s and 2080s"
"Comparative Assessment of the Effects of Climate Change on Heat and Cold-Related Mortality in the United Kingdom and Australia"



"Climate scientists are attempting to use fear and threats to manipulate human behavior according to their beliefs about how humanity should live.  I don't trust them at all."

Paranoid conspiracy theories from you. Pathetic. It's as silly as saying that:

B1) Doctors say "smoking is a danger to humans; one reason for this is that smoking causes lung cancer." These doctors are attempting to use fear and threats to manipulate human behavior according to their beliefs about how humanity should live. I don't trust them at all.
B2) Virologists sat that "HIV is a danger to humans, since HIV causes AIDS in humans." These virologists are attempting to use fear and threats to manipulate human behavior according to their beliefs about how humanity should live. I don't trust them at all.



"Bullshit. Willingness to yield to social pressure and consensus is how you authoritarians manipulate people."

Again, this is pseudoskepticism and a foolish refusal to listen to experts who know more than you:

"Accounting for the Appeal to the Authority of Experts
[...]
The account of expert/citizen communication starts by acknowledging the general (if ambiguous) norm: it is imprudent for the nonexpert to go against the expert view (Goodwin 1998). When a local tells a tourist that a road is dangerous, or a doctor advises a patient that smoking is harmful to her health, or a climate scientist tells the rest of us that the world is warming because of our activities*, then the tourist or patient or we would be dumb keep going along regardless. ‚Äò‚ÄòOnly the *fool would not want some expert advice in technical matters‚Äô‚Äô (Fischer 2009, p. 139); ‚Äò‚Äòother things being equal, we ought to prefer the judgments of those who ‚Äòknow what they are talking about‚Äô‚Äô‚Äô (Collins and Evans 2007, p. 2)."
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text:
+Paul Stringini

"What makes this an annoying discussion is your insistence of stereotyping me and refusing to actually address the substance of my argument, but rather cherry pick sections of my remarks and mischaracterizing them as if I am trying to say climate science is alchemy or something."

Your reasoning has no substance. You're basically just making up baseless conspiracy theories about climate scientists, while making incorrect statements that reveal a lack of understanding of the relevant scientific evidence and how scientific reasoning works. And I'm not cherry-picking at all. I'm dealing with specific things you said, and showing how they are wrong.



"I start to feel like I don't want to listen to you, because you are not really listening to me. Half of what you are saying is not relevant to the issue I have, and in that case I don't know why you are even replying to my comment."

I am listening to you; I'm directly quoting what you say, and then responding to it. You're now doing the same thing, so I suggest you stop complaining about it (lest you engage in hypocrisy).

The likely problem here is that you're not used to the sort of debating I do, which is the sort of debate done in philosophy and science: I address specific points someone makes, and provide evidence/arguments against those points. This is not what many non-experts like you do. Instead, you guys just tend to make stuff up (without any evidence), and rely on the other person not to call you on this. Sorry, but that's not how I operate.



"For one,  I do not say that global is not happening.  I do not say that global warming is not caused by human activity.  In fact, I said that the idea made sense to me on a gut level."

Yet in your first post, you said that:
"There's one reason why I'm skeptical.  Simulations. So much of this rides on the trustworthiness of simulations written by people who went into the climate field, very likely BECAUSE they believed the climate was changing and that man was responsible.  How do I know that this bias is not being programmed into the simulation.  "Opps!  Looks like the simulation is not working right, we are not getting the "right" answer, tweak those numbers a bit.""

That sounds like someone being "skeptical" (really being a denialist) about whether "climate was changing and that man was responsible". And this person was misrepresenting scientists and their simulations/models, in order to justify being "skeptical".



"You claimed, "Stop moving the goal-posts. You claimed that the models made no accurate empirical predictions." I never claimed that."

Yes you did. You said:
"None of the predictions of these models are empirical."
"And the degree and nature of the change caused by rising CO2 levels is a question for which we do not have empirical answers."

You said this before I ever mentioned climate change being a serious problem and/or a threat to humanity. So please don't pretend your claim was an objection to that. Instead, you were objecting to my claim that:
"Because the models/simulations are compared to data to make sure they are accurate."  

When I then showed you evidence of the confirmed empirical predictions of these models, you moved the goalposts to demanding that the models show that climate change was a danger to humanity.



"Serious problem and a threat to humanity are not equivalent.  So when climate scientists say "threat to humanity" where do they get the evidence for that?"

I already cited evidence on that to you. Please stop acting otherwise. As I told you, there's abundant scientific research showing that anthropogenic climate change has caused (or will cause):
- increased heat-related mortality (which outweighs any decreases in cold-related mortality)
- increased drought intensity
- economic losses from sea level rise
- increased hurricane intensity
- ocean acidification (which results in things such as loss of marine crops and marine food)
- reduced crop yields
and so on.



"None of those things are "threats to humanity""

Anything that kills humans (i.e. increases human mortality) is a threat to humanity, by definition. Humanity is a collection of humans, and killing humans is a obviously a threat to humans. Of course, we often put up with threats to humanity, for various humans. For example, we put up with smoking because we want people to have the legal freedom to smoke. We put up with peanuts (which kill people via peanut allergies) so other non-allergic people can enjoy them. And so on.



"I'm sorry, but increased heat related deaths of the very old and very young is a serious problem, but it is not a "threat to humanity."  Keep your baby and grandparents cool."

It takes a truly unscrupulous person to pretend that increase mortality isn't a threat to humans. Anyway, not everyone has access to adequate home cooling; otherwise, no one would ever die from environmentally-induced heat stroke. And if you'd bother to read some of the research in question, then you'd know that the increased heat-related mortality occurs even with adaptation strategies (like home cooling). For instance:

"Heat-Related Mortality and Adaptation to Heat in the United States"

This is one of the main problems with you, Paul: you just make stuff up (usually, whatever you think will help your position) without reading up on the evidence to see if your claims are supported.



"Glad to hear you concede that I'm right about the science not providing evidence that humanity is "threatened"."

I said no such thing.



"But you are wrong about the sociology, climate scientists are promoting climate alarmism by claiming global warming is a "threat to humanity.""

I dealt with this distortion of your's the first time you offered it. Please stop repeating your debunked point. Once again:


The scientists at the IPCC are fairly accurate in their model-based predictions. And when they get things wrong, they tend to under-estimate the effects of global warming, as opposed to exaggerating them, contrary to the claims made by denialists about scientists being "alarmists". See the following source on this:

"Climate Change Skepticism and Denial: An Introduction
[...]
A constant refrain coming from the denial campaign is that climate scientists are ‚Äúalarmists‚Äù who exaggerate the degree and threat of global warming to enhance their status, funding, and influence with policy makers. The contribution by William Freudenburg and Violetta Muselli provides an insightful empirical test of this charge and finds it to lack support."

And this is some of the relevant supporting research on this point:

"Reexamining Climate Change Debates: Scientific Disagreement or Scientific Certainty Argumentation Methods (SCAMs)?"
"Global warming estimates, media expectations, and the asymmetry of scientific challenge"
"Climate change prediction: Erring on the side of least drama?"



"Right there, you moved the goal posts from threat to problem."

Not a goal-post move, since I mentioned "serious problem" *before" I mentioned "threat to humanity", and I made it clear that this was an "and/or" claim. Here the first instance in which I mentioned them:

"A4) Climate change is a serious problem and/or a danger to humanity."
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text:
Your reasoning has no substance. 

That is a purely rhetorical turn having no basis in reality.  You are getting entangled in gathering rhetorical victories without actually addressing the point I'm actually trying to make.   

You're basically just making up baseless conspiracy theories about climate scientists,

One, it is not a conspiracy, it is fear-mongering and it is absolutely being done.  I believe it is being done out of a sincere belief on the part of climate scientists that global warming is happening, but in order to provoke people to change, climate scientists are giving their silent approval to climate alarmists by not doing a very good job reproving them.

You might complain a bit about my changing position.  That's because I'm learning and I don't have an entrenched position.  I'm one of those middle Americans whose friends all believe global warming is a hoax, but I think there may be something going on.  So shoot me.

I showed you that Puttnam video.  In the comments, I dare you to say he is being alarmist when he claims that within a century global warming would cause human extinction.  You will get your head bit off!  

Two, my questioning of BIAS in testing and interpreting data is NOT a conspiracy theory, it is a well-known sociological phenomenon which researchers do well to be wary of.  It is a valid concern, especially when some of the scientists in question may believe that if no action is taken we may irreparably damage the Earth.  If you are trying to prevent a disaster, you might be tempted to turn a blind eye on  a little alarm.  

Three,  the assertion that climate alarm does not exist is manifestly not true.  Do I really have to fill this comment with references to people claiming that the coming climate change is an existential threat to the human species?  

while making incorrect statements that reveal a lack of understanding of the relevant scientific evidence and how scientific reasoning works.

"As an uninformed skeptic" I think I made it clear from the beginning how much I know about climate science.  I'm merely an everyday fellow looking in on a subject I'm only marginally interested and running into you, is this what climate fundamentalism looks like?  Insulting or attempting to shame me into submission will not work.  If you really care about the environment, you should study human nature. 

And I'm not cherry-picking at all. I'm dealing with specific things you said, and showing how they are wrong.

No, you are cherry picking.  The cherries are the specific things I said which you feel are most useful in your line of argumentation (that I am a climate denier).  The issues which are at the core of my questioning of climate science you dismiss without consideration.  Bias, fear-mongering, and a tendency to authoritarianism.  Those are my concerns, but you treat them as if they are merely tools I use to undermine Climate Science.  I may be doing that on some level, but that does not mean that my opinions are not sincerely held.

For example, you did not address the video I linked, which is clearly alarmist.  

The likely problem here is that you're not used to the sort of debating I do, which is the sort of debate done in philosophy and science: I address specific points someone makes, and provide evidence/arguments against those points.

This comment literally makes me groan and figuratively makes me want to puke.  I've been engaging in philosophical debate for over twenty years.  I am very familiar with the kind of debate you are engaging in (for better or worse).  And I am very used to people who do not understand the other side of a question consistently pushing the debate towards ground they are comfortable with. 

I'm doing the same thing this time but I will respond to every point, that is my usual custom, but this is not my field of interest, so I was not following my custom.  It's not some grand thing.

This debate is essentially over my comment.  Your assertion is that I'm a climate denier.  It is the most pointless kind of debate, because I have already demonstrated that I am not a climate denier.  Just because I am not an expert on climate science does not mean that I can't be sincerely skeptical and question claims that global warming is an existential threat to the human species.  Claims you say are not being made, ok, but, in fact, I have heard those claims being made.  They are implicit in the video my comment is attached to.

This is not what many non-experts like you do.  

Full of yourself much? I had no idea my comment on this video would attract the notice of someone so astute and important as yourself!  I fan my self in nervous apprehension!

And I am an expert.  Just not in climate science. 

Instead, you guys just tend to make stuff up (without any evidence), and rely on the other person not to call you on this. Sorry, but that's not how I operate.

Hey, before I throw up after having attempted to swallow your virtue signaling, I'd like to remind you that this is not my area of expertise.  I never claimed expertise in this area, and judging me as if I had claimed so is transparently unfair and demeaning.

As far as the "no evidence" claim, that is not completely true.  Suspicions do not require evidence. Motive is different from direct evidence but no less worth of consideration.  And as far as my claim that there is a lot of climate alarm going on out there, I have plenty of evidence for that, I provided one source and really this is a point which does not need to be proven, because it is self-evident.  You are simply denying that Climate SCIENTISTS are alarmist.  When I hear an alarmist, I assume he is basing his alarm on something a scientist said.  That may be incorrect.  But since you have confirmed that scientists say global warming could be a "threat to humanity" I think it is a fair assumption.

My claim For one,  I do not say that global is not happening.  I do not say that global warming is not caused by human activity.  In fact, I said that the idea made sense to me on a gut level.

Your assessment Yet in your first post, you said what I said. 

That sounds like someone being "skeptical" (really being a denialist) about whether "climate was changing and that man was responsible". And this person was misrepresenting scientists and their simulations/models, in order to justify being "skeptical".

What it sounds like to you becomes a moot point once I clarify my mind to you, since this is a question of what I think, and on this score, I am the authority..  

I questioned their motives, I questioned their bias,  I did not say that I myself was convinced that there is no global warming or that could not be a human caused problem.  You keep trying to cast me as a "denier" but I am clearly a "questioner."  Why is it that you cannot understand that distinction?  Even religious people question their faith, and questioning my belief in climate change is like that, because I don't believe it based on science, I'm ignorant of the science,  I believe it based on other factors.  I do tend to trust science, but not completely.

You sound like a climate fundamentalist, as though any sort of questioning of the anointed group is forbidden.  I question authorities.  That is how I operate. You already told me what you think of that.
author: Paul Stringini

text:
I already cited evidence on that to you. Please stop acting otherwise. As I told you, there's abundant scientific research showing that anthropogenic climate change has caused (or will cause) increased heat-related mortality (which outweighs any decreases in cold-related mortality) increased drought intensity...and so on.

I saw that.  Those sound like serious problems. Those are not threats to humanity.  What about Human population?  How will climate change effect human population?  Where is the evidence for that?  That is the claim I  am interested in.  The threat to humanity.

Anything that kills humans (i.e. increases human mortality) is a threat to humanity, by definition.

Uh, no.  That was a transparent rhetorical device using "by definition" incorrectly, you can't get that past me.  I am calling Capital T and capital B.  Total Bullshit. 

Humanity is the whole human race.  (By definition).And not merely a part.  This is an error of logic on your part.

So a threat to the whole human race does not, I repeat does not, include things which merely increase human mortality like  "obesity" or any of the things you listed.  Linguistically, you are living in George Orwell's 1984.

These are the things which are commonly classified as potential threats to humanity.

Artificial intelligence.
Synthetic biology.
Extreme climate change.  (I did not add the "extreme")
Nanotechnology.
Nuclear war.
Major asteroid impact.
Global pandemic.

Notice, things at the level of obesity and severe drought don't make the list.  They are not threatening humanity as a whole and have little potential to threaten humanity as a whole. And humanity is the whole of humans.

Humanity is a collection of humans, and killing humans is a obviously a threat to humans.

Incorrect.  Humanity is ALL HUMANS.  Not a collection.  A threat to humans is not a threat to humanity.  On this level I am probably more of an expert even than you.  You are not going to bully me on language.  You are totally wrong here.

Of course, we often put up with threats to humanity, for various humans.

No, threats to humanity apply to all humans, not to various groups of humans.  By definition.  And I mean that.  This is a major blunder.  Category error.

For example, we put up with smoking because we want people to have the legal freedom to smoke. We put up with peanuts (which kill people via peanut allergies) so other non-allergic people can enjoy them. And so on.

You should stick to the environment.  When it comes to changing the meaning of words to suit your purpose, I will catch you.  This is what happens when you degrade your opposition, you begin to believe I am actually as ignorant generally as you suggest I am on the environment specifically and justifiably.

It takes a truly unscrupulous person to pretend that increase mortality isn't a threat to humans.:

That, is what they call moving the goal posts.  You went from a threat to humanity to a threat to humans.  A knife is a threat to humans, not to humanity.    If there were no hippopotamuses, it would save a few hundred lives a year.  So does that make hippos a threat to humanity?

Did you not consider that the current climate is actually a threat to humans?  What if the climate changed for the better?  (This is purely hypothetical) What if the climate changed in some hypothetical way so that humans lived longer?  In that case, the current climate is a threat to humanity.

It takes a truly unscrupulous person to pretend that increase mortality isn't a threat to humans.:

Unscrupulous is the wrong adjective in that sentence.  You mean stupid.  Really no other word makes sense.  It takes a truly stupid person to pretend that increased mortality isn't a threat to humans since increased human mortality clearly kills humans.

Anyway, not everyone has access to adequate home cooling; otherwise, no one would ever die from environmentally-induced heat stroke.

I understand your moral point about scruples, even though your point about threats to humanity was inaccurate.  I care about people too.  And I care about the environment. 

When I say "keep your baby cool" what I'm saying is that people might choose to live with those risks, just like they choose to live with smoking.  But I believe that climate change is being advertised as a threat to human existence which, if not dealt with, will amount to human suicide.  

We already have people dying of heat stroke (and have had) for all of human history.  It is s serious problem, but people deal with it.  Stopping global warming will not end heat related deaths.  There is (as I suggested) a more ideal climate for humans than the current one.  Death by exposure is a constant threat to human life. (Still not the same as a threat to humanity).  Always has been.

And if you'd bother to read some of the research in question, then you'd know that the increased heat-related mortality occurs even with adaptation strategies (like home cooling). For instance:

 I think what you mean is that the cost of maintaining a livable environment would make certain areas uninhabitable for all practical purposes.  We have put men on the moon.

This is one of the main problems with you, Paul: you just make stuff up (usually, whatever you think will help your position) without reading up on the evidence to see if your claims are supported.

My main problem with you is that you don't see what I am.   I don't really have a position.  I kind of believe in climate change, but I kind of mistrust climate alarmist claims of Armageddon, I think they get that idea from models, so I wonder if the models could be wrong.  You deny the alarmist point of view exists among scientists, but I,  the uninformed moron, have happened to hear the alarmist claim repeated over and over. I see it in movies and on YouTube.

It seems like you want to demean and shame me into studying the field of climate change.  I don't respond to shame due to the way I was raised.  Personally I think climate science has enough apologists.  I wanted to watch a video where my admittedly uninformed opinions would be informed. This video wasn't it.  I commented and went back to my normal activities, which include total disinterest in climate change.  If I was full before, I'm bursting now.  I'm not going to read a research paper.  

*"Glad to hear you concede that I'm right about the science not providing evidence that humanity is "threatened"."

I said no such thing.*

Yes, I see, you define threats to humanity as threats to humans.  A category error.  Logic, don't leave home without it.

*"But you are wrong about the sociology, climate scientists are promoting climate alarmism by claiming global warming is a "threat to humanity.""

I dealt with this distortion of your's the first time you offered it. Please stop repeating your debunked point. Once again:*

There's the rub, you don't want to address what I'm seeing, you are denying that a threat to humanity means a threat to humanity.

The scientists at the IPCC are fairly accurate in their model-based predictions. And when they get things wrong, they tend to under-estimate the effects of global warming, as opposed to exaggerating them, contrary to the claims made by denialists about scientists being "alarmists". See the following source on this:

Ok, but you are saying that a threat to humanity does not mean a threat to humanity, but a threat to humans.  So how can I trust what you are saying since the meaning of your words is unclear?

*"Climate Change Skepticism and Denial: An Introduction
[...]
A constant refrain coming from the denial campaign is that climate scientists are "alarmists" who exaggerate the degree and threat of global warming to enhance their status, funding, and influence with policy makers."*

TThat is not really what I'm saying.  I'm saying that they believe in climate change and that they exaggerate the threat in order to make us do something about it, because most people would rather deal with the consequences of global warming than do anything about it.  

I don't think they do it for money.  I think they do it because they think they know what is best for the world.

*And this is some of the relevant supporting research on this point:

"Reexamining Climate Change Debates: Scientific Disagreement or Scientific Certainty Argumentation Methods (SCAMs)?"
"Global warming estimates, media expectations, and the asymmetry of scientific challenge"
"Climate change prediction: Erring on the side of least drama?"*

I'll keep that in mind if I ever become sincerely interested in the subject.

My claim Right there, you moved the goal posts from threat to problem.

Your response Not a goal-post move, since I mentioned "serious problem" *before" I mentioned "threat to humanity", and I made it clear that this was an "and/or" claim. Here the first instance in which I mentioned them:

Evidenced by A4 Climate change is a serious problem and/or a danger to humanity

Ok, but from my perspective you've been moving the goal posts the whole time if the point was to address my comment on this video.

I question the idea that climate models predict human extinction.  Uninformed as I am, I assumed this position came from the models and scientists behind them.  I have seen video (either fictional or non) of climate models showing an apocalyptic end to climate change. Whether these were real, Hollywood, or outdated Discovery channel, I cannot remember, but they left me with the impression that models were predicting human extinction.

text:
+Paul Stringini

"One, it is not a conspiracy,"

No, you're making up conspiracy theories, which is pretty typical for denialists. For example, take the following for AIDS denialists:

"Deniers argue that because scientists receive grant money, fame, and prestige as a result of their research, it is in their best interest to maintain the status quo [15]. This type of thinking is convenient for deniers as it allows them to choose which authorities to believe and which ones to dismiss as part of a grand conspiracy. In addition to being selective, their logic is also internally inconsistent."
http://journals.plos.org/plosmedicine/article?id=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040256

Now, we can see the same sort of conspiract theories from AGW denialists:

"Climate Change Skepticism and Denial: An Introduction
[...]
A constant refrain coming from the denial campaign is that climate scientists are ‚Äúalarmists‚Äù who exaggerate the degree and threat of global warming to enhance their status, funding, and influence with policy makers. The contribution by William Freudenburg and Violetta Muselli provides an insightful empirical test of this charge and finds it to lack support."

Your claims about "alarmists" fit into this pattern of inventing conspiracy theories.



"I think I made it clear from the beginning how much I know about climate science.  I'm merely an everyday fellow looking in on a subject I'm only marginally interested and running into you, is this what climate fundamentalism looks like?  Insulting or attempting to shame me into submission will not work."

Then ask questions, as opposed to making up baseless claims about scientists working in a field in which you're ignorant. I cannot EMPHASIZE that enough. That's what sensible people do. 

For example, I don't know much about macroeconomics and I'm only marginally interested it. However, I wouldn't invent some baseless, silly conspiracy theory about how: 
"economists are building their bias into their models/simulations, so the economists can claim humans are responsible for bad things!!!" 
I would instead ask questions about the subject so that I could learn. Or I'd read reputable sources on macroeconomics, such as peer-reviewed papers in the subject or textbooks. Or I would defer to the experts in this subject.



"Bias, fear-mongering, and a tendency to authoritarianism.  Those are my concerns,"

Baseless concerns for which you have no evidence.



"You are simply denying that Climate SCIENTISTS are alarmist."

I'm not just denying; I cited evidence against it. You just refuse to engage that evidence, which is typical for denialists.



" I'm saying that they believe in climate change and that they exaggerate the threat in order to make us do something about it,"

And your wrong when you claim this (as I repeatedly explained to you) that source that scientists tend to under-estimate the effects of climate change, as opposed to exaggerating them in the way you claim. You still keep dodging this point.



"I'll keep that in mind if I ever become sincerely interested in the subject."

I already knew you weren't sincerely interested in any evidence that shows you're wrong. I expect that of denialists:

"It is, however, important not to confuse denialism with genuine scepticism, which is essential for scientific progress. Sceptics are willing to change their minds when confronted with new evidence; deniers are not."
http://www.bmj.com/content/341/bmj.c6950.full




"You sound like a climate fundamentalist, as though any sort of questioning of the anointed group is forbidden.  I question authorities.  That is how I operate."

You're not just questioning. You're making ridiculous, baseless accusations. Basically, you're JAQing off and using "implication by question":

"Just asking questions (JAQ-ing off) is a way of attempting to make wild accusations acceptable (and hopefully not legally actionable) by framing them as questions rather than statements."
http://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Just_asking_questions

"One form of misleading discourse involves presupposing and implying something without stating it explicitly, by phrasing it as a question."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_question



"What about Human population?  How will climate change effect human population?  Where is the evidence for that?"

Already explained that to you and cited evidence on it to you. It's sad that you keep pretending otherwise. Once again:
There's abundant scientific research showing that anthropogenic climate change has caused (or will cause):
- increased heat-related mortality (which outweighs any decreases in cold-related mortality)
- increased drought intensity
- economic losses from sea level rise
- increased hurricane intensity
- ocean acidification (which results in things such as loss of marine crops and marine food)
- reduced crop yields
and so on.



"Humanity is the whole human race.  (By definition).And not merely a part."
"No, threats to humanity apply to all humans, not to various groups of humans."
"So a threat to the whole human race does not, I repeat does not, include things which merely increase human mortality like  "obesity" or any of the things you listed."

You're abusing language. For example, one can be prosecuted for "crimes against humanity", even if one doesn't commit a crime against all humans:
http://www.internationalcrimesdatabase.org/Crimes/CrimesAgainstHumanity

Furthermore, public health issues and anthropogenic climate change are categorized as threats to humanity, even if they don't kill everyone. See, for example:

"Zika virus: a global threat to humanity: a comprehensive review and current developments"
"The counterfeit anti-malarial is a crime against humanity: a systematic review of the scientific evidence"
"New vision, new paradigm: health and wealth for all by 2100 ‚Äî or for no one"

"Infectious diseases are a major threat to humanity, and accurate
surveillance is essential."
https://hal-amu.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01199455/document


Yet here you are, acting that something must be a threat to the entire human race in order to be a threat to humanity. Amazing.

"You deny the alarmist point of view exists among scientists, but I,  the uninformed moron, have happened to hear the alarmist claim repeated over and over. I see it in movies and on YouTube."

Goal-post move by you. The issue was not ending all heat-related deaths. Instead the issue was that:
There's abundant scientific research showing that anthropogenic climate change has caused (or will cause) increased heat-related mortality (which outweighs any decreases in cold-related mortality), even with adaptation strategies such as air conditioning.

text:
+Eric Rini

"What ARE the scientists trying to tell us? I've heard legit scientists say that creating a predictive model relating CO2 emissions (or reduction in CO2 emissions) to global temperature is impossible. When put under the gun they can not give clear, predictive models. In any other branch of science this would raise legitimate skepticism."

That's not what the scientific community is telling us. I suggest you look up some of the evidence on climate models. For example:


1) Climate models incorporating internal climate variability (such as ENSO or the IPO) and greenhouse gas forcing (amongst other factors) pretty accurately modeled the current warming period:

"Well-estimated global surface warming in climate projections selected for ENSO phase"
"Investigating the recent apparent hiatus in surface temperature increases: 2. Comparison of model ensembles to observational estimates"
"Forcing, feedback and internal variability in global temperature trends"
"Observations of Climate Feedbacks over 2000‚Äì10 and Comparisons to Climate Models"
"Climate model simulations of the observed early-2000s hiatus of global warming"
"Clarifying the Roles of Greenhouse Gases and ENSO in Recent Global Warming through Their Prediction Performance"
"Deducing Multidecadal Anthropogenic Global Warming Trends Using Multiple Regression Analysis"
"Atlantic and Pacific multidecadal oscillations and Northern Hemisphere temperatures"
"Decadal modulation of global surface temperature by internal climate variability"


2) Many of the climate models have been doing fairly well in their predictions, with their parameters being confirmed. For example:

https://www.skepticalscience.com/climate-models-intermediate.htm
"Evidence for climate change in the satellite cloud record"


3) The IPCC is fairly accurate in their predictions. And when it is wrong, the IPCC tends to under-estimate the effects of global warming, as opposed to exaggerating them, contrary to the claims made by denialists. See the following source on this:

"Climate Change Skepticism and Denial: An Introduction
[...]
A constant refrain coming from the denial campaign is that climate scientists are ‚Äúalarmists‚Äù who exaggerate the degree and threat of global warming to enhance their status, funding, and influence with policy makers. The contribution by William Freudenburg and Violetta Muselli provides an insightful empirical test of this charge and finds it to lack support."

And this is some of the relevant supporting research on this point:

"Reexamining Climate Change Debates: Scientific Disagreement or Scientific Certainty Argumentation Methods (SCAMs)?"
"Global warming estimates, media expectations, and the asymmetry of scientific challenge"
"Climate change prediction: Erring on the side of least drama?"


4) The IPCC first consensus prediction also did rather well, as discussed in the following paper:

"Assessment of the first consensus prediction on climate change"

potholer54 provides a discussion of this at a laymen's level in the following Youtube video:
"Response to "The Global Warming Hoax Lord Monckton & Stefan Molyneux" from 1:07 to 2:55


5) During the 1960s and 1970s, the scientific community predicted imminent global warming, largely due to greenhouse gases. This prediction was borne out. Of course, many AGW denialists lie about this prediction by pretending that there's was a 1970s scientific consensus on an imminent ice age. For more background on this, see the following sources:

"The myth of the 1970s global cooling scientific consensus"
"The idea of anthropogenic global climate change in the 20th century
[...]
In 1979 the U.S. National Academy of Sciences convened a panel, chaired by veteran meteorologist Jule Charney, to look into climate models. They found that any model capable of reproducing something vaguely like the present climate showed a rise in global temperature when its CO2 level was raised. The Charney panel announced they had rather high confidence that as the CO2 level doubled the planet would warm up by about three degrees, plus or minus 50% (i.e., 1.5‚Äì4.5C)."

potholer54 provides a discussion of this at a laymen's level in the following Youtube video:
"3 - Climate Change -- Anatomy of a myth"

text:
The Little Ice Age was a terrible event, which was caused by 4 Grand Solar Minimum (GSM) events: Wolf (1280~1350), Sporer (1450~1550), Maunder (1645~1715) and Dalton (1790~1820).

During the Wolf GSM, 25% of Europe's population was wiped out from: exposure, frozen rivers (stopped transportation), short growing season, huge crop frost loss and famine...

When the Black Death started in 1352 (just 2 years after the Wolf GSM ended), 50% of the remaining population was wiped out...

The next solar cycle starting in 2021 will be as weak as the Dalton GSM, and the one after that from 2032 will be as weak as the Maunder GSM (1645~1715)....

Brrrr....

The Mother of All Ironies is that the tiny amount of CO2 induced warming will help offset SOME of the coming cooling we're about to experience....

text:
Here are the facts, Stephanie.

CO2's forcing effect is only 0.7C per doubling by 2100, which not only isn't "catastrophic", it's beneficial.

We've ENJOYED about 0.81C of beneficial warming recovery since the end of the Little Ice Age in 1850, of which, CO2 contributed just 0.3C of the total.

Since CO2 forcing is logarithmic (each incremental increase has less and less of an effect), we'll enjoy another 0.4C of beneficial CO2 warming recovery by 2100, LESS the coming COOLING from collapsing solar cycles....

Because of the Grand Solar Minimum event we'll face from 2032, which will last 50~100 years, global temps will actually be COLDER than they are now by  2100.....

The tiny amount of CO2 forcing between now and 2100 will help offset some of the terrible cooling that's coming...

Oh, the irony....

text:
+Steve Dekker

"CO2's forcing effect is only 0.7C per doubling by 2100"

You willfully left out sensitivity, which is crucial for determining how much warming would result from doubling of CO2. Sensitivity is a net positive, meaning that the warming would be more than 0.7C.



"which not only isn't "catastrophic", it's beneficial."

"Catastrophic AGW" is a strawman you denialists made up. And you're willfully ignoring the negative effects CO2-driven anthropogenic climate change (ACC) has, such as ocean acidification, increased hurricane intensity, etc.



"Since CO2 forcing is logarithmic (each incremental increase has less and less of an effect),"

Another denialist PRATT. Atmospheric CO2 is currently increasing at a roughly exponential rate. Combined with the logarithmic effect you mentioned (along with other effects, such as decreasing CO2 uptake by sinks such as the ocean), this means the temperature increase roughly linear overtime (in a ~30 year time-scale), as opposed to the decreasing over-time. 



"e'll enjoy another 0.4C of beneficial CO2 warming recovery by 2100, LESS the coming COOLING from collapsing solar cycles...."

Nope. CO2 has been more than offsetting effects from the solar cycle, and will continue to do so for decades and centuries to come.

text:
+James Adams

"Temperature doesn't always correlate with CO2 and using a 40 year timeframe is cherry picking."

First, it isn't cherry-picking, since scientists have a justified reason for looking at this time-frame: this is the time-frame is which warming from anthropogenic greenhouse gases began to swamp the effects of other climate factors. Furthermore, this 40 year window is large enough to get statistically significant trends, unlike many of the smaller time-scales denialists cherrypick. If you want want more background on this, I suggest you read sources like:

"Causes of the Global Warming Observed since the 19th Century"


Second, CO2 temperature correlate quite well in the long-term, on time-scales ranging from hundreds of years to hundreds of millions of years. For example, see the following sources on this correlation:

"CO2 as a primary driver of Phanerozoic climate"
"Temperature change and carbon dioxide change": http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/paleo/globalwarming/temperature-change.html
"CO2-forced climate thresholds during the Phanerozoic"
"Atmospheric carbon dioxide linked with Mesozoic and early Cenozoic climate change"
"Atmospheric CO2 and Climate on Millennial Time Scales During the Last Glacial Period"
"Atmospheric CO2 over the last 1000 years: A high-resolution record from the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide ice core"
"High-resolution carbon dioxide concentration record 650,000‚Äì800,000 years before present"
"Mode change of millennial CO2 variability during the last glacial cycle associated with a bipolar marine carbon seesaw"
"Carbon Isotope Constraints on the Deglacial CO2 Rise from Ice Cores"
"Iron Fertilization of the Subantarctic Ocean During the Last Ice Age"
"Expression of the bipolar see-saw in Antarctic climate records during the last deglaciation"
"Palaeoclimate: Windows on the greenhouse"
"EPICA Dome C record of glacial and interglacial intensities"
"Abrupt change in atmospheric CO2 during the last ice age"
"Synchronous Change of Atmospheric CO2 and Antarctic Temperature During the Last Deglacial Warming"
"Global warming preceded by increasing carbon dioxide concentrations during the last deglaciation"

author: James Adams

text:
+Jame Adams

"Yes, it is if you're making a case that the climate is changing rapidly, that it is going to be a disaster, or that this is something that the Earth hasn't seen before."

It isn't cherry-picking when it's being used to show that climate is changing rapidly. 40 years is long enough to get statistically significant results on climate change. Similar point for showing climate change will be a disaster. Heck, 40 years is longer than the period of time in which we knew that HIV causes AIDS. Yet we still know that HIV has has disastrous effects for humans. Are you going to claim that's cherry-picking?

Also, you're attacking a straw man if you think scientists are trying to claim that climate change something that the Earth hasn't seen before. Large-scale anthropogenic global warming, is something Earth has not seen before. Also, please don't wander into straw men about "catastrophic anthropogenic global warming"...

"Polluted Discourse: Communication and Myths in a Climate of Denial
[...]
Additionally, we find that catastrophic anthropogenic global warming [CAGW] is essentially a term that is never used in the relevant scientific literature by mainstream sources. Furthermore, in the press it appears to be used exclusively by climate contrarians. The term is typically neither defined nor attributed to a mainstream scientific source. Our conclusion is therefore that CAGW is simply a straw man used by climate contrarians to criticize the mainstream position (50)."



"This makes sense only for proving that human action is to blame, not the other claims."

You mean the other claims which were straw men?

"On the definition and identifiability of the alleged ‚Äúhiatus‚Äù in global warming"

Surface warming / ocean warming: 
"Possible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus"

Ocean warming: 
"A review of global ocean temperature observations: Implications for ocean heat content estimates and climate change"
‚ÄúAssessing recent warming using instrumentally homogeneous sea surface temperature records‚Äù 
http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf ["Ocean warming dominates the increase in energy stored in the climate system, accounting for more than 90% of the energy accumulated between 1971 and 2010 (high confidence).[...] On a global scale, the ocean warming is largest near the surface, and the upper 75 m warmed by 0.11 [0.09 to 0.13] ¬∞C per decade over the period 1971 to 2010."]

Energy balance:
"Anthropogenic and natural warming inferred from changes in Earth‚Äôs energy balance"
