This has led to many scientists saying that there's been no "pause" or "hiatus" in global warming:

"Has there been a hiatus?"
"Debunking the climate hiatus"
"Change points of global temperature"



"Before 1850 it was warmer and called the medevil warm period."

Which doesn't change the fact that humans cause most of the global warming that occurred since the mid-20th century:

"Critics have argued that, if temperatures were as warm or warmer than current conditions before the onset of anthropogenic forcing, this would provide evidence that ‚Äúnatural‚Äù fluctuations alone could explain current conditions, since greenhouse gases were only ~280 ppmv during Medieval time (versus 400 ppmv today).
[...]
With the increase in irradiance and a decline in explosive volcanism in the early 20th century, global temperatures might then have returned to an unperturbed level similar to that of the MQP [Medieval Quiet Period], but the rapid rise in anthropogenic greenhouse gases propelled temperatures well beyond that level, as positive anthropogenic radiative forcing overwhelmed natural variability (Myhre et al., 2013)."
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/291523102_The_Medieval_Quiet_Period

"These examples illustrate that different climate changes in the past had different causes. The fact that natural factors caused climate changes in the past does not mean that the current climate change is natural. By analogy, the fact that forest fires have long been caused naturally by lightning strikes does not mean that fires cannot also be caused by a careless camper."
https://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg1/en/faq-6-1.html



"not saying the oceans will become acidic because in fact they are not acidic, they are becoming less basic. The oceans are currently becoming more neutral and projected to not become acidic at all, but we fib and call less basic acidic. We are on course for the oceans to hit ph 7.8 in 100 years, which is still not acidic. Acid is ph 7 or less but we think our viewers are scientifically illiterate idiots and we make it sound like the oceans are becoming acidic when we know they aren't"

"Acidification" does not mean something has become an acid. It means a decrease in pH. For example, blood acidosis involves blood pH dropping below 7.35. So a blood pH of 7.1 counts as acidosis (i.e. acidification), even though the blood pH is above 7 and thus the blood is still basic.

This is covered in junior-high-school level courses. Please do your homework:

"Ocean CO2 uptake, however, is not benign; it causes pH reductions and alterations in fundamental chemical balances that together are commonly referred to as ocean acidification."
http://cmore.soest.hawaii.edu/oceanacidification/documents/doney_annrev_marsci_2009.pdf

"A time-series view of changing ocean chemistry due to ocean uptake of anthropogenic CO2 and ocean acidification"
https://eprints.soton.ac.uk/363195/



"I don't have any specific reasons why it's catastrophic."

Drop the "catastrophic" straw man:

"Polluted Discourse: Communication and Myths in a Climate of Denial
[...]
Additionally, we find that catastrophic anthropogenic global warming [CAGW] is essentially a term that is never used in the relevant scientific literature by mainstream sources. Furthermore, in the press it appears to be used exclusively by climate contrarians. The term is typically neither defined nor attributed to a mainstream scientific source. Our conclusion is therefore that CAGW is simply a straw man used by climate contrarians to criticize the mainstream position (50)."


Anyway, among AAAS (American Academy for the Advancement of Science) scientists with relevant expertise, there's a 95% consensus that climate change was a serious problem and a 93% consensus that recent warming is mostly caused by humans:

"Earth Scientists Views on Climate Change"
http://www.pewinternet.org/2015/07/23/elaborating-on-the-views-of-aaas-scientists-issue-by-issue/

And in another survey, ~87% of climate researchers thought that humans caused (or will cause) most of the recent (or near future) climate change, while ~86% of climate researchers thought that climate change poses a very serious problem and a threat to humanity:

Figures 88 (v043) and 2 (v007) of "The Bray and von Storch 5th International Survey of Climate Scientists 2015/2016"
https://www.hzg.de/imperia/md/content/hzg/zentrale_einrichtungen/bibliothek/berichte/hzg_reports_2016/hzg_report_2016_2.pdf

That consensus arose (in part) because there's abundant scientific research showing that anthropogenic climate change has caused (or will cause):
- increased heat-related mortality (which outweighs any decreases in cold-related mortality)
- increased drought intensity
- economic losses from sea level rise
- increased hurricane intensity
- ocean acidification (which results in things such as loss of marine crops and marine food)
- reduced crop yields
and so on.

Here's some research on this, to get you started:

"Global warming and changes in drought"

text:
This entire video presupposes that the "97% of scientists agree that climate change is real" argument is somehow valid.  Is the climate changing?  Yes, nobody disagrees.  However, there is evidence that the climate is changing at a slower rate today than in the past, destructive climate events are not as prevalent as in the past, and we are gaining ice in the south as fast as we are losing it in the north.  Additionally, only 2% of scientific papers on climate change were in agreement that modern climate change has any relation to atmospheric CO2 concentration.

Yes, the theoretical model for climate change due to the greenhouse effect is respectable, but unfortunately, the theory doesn't fit the data.  This happens all the time in science.  Just look at supersymmetry, which was a beautiful theory that has now recently been found not to be true thanks to the data collected at the LHC.  Theory looked good, had a ton of support from physicists, but they just couldn't get it to explain the data they were getting.  

The problem is that there is already too much money in climate change, so despite that fact that global warming models are not able to explain the data (at least not without unethical scientists manipulating data) we just can't seem to let it go so we can go back to the drawing board and start fresh on the science.  It is no longer a scientific debate at all, even though climate change alarmists will yell "science this! science that!" without a shred of evidence.  

The reason why climate change is such a compelling and money generating narrative is threefold.  The guilty party is EVERYONE and not just some greedy corporation overseas clearcutting a jungle somewhere, the consequences are tantamount to the apocalypse, and it is supported by a scientific theory that normal people will not understand but will buy into because it is "science".  

For comparison, you can go tell a factory dumping waste into a river that they need to clean up or you can tell an agricultural export company to stop clearcutting overseas, but to the general public they are unlikely to become interested and form any kind of widespread movement because it does not directly effect them.  With global warming, we have a scientifically backed hypothesis that not only provided a doomsday scenario, but also provided a responsible party that can be anyone on the face of the planet.  

This is pay dirt, greenies ate it up.  Now they can tell the guy driving a big diesel Ford that he is killing the planet, no matter where he is.  Now the guilty party is you.  And now they can sell you something to help you make up for it.  

Not only that, but the narrative is perfect from a political standpoint, because as soon as you buy into it, the enemy becomes everyone that does not buy into it by default.  You already bought an electric car, you did your part, now that asshole still driving his truck and doesn't believe in climate change is the one killing the planet!  Get that guy!

There is nothing scientific about this video, it just repeats the alarmist political catchphrases that we hear over and over.

text:
"Fact" number 5 is only half true. The stratosphere has shown cooling which is consistent with greenhouse warming, but the troposphere has not warmed enough to be consistent with greenhouse warming. Number 7 is a bit of a red herring. CO2 levels have varied¬† greatly¬†throughout geologic history and there is no strong correlation between CO2 and temperature. Number 8 is really just a statement of faith. CO2 MAY be responsible for some of the warming we have observed, but it is very difficult to demonstrate how much. And .6C warming¬†per century is not 'fast'. It is mild, and can only be beneficial. Number 13 is based on "simulations", you may as well rely on¬†your horoscope. Climate models have failed time and again, and to presume that¬†they have¬†predictive value is just hubris.¬†Number 16, the 'warmest in 8 centuries'?? So what caused the equal or greater¬†warming 8 centuries ago? He¬†has to answer that question before he can¬†blame CO2 for the current warming.
Number 21 is a really bad one. There is not one data set that I have seen that puts Ocean PH at 9.0 in 1990. He has to be kidding. And then to say that Ocean PH has changed by .92 during the last 25 years is ludicrous. Most data sets suggest that Ocean PH has gone from around 8.3 to 8.1 over the last 200 years, and that¬†PH varies greatly in the oceans over time. Number 22 about 'animals with calcium shells' is pure¬†speculation. There has been no observable negative effect of rising PH on ocean¬†crustaceans.
[To be continued]

text:
So our friend here Joe Hanson is a Phd in Biology. If that is so, then¬†he¬†has a little explaining to do. Firstly he starts out by making a big claim that "climate change is happening, and we are causing it". Well the climate may be changing, but there is no definitive evidence that 'we are causing it'.¬†Even the IPCC¬†does not make such an absolute statement. He has started out with propaganda, now lets see if he gets any better with his list of "facts".¬†
Ok, his first 3 points are science based and acceptable. It is number 4 where the trouble starts. When he talks about 'solar activity' he means sunspots. But why use data only from 1970¬†?? That is only 3 solar cycles. Why not use¬†more of the record? The¬†reason is¬†because using¬†other parts of the record disproves his assertion. Using the whole solar record DOES¬†show a general correlation between sunspots and temperature. Secondly he claims that the temperature rose fastest during the period of the graph. That is simply not true. The rate of temp rise from 1910 to 1940 was the same as for 1975 to 1998, and it was roughly the same amount. Fail.
[To be continued]

text:
His stupid "pH9.0 in 1990" is so devoid of reality, it just shows this video is bogus government propaganda for idiots...

Ocean pH changes on a daily basis.  If anything, ocean pH is too alkaline!  

In ancient oceans, there were 385,000 BILLION tons (currently 38,500 billion tons) of carbon dissolved in the oceans as carbonic acid, and oceans were STILL alkaline at around pH 7.6 and corals/sea life THRIVED!  Current carbon in oceans is around 38,500 billion tons...

Man's teeny tiny 700 billion tons of carbon added to the oceans since 1750 has had almost NO effect on ocean pH ( just 1.8% of the total) with a portion of it already fixed as CaCO3 in corals, dead plankton and dead shellfish..

Oceans are buffered solutions held in an alkaline inducing basaltic rock container....

¬†@Leonardo Cisija¬† Actually, if you look back into the history of the Earth, you'll see the climate has changed MUCH faster than what it is now. For example: the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs. Within a matter of YEARS (and possibly sooner) after the initial impact, the climate went from being steamy and tropical to frozen and completely desolate. Secondly, as mentioned in one of my previous posts, when the supervolcano Toba erupted like sixty or seventy thousand years ago, it plunged the world into a multi-decade long volcanic winter, only a few years after the eruption. The human race as a whole was almost completely wiped out. Even as recently as the early nineteenth century, Tambora erupted in Indonesia and caused several years of unusually long and harsh winters. It was responsible for causing the "Year Without a Summer" in the United States, which brought about massive crop failure and widespread starvation. Hell, there was even measurable amounts of SNOW on the ground in New England in JUNE or JULY, directly the result of Tambora.

Of course it's going to do bad things when an abrupt climate shift occurs (and by bad I generally mean cataclysmic), but that's normal. To suggest that humans have changed the climate faster than anything in history is a ridiculous statement, simply because it takes A LOT to make it change very abruptly. CO2 won't do it. Recorded history of the climate with modern instruments doesn't go back very far (only about 150 years or so), nor does it say much about our future.

text:
¬†@Leonardo Cisija¬†

They'd probably love being in an even warmer and steamier climate. Just because the world gets warmer doesn't mean it'll be consumed by a planet sized desert, and the reason for that is because we have vast quantities of water all over the planet. In order to boil all the water off of the surface, you would need the planet to be hundreds of degrees hotter so that it couldn't condense back into a liquid and rain down to the surface. Such massive amounts of warming has practically no chance of occurring for the next several billion years until the sun finally dies.

There may be more extreme storms in a warmer world, but there are likely just as many of them in an equally colder one. This probably isn't a very good example, but look at the outer planets of our solar system. They're absolutely frigid, but they produce extremely powerful storms in their atmospheres. Neptune's atmosphere actually produces sustained winds of like 1,000 mph, and it's the planet farthest from the sun. So warmer doesn't necessarily mean more powerful.

As for the cooling bit, I said nothing about there being cooling at the moment. I merely added onto another person's comment by saying a colder world would hold much more disastrous effects on society than a warmer world (longer and fiercer winters, shorter growing seasons, lower food supplies, higher food prices because of the lower supplies, mass starvation, etc.)

By the way, I'm pretty sure a solar minimum would cause significant global cooling because of there being less solar radiation being generated by the sun. CO2 has NOTHING to do with changing the climate. At all.

text:
¬†@Steve Dekker¬† 
1. DDT is banned internationally for use in agriculture, but its use in malaria control remains
permitted under the regulations of the Stockholm Convention. The production
of DDT and its use in malaria control have never been discontinued.

2. While DDT is cheaper than most other insecticides, cost of manufacture has risen
in proportion to that of petroleum, the major required raw material. Moreover, like
other insecticides, DDT selects for resistance in the targeted insect vectors. Rising
cost and widespread resistance, not regulation, are the key reasons for the limited
and declining worldwide use of DDT.

3. Most malaria fatalities occur in Africa. On this continent, no comprehensive effort has
ever been made to control or eradicate malaria; instead, all such projects occurred
only on a local or regional scale, and many were abandoned after only a few years.

4. In the most severely affected parts of the world, only a small fraction of malaria cases
are actually seen by health care workers or recorded by health authorities. Regardless
of the tools employed, effective malaria control is impossible with such inadequate
levels of organization and preparedness.

taken from this well-sourced and well-written treatise: http://www.science.uwaterloo.ca/~mpalmer/stuff/DDT-myth.pdf

the human fingerprint on recent warming is very clear. co2 and temperature have been well-correlated for a very long time. here's just 800,000 years using ice cores: https://www.desmos.com/calculator/3scwxkg4t6

this correlation is backed-up by, and given a causal relationship by, the greenhouse effect, which has been studied since the early 1800s and accepted since the late 1800s.

the human fingerprint comes in when you analyze the isotope concentration of atmospheric co2. the carbon we emit is a distinctly different isotope than what is naturally part of the carbon cycle (carbon 12 vs carbon 13). we see an increase in the 12c:13c ratio that ties the recent co2 increase directly to humans.

but before i get into that, you probably want some more proof that no one "cooks the books", since once that door of doubt is open it's hard to close.

for recent warming, here's a comparison of land-ocean temperature indices from 4 independent organizations: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Ywx9fDLyJrCZfAjyfJjgSQq1YFjmkxbKuBVEMXEJAsk

also, an analysis of noaa's normilzation and homogenization procedure showing it makes the data MORE accurate: http://www-users.york.ac.uk/~kdc3/papers/crn2016/CRN%20Paper%20Revised.pdf

Mann, who published the original "hockey-stick", was constantly under fire when an analysis revealed the statistical method he used may have helped erase previous warming. he rebutted with a compilation of multiple graphs showing the hockey stick result using different sources, stastistical methods, and proxies. see page 5 here: http://www.pnas.org/content/105/36/13252.full.pdf

notice that a few of the graphs show a very slow "medieval warm period". notice also how it does not compare with the recent warming.

the graph i used was made from ice core data that also produced a carbon proxy, which is why i picked it. you can find more data to use for yourself at the world's largest climate databse: https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/data-access

i'll stop here for now so you can ask questions and make rebuttals.

text: +Mellanie Mellbourne, "disturbing" that the planet is warming a tiny amount in an ongoing Ice Age? Our Modern Warm Period is wholly natural, showing up right on schedule as one of the Holocene's 10 major warm periods on a 1,000-year cycle. Ironically, it is the coldest of the Holocene's 10, and part of a 3,000-year massive cooling trend reminiscent of the tail end of the Eemian interglacial of the current Ice Age -- just before Alaska got hit with 90,000 years of brutal cold and zero summers. Now, that's truly disturbing and potentially important.

If people won't listen to politicians or scientists...maybe they'll listen to their dinner tables.  Hopefully not too late.

text:
Looks like the greenhouse effect is an adiabatic (pressure-induced) process and therefore doesn't depend on the composition of the atmosphere. The CO2 concentration in the atmosphere is thus irrelevant to the greenhouse effect, because its concentration in the atmosphere doesn't affect the intensity of such effect. Here's the DOI code of such scientific paper: 10.4172/2573-458X.1000112
In a nutshell: it's not that global warming doesn't exist, but stating that it's caused (or mostly caused) by anthropic (i.e. human emissions of) CO2 is the actual flaw.
Also, Nature is responsible for about 200 billion tons of CO2 that circulate in the atmosphere every year, while humans are responsible for only 9 billion tons of CO2 in the same period.

Man cannot stop the climate from changing.... It's been changing for 4.5 billion...

Man's CO2 emissions have PERHAPS added 0.2C of beneficial warming recovery since the end of the LITTLE ICE AGE in 1850, and because CO2 forcing is logarithmic (each incremental increase has less and less of an effect) we'll enjoy another 0.3C of beneficial CO2 induced warming between now and 2100, which is a good thing....

Unfortunately, the sun is approaching a Grand Solar Minimum event from 2035 and will last 50~100 years, which will cause significant global cooling. 

The stupid CAGW hypothesis projected 3C~5C of catastrophic manmade global warming by 2100....  Global temps will actually be COOLER by 2100 than they are now....

Grow up and stop believing government propaganda.... CAGW is ALREADY a disconfirmed hypothesis given the HUGE disparity and duration of disparity between CAGW projections vs. reality:

The HUGE disparity only increases quickly in the years and decades ahead.

text: +Paul Stringini   The 10% energy transfer is not specific to vegetarian diets, it's a facet of ecological trophic levels ‚Äì all levels. For example, only 10% of all energy in the fish that eagles consume ends up stored in the eagles' flesh. And as far as I've read, there's nothing inherently harmful about digesting a more plant-based diet. After all, we did evolve from hunter _gatherers_, and the hunting was much less often than the gathering. If anything, the amount of meat we Americans eat, especially red meat, is less than healthy.

Iam neither a vegan nor vegetarian, I eat meat and I will continue to do so, but the b12 argument is bullshit. Animals raised in the usual mass production we have dont get b12 anymore, because it comes from natural soils. These animals get fed with B12 pills, so you dont have too. Its a less known fact though.

Iam eating meat for health issues btw. ANd yes for taste and all the other stuff. My body stores energy very very badly, so I have to consume at least 3k calories every day to hold a normal weight. And iam of average size. This is not only very time consuming and exhausting, it can also be expensive if you dont want to consume 3 liters of milk or coke a day. When I measure price/calories/taste/health/time  a meat/wheatproduct combination is just the best option.

text:
Please keep in mind that this fellow is WRONG and IGNORES a LOT of history.

Bill Gray, who died on April 16, 2016, was a world renowned expert on hurricanes.  From an article on his work, "In recent years, he had been known for his challenges to the science behind human-caused climate change. In March 2015 he wrote a column in the Coloradoan criticizing a Fort Collins plan to reduce its use of fossil fuels.

‚ÄúHe has always been at the forefront of a being a free-thinker,‚Äù Landsea said. ‚ÄúAll of us as scientists need to be skeptical. If we are not being skeptical, we are not being scientists.‚Äù

He also had a sense of humor. Every year on Aug. 20, Gray went into the offices where the Colorado State hurricane researchers worked, rang a bell and announced: ‚ÄúI have been appointed by Chicken Little to inform you that the heart of the hurricane season has begun.‚Äù

Bill Gray would fall into that category of people who just don't know better.

History:

In the 1450's French nobility were passing laws against the importation of British wine because it was hurting the French wine industry.  You did not know that the British produced wine?  They haven't because they are now 200 miles too far north to produce grapes in Britain.  Not the case some 600+ years ago.

The Weather Channel USED to run a clip of a older bearded man wearing a hat exclaiming, "We haven't seen conditions like this in Alaska for 6000 years!"  I am a native English speaker.  This sentence tells me that we HAVE seen conditions like this in Alaska approximately 4000 BC.  Now, I did attend public school until my college days, but I don't think that my history classes were all that wrong.  In 4000 BC we have no evidence of a large installed industrial base.  Whatever caused the conditions in Alaska in 4000 BC, it is highly doubtful that it was caused by human activity.

With the censorship in science, Bill Gray, despite his towering academic stature did not get invited to a lot of speaking engagements.  Anybody out there applying for grants to investigate any other POSSIBLE cause for temperature increase BESIDES CO2?  If they are, it is highly unlikely that the grant requests will be awarded.

Historically human populations have THRIVED during periods of warmer temperatures and suffered during periods of lower temperatures.  The opposite might be true for polar bears, but hey, I am not a polar bear.  Sucks to be them!

Please feel free to challenge this fellow on all the bad science he is spouting!

World Renowned hurricane researcher William M. Gray- here is a link to his biography along with his academic creditials:

British wine industry.  There are about 2000 acres of commercial grape production in England for wine production.  Because of weather they produce 4 crops in 10 years on average because of weather.  Here is the link to a good site: http://www.english-wine.com/history.html  You will notice that the grape juice used in British wine is almost all imported.

Weather Channel promo.  No I don't know the man's credentials, but I raised the question as tto why the Weather Channel was constantly rrunning this nearly hysterical person proclaiming "We haven't see conditions like this in Alaska for 6000 years."  This is part of the propaganda machine running in the United States that pushes climate change on a naive public.

Historically humans have thrived in periods of warmer climates.  Look at European history around 1300 called the Little Ice Age.  Crop production was down and people were cold.  

Climate Change DOES occur and has occurred through out Earth's history.  During the ice age we had glaciers in North America up to about 10,000 BCE.  Previously the planet was pretty tropical world wide.  Are we returning to the norm?  During the Carboniferous period http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/carboniferous/carboniferous.php
some studies suggest that the oxygen concentration in the atmosphere was as high as 40%.

During either of these periods not a single steel mill, coal fired power plant, or gasoline powered automobile existed on the planet.  So what caused climate change back them.

text:
+Kevin  I know it's 5 months since, but here goes.  You said " does it really hurt to move to renewables?"  Well, yes it does.  Fear drives people away from nuclear energy, the only one that can replace ffs, and all the others I can think of are either very far from engineering proof (tide, geothermal) or intermittent (solar, wind), have transmission limits (solar), are criticized by many of the WWF group who promote the fear of AGW (mills kill birds), and of course, burning trees just complicates everything (CO2?, replacement v rate of removal).  So it really hurts to move to renewables.  

Not to end on a negative note, I think engineers should really be engaged in developing safe nuclear power.  We could start by buying design plans from France and getting to work solving the storage and use of hydrogen for transportation.  Should be able to get the work done before we use up oil/gas, but education will be critical (and proven safety has to be behind that: I've had about all the fake science for one generation).  What do you think?  Can it be solved and education started?

text:
+Steve C D    No the industrial sector in Germany is doing fine - thank you very much. (As I know).  The energy prices in Germany (and Japan) have always been much hihger than in the US. Did it keep these countries from being successful - for instance in car manufacturing ?  The "Energiewende"  (losely translated New Energy) is a double-edged sword. A conservative spineless, big-biz serving, long-term  chancellor (Angela Merkel) dismantled the plan of the former government for an exit from nuclear power  plants ( 30 years or older). Instead she arranged for longer operation times with not too much investment. A gift to the industry.
¬†And then came Fukushima and very negative polling. So she had a "change of heart" and went green and  arranged an ABRUPT "exit from the exit". You can see that her heart is not really into renewables in the haphazard and erratic way these policies were enacted.

The thing about renewables (mostly PV,  wind) is: production is already cheap and will get even cheaper. Storage is the unresolved technical challenge. And good storage/battery/artificial fuel solutions would RADICALLY CHANGE  the nature of the energy sector and also the influence of politics in that sector. Green power would lead to decentral, maybe citizen-operated units. At least "small is beautiful" would be possible. The old energy sector needed big players, large and centralized plants and power lines through the country.

There is a political aspect: large companies especially when they are natural monopolists,  usually offer a lot of cushy jobs for ex politicians. Small decentral power plants have no need to "bribe" politicians (revolving door, cushy jobs, in the US campaign donations) and they would not have the financial means for it either. 

Meaning, that gravy train for CEOs, board members and politicians would stop with New Energy.

Germany is known to excel in complex technology, including cars. They prefer the Diesel motor, the most complicated motor of all - no one can compete with German technology here, the Chinese certainly not. The Japanese would be the only challenger but because of the coincidences of history they never got as much invested in that technology as the Germans. 

An ELECTRIC CAR is much easier and cheaper to build, more durable and easier to maintain - think  brakes, clutches, motor. Countries with less engeneering brainpower could start building electric cars in good quality. The natural advantage of Germany (high techology) would be obsolete. It goes without saying that the German automotive industry is VERY cosy with politics (gravy train, revolving door). And since Germany is such an important country in the EU, their interests are also well represented in Brussels. 
That was the incubator for VW's Diesel Gate. The pressure was on to come up with  more and more  "clean" and "energy-efficient" Diesel motors, they were operating at the limits of the technology (it also shows in failures rates, a German Diesel motor used to be a long running, very robust device, now they often fail after only 5 years regular use).

A leader with a vision would have disregarded all these petty considerations. She would have put the long-term success of Germany first, she would have studied the inevitable changes, and would have come up with a formidable research program for storage solutions - in the spirit of the bold US programs like the Race to the moon or the Manhattan project. That would be the new export hit of the German industry compensating job losses in other industries and empowering the rural areas.
Not.
Merkel instead did "same old same old". She always, always serves big biz and special interests first, if then there are some resources  left, she will throw  some bones to all other businesses and to affluent conservative voting citizens.

So they came up with an investment plan that favours big investors for solar and even more for wind farms. (And to a lesser degree for citizens).
Wind energy is harvested in the north, the electricity is needed more in the south, they are now building the necessary new power lines to transport that electricity. Remember no good storage solutions yet.

The financial burden for that systemic change was slapped onto the consumers NOT the industry or medium sized enterprises. Not that it would be that bad IF the whole thing woud make sense for the future of the country. 
It is a present to the industry with a big green bow. And she could avoid the criticism for the nuclear fission technology.

With the money they used for that plan (courtesey of consumers!) they could have done much better things. She is not into renewables - but if she thinks she needs them to ensure reelections and good polling she will use them - but not for the greater good of the country or with a long term vision. No, it must be an immediate advantage for HER buddies - big biz, big banks.

There is a reason that wind was favoured as well. Solar (PV) panels are produced in China. The German producers could not compete with cheap Chinese labour anymore (I would have demanded the use of German manufactured goods for the subsidized projects - not doubt some "free" trade agreement - which Merkel also likes very much - does not allow such provisions). 

Siemens (German big player) had invested in a wind tower manufacturing plant in Denmark and there are other companies in Germany as well. So wind it was.

It just needs avoiding that over the top profits for a few suck the life blood out of the money cycle. That can be fixed with good wages and high(er) taxes. Worked like a charm from 1945 - the 1970s.

I guess we will need to have more durable goods, less throw away stuff, recycle more, find compostable substitutes for plastic, we would pay more for food and energy, and much less for housing. Big ag is very energy intense and not good for the soil which is a very valuable (but currently underrated resources. So less big AG, and more people working in smaller farming. And we will use more robots and work shorter. Maybe more costs for healthcare (new technologies and higher life expectancy). Well the US pays + 9k per capita vs. on average 5 - 5,5 k for healthcare in the rich European countries, so the US could use an increase in efficiency to absorb increasing costs.

text:
LPS Kawaii panda
Not exactly sure what you mean. but I'm fairly certain that's not how economics works. We are currently producing renewable energy sources like solar panels and wind turbines at the most economically efficient rate when we take into account the government subsidies for them. If the demand curve for these generators increases, the market price and quantity traded will increase. When new technology is created that allows us to make these devices at a lower cost is invented, the supply curve increases, the market price will decrease and the quantity traded will increase. But that's basic economics. We are devoting plenty of research into such new technologies, and devoting too much more may harm us in other sectors.

As far as Hydro goes. we've basically tapped every hydroelectric source possible. And geothermal while promising, has its own challenges. Hypothetically Yellowstone wold be ideal since the entire park is sitting on an active volcano with dozens of geysers that could be capped with turbines, but since it's a national park, that might be difficult.

text: For the time being, yes, the best thing you can do for the environment, for now, is to use less energy, less water, and recycle what you can. We've been saying this since before you were born and we will continue saying it until we either have extremely cheap renewables or sustainable fusion. Incidentally, we already have the technology to pull CO2 from the atmosphere, but while our main source of energy is hydrocarbons, it will just put more CO2 into the air than we capture to do it. When we have somethign like fusion how ever we will basically be able to use gasoline and other fuels like a battery, which will more or less eliminate any need for electric cars, since fuel is a more stable energy storage medium than any form of battery.

I feel that some dude, hired NOT by the government but rather oil companies, who literally tries to convince as many people that global warming is a hoax is gonna respond to this comment and say that I'm an idiot to try to make me feel guilty and left out so I switch sides without even reading my whole comment.

Just try to help the environment in indirect ways for now, like Seth Apex said. More trees and such = less CO2. You can't help solve the problem in a direct way (unless you have a lot of power, of any kind), so don't try.

The question isn't whether global warming exists or not: It does. It's not if there's a solution to the problem: There is. The question is what the best solution is, and if that solution is worth it: It probably is, but we're not 100% sure about it.

text:
Kevin, I would like to address the question "Does it really hurt to move towards renewables?". To begin heading toward renewables is not in itself a bad idea. It would be great for some young entrepreneur to discover a way to provide the world the energy it needs to continue its population and economic growth through the use of renewable resources. 


The problem arises when governments begin to enact regulations that stifle the current means of energy production in an effort to artificially enhance the competitiveness of renewables before the technology exists to truly provide a direct replacement.   


The reason is simple. All of the advancements in technology that the human race now have to thank for elevating the standard of living have a direct link back to cheap and plentiful energy. Humans have been faced with many challenges in the past that have all been rectified by the technological boom we have seen since the industrial revolution (caused by the discovery of cheap and plentiful energy). I might suggest that the answer to successfully overcome the problem of climate change is not to stifle the means of energy production, in turn, slowing the rate of technological advancement needed to combat the "impending doom" of climate change. Instead, we should do everything in our power to exploit the resources currently available; fossil fuels, to the provide the young entrepreneurs out there with the lowest cost materials and cutting edge advancement available so that they may create something with a higher energy density than fossil fuels.


In short, allow the markets to do what they do best. Reward those with the greatest minds to be handsomely rewarded by being better than the competition. Don't try to hold back the current competition so others can play.

text: We can't agree that we're damaging the environment because that statement is largely subjective. Is the climate changing? Yes. Are we emitting gasses that expedite climate change? Yes. Is this bad? Possibly. We know that several thousand years ago the Sahara was a jungle. Why isn't it? Global weather changes. We also know that 65 million years ago California was a tropical forest/swamp. The climate does and always has changed. The main thing to consider is that ocean levels will rise as temperatures increase and the majority of the population is costal. That is bad. So we simply pick up and move. With current statistics I understand that converting our consumption of fossil fuels will only mitigate the time frame for which this occurs. In order to reverse what we've done we need to replant millions of acres of forest and grassland and reduce the rate at which gasses enter the atmosphere and oceans. It's sad to me that people assume this is a One way road. To know climate change is real is synonymous with thinking the Paris Climate Accords were a good idea, assuming we can and should try to reduce our carbon footprints, and that somehow we can accurately predict what the changes will look like. Personally I know the American corn belt is the biggest carbon eater globally. Better than the Amazon Rainforest and better than he swaths of plankton and algae in our oceans. But it also needs nitrogen in its soil and so is demanding. What we really need is to replant forests and work on giving land back to wildlife and wilderness. Without large amounts of plant life we cannot change the climate effectively. So this is a nonissue because it's not economical to give land back to Mother Nature. The real question facing us is how to make it economical, niece people realize they can make money reversing clumsy change they will believe the science. I for one think we should let it run its course, after all it's not necessarily bad especially when you consider Earth was at the period of most biodiversity that we can measure and as such it's likely to reduce certain populations and favor others as environments change. We as humans have the unique ability to witness, know beforehand, react, and successfully understand, all of the changes we face and as such will survive whether we do anything to stop climate change or not. Up to you really, I just don't have enough information to suggest we need to stop the climate change or enough evidence to say climate change is bad. I do still stand by its existence.
author: Davis Brethen

text:
+Davis Brethen, some good points. CO2 is near the lowest it has been in the history of planet Earth. Zero CO2 means the death of all plant and animal life. 150 ppm CO2 means the beginning of Mass Extinction for all C3 species (85% of all plant species, and nearly 99% of all food crop species). 400 ppm = today. 800 ppm was the approximate threshold which led to the evolution of C4 species to cope with CO2 starvation. 1,200 ppm CO2 is the level at which wheat and rice yield +30 to +40% over 400 ppm. Somewhere between 1,600 to 2,300 ppm is the average CO2 level for the last 600 Myrs. At 2,000 ppm, wheat and rice yields are still +5 to +15% above those at 400 ppm. 20,000 ppm produces yields that are roughly equivalent to those at 400 ppm, and it's  NASA's maximum recommended CO2 level for astronauts for up to 1 hour.

Climate change is the only constant in climate. It has changed for nearly 4.5 billion years. This notion of stopping climate change is nonsense. It's like saying -- stop the wind or stop the ocean currents.
author: Rod Martin, Jr.

text:
The notion that climate change might be stopped is nonsense. 
The notion that we might reduce human contribution to climate change is not. 
Only my dear Aunt Sally, I suspect, would advocate for the former.
author: Corey

text:
+Corey S, either your Aunt Sally is one powerful lady (rich, perhaps?) or your statement is incorrect, because the meme "stop climate change" has been said by major news organizations (TV, print, online) and hundreds of people I've read online making comments, writing blogs, etc. The rest of your comment makes perfect sense, but the implication is questionable -- that "climate change" is bad. Everything the mainstream media says about "climate change" shows that it's bad; nothing ever good. If there were a good climate to have, we'd likely have to change to get there. And that makes the entire "climate change" is bad idea illogical and anti-science.

What is the best climate for humanity and life? I'm sure there would be a great deal of disagreement on this.

Before "climate change" became the big topic, it was "global warming is bad." But is it really? We live in an ongoing Ice Age, our Holocene is already overdue to end, based on average interglacial durations (Ref: W.S. Broecker, 1998). And history shows that civilizations have prospered during far warmer climates, but fell apart with famine during cooler climates.

CO2 is a vital gas of life. We've been in short supply for millions of years. Nature is slowly sequestering CO2 toward Total Extinction. But humans interrupted that death spiral by burning fossil fuels.

150 ppm -- CO2 Mass Extinction
400 ppm -- CO2 today
800 ppm -- CO2 starvation trigger which forced plants worldwide to evolve C4 species
1,600 ppm -- CO2 Normal
4,000 ppm -- CO2 abundance
8,000 ppm -- Rich CO2 levels, the kind which allowed so many plants that it gave us our fossil fuels
10,000 ppm -- Nominal CO2 on naval submarines
20,000 ppm -- Maximum recommended CO2 on NASA spacecraft
210,000 ppm -- The level of oxygen in our atmosphere, and possibly the level of CO2 when Earth had zero oxygen (before photosynthesis).
965,000 ppm -- CO2 level on Venus (for those who think Earth might ever be like our sister planet); but add to this the fact that its atmosphere is 92x thicker than that on Earth. This gives Venus more than 220,000 times as much CO2 in its atmosphere as we have in ours.
author: Rod Martin, Jr.

text:
I was being glib. 'Aunt Sally' is another name for a straw man. 

To claim that we should stop the climate from changing one bit is indeed ludicrous. To claim that when people say/write 'stop climate change' they mean precisely that, however, misrepresents the issue in a way that at best makes a joke of the view you're advancing, and at worst misleads others. 

As I've gathered, it seems that the issue is not that warming is itself bad- any geologist might happily point out that warming is not of itself a bad thing or a good thing. The issue is that we are having a clear and unprecedented impact on the rate of climate change, and that hastening toward a climate more like the one seen in the Eocene would cause unnecessary (or at the very least deferrable) world-wide suffering.
author: Corey

text:
Corey, thanks, but unprecedented change? The amount of warming during the 20th century was 0.9C of warming. The rate of warming 11,600 years ago was more like 100C of warming per century (based on +10C in a decade). That's more than 100x the modern rate of warming. So, unprecedented it is not.

We stand now at the coldest of the 10 major warm periods of the Holocene. The 2nd coldest was the Medieval Warm Period, and it was warm enough for the Vikings to grow crops in Greenland for hundreds of years. So far, it has not yet warmed to that point during our "scary" Modern Warm Period.

No correlation; no possibility for causation. There are feedback loops in nature, but CO2 is such a tiny one (if it exists at all), it'd be like spitting in the ocean and expecting to measure sea level rise from your added saliva.

Facts, not fantasy!

text:
¬†@Goldsword Animations¬† Yes, same with CO2. The amount of warming from this one trace (tiny, tiny amount) is so small that it cannot be measured! And the amount of water vapor released from that immeasurable CO2 warming is vanishingly small -- perhaps enough to fill a bucket, but for a planet the size of Earth, that's nothing. So, no. I did address your point. Nothing + nothing = nothing!

When CO2 can continue going up, as it has on numerous occasions for hundreds of years, while temperatures go down, it shows that CO2 is a very, very weak green house gas. When you look at Al Gore's graph in his "inconveniently wrong" film, you see a monstrous spike in CO2, but we've had no commensurate spike in temperature. Compared to the ups and downs over the last 650,000 years, the spike in temperature should've been +10C of warming, but we've barely had +1C, and that meager warming had already been planned by nature as part of the 1,000-year cycle of warming periods throughout the Holocene interglacial of the current Ice Age.

Now, do you see why CO2 is a non-issue with warming?

But worse for the warming alarmist side of the argument (and I used to be on that side), global warming is far, far, far better than global cooling at our current stage near the bottom of Earth's livable temperature range. History proves this, if you care to study it.

author: Mr Phwibbs

text:
¬†@Mr Phwibbs¬† From our current levels of CO2 and warmth, massive increases in both are indicated as desirable. Let me take your points, one-by-one.

RATE OF INCREASE
You said, "The rate at which CO2 and temperature has been rising has never been seen before in earths climate..."

For CO2, and the planet as a whole, you would be right. To my knowledge, at no time in Earth's long history has CO2 jumped as quickly as it has in the last 70 years. But anyone entering a submarine or a crowded meeting hall after an hour or two of conference, will have experienced extreme rates of increase that make the worldwide increase look like a turtle swimming through cold molasses. One video I watched recently of climate skeptics included a crusty old curmudgeon on-stage holding a CO2 meter registering 8900 ppm. Anyone walking into that room would go from 400 to 8900 in the time it takes to gulp in another breath of air. No ill effects!

Farmers are forever filling their greenhouses with CO2 to make their plants grow bigger and produce plumper. That's increases to 1200 ppm within minutes or hours, instead of centuries. Only positive effects.

Warming rates have been far faster in the past with wonderful effects, overall. Not all locations experience the same benefits, but more locations have benefits than do not.

20th century Warming: +0.9C/century (21st century has slowed down from this rate, almost flat)

1817-1818 AD Warming: +50C/century for 2 years after 1816 year without a summer (approximation)

9620-9610 BC Warming: +100C/century for 10 years after end of Younger Dryas "Big Freeze" (est. by some scientists)

Read my book Climate Basics: Nothing to Fear for more information and sources.

DESERTS AND DROUGHTS
You said, "Although it isn't wrong that plants will benefit from more CO2, they won't from desertification and droughts caused by global warming."

On this point, you have things completely backwards. You have to ask yourself how land ever gets water in the first place. If you cool the planet, you get far, far less rain -- and more deserts! In fact, during the last glacial period, as much as 70% of all land surface was either desert or semi-desert. All that ice covering North America and Europe was desert! If you study paleoclimate, you find in the literature (even in rinkydink Wikipedia) references to massive amounts of drying out or desiccation during the 50 million years of cooling to our current Ice Age. Earth was far, far wetter during the Eocene -- a veritable garden from pole to pole, and deserts far smaller, but also drier in their interiors.

Read my book Deserts & Droughts for more information and sources.

OCEAN ACIDIFICATION
Did you know that some unscrupulous scientists used a different acid to determine that pH changes from CO2 would destroy life in the oceans? Did you know that CO2 does not produce the same effects?

Did you know that shellfish shells are not in any danger from an alkaline ocean or even a neutral ocean? And did you know that when shellfish first evolved those wonderful shells that atmospheric CO2 was in the range of 4,500-7,000 ppm?

Read my book Red Line - Carbon Dioxide for more information and sources.

NASA SMAC and CO2
You must have looked at an earlier version. NASA SMAC vol.5, p.119, "RATIONALE FOR AN INCREASE IN THE 1-HOUR SMAC," says, "Mild headache and hyperventilation would be easily tolerated for 1 h, thus the 1-h SMAC is increased to 2%." And 2% = 20,000 ppm.

If you don't already know, NASA is, of necessity, a conservative government agency. People there do not like to take big risks. So, the spacecraft maximums are very conservative and the difficulties are minor.

If you look at their table 7.2, you'll see that other agencies are even more lenient than NASA. The most lenient is NIOSH (IDLH) with a brief maximum of 40,000 ppm. National Research Council (NRC) allows 25,000 for up to 24 hours!

One plant study showed that rice and wheat grown under 20,000 ppm CO2 had roughly the same produce output as 400 ppm. So, it's relatively safe for crops, too. It would take us a very long time to reach that level.

GLOBAL WARMING
Your fear of warming is unwarranted. Climate changes all the time. We've had far faster warming in the past, as I've already discussed. And life does not wilt from even 11C of warming in a 24-hour period. That much happens in mild Los Angeles every day. The feard +3C is nothing by comparison. That leaves ecological changes to contend with. Every species on Earth can quickly adapt to far greater warming in minutes!!! I dare you to find any species that dies from warming of +5C from the daily ambient minimum.

There are always changes to the environment. If we get +3C over the next century, a turtle could walk the 200 km to an equivalent temperature. That would take a few weeks, and the turtle could relax the remainder of that "scary" century, waiting for climate change to catch up with it.

Read my book Thermophobia: Shining a Light on Global Warming for more information and sources.

Hope this helps.

You do understand that that would mean AGW theory was disproved.

I'd like to tell you that that has already happened, but the AGW folks have a moving target, a slick process by which they ad hoc adjust something so predictions (actually retrospective, and not proper prospective) become closer and closer to actual temperatures for a time, and they say this is simply how science works...trial, error, adjustment, and so on, but all their work is based on a computer program, a set of algorithms (do this, then do that, then do another thing) that is like a black box that they ask us to "believe in".  Sorry, GIGO is and always will be true.

A famous map coloring problem called the 4-color hypothesis has resisted all attempts to solve by reasoning, but was solved about 20 years ago, by having a computer create all possible planar maps and try to color all of them with 4 colors.  They succeeded, though some purists were dissatisfied with the Monte Carlo method...the point being that any attempt to do the same thing with climate would require more time in calculation than the change in the climate itself would take, and any less time would involve assumptions that have to be made by individuals, many of whom have shown a vested interest.

text:
In¬†my opinion most of these presentations are lacking on the most important point, and this one is no exception.

I have never doubted the reality of global warming; scientific evidence for it has been around for decades.¬† It's even conceivable that human activity is having some measurable effect on the¬† process, especially in recent centuries.

What is /not/ clear is whether human activity is the /cause/ of the current warming trend.¬† In this presentation that question is only addressed once:¬† with the carbon isotopes.¬†Indeed, there is much scientific evidence /against/ the hypothesis that human beings have caused the current warming trend.¬† Long term temperature date (e.g., the Vostok ice cores) show that over the last half-million years there have been repeated cooling and warming periods recurring in roughly 80,000 year cycles.¬† This data also indicates that at this point in time we should expect to be nearing the high point of the warming portion of one of these cycles.¬†¬†¬† There was no human industrial activity driving the three or four documented cycles prior to the current one.¬† It is clear, therefore, that there have been other causative factors responsible for global warming in the past.¬† 

Even the warming current trend, which would have began about 75,000 years ago, can hardly have been initiated by human activity.¬† At that point in time the entire human population was fewer than a hundred thousand, and most of it had yet to move out of the trees and into caves.

There is also data showing that atmospheric CO2 increased do not /precede/ warming trends, but /lag/ behind them by roughly 800 years.¬† This also suggests a different driving mechanism for warming cycles other than the CO2 driver proposed by the anthropogenic warming hypothesis.

You waste too much time arguing that there IS warming -- anyone who doesn't have their head stuck in the sand already knows that, and has known it for a long time.What you have NOT done is convincingly show that humans are responsible for anything more than (possibly) a recent pittance of that warming.

I worry that we are wasting resources attempting to reverse something that we don't know for certain we cause, and which we certainly don't know how to reverse.¬† Instead, we need to accept the fact of climate change, and devote our resources to mitigating the detrimental effects we believe it may have on the human species.

It's the difference between wasting time and money trying to uninvent a rogue germ, instead of spending it on developing a vaccine that will allow people who contact the grem to survive it.

I have read that our contribution to total CO2 is maybe 4%, which is statistically insignificant. Is the climate changing, yes. It always is. Now explain how we add to water vapor in the atmosphere.
author: Patrick Winn

text: ¬†@Patrick Winn¬† You're right! And thank god they're only trace gasses. Our atmosphere is comprised of mostly nitrogen and oxygen (the air that we breathe), where as Co2 makes up 390 ppm (0.039%) of the atmosphere, how can such a small amount be important? The problem is, small amounts of very active substances can cause large effects to reverberate throughout the ecosystem.  Saying that Co2 is only a trace gas is like saying that arsenic is only a trace water contaminant - small doses go a long way. It's also analogous to blood alcohol content and drunk driving, 800 ppm (0.08%) is the limit in all 50 US states. Now as far as humans only contributing a small percentage of Co2, you're in essence correct with that statement too! Natural cycles in the climate emit vast amounts of Co2 into the atmosphere, and they have for quite some time. The problem arises with this: The natural cycle adds and REMOVES Co2 to keep a balance in our climate; whereas humans add substantial amounts of extra CO2 without removing any in-turn.
author: Ryan Elcock

text: ¬†@Patrick Winn¬† Okay! So that was in response to your first points, now lets address how we're adding more water vapor to the atmosphere - this all stems back to a problem in the hydrological cycle yet again, which is really what climate change is all about. As global temperatures rise, its no debate that the earth's ice caps have been melting without refreezing like they normally do during the winter periods (around 30%-40% of the earth's polar ice has disappeared since 1979 when we really started recording this stuff). So, as that ice melts it transitions into water in its liquid form (meaning more water in the oceans, etc.), and because there is now more water in its liquid form available in the world, more water is consequently evaporating into the atmosphere as part of the water cycle, hense why we're putting more water vapor into the hydrological cycle without even meaning to do it.

text:
¬†@The Andoxico¬† melting ice has nothing to do with cloud formation.

An increase in ocean temps will slightly increase ocean evaporation, which leads to increased cloud cover, which acts as a negative feedback to global warming.

Conversely, falling ocean temps decrease ocean evaporation, which decreases cloud formation leading to more solar radiation hitting the earth and warming it back up...

Increasing Solar TSI/ sunspot activity increases global warming as we saw in the 20th century.  The strongest 63-yr string of solar cycles in 11,400 years occurred from 1933~1996.  When these string solar cycles ended, so did the global warming trend...

The next solar cycle starting around 2022 will be the weakest since 1790, and the one starting 2035 is expected to be the weakest since the Munder Mimumum in 1645~1715.  

There is an excellent chance of another Grand Solar Minimum starting from2035 and lasting 50~100 years.  If one occurs, global temps will be colder by 2100 than they are now....

Oh, the irony...

text:
Well, to help you out a bit;

First of all, CO2 blocks radiation both ways. For the amount of heat that it keeps on earth, the same amount of the sun is blocked away. It differs from a actual greenhouse because a greenhouse is a glass building that prevents airflow. The heat is therefore trapped in a small space instead of spreading over a wider area.

Secondly, nature tend to balance things out. Some species might indeed go extinct but other better suited ones might thrive and adapt to the increased amount of CO2. Have you ever given a plant 1.5% more sunlight or water¬†than it used to have? Trust me, It will survive.

Also, the ocean is great at absorbing CO2. This will increase the amount of algae which will boost the amount of fish that is currently way too low anyway.

There are far more important things to worry about, such as the radiation leaked from Fukushima. Maybe you should take a look at that.
author: ChickenStealer

text:
¬†@ChickenStealer¬† Those are all common misconceptions. The presence of greenhouse gasses increases temperatures, since any light waves which aren't reflected into space go to the planet, and then from the planet back to the atmosphere, and then a portion of them back to the planet, which is reflected back to the atmosphere, on and on. This ends up with a net heating effect. This is what is known as the Greenhouse Effect. That argument is the same kind of argument Creationists make when they say "If man came from monkeys, then why are there still monkeys?" It stems from your misunderstanding of the concept, not a flaw in what the science says.

Second point, there have been previous mass extinctions on this planet, previous warming events, and yes, the planet is still here. The problem is that we haven't been here before. Human beings have never had to deal with temperatures rising on the scale that the models show. Our survival is not guaranteed, not by a long shot, even if the continuation of life on this planet pretty much is. Plus, the problem is not "1.5% more sunlight", as you claim. The issue is highly increased temperatures, melting antarctic ice caps raising sea levels, and increased ocean acidity. These are all problems which are being researched, and the research thus far isn't exactly promising. Yeah, the trees are probably fine, but we're not trees.

Finally, remember that "ocean acidity" thing I mentioned? The ocean is, indeed, a great absorber of CO2. But CO2 isn't like light waves. It's a chemical. Mixin CO2 with Water makes Carbolic Acid. That raises the ocean's pH, and that can be devastating to anything using a calcium carbonate shell. At around pH 6, coral reefs blanch and disintegrate. Fish die when the acidity of the water reaches a level they can't tolerate. This shit is not theoretical either, it's happening. Measured ocean alkalinity used to be around 8 to 8.5... now it's around 7. And falling.

And I'm ignoring the Fukushima angle. Just because there are other problems on Earth, doesn't mean this isn't a problem.
author: Jeoshua Collins

text:
First of all, how is saying that CO2 reflects both ways the same as this creationist argument?¬†

Also, humans are probably one of the most adaptable of all species. Look at the distribution of humans. They are found in the warmest to the coldest places on earth. Unless the whole planet turns into a desert, which deforestation is more to blame, we will be just fine.

About that ocean, there are aquatic animals found living in almost boiling water near sulfuric vents. I would¬†agree that a significant part of the life forms could die out, or at least decline in population, but other types might take over their territory. The total amount of fish is only dependent on the amount of food there is.
author: ChickenStealer

text:
¬†@ChickenStealer¬† Because it is based on a misunderstanding of the very concept. You claim that CO2 reflects light away. That's true, but your followup with saying that means there is no net warming is patently false, and does not follow from the premise. The light which is reflected can be ignored, but the light that gets trapped underneath the greenhouse warms the planet, as it also reflects the light escaping back to the planet, which is then absorbed into the planet to be re-emitted, which is then reflected back again, etc, etc. The light which is reflected away isn't even fully devoid of energy input into our atmosphere, because the light must interact with the atmosphere to even be affected in the first place! This is the very concept behind how greenhouses work, and I don't just mean in climate change! I mean that literally, if the Greenhouse effect worked like you claim, actual greenhouses would not work, which they quite clearly do.

And just because extremophiles can survive anywhere you look does not mean that human beings can, or that all life is just going to adapt to whatever changes are thrown at them. Those microbes you're taking about have been shown to be some of the most divergent creatures on our planet. They would have had to be separated from the line of creatures which gave rise to higher animals by billions of years. No amount of fortuitous luck is going to allow all of life on this planet to adapt to the conditions that they thrive in. You might as well be talking about space aliens, for all the relevance it has to this topic.
author: Jeoshua Collins

text:
Actual greenhouses work because they trap the warm air inside of it.¬†They use¬†windows to regulate this.¬†Temperature is not all about radiation. If a greenhouse worked without this, they would not have been made this way.

About the light reflected back by the atmosphere, I do agree that a certain amount is reflected back multiple times until it turns into heat. This however is not a vicious cycle thing. Every time the light gets reflected back¬†the amount¬†decreases and it approaches a mathematical limit that is on the same scale as the light reflected into space during the initial phase. So I strongly disagree with your claim that the latter is irrelevant.

Just like when you provide a house with¬†10x the amount of insulation. Without an auxiliary heating element inside it, your house won't become a boiling sauna.

__

As I said, humans are not solely dependent on evolution anymore. We tend to adapt with the help of¬†technology. Humans are capable of providing for themselves in a wide range of environments. Most of our food is cultivated and people are great omnivores.

About the rest of earth,¬†again, some creatures will be negatively affected by a change in ocean acidity. Other species will fill their void and¬†it is not only extremophile bacteria.¬†Some fish are more resilient and will replace those that are gone.¬†
author: ChickenStealer

text:
+Paul Pillau, "do something against climate change?" You mean like "do something against volcanic eruptions" or "do something against earthquakes?" Nice! What did you have in mind?

But if you think CO2 and warming are bad, then you're living in a delusion. We live in an Ice Age (those 2 little white things at the poles). And CO2 is at starvation levels, dangerously close to Mass Extinction levels.

150 ppm -- CO2 Mass Extinction
400 ppm -- CO2 today
800 ppm -- CO2 starvation trigger which forced plants worldwide to evolve C4 species
1,600 ppm -- CO2 Normal
4,000 ppm -- CO2 abundance
8,000 ppm -- Rich CO2 levels, the kind which allowed so many plants that it gave us our fossil fuels
10,000 ppm -- Nominal CO2 on naval submarines
20,000 ppm -- Maximum recommended CO2 on NASA spacecraft
210,000 ppm -- The level of oxygen in our atmosphere, and possibly the level of CO2 when Earth had zero oxygen (before photosynthesis).
965,000 ppm -- CO2 level on Venus; but add to this the fact that its atmosphere is 92x thicker than that on Earth. This gives Venus more than 220,000 times as much CO2 in its atmosphere as we have in ours.

this graph pretty much illustrates how science operates,

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/The_Scientific_Method_as_an_Ongoing_Process.svg/2000px-The_Scientific_Method_as_an_Ongoing_Process.svg.png

how falsificiation, (re) testablity and (re) verification of data by independent peers create a constantly improving picture of the natural (so not the supernatural) world. text:
Thank you and cheers :)   I should point out though that you didn‚Äôt conflate the two in the sense that you mentioned them say directly in the same sentence together, so I should set that right here, but the concept of having faith in God vs conclusions that the scientific method/science makes are just two completely separate issues, hence my confusion.

As for your main question‚Ä¶ I want to clarify first off that there isn‚Äôt one single individual piece of evidence that proves it on itself. A single piece of evidence in almost any hypothesis or scientific theory is not enough by a longshot. The strength/ validity of a theory or scientific conclusion is measured by the body of evidence. So basically the continuously piling amount of evidence, (that each has to undergo scrutiny and critical peer review before it can count as such.)  In case of anthropogenic climate change there‚Äôs a gigpile of pieces  and studies ranging from measuring ocean/ ground acidity and comparing that to geo and ice drills in that date back x time, Vs measurement of solar activity compared to  lower atmospheric heating and the amount of carbon twelve located there..  The video points to most of these though sometimes in not very convincing tiny nutshell. This is because  the problem with a body of  empirical evidence is that the more detailed and abundant it gets, the harder it becomes to communicate to a layman‚Äôs audience. If one isn‚Äôt somewhat educated in the subject, eyes quickly glaze over if you know what I mean. (hence me pointing to the link in the description/google Scolar search for sceptics like yourself (that‚Äôs a compliment by the way). If you however still don‚Äôt trust any of the (I think it‚Äôs around 12 thousand from the top of my head?) papers/experiments/studies etc.  You can of course always set up an valid empirical study/ scientific test for yourself, but that takes a lot of effort/time.

Now being a former technical university student, (though with a completely different degree) I did have the opportunity to be a part of an university experiment once taking weather balloon measurements of  CO2 in the atmosphere and its specific isotopes.  So yeah I‚Äôm definitely convinced that the climate is changing and that humanity plays a huge roll in it. Despite whatever politicians/industrials agenda, both from the peer reviewed studies by various experts as well as testing/witnessing the results myself first hand (though that was just a single experiment/measurement)

by the way, one of the key merits in finding truth, any truth is Skepticism and Honesty and you‚Äôve shown both of those so Kudos to you for that ÔÅä

text:
¬†@Rosanna Miller¬†
¬†Hey! Sorry for the late reply, lots of life happening : ).

Yeah I agree, the power of Empirical evidence lies in a specifically defined set of parameters, and the fact that the experiment has to be duplicable, making sure that people can re-con/affirm it and get similar results. Herein also lies the misunderstanding when people talk about for instance the 97% consensus.¬† It‚Äôs not that there was a poll and out of 100 scientists 97 agreed for some reason, out of most of the empirically set up experiments¬† 97% concluded positive on data that potentially points out Anthropogenic climate change (like carbon 12), the remaining 3 didn‚Äôt but pretty muc did agree that the climate was in fact changing.¬† So it‚Äôs not a ‚Äúvote consensus‚Äù but a count and divide of empirical data.

Evolution is a different topic all together but evolution is in a nutshell another way of saying that if you have a lifeform, and you expose that lifeform to selection pressures, then over x time that lifeform with slightly alter.
¬†We see this all the time in for instance dog breeding (The only difference is that the selection pressure is human intervention or artificial selection, rather than nature.)¬† So if you for instance want to breed a dog with more aggressive tendencies you select and breed only those who have those tendencies out of the flock and keep doing this tell eventually you end up with a more aggressive dog race. That‚Äôs evolution at work right there, it‚Äôs the reason we have say.. Pitbulls. I don't see that conflicting with scripture but then again I'm no pastor/priest/specialist in that :)

What would prove that climate change doesn‚Äôt really exist‚Ä¶ oof..that‚Äôs a tough one..¬† it‚Äôs hard to disprove the current body of evidence by a just single piece to the contrary, but what it could be like would be for instance drilled ice cores samples that would not display any change in composition over the x thousand year timespan in which the layers grew. Or us detecting only naturally occurring CO2 isotopes in the atmosphere. But alas that‚Äôs not what we‚Äôve seen so far. Not by a long shot :(

In my experience (but that‚Äôs me) science and the scientific method has consistently produced reliable results over time. even though it is always operating in degrees of certainty, rather than absolute certainty. I remain sceptical of various findings however, but the currently body of evidence alongside having witnessed evidence first hand rather than on paper, I have no compelling reason so far to doubt that it‚Äôs happening, thus I stick to it (for now).¬†¬†

The correlation between humanity‚Äôs activity and climate change is for one highlighted by the amount of fossil fuel carbon isotope levels in the atmosphere vs levels several years back. Something the experiment I told you about earlier directly confirmed.

Heh. I‚Äôm not a biblical expert of any kind so I can‚Äôt tell you if that‚Äôs true or not and I don‚Äôt really have an opinion on it.. But regardless of the Apocalypse...(and this might be very silly of me so apologies if it is)¬† but If it is true what you believe, and God did create this world and all its natural beauty.. I‚Äôd almost expect that it would be especially the people who deeply believe that this earth was created by God to be most angry towards the fact that humanity is ignorantly polluting and destroying so much of it. ¬†¬†But again that‚Äôs just me..I don't know enough about you or your Faith. I do want to Thank you¬† for your kind words and open mind. may your days be long and full of happiness :)

text:
+bryce2124 
     Because it's happening much too rapidly.
     One of the biggest factors effecting global climate is how the oceans circulate water. During periods of time such as the one we currently live in, in which land mass is not concentrated into a super continent around which the ocean can flow easily, the planet tends to be colder and experience ice ages. The current rise in average global temperature cannot be explained by better circulation of ocean currents, because the position of landmass hasn't changed drastically.
     Further, it can't be explained by natural solar cycles which last ~11 years, nor by the more significant Milankovitch cycle of ~100,000 years.(To clarify, Milankovitch cycles are related to glacial and interglacial periods during ice ages, such as the one we are still in)
     The only way I've seen to explain the deviation from these established trends with such speed is that human exploitation of resources, especially since the beginning of the industrial revolution, have disturbed the cycle. From clear cutting forests, to burning fossil fuels, causing eutrophication, to increasing the population of animals we use for consumption drastically, we have introduced factors affecting the climate that previously were not present.
     This in no way means that we are evil for expanding our civilization. It does however mean that in order to ensure this planet remains habitable for humanity, we must work to limit the damage to our environment that we cause, and ideally find ways to reverse the damage we have done. If we continue to damage our environment, it will result in an environment we are radically unprepared to adapt to even by means of advanced technology.

text:
First we have to start out with, when did the mos recent Ice Age end?
We are STILL in it!
Geographers define an ice age as a period in the Earth's history when there are polar caps.  Our current climate is an "interglacial" period.  This does not mean "between ice ages."  It is used to describe the period within an ice age when the ice retreats because of warmer temperatures.
"Our" intergglacial started 10,000 years ago in what we think is the Fourth Ice Age.  
When it will end is anyone's guess; ideas about the duration of the inter glacial period range from 12,000 years to 50,000 years (without allowing for man-made influences).
The causes of the fluctuations are not well understood.  Possible factors include the position that he land masses happen to be in, the composition of the atmosphere changes in the Earth's orbit around the Sun and the Sun's orbit around the galaxy.
The Little Ice Age which began in 1500 and lasted for 300 years saw the average temperature in northern Europe drop by 1 C.  It also coincided with extremely low sunspot activity.  Though whether the two were linked is still being debated over.
The catastrophic decline in population across Europe meant that abandoned farmland was gradually covered by millions of trees.  This would have led to a significant absorption of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, forcing the average temperature down in an "anti-greenhouse effect".

text:
+Pascoal Freitas That is absolutely not how it works. The amount you have evaporated is nothing... The water vapor stays in average only a few hours to a few days in the atmosphere (water is in a fast cycle in the atmosphere in opposition with CO2 for example staying around 100 years).

The amount of water vapor that is contain in a volume of atmosphere is directly linked to the temperature of this volume. And it only depends of this, heating water will not change anything to it because the temperature fix what a volume of atmosphere "can hold" in water. It means that additional forcing from greenhouse gaz will warm up atmosphere. This warmed atmosphere will contain more water vapor and warm even more... etc. It is what we called a feedback (and in this case it is a very reactive one compared to others in the climate system that can take centuries...). So basically when we are counting the effect of CO2 we are counting this kind of feedback with it. 

Now a more interesting question : how can you think that you are more clever when heating water that hundreds of scientists worldwide ?

The oceans won't take all the CO2. Moreover, a warming oceans release a part of the dissolved CO2 (because solubility is dependent of the temperature). It means that in a warming world, oceans will more probably release CO2 and the CO2 pump will break on the long term (centuries to millenials)...

This is what happen when you are going out of an ice age. An initial perturbation (orbital) warms a little the Earth and its oceans. Warming oceans release CO2. More CO2 built-up in the atmosphere leading to more warming... etc. This is the main positive feedback to go out of an ice age with the decreasing of albedo (due to ice melting).

Note: On a very very long term (millions), CO2 is stocked in sedementary rocks and so on and pulled out of the carbon cycle.

text:
We are legitimately in the middle of a mass extinction, judging by the fossil record we're going to be leaving behind. It's even a defined geological layer, enough so to have a whole branch of science devoted to it's study, Archaeology. And the mass extinction has a name: The Anthropocene. Because smarter people than we have named it, and it's people that define it's extent. All the lack of other species, habitats, and such, is secondary to the addition of parking lots and farms.

And before people say "the science isn't in" or "it won't happen in our lifetime" that's completely missing the point. These are geological scale changes. You can't pave half the world and burn everything flammable you find without causing some changes, and those changes classically haven't been for the better. They are periodic, however. And when they occur, shit goes haywire and things die in the reset.

People have compared humans to a cancer or a virus in pop culture, but we're not. Industrial society is more like a Volcano; a destructive force of nature capable of scouring the Earth black to spread itself, and belching volumes of black smoke into the sky. Not always active, often dormant, but powerful and leaving a mark on the Earth either way.
