text:
Why don't we all take a page or two out of a new book discussing climate change by Bill Nye. 

     "Modern climat models are extremely complicated, much more so than the ones Pollack and Sagan where using back in my student days. Todays models include the effects of clouds, oceans, glaciers, mountains, forests, open lands, and all of the different gases and particles that humans are sending into the atmosphere. As Earth circles (or ellipsis, sic) the Sun, its axis wobbles a little on a twenty-six-thousand-year cycle. Earth's orbit itself oscillates, changing its ellipticity over a one-hundred-thousand-year cycle, and it shifts its tilt over a forty-one-thousand-year cycle. These motions change the amount of sunlight that falls in different parts of the Earth at the different times of year over millennia. To be accurate, the models need to include all of these variations --- and they do.
     The results are computer models that represent Earth, its atmosphere, and its seas, using everything we know. Mathematicians and scientists use the physics and chemistry of water, air, and sunlight to create billions of imaginary boxes in the sky. They mathematically simulate air, water, and land. The individual properties of each box -- each mathematical element -- are well known. The researchers build complex equations to describe how each box interacts with all the boxes around it to determine what will probably happen next, i.e., as time goes by. But just as important, they check the models by using them to predict what has already happened; they run the models backward and 'postdict' the past. It's a term of art closely related to terms of sport, especially the mathematics of baseball.
     One of the fascinating things about baseball compared with a great many other sports is that in baseball, the statistics are especially meaningful. Each pitch is a datum. Each outcome of that pitch, whether it be a ball, a strike, a hit that takes the runner one, two, or three bases, or all the way around to home plate, goes in the baseball record books. In recent years, those statistics have been revisited to come up with a set of criteria that can, as the saying goes, 'predict the past.' Modern baseball statisticians have revolutionized the way players are chosen and used in each game by comparing what has happened with each player's past at-bats with the overall outcome for each team each season. This technique was celebrated in the book and the movie 'Moneyball." Any proposed set of statistics is not considered to be of any special value unless it can be used to show that outcomes of the past season are consistent with what these statistics would have predicted had they been in use years ago.
     So it is with climate models. we want to put certain data into a complex computer program and have the outcome be consistent with climate data gathered from patterns in rocks, pollen grains found in lake sediments, tree ring counts, and the bubbles of ancient atmosphere. A climate computer model is not trusted unless it can predict the past. Nowadays, the models are converging. we are getting increasingly accurate and we are seeing exactly how serious climate change will be."

He goes on in the book to explain how bad it will get but gives hope that we can still do something and hurt a little less and be okay. Its a really good educational read and I recommend it to everyone including those still in denial.

http://berkeleyearth.org/summary-of-findings/
author: Jeoshua Collins

text:
No
Everything there is an estimate. Wild ones.
Despite the claims of Berkley Earth (LOL) there was no way to measure the surface temperature of the globe in the year¬† 1750.¬† That is laughable.¬† And their claims to be able to do it to hundredths of a degree Celsius....somebody failed science class.
Didn't you notice how those graphs have very different patterns for the different time periods?

The first year it was possible to measure the global surface temperature was 1978 with the advent of satellite technology by John Christy at UAH.¬† Since 1978 when global surface temperature measurements began the surface has been warming at a rate of roughly 0.12 degrees C per decade or 1.2 Degrees per century.¬† There is no reason to believe this is greater than the rate of warming in the 19th century let alone what is causing it
http://www.nsstc.uah.edu/climate/2016/july/July2016_graph.png
These measurements also show that the predictions of global surface¬† warming that were made 25 years ago were wrong.
http://www.nature.com/news/climate-change-the-case-of-the-missing-heat-1.14525

You can not prove this hypothesis based on global surface temperature measurements and the world's leading expert on the trend of global surface temperature John Christy disagrees with the IPCC
author: Reuben Handel

text: ¬†@Reuben Handel¬† See, that's what  I'm saying. Every time someone comes up with anything resembling a graph or some data, you critics have a rebuttal prepared that discounts everything. Go away, I'm not playing this game with you.
author: Jeoshua Collins

text:
¬†@Jeoshua Collins¬†
You pointed me to an advocacy website which had a bunch of crap on it.¬† What do you expect?

Describe to me the process by which you would measure the global surface temperature to any accuracy in the year 1977.¬† Because I bet your method isn't a real measurement like mine.¬† It's an estimate.¬† The GISS is politicized crap.¬† UAH and RSS are the only global surface temperature measurements

As a matter of fact the only measurement with any accuracy to it that we have for global temperature (not just the surface) that go back into the pre industrial age are the tidal gauges.¬† This is the only way we can compare the rate of warming in the 19th century as opposed to the 20th century.
The IPCC reluctantly admits that:
"No significant acceleration in the rate of sea level rise during the 20th century has been detected."¬†
https://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/tar/wg1/409.htm
The current rate of sea level rise is less than 2mm per year according to the gauges and as far as we can tell that's been the rate since the end of the little ice age.
http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/globalregional.htm

Actually in this theory the greenhouse effect of water vapor is more important than c02.¬† The idea of this theory is that the small increase in warming from the co2 will then cause a chain reaction of events called "feedbacks" including more water vapor evaporated from the ocean .

If it were just about the greenhouse effect of c02 then all the models would be the same and you wouldn't have a huge range of predictions.¬† You would simply be plugging in the amount of c02

author: Tim M

text: Tim M...I don't think you meant it that way, but in fact you've hit upon a basic truth.  Argument acceptance is not the basis for science.  The basis for science is that the validity of an argument can be tested to failure (called "falsifiability") by anyone using known procedures, and everyone who does the same trial the same way gets the same result.  The effect is one of acceptance only because it always works out the same.  When many of the proponents of AGW write and speak, they are not talking about the direct evidence, but of their models.  See the presentations by Freeman Dyson for another view of their models, but I and many others (including Dyson) consider that so much has been left out of the model creation that it unable to make good predictions.  Perhaps you might view my YouTube presentation...just click on the orange "W" and the page will come up.

One of my favorites is the Milaknovitch cycles that I first saw in a presentation by James Hansen at Bergen Community College in 2006 (about 2 weeks after my presentation, but with far more fanfare than I got).¬† I asked how it was that with all the CO2 at the peak of heating that the curve ever turned back down (and this on the basis that the curves showed CO2 causing the warming, a fact disproven later).¬† He was unclear in his answer, and I'll make no further comment about it except to say that he was NOT merely exemplifying a trend without causal implications.¬† However, NOW that the 800 year lag of CO2 is understood, some including the scientist who found it, are decrying its use to refute causality by NOW claiming that it was NEVER the historical cause.¬† But it was claimed to be, and that was not true, and the ad hoc answer now says that while it was never a cause per se, it was a trigger.¬† Oh, that answer eh? untestable, unverifiable, undisprovable, unscientific?¬† That answer like astrology...

text: You simply don't understand the difference between "consensus" in the popular sense, and the term in the scientific sense. When consensus is based on evidence, it is very useful. That's when a hypothesis becomes a working theory, and is tested, observed, and more and more evidence builds up -- until guess what -- eventually a consensus is achieved based on the overwhelming evidence. That's how science works. After that, we try to make the world a better place through practical application of the science, and that's exactly what scientists are trying to do when it comes to GW and the evidence-based solutions we can bring to the table. Unfortunately, agenda-driven ideologues, and sheer morons, simply refuse to accept the evidence. Stubborn, willful stupidity is detrimental to the human species.
author: iiwatcher

text:
¬†@iiwatcher¬† It's important that your response is to a commenter/poster, but I thought I'd take a stab at replying anyway.¬† If you had someone else in mind, you might have added a +Name to your reply to clarify it.
Point 1.¬† You said, "When consensus is based on evidence, it is very useful."¬† While this is often true, it is still not definitive and it is often not timely. Copernicus anticipated Galileo by nearly a century, and there was still no "consensus" when Galileo observed the moons of Jupiter and got himself confined to his house by the powers that be.¬† According to wikipedia, Aristarchus of Samos had anticipated Copernicus by 18 centuries but there was still no "consensus".¬† Is that only because the old system had no internet?¬† No, it's because humans have imagined themselves more important to the function of the universe than was true, so no one else looked or they figured it was unwise to contest the "consensus" then at hand.

Point 2 is related to Point 1 in that you qualified your statement as "based on evidence", but if it's the evidence itself that's under challenge, then mere consensus has no value whatever.¬† Ptolemy's strange spheres within spheres were in agreement with most sightings...but he was wrong and his predictions did not envisage moons around Jupiter.¬†

Point 3 is that the claim of "consensus" is completely fabricated in the sense you seem to think relevant: evidence.¬† Most of the publications on AGW are about consequences and simply presume it as a basis for their analyses of those outcomes.¬† Thus, all the studies about rising oceans, malaria outbreaks and other disease increases, increased storms' number and severity, increased loss of life, etc., etc. are simply not probitive at all, but the publication of such articles is included in many assertions of "consensus" despite their irrelevance.
author: W. Hoffman

text:
Dear shyster piece of shit:  I don't take "youtube researchers" too 
seriously. I happen to have a life. The scientific consensus on GW is 
based on sound evidence. You can spew conjecture, non-sequiturs, and name drop all you want as part of your spin-talking-points all you like.   Of course there are gaps in consensus and certain individuals shed light on new evidence. That doesn't change that after the fact, once such evidence is tested, and repeatedly observed a consensus is reached. Merely "challenging" evidence does not nullify evidence-based consensus  you fucking moron. New evidence has to come into the mix that  either adds to existing evidence or nullifies it, and it has to be compelling, testable, repeatable, etc, based on the hierarchy of evidence (from hard  evidence (aka proof) or the best available evidence one can find). All you did was basically repeat yourself in a long-winded manner, and still  fail to understand what scientific consensus is. author: Ryan Elcock

text:
There's a correlation, and over a hundred years ago chemists showed why there's probably also causation (though that wasn't their aim, and correlation is also not without merit if you can rule out other factors); CO2 absorbs outgoing radiation in a part of the spectrum where water does not, meaning that that radiation "vent" if you like is getting plugged by rising CO2 concentrations. That water vapour traps heat is pretty intuitive to anyone who's been out on a cold winter day with and without clouds, and CO2 works by the same principle. 

CO2 isn't the only reason for the temperature increase, but it's the main one. Changes in Earth's orbit, the sun's radiation output (as mentioned in the video) or a lowering albedo can't explain the increase in temperature, so CO2 appears to be the main culprit. 

Of course all afaik, but there you go.

1) yeah there's like hundreds of thousands of scientists that have done work on climate change, and those claims came from one university and when taken in context actually are not trying to fudge data on climate change, rather they found outlying figures on tree rings, these are usually discounted in statistics anyway. 

2) which failed climate models? There are basically new models of the climate being produced every year, that's kind of like saying some models of solar system formation failed to show the formation of our solar system - therefore the solar system does not exist. Models are not surrogates for data.  

3) I'm not a biologist so I couldn't comment but you could probably find helpful resources from google scholar.

4) Ice forms on the icecaps, not by the freezing of water from the sea, but by the falling of snow, which is compacted into ice over time - similar to how glaciers form. Air gets trapped beneath the snow and that's basically how you can find CO2 in ice cores. 

5) Well climate is effected in a whole bunch of ways, to list them all here would be kind of a hefty task, not all of them are bad though. The length of the growing season has increased by around 2 weeks since 1950 for instance in temperate regions. However with warmer seas you could find more evaporation and precipitation in those temperate climates also, and also more energy for large storms and hurricanes. You will probably find a lot more destructive storms and flooding events. Not only that, areas with high temperatures already, like in desert climates, could find water becoming a scarcer resource. Solar activity means essentially the amount of energy that the Sun is outputting. 

6) Again what do you mean? Are you talking about past Earth climates, or the present climate? In the present day CO2 has increased first. In past climates its due to Earths orbit, inclination and eccentricity. You should read up on gases absorption spectra if you have doubts about the heat trapping effect of carbon dioxide - there are some fun experiments you can do in your home to see this effect yourself.

7) Other than government policy, there are little things you can do to cut down your CO2 emissions. Definitely it has to be a collective effort. Even things like just taking a mug or thermos with you to get coffee helps. If you can walk instead of taking the car, that's good too. Eating less meat and energy efficient technology is a big plus. I don't know if its necessarily regulations that will help most, but definitely governments could help making greener technology more accessible and cheap - the growth in the renewables sector makes this look promising.  

No doubt the world has survived worse than this, the real question is, will humanity survive the new world? Carbon dioxide is super important for life on Earth, but just like everything in life, having it in moderation is key.

text: Although it's true that we only emit a small amount of the carbon dioxide which is released into the atmosphere every year  (36 gigatonnes vs 780 gigatonnes emitted through natural processes), this small amount is throwing the system off balance. Before the Industrial Revolution the Earth used to reabsorb those 780 annual gigatonnes. We are now seeing CO2 levels in the troposphere increasing by 15 gigatonnes per year, meaning that natural carbon dioxide sinks cannot take up more than (roughly) 800 gigatonnes annually.

text:
Ok, now we're starting to become offensive and I sincerely don't like this. We should keep our manners polite in order to have a productive conversation.

This said, it's true that nothing is absolutely certain, and thus scientists consider a hypothesis certain when it becomes really really probable that it is. 97% of climate scientist say that global warming is man made, and there is a scientifical explanation.

When photons (light particles) hit the ground, their energy is transferred to the Earth in the form of heat. That heat is usually radiated away into space as infrared radiation (IR). CO2 and various other gasses, though, can decrease the quantity of energy radiated out of the planet.
I'll give you some chemistry basis for you to understand this just in case you don't know what chemical bonds are. An atom is made up of nuclei (which are composed of positively charged protons and neuter neutrons, and thus are positively charged) and electrons (negatively charged). Electrons orbit their nucleus very rapidly and they do so arranging themselves in several layers. Atoms that have eight electrons in the outer layer are very stable, therefore many atoms will try to get to have that number of electrons in their outer layer. Sometimes, atoms which lack electrons in this layer share their electrons with other atoms which share their own in return. For example, carbon has four electrons in its outer layer and oxygen has six. Each oxygen atom will share two of its outer electrons with the carbon atom, and the carbon atom will do the same with the oxygen atoms. As a consequence, one carbon atoms and two oxygen atoms combine to form a carbon dioxide (CO2) molecule in which each nucleus has eight electrons orbiting in its outer layer. This makes this molecule very stable.

Now, what happens is that photons carrying infrared radiation hit CO2 molecules' bonds and transfer their energy to them. When a bond receives energy it tends to stretch, but while one is stretched the other bond doesn't vary. The two bonds, as a consequence, happen to have different lenghts: this unbalances the electrical charges of the molecules, because the stretched part will have a given number of electrons (four) in a given space, whereas the non-stretched part will have that same amount of bonding electrons in a smaller space, making it more negative than the other.
Turns out that gaseous molecules can only absorb IR photons if their charge gets unbalanced in the process, this is why many gaseous mocules whose charge cannot get unbalanced do not act as greenhouse gases (oxygen O2, nitrogen N2 and many others).
Carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide (NO2), ozone (O3) and many others, though, can absorb this kind of radiation making it linger in the atmosphere instead of letting it leave the planet. The more we pump this kind of gasses into the air, the more the troposphere (the lowest part of the atmospere) is going to heat up, because energy that is caught by these molecules causes them to vibrate, and molecular vibration is the cause on the microscopic scale of heat on the macroscopic scale.

Please tell me if you haven't understood. This problem is very serious and we really need as many people as we can to comprehend it and its magnitude.

text: The point is that the science is not inconclusive. 97% of papers published in climate science which take a stance of AGW conclude that AGW is happening. The amount of evidence for AGW is similar to the amount of evidence for evolution or general relativity. The greenhouse gasses with the largest impact, measured via¬†Global Warming Potential (GWP) are synthetic (eg. CFCs). Nitrous oxide is also a large contributor and is mostly produced thanks to the industrial sector. Similarly we contribute the largest methane emission through the large beef industry, since we raise an insane amount of cattle for food. So yes, humans are the largest contributors to all greenhouse gases by far. I already said the only three things contributing are the sun, the reflectivity of the atmosphere/surface and greenhouse gases. Tol, himself, has no doubt that there is major scientific agreement, he just had issue with how the study was conducted and its ideas of what qualifies as consensus.

author: Ryan Elcock

text:
+youngbloodx

"That 97% consensus was a fraudulent poll that has been debunked years ago  by various articles on Forbes and NY Times."

Please cite reputable sources, not just press sources. Relying on the press for scientific information on climate science is as silly as relying on the press for medical advice.

Anyway, the 97% consensus has been shown again and again, as discussed in table 1 of:

"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming
[...]
The consensus that humans are causing recent global warming is shared by 90%‚Äì100% of publishing climate scientists according to six independent studies by co-authors of this paper. Those results are consistent with the 97% consensus reported by Cook et al (Environ. Res. Lett. 8 024024) based on 11 944 abstracts of research papers, of which 4014 took a position on the cause of recent global warming.
[...]
We examine the available studies and conclude that the finding of 97% consensus in published climate research is robust and consistent with other surveys of climate scientists and peer-reviewed studies."
http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/4/048002/meta

In table 1 of that paper, you'll find at least five studies that get the 97% figure:
1) Oreskes (2004)
2) Doran and Zimmerman (2009)
3) Anderegg et. al. (2010)
4) Cook et. al (2013)
5) Carlton et. al. (2015)



"This just serves to show how little you guys actually fact check where these statistics come from."

Says the person who did so little homework that they think the 97% figure comes from just 1 study...

text:
Good video to raise understanding of man-made climate change, but there are three problems with it:

1) 2:15 - The fact that CO2 levels are higher now than any time in the past 800,000 years is indeed "uncharted territory" for anatomically modern humans, but it's not necessarily a completely bad thing for us or many other species. It's probably a mixed bag, with some advantages and disadvantages.

2) 3:15 - All ruminants eructate (belch) methane, be they cattle, antelope, deer, giraffe, etc. North America used to have 10 million elk, 30 million bison, and 60 million pronghorn, all of them belching methane, the way large ruminant populations still do in Africa and Asia today. Now North America has 100 million cattle belching methane, but that problem has more to do with degree than kind, as ruminants have been belching methane all over the world for 50 million years.

3) 5:15 - Climate change is not "the biggest deal" or "the biggest issue facing our species," and folks would get a lot farther slowing down climate change if they would stop claiming that the sky is falling. The biggest threats to wildlife are poaching and habitat loss. The biggest threats to public health are sanitation and nutrition. The main factors affecting infrastructure are resources and technology. And affluence affects all these things. Yes, climate change affects these issues indirectly, but we have to deal with them regardless of what the climate is doing. It's lamentable that "climate change" has become synonymous with "environment," because it's only one factor among many, and not even the most important one.

author: McOddzen

text:
Unfortunately, this video doesn't put forward any of the contrary scientific evidence.  The claim that we're warming faster than when coming out of an ice age is completely bogus.  When coming out of a serious ice age, the planet can actually warm as much as 50 degrees in just 1,000 years!  That's 5 degrees a century!  The video also doesn't talk about the changing rates of absorption of the carbon sinks, like plants growing larger at an exponential rate (and taking up carbon at that rate) when CO2 increases geometrically.

Or the recent NASA study of radiation of heat off our planet (the heat loss the greenhouse effect blocks).  It found the rates were orders of magnitude higher than what global warming theory predicts.  It also doesn't talk about the gross uncertainties of the historic temperature claims based on tree rings (which grow dependent on a host of factors, many of which will be consistent over a range similar to temperature).

And, ultimately, it doesn't talk about the fact that climatology is a science almost entirely based on computational modeling.  Now, as a computational modeler myself (dealing in atmospheric changes more in the range of meters over periods of seconds due to objects passing through at high speed) I have no problem with this.  An entire planet's atmosphere is way to big and important to actually experiment with directly, so modeling it seems like a good idea.  The problem is, a computational model is nothing more than a theory.  It has to be validated by experimentation.  The classic way would be by comparing it to known historical periods that we have known starting conditions for.  This was tried in the '90s.  Climatologists said the model predictions matched history wonderfully.  Then all the other sciences looked at the graphs and went ape-shit crazy because it claimed global temperature had been essentially flat for the past 2000 years!  This flew in the face of accepted science and widespread evidence in several MUCH more established fields.  What's more, those models' predictions of what would happen over the next 20 years have fallen just as flat.  And the newer models aren't actually doing any better.  I haven't even seen a validation study of a climatology model in years.  These should be standard hat, but somehow they just seem to get forgotten about.

author: David Colombini

text: +PlainsPup It is the most important one, and for one simple reason: irreversibility. As the warming continues, it hits a series of "tipping points" which can't be reversed, activating positive feedback loops which speed up the process. That's why we have to deal with this before doing anything else.
author: Ammonal

text:
¬†@Ammonal¬†¬†I appreciate that, but I think the urgency is overstated. If your basement were flooding or if your house were burning, the first thing to do would be to get everyone to safety ... only then should you try and stop the flooding or the fire.

Although anthropogenic global warming is¬†
real, there is a lot we don't understand about it. As I said, there will be pros and cons to it. Warm climates and their organisms will advance higher in latitude and altitude, while cold climates and their organisms will recede accordingly. Some areas will become wetter, others drier. Glacial melting will mean less spring runoff. Coastlines will move inward. Northern countries are already negotiating routes through the Arctic where none were possible before. Northern countries may be able to conduct agriculture to a degree they once could not. As you can see, it's a mixed bag.

Reducing CO2 emissions is important, but CO2 levels are already elevated compared to the rest of the Holocene and the late Pleistocene (but not before that). We're already in an increased CO2 system, so we have to deal with it. Meanwhile, some people still struggle to get clean water, grow enough food, and live in free societies, while poaching and habitat loss continue to endanger plants and animals regardless of climate change. We do need to do something about how rapidly we are altering the climate, but we will get more done if we are more levelheaded about this and prioritize better.
author: PlainsPup

text:
+PlainsPup You aren't paying attention: if we don't do something within the coming decades, there will be nothing we can do anymore, because natural carbon dioxide sinks will be emitting greenhouse gasses at a rate so high that we won't be able to stop it. What is the point in making sure all of humanity is fed now if we know that future generations will have to fight over the last cultivable areas?
I think that before ensuring everyone lives well, we have to make sure mankind makes it through this crisis.
Believe me, the whole matter is much more serious than you put it. The downturn greatly outdo the advantages.
author: Ammonal

text:
+Ammonal Perhaps I used the wrong wors. I meant "drawback"-"disadvantage", not "downturn".
Sorry, I'm not a native English speaker.
author: Ammonal

text: ¬†@Ammonal¬†¬†Yes, advantages vs. disadvantages. I would really like to see a comprehensive analysis of that.
author: PlainsPup

text:
+PlainsPup It simply requires some more precise studies.

Advantages:
-Some areas will receive more water, therefore reducing droughts and enhancing crops
-Some previously cold areas will become warmer, decreasing the local energy demand and making agriculture possible.
-New trade routes will open up in previously frozen areas.

Disadvantages
-As oceans become hotter and more acidic a lot of marine life will disappear and many species will have to migrate northward.
-Some areas become drier, causing desertification and crop failures (thus famines, droughts and migration).
-Sea levels rise, displacing millions of people.
-More intense storms will be likely to occur.
-Nortward migration causes problems to northern countries, possibly causing conflicts.
-Previously permanently frozen ground thaws out causing landslides.
-Positive feedback loops will be triggered and will trigger further warming.

This is all I could think of now; I'm almost sure, though, that I'll add some to both categories as they come to my mind.
If you want to add any, please do :)

Setting aside warming, ocean acidification is causing havoc with coral reefs around the world.  Already 80% of the reefs in the Caribbean are gone - GONE!!!  Thes reefs are the breeding ground for the majority of fish species on the planet so we are looking at a collapse of fish stock globally.
author: Mike Arkwright

text:
@PlainsPup - touching on something you mentioned - 
1 - Roughly 75% of current species are expected to go extinct in the next century if climate change isnt controlled quickly. It is well believed in the scientific community that we are on the verge of a 6th mass extinction. Yes, hunting/overfishing/overpopulation (of humans) etc are all large factors in this, climate loss and climate change are going to be the tipping point for most of life on earth that cannot adapt to the rapid shift in temperatures and conditions globally. Humans included.

2 - while there used to be a few other animal species that don't exist in the same numbers today, there are hundreds of millions more humans (just in NA) as well as The 100 million cattle you noted. They have a different digestive tract than the elk, bison and pronghorn. Cattle emit alot more methane per animal than those mentioned. Just because there used to be millions of a different species compared to a species today, does not mean 1 equals 1. This is why its an issue. 

3 - Climate change is the biggest deal, because it has the biggest impact to survivability of the planet. If we continue on this path, eventually the positive feedback loop will bring this planet to be completely uninhabitable much like Venus. Yes, in the next decade poaching/overfishing etc are the biggest threats to immediate extinction of animals, however if we dont curb GHG's in the next 12 or so years, then we are destined to an unstable, and largely uninhabitable future within the next 2-3 decades. This is in our lifetime, not our future generations.  The oceans not only provide food for much of the human population, they absorb much of the carbon dioxide. When the reefs and plants die from ocean acidifcation, not only does much of our food supply go away, but so does a lot of our oxygen production, and our ability to absorb carbon.

author: Collin Perry

text: +Collin Perry Directly cooling is hard, as this would require transferring energy out of the system actively. CO2 reduction would lead to less isolation (but only in centuries). Alternatively, we could paint mountains white and install solar panels on every roof. This would reduce the addition of energy to the system. Solar panels, because they reflect more sunlight back than normal roof tiles. However, this is not really cooling the earth, it is just reflecting new energy out of the system. You could send up a satellite to the Lagrange point between earth and sun where is explodes and emits some sort of dust or reflective particle blocking the sun, but you would need to create a really large area with all the particles. The result would be less sunlight which would also have a negative effect on oxygen production by plants and may even increase CO2.

author: Alexander Quilty

text: There's legitimate concerns by skeptics regarding the sources of data for much of the science behind climate change, and the manipulations the data had to go through before it was plugged into predictive models. This video presumably aims to convince skeptics of the science but it starts out with a straw man of the skeptical position, that we're somehow conspiracy theorists. This does nothing to bridge the gap except for framing skepticism as a bad thing, and your follow up video addresses psychological issues regarding the adoption of beliefs but again doesn't address legitimate issues skeptics have with the science. This whole thing has become strictly unscientific and instead has become a PR debate with aggressive use of framing by labeling people climate change deniers and conspiracy theorists rather than logically addressing flaws in the science. When half the source data isn't even made available then people have no reason to believe the conclusion.

author: M0rdH0rst

text:
¬†@M0rdH0rst¬†¬†lol You're ignoring the fact that the RSS satellite data accurately matched the original land and ocean data. Matched it, that is, until NOAA began falsifying the land and ocean data. This fraudulent data manipulation is well documented. It seems if the data doesn't fit the models, instead of admitting the models - and thus the assumptions - are wrong, and adjusting them, it's easier to just adjust the data to fit. This is not how science is meant to be done. But it is how pseudo-science is done when you begin with a conclusion (CO2 is driving temperature) and set out to prove it regardless of the actual facts (because the aim is to regulate CO2).¬†

If you only have one set of data that can be trusted - i.e. the RSS data - it's not confirmation bias to use it. But it is confirmation bias for the UN to ignore the only accurate data and instead use the falsified data to support their agenda.¬†

The only people who are unteachable are those who are easily convinced of things with insufficient evidence; those who lack common sense; those who fail to be skeptical; those who cannot spot a political agenda; those easily swayed by appeals to emotion; and those who think science operates according to consensus (not that there ever was one)..¬†

author: M0rdH0rst

text:
¬†@M0rdH0rst¬†¬†RSS gathers satellite data of atmospheric temperatures for 4 tropospheric and lower stratospheric layers. The layer hypothesized to warm due to an increased concentration of CO2 has not done so. The data therefore falsifies their hypothesis. The fact that there's been no significant warming in 19 years also falsifies their hypothesis.

RSS plot from 1979 to 1997:

http://woodfortrees.org/plot/rss/from:1979/to:1997

RSS trend from 1979 to 1997: +0.13 C

http://woodfortrees.org/plot/rss/from:1979/to:1997/trend

RSS plot from 1997 to 2016:

http://woodfortrees.org/plot/rss/from:1997/to:2016

RSS trend from 1997 to 2016: +0.02C

http://woodfortrees.org/plot/rss/from:1997/to:2016/trend

Apart from the fraudulent adjustment of land and ocean temperature data there are several factors that make surface data problematic in giving an accurate picture of global temperatures. ¬†

text:
We are NOT causing climate change!!! This is such PSEUDO science and I am tired of listening to it. You arrogant plebs, 

We are in an interglacial period called the Holocene, that is an ICE AGE. Did you know that 30,000 years ago we DIDN"T HAVE GLACIERS?? **SHOCK** 22,000 years ago we got glaciers on both ends of the poles. 

There is NO DOUBT that Climate Change is changing, OF COURSE IT IS. Nothing is constant, the only constant thing about climate change is that it is changing! Nobody is disputing this but the fact that we claim WE are causing "Global Warming" ...is beyond idiotic. Yes glaciers are melting, this is nothing new and has been happening through many other periods of times through earths history. The fact that we are in a "stand-by" temperature mode but somehow are claiming anthropogenic CO2 is NOT science. If the earth has been hotter than typical for 400 years and the industrial revolution has been around for 200 years.. WELL CLEARLY ITS THE INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION!! ..seriously though?

author: Max Doubt

text:
While I appreciate your deeply held beliefs in the field of AGW, I do wish that you'd cite scientific research papers which support your many claims. I have sought such for over ten years now without finding even one solid bit of peer-reviewed, published research which supports your claims. Some of your claims are just silly; the ocean levels, for instance, have NOT risen 8 inches since the start of the century; they have risen about one centimetre. Arctic ice has expanded, not contracted, although different years can see it doing either for that year. And the planet has cooled or remained unchanged during the last 19 years. 

THESE are facts. They can be checked by anyone, including you. Only a real religious fanatic of the Church of Anthropological Global Warming can, and will, ignore the facts as put forward in scientific research papers and continue to flat out lie, as you are doing.

You alarmists are very fond of saying, "Go with the science". I do wish that you'd follow your own advice.

author: Jacob Nair

text:
Another video using ad-hominems which acts as though it is definitive but is not.

Please, rather than making "deniers" look stupid, convince them with enough evidence.

If you want people to change their behavior you must first demonstrate you are correct. So do it, rather than making them look stupid and leaving holes in your theory. I am not saying you are wrong, what I am saying is you're leaving holes in this video.

So let me begin...

Sun is source - yep
Some reflected, some absorbed - yep
But human activities have increased... - NOW is where you need to start proving it
40% - Evidence please, this is important, don't leave gaps in your theory if you want to convince people
Temp vs Solar Activity - I don't personally study this, so for the sake of argument I'll give you that one
Upper lower levels together - Again, I'll just give you this one
2000 gigatons - Great, now tell me how much CO2 was added by other sources. Tell me how many other greenhouse gases were contributed by us vs cycles. Want to convince a skeptic? Don't leave holes in your theory.
2 million million tons - Don't be an alarmist, don't assume I am stupid. Rather, simply compare the 2000 gigatons to something to give the skeptic an idea of what percentage of climate change is caused by people.
Ice Cores - Sorry, but with these current holes you haven't shown that humans caused this. I'm not saying you're wrong, I'm saying you need to fill these holes to convince skeptics.
Uncharted territory etc - More alarmist stuff. Give the skeptics some facts. Show the linearity. In all experiments I did I tried for at least 5 measurements in order to show the linear/exponential relations of what I was measuring. Show at least 5 measurements in those ice cores. Don't alarm me. Facts sway me, not that.
Temperatures increase - Yes. But you have yet to convince me through this video that humans are the cause due to the holes in your theory.
10X FASTER - Holy cow well now you convinced me. You scared me in to believing you.
How do we know it's our fault - FINALLY, THANK YOU
Isotopes - OK cool bring it on. Convince the skeptics with evidence.
Fossil fuels from old plants - I don't study this, but I think it's true and will give you this one
12 vs 13 - Again, this isn't my field so I'll give you this one
12 should go up - Well sure, but is it the only source of 12? I hope you cover this in the next minute or you just left another huge hole in your "proof"
And that's exactly what we see - I'm not stupid. Don't give me garbage. Realize I am smart enough to have arguments in my mind, I am skeptical of everything and am only convinced through reason and evidence. Address the other sources of 12. Address how much 12. Don't leave a hole in your proof.
It's not because of volcanic activity - Good, please tell me you're going to address these arguments.
1% as much CO2 - I don't study this. This is one I am less likely to just assume you are right. I am also curious how much is 12 vs 13. Hopefully you cover this in the next few seconds.
Balance etc - Bleh don't diverge, go over how you know, go over the 12 vs 13. Don't leave these holes in your theory sit back there and grow and allow my skepticism to remain. Convince the skeptic.
Methane - OK so you're hopefully starting to answer a question I had probably about 2 minutes ago. PLEASE make a strong logical chain to convince me.
Simulations - Groan. This is so little information how am I supposed to handle this? We simulate cooling - I can only assume next you're going to say BUT INSTEAD IT'S GETTING WARMER, I can predict what you're going to say. How are you going to back it up. Who ran the simulation? What assumptions were made? Where is the peer reviewed writeup? Don't just brush over something like this.
And that is not what's happening - Well there we go. Please don't back this up with another insult.
Derp I have no teeth, it snowed, derp - Groan
Twice as many record highs as lows - Interesting fact. Thank you. But you've yet to convince me through this video that humans are the cause. Make a strong logical chain to convince a skeptic.
Warmer - Well thanks for that observation. Heaven forbid instead of saying crap like this you address the other gigatons, the 12 vs 13, the simulation, if this is so important can't you spend the time to make a video that actually addresses arguments? Few would argue it is getting warmer. Facepalm. PLEASE tell me you're going to address these things and I haven't wasted 4 minutes of my life.
A full degree - If you're trying to alarm me at least do a better job than this.
Warmest in 8 centuries - Enough of this. Show me the 12 vs 13, show me the simulation in more detail, tell me how many gigatons are related to cycles, just fill the gaps in your arguments.

At this point my fingers are getting tired and I have other things to accomplish tonight. So I won't go point by point and I'll just say whether you addressed any of the gaps you left. Again, I'm not saying you're wrong. I'm saying that if you want to convince a skeptic you need to show a complete logic chain that can hold together when subjected to the slightest tug.

Sorry fingers, I lied:
Up 8 inches since 1901 - PLEASE tell me you're going to show how many inches it would have been if humans didn't exist. PLEASE tell me you're going to in some way use this to prove humans are a significant contributor to rising sea levels.
Calcium shells - Thank you I didn't actually know that. Interesting thing to know. BUT you've yet to convince me of humans contribution.
Current trends, warmer - ...and now you're going to say "but without humans, that would only be 0.5 degrees or something". Sorry again for more sarcasm. Can't help myself.
Bad Time - Thank you for at least giving me a laugh.

And now you're acting like you proved something. Facepalm.

So let me summarize:

To convince a skeptic, avoid insults, and instead create a chain of logic strong enough to handle a slight tug. In your case there are complete links in this chain missing.

One link in your chain is showing the proportion of gigatons. Instead of treating me like I am a complete moron, imagine that I'd like to know what percentage of total CO2 that is annually. Give me some form of comparison.

Another is 12 vs 13. You never really covered this in the level of detail it would take to tie this together. Other sources of 12? Time graph of 12? Anything? NO.

Another weak link in your chain, the simulation. Don't just brush over this so briefly.

Again, I am not saying you're wrong. What I am saying is that when I made up a new equation describing how a new type of aircraft would behave (this sentence is simplified) I showed every step of my derivation. I questioned the result. I checked my units. I made sure that every single step in my derivation was correct and in a logical order. I listed my assumptions thoroughly. What I didn't do was alarm the equation reader person (whatever you call them) in to believing it. I laid out a strong sequence. I addressed arguments against my equation.

For the love, seriously, drop the insults and lay out a strong argument that will actually convince a skeptic. Convince me. Convince the skeptic. Lay this out in a way that is so well documented and proven that only the hopelessly illogical and mental gymnastics gold medalists can refute your claim. Don't leave giant gaping holes in your chain. If this is so important, take the time to actually convince people rather than insulting them.

Less insults, more strong logic and evidence.

Sorry, I wrote this "quickly" and didn't proof read. Please understand that each line I wrote was based only really on what you had said up to that point in the video.

It would be great if people could comment and fill these gaps. What would be better is if someone could make a strong convincing video with no holes in the logic that would take say 10-20 minutes, with links to more information.

Get with it people. Stop insulting. Start convincing.

Okay, so back to my point: if we can't convince ourselves to fortify our electrical grid, don't expect us to jump as saving the world climate-change wise.  This is a pure scientific fail for us not to do something about the grid  because it is a given that one day and one day soon there will be a major solar event.

Science also failed to deliver us Thorium nuclear reactors.  Science has done a vast wealth of good for us, but on topic like this, science has no balls.

text: I'm definitely a believer in climate change.  And this video provided just a bit more evidence for me to get freaked out.  But, alas, one has to deal with a very human truth--one person can be a smart, even genius, individual who is able to meet and solve all major threats and challenges quickly and effectively.  7 billion plus people, on the other hand, is just one stupid mass that is very hard to change, let alone influence.  This mass of humanity finds it very difficult to even identify a major problem or threat, let alone meet such a threat head-on.  As a result, I'm pretty down on fixing climate change.  Agricultural systems will be severely disrupted, sea levels will rise, whole countries will disappear, huge cities and all their infrastructure will be lost, economies will collapse and hundreds of millions will lose homes--we just have to adapt to that reality because we ain't going to convince most people to stop consuming and pumping greenhouse gases into the atmosphere in any meaningful quantity.

author: Robert Massaioli

text:
¬†@Robert Massaioli¬†¬†Thanks for the reply.

The first one that comes to mind is the Polar Defense Project's kayak expedition. Here is a post explaining some of the problems with that:¬†http://wattsupwiththat.com/2008/09/09/polar-defense-project-deletes-the-tough-questions/

I'm not a wildlife expert, but the polar bears come to mind, as well. Here is an article from 2008:¬†http://www.factcheck.org/2008/06/polar-bear-population/

Here is another page that is up to date (at least 2015): http://www.worldwildlife.org/species/polar-bear

There seems to be very little change. The fright is not based upon observation, but on continued assumption. There are other articles I could post about polar bears (i.e., An Inconvenient Truth, Never Look a Polar Bear in the Eye), but maybe you can see why some of us are wary of the sensationalism.

Maybe the problem is not always with the actual SCIENTIFIC models themselves. Maybe the problem is that the climate scientists aren't coming down hard and loud on these sensational claims and documentaries. There seems to be a "protect your own" approach, so that the truth isn't what's important, only that people are convinced. That doesn't sit well with me, and makes me immediately wary as someone who is NOT an expert.

It's like how people used to use balances to see how much gold was in a bag. If you tweaked the balance, you could cheat the buyer. It's the same thing, but instead of gold it's truth. The balance is tweaked so that more is perceived as truth than is actually true. If I see that, it makes me immediately wary of the peddler of "truth". And who can blame me?

Then again, it's hard for even a climate change scientist who supports the global warming consensus to come down hard and loud on these things when he is liable to be attacked and called a quack by his own for doing so. So the movement seems to have created its own monster in regards to that.

Then there is this:
http://www.drroyspencer.com/2014/02/95-of-climate-models-agree-the-observations-must-be-wrong/

While we're only talking about tenths of a degree here, you must admit that those models seem quite biased the other way, either by human bias or simply by incorrect assumptions.

Again, it's hard to blame me for being a doubter, isn't it? I'm not a complete disbeliever, and neither am I an angry die-hard denier. It's just hard to see past the sensationalism, etc. to ascertain whether there is much truth. Yes, it's getting hotter, but that's not the proof, is it? It will usually be getting hotter or colder. If they want to convince people like me‚Äîwho they actually do, believe it or not, have a chance of convincing‚Äîthen they could start by using an equal scale of reason. Let the whole movement rise up and silence the sensationalism and fully admit when they are wrong. Then they would have more credibility from me.

Do you agree at all?
author: David Odum

More CO2 doesn't absorb more energy from space as most is already trapped by the CO2 in the greenhouse effect. But it does prevent the same energy from reflecting back out to space. Aslong as the flow of heat is the same into our atmospher as it is out, the atmosphere doesn't warm. But when it is prevented from escaping, then we end up with similar conditions as Venus (not nearly as drastic, but same concept). A planet 2nd from the sun but much warmer than Mercury, which is closest to the sun. However the higher pressure of gases and sulfuric acid clouds also contributes to Venus's temperature, as it prevents heat from venting back out from the atmosphere. The upper atmospher absorbs most of the solar radiation, while the lower atmospher holds radiation that reflects off the surface of a planet allowing it to build up.

text:
¬†@Rusty Shackleford¬†

As I stated, once it is in saturation, more does not heat anymore.¬† It can't.¬† You can't take more blue light out when the blue light filter has removed all the blue light.¬† If you have a filter for dirty water and it cleans the water, adding more filters does not make pure H20 more pure as it is only H20.¬† Once the frequency is gone (saturation) then more does nothing, just like adding more water filter does nothing and adding more blue light filters does nothing.¬† All that happens with CO2 is the height at which the frequency that CO2 reacts to is gone quicker or lower.¬† That height is about 32 ft and adding more just lowers that height.¬† All the warming that can be done is already done so adding more does not warm anymore.¬† Clearly the warming will be closer to the ground, but it is well mixed due to convection.¬† Notice also if the air closer is warmer, then the air higher is colder. ¬† Understand?¬† Keep in mind that the distribution of temperature in a black body (earth and the atmosphere) cannot change the net flow according to the Stephen Boltzman equation.¬†

Think about it this way.¬† If water can vary by 400%, why would it matter if CO2 vary by 400% considering that water is much more effective as a greenhouse gas (a molecule that can resonate that has three adams)?¬† Does the ground change in temperature when water increases?¬† No.¬† Why would CO2 then?¬† It doesn't that is the answer.¬† All that happens is the height to extinction lowers.¬† So what.¬† If the height is 4 ft for water and you increase the concentration by 400% you get 1 ft to extinction.¬† The air just mixes faster.¬† No additional heat can be trapped because there are no frequencies remaining.¬† They have been eaten up already.

text:
+Facey Neck I beg to differ, arguing about the cause of climate change is very important. That climate change happens, and that it is caused by humans, are two different things that have been proven separately. Yet the latter needs to be discussed as much as the former.

Because it is our doing, it reflects our sense of accountability (or lack thereof). The question isn't only : "how to resolve the current situation ?" But more generally : "how do we learn from this and make sure that our actions, current and future, don't generate similar situations ?"

In short, the deeper problem is the incapacity of our production system to think on the bigger scale. For example... When evaluating the benefits of fossil fuel exploitation, if the cost of its consequences over the next centuries was added, we would stop it immediately. It is not even profitable in the long run. Yet we won't stop because we ignore this kind of cost.

That's why a green revolution can't happen merely by changing energy sources. Of course it needs to be encouraged. But as long as our industry doesn't include a larger and more scientific way of evaluating what a benefit is, we can reasonably doubt that future solutions won't create bigger problems.

text:
This is the issue with your interpretation of the science. You are using "C02 has increased since the industrial revolution by 40%" and then attaching that statement to "humans are the cause of the C02 increase". Then you say it is the highest it has been in "1 million years" as if that is a huge number when it is not relative to the supposed 4.5 billion year old planet that is a fraction of time which can not be used as an indicator for an accurate global climate average. That is entirely inaccurate. Really you just calculated the average of 2.2% of the earths climate since it has existed which is not empirical data. Don't get me wrong, humans certainly do add to the C02, and more then they had hundreds of years ago, but to make the assumption, which is what it is an assumption that humans are the cause is not based on proper analysis. Especially when you don't know what the Earths climate cycle actually is. What makes anyone think that this temperature we live off of is normal and not temporary in the first place? That's what I find odd.

The primary sources of CO2 in our atmosphere are biological (decay & plant respiration) and outgasing by the oceans as they warm. You did not mention which isotope of Carbon these produce. Since they are organic sources, my guess is they are the same as fossil fuels.

The real question is what part of the warming over the past 160+ years is due to natural variation and what, if any, is due to CO2. Since we've only warmed (from abnormally low levels) about 0.8C during the period when CO2 has increased 40%, CO2 plays only a trivial role, if at all. Millions of years ago, CO2 levels were between 2,000 & 7,000 ppm, or 5 to 18 times today's concentrations. We didn't have catastrophic warming then, so we won't have it now.

Ice core analysis from Greenland and Antarctica show that CO2 concentration changes lag temperature changes. Therefore, we would expect CO2 to have risen (with or without our contributions) since the Earth has warmed from the LIA.

Bottom line, it doesn't matter that our fossil fuel consumption is increasing CO2 levels. All that does is help the vegetation we depend on for food, shelter and oxygen recycling.

I came here to get smarter, not to be read a poor analysis of data and then add all the intense music and dramatic speaking to scare me into believing it...

text:
+gtrmaster2000 Oh my, you really have no idea how these things work do you?

"Don't get me wrong, humans certainly do add to the C02, and more then they had hundreds of years ago, but to make the assumption, which is what it is an assumption that humans are the cause is not based on proper analysis"
That's not what those words mean. We know carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas because of chemical theory. Specifically the absorbance at wavelengths of 2,000-2,400nm is 4.3AU; the peek absorbance experiences by carbon dioxide under any wavelength. So we know that carbon dioxide has the capacity to absorb (and thus trap) infrared light (heat) and is therefore a greenhouse gas by definition. It's not an assumption we can prove it.

"What makes anyone think that this temperature we live off of is normal and not temporary in the first place?"
That's irrelevant. We know that carbon dioxide increase is responsible for the increasing temperature because the p-value for their values, as plotted each year, is lower that 0.05. Any relationship with a p-value lower than 0.05 is deemed statistically significant, and because we have a causal relationship, we know one causes the other. It doesn't matter if our climate is stable or not we know that's causing it to change in any case; us.

"The primary sources of CO2 in our atmosphere are biological (decay & plant respiration) and outgasing by the oceans as they warm. You did not mention which isotope of Carbon these produce. Since they are organic sources, my guess is they are the same as fossil fuels"
Actually it'll be the same as wherever they're getting their carbon from. For terrestrial life it'll be the same isotope composition as the atmosphere but for aquatic life it'll be the same as whatever body of water they're living in and for fossil fuels radioactive decay means that you'd have to take into account where the carbon is originally from and the age of the sample. The fact that the source is organic or not has nothing to do with isotope composition.

"Ice core analysis from Greenland and Antarctica show that CO2 concentration changes lag temperature changes. Therefore, we would expect CO2 to have risen (with or without our contributions) since the Earth has warmed from the LIA"
No we wouldn't. The carbon dioxide release documented in the samples you're describing is due to warm water's inability to hold as much dissolved carbon dioxide as cold water. As the ocean's warm up carbon dioxide is released. There's a lag period though, as you said, between a rise in atmospheric temperature and carbon dioxide release by the oceans. Since no such lag is observed in the relationship between temperature and carbon dioxide levels, and in fact the relationship is the reverse, we know that ocean-dissolved carbon dioxide is not responsible for the rise in temperature we're experiencing now.

Here maybe if I let someone else explain it for you. Good luck...

"Whenever the p-value is less than the magic number, people believe or ‚Äúact like‚Äù the alternate hypothesis is true, or very likely true. (The alternate hypothesis is the contradiction of the null hypothesis.) We have just seen this is fallacious. Compounding the error, the smaller the p-value is, the more likely people believe the alternate hypothesis true.

This is also despite the strict injunction in frequentist theory that no probability may be assigned to the truth of the alternate hypothesis. (Since the null is the contradiction of the alternate, putting a probability on the truth of the alternate also puts a probability on the truth of the null, which is also thus forbidden.) Repeat: the p-value is silent as the tomb on the probability the alternate hypothesis is true. Yet nobody remembers this, and all violate the injunction in practice."

text:
+Uzziya Your issue is this; you propose that because CO2 is a gas that causes heating, it is responsible for the majority of global warming.


"Specifically the absorbance at wavelengths of 2,000-2,400nm is 4.3AU; the peek absorbance experiences by carbon dioxide under any wavelength. So we know that carbon dioxide has the capacity to absorb (and thus trap) infrared light (heat) and is therefore a greenhouse gas by definition. It's not an assumption we can prove it."



However, you fail to take the dampening and warming effects of carbon dioxide into account; for example,  if heat rises due to excess carbon dioxide, then more clouds form due to the evaporation of water. Sunlight is then reflected this light, and cooling occurs. This just once such example of dampening and warming effects in action; in order to support the assertion that "carbon dioxide causes warming", you must have data documenting all of these effects, and taking into account each outcome of warming and dampening. You must show that the net warming is higher than the net dampening.

"[The fact that we know carbon dioxide has the capacity to absorb heat is] not a casual mechanism if it doesnt cause anything; you could considered a mechanism in the sense that it affects the overall effect of C02, but not as a casual mechanism of warming."
Yes it is, that's what a causal mechanism is; a proposed mechanism for action. Carbon dioxide's capacity to absorb heat is the proposed mechanism for its contribution to global temperatures.

author: Uzziya

text:
¬†@*****¬†

"A strawman is a deliberate misrepresentation or oversimplification of someone else's position. ¬†"

You are talking about the direct ability of C02 to trap heat as if it contributes to the conversation of global warming, almost as if nobody had accounted for it. Nobody contests this, and nobody cares about it.


"Cherry picking is where to pick one part of a piece of evidence but ignore the rest. You said that it was the same as not taking other variables into account."

...... you are literally claiming that a casual mechanism for changing the effect of C02 is a casual mechanism for global warming by ignoring the rest of the casual mechanisms involved.

"And a causal mechanism isn't something you can just give part of. "

I meant to say that you were giving a casual mechanism for a change in the effect of C02, not for global warming. It was clarified later.

"Even if everything you've said is true that doesn't change the fact that I gave a causal mechanism for how carbon dioxide can cause global temperatures to rise."

It is only a casual mechanism for global warming if you ignore all other effects of C02. CHERRYPICKING

""Citation needed. Not that it isnt true [carbon dioxide levels are not correlated with global temperatures]""

Okay this pathetic of you; you added words in the brackets into my quote to make it seem like I was denying an obvious fact. Thats strawmanning and misquoting all in one.

"Yes it is, that's what a causal mechanism is; a proposed mechanism for action."

Yes, but you are suggesting that this action is global warming, rather than an effect on the C02's effect on temperature. This has not been demonstrated.

¬†"Carbon dioxide's capacity to absorb heat is the proposed mechanism for its contribution to global temperatures."

That has not been demonstrated in any way; to call is a mechanism for something without accounting for all data is not science.

If you say that C02 traps heat, and therefore changes the effect of C02 by adding some warming, then I am right with you.

However, if you say that C02 traps heat, and therefore there is a NET WARMING (in other words, global warming), then I am not with you; it just hasnt been demonstrated.¬†

"We know that carbon dioxide increase is correlated with increasing temperatures"
Since your response was only "Citation needed. This is not true" without any context there was no way for you to tell which part of your response I was replying to so my edited version of your quote read as follows:
"Citation needed. Not that it isnt true [carbon dioxide levels are not correlated with global temperatures]"
I'm not misquoting you. You actually said that. You said that carbon dioxide levels were not correlated with global temperatures and that I needed to provide a citation.

"...you are suggesting that [the] action [for carbon dioxides ability to trap heat] is global warming, rather than an effect on the C02's effect on temperature. This has not been demonstrated"
I didn't say that, this is a straw man. Rather, I said that carbon dioxide's ability to trap heat combined with a statistically significant correlation with global temperatures is demonstrative of carbon dioxide's effect on climate change. We have a statistically significant correlation and a mechanism by which one variable can effect another, we have proof.

"[The claim by the scientific community that carbon dioxide's ability to absorb heat is responsible for climate change] has not been demonstrated in any way; to call is a mechanism for something without accounting for all data is not science"
Except that's not what a mechanism of action is. A proposed mechanism is just that, a proposed mechanism, it has no authoritative power on its own. Combined with appropriate data though it does. That's how everything in science is done. Experimentation and statics.

"If you say that C02 traps heat, and therefore changes the effect of C02 by adding some warming, then I am right with you. However, if you say that C02 traps heat, and therefore there is a NET WARMING (in other words, global warming), then I am not with you; it just hasnt been demonstrated"
Except it has. I just gave you two papers that did exactly that.

To break it down for the stupid;

My position;

1) One effect of C02 is trapping heat.
2) C02 is correlated with temperature.
3) The trapping of heat by C02 contributes to warming of some kind; whether it causes net warming has not been shown.
4) Correlation between temperature and C02 combined with a casual mechanism for warming is not proof of, nor is it evidence for global warming. The casual mechanism must contribute net-warming (in this case, C02's trapping of heat must contribute net-warming) to provide an explanation for global warming.¬†
5) You must show that C02 has a net-warming impact in order to demonstrate it as a contributing factor to global warming.

"What the hell is "net-warming" and how is that functionally different?"

Did you not read my first comment to you? I talked about the different effects of C02; dampening and amplification (better word than warming) of the direct effect of warming due to C02 trapping heat. Nobody denies that C02 traps heat; however the resulting cycles of dampening and amplification caused by this additional input of heat and the presence of C02 itself contribute to the overall warming or cooling. The direct effect of the trapping of heat due to C02 cannot be assumed to account for net-warming (the overall effect of the C02) without accounting for the amplification and dampening effects of the direct warming and feedback loops.

I gave the example of clouds being formed due to excess heat, and bouncing off sunlight; a dampening(cooling) feedback.

In order to make the case that C02's trapping of heat is causing a rise in temperature, you need to demonstrate that the warming it causes is not offset by dampening feedback loops. In other words, you must show it is responsible for net-warming.

¬†"We have a statistically significant correlation and mechanism of action by the definition of the word we causal relationship."

Except your mechanism of action is not representative of the entire effect of C02. What about the formation of clouds due to heat for example? Where is that being adjusted for? You have understand the other factors before establishing a casual relationship.

"These observations, together with transient global climate model simulations, support the conclusion that an antiphased hemispheric temperature response to ocean circulation changes superimposed on globally in-phase warming driven by increasing CO2 concentrations is an explanation for much of the temperature change at the end of the most recent ice age"
-Shakun, 2012
His model, of course, deals with what you call "net-warming" like all climate models. Which is why I was confused as to why you bothered to use that term at all since these are real world numbers and not those under laboratory conditions.

"CO2 and other molecules with a similar structure (e.g. O3, H20) insulate the earth.¬†This greenhouse effect keeps the earth‚Äôs surface temperature at a habitable level of about 14 ¬∞C (57¬∞F) instead of the temperature -19 ¬∞C (-2.2 ¬∞F) which it would have without the atmosphere absorbing the radiated IR. Thus, the greenhouse accounts for approximately a 33¬∞C (59¬∞F) warming (Le Treut et al., 2007). By trapping energy, the greenhouse heats the earth and its atmosphere by raising the radiative equilibrium"
-Jordan, 2013
Jordan then, of course, goes on to explain how the ability of carbon dioxide to absorb heat works on a global scale. He then goes on to say:
"The NIR bands of absorption in CO2 significantly affect the thermal budget of the mesosphere. NIR absorption by CO2 can contribute up to 30% of the total solar heating in the mesosphere... However, the inclusion of NIR parameters does not significantly change the model‚Äôs thermal response to a doubling of CO2; therefore, the radiative forcing not strong enough to have an overall effect"
Even with all possible perimeters covered it doesn't change anything; the effect remains the same. Carbon dioxide-based heating is primarily done in the upper atmosphere. Jordan's model shows that the exact amount of heating we'd expect to see if carbon dioxide was uninhibited is what we observe in current trends.

I didn't lie about what you said you edited your comment because you said something stupid. My original copy-paste portion is still there from my explanation of why I edited your original quote but the original is no longer there.

On a side note: that's not what a strawman argument is! Three times now I've had to explain to you how to use that term. In the same way a real straw man is a representation of a real man but a much simpler dummy meant to fool birds, a strawman argument is a deliberate oversimplification or misrepresentation done to fool people who haven't read the original passage. Lying about what someone says and a strawman are not the same thing. For example: "The big bang was an explosion of nothing that made everything" is a strawman but saying "The big bang was a star exploding and the universe came from that star" is just lying about what the big bang is. Holy shit you are stupid.

"Quote [five pages of a pdf document where you can't highlight and copy text directly] please"
I'm not going to quote five pages of a pdf document because:
1. Editing the document to where I can actually highlight the text at all is a pain in the ass. I'm not even sure that's possible since it looks like a scanned image to me.
2. It's five fucking pages! I'm not typing out five pages of crap just because you refuse to read the citation you fucking asked for.

"If you want to give me pages upon pages of scientific literature, you need to explain how it supports your position. I dont understand how it does"
I did explain it. You just can't be bothered to read the fucking source document so you want my explanation, the source and a transcript of the source. I've given you the first two but I'm not doing the last one.

text:
+Juan Valadez It used to be called global warming but they were way off with all the temperature raises(and i mean way off, right out the gate) so they just changed it to climate change. No events or facts will disprove this theory as the theory will simply change to become consistent with new data and speculation. CO dissipates so that's not really going to be an issue long term as fossil fuels will run out sooner rather than later. Moreover, there is way more vegetation on this planet now than ever before as humans bend over backwards preventing forests from burning down. Plants absorb CO. This whole concept has turned into a belief system which is why I opt out of "following" the theory. There are way to many variables to actually create a theory that will be anything close to true. Perhaps if everything was observed for about 300 million years I would consider simply believing a theory on this.¬†


For now, I just look at facts and any obvious correlations. For example, CO from emissions and CO being absorbed by the ocean is a huge deal. The video was misleading as anything above a PH of 7 is not considered acidic. However, changes in the equilibrium throws everything off. In the end it wont matter. Just like a fish tank, when something is changed it throws the balance off but then it adapts. You add a plant then the plant absorbs nitrates ammonia and CO. In this case algae may die off but fish may be more healthy. You add a bubbler, then it moves water to much at the surface causing CO to dissipate then the plant may die and nitrates and ammonia may go up causing a fish to die then a huge ammonia spike causing a bacteria bloom and you have cloudy water. If you do nothing, it sorts itself out.¬†


Anyway, my whole point is, within this theory they have lots of neat little correlations. Like the CO type from emissions from fossil fuels from plant matter. But that's all it is. There are way to many variables to connect little correlations with other little correlations. All murderers eat plant and/or animal mater. The plants and animals have very little correlation with the actual murders. Some but very little and changing those variables probably wont change the outcome. I eat plants and animals, I never murdered. BTW, one thing that is consistent is cooling periods. Not the time between them but the pattern that lead up to them. Id buy a jacket as 2016 will be the beginning of the next cooling period. (I bet someone takes credit for this by saying they cut emissions or something supporting climate change theory). Its all a sham.

text:

That's a common statement I hear from people who believe this is some sort of conspiracy.  The fact is that while the extent of the antarctic sea ice has been increasing, the total amount of antarctic sea ice and glacial ice has been decreasing.  What this means is that the ice is considerably thinner. author: zach korinis

text:
+vitas75 No. Treating ourselves as the main cause has been the Bain of the problem. We need to find solutions, both economically, and socially. We have to get off whatever we think is contributing, how ever severe, or slight. We have to replace it with something safer. We need to be very aware and self conscious of the people around us and how they are already going to have to deal with the effects, whether we reverse course or not. We need to consider preparing towns and cities for new types of agriculture and infrastructure to handle the changing weather. Postulating on prevention alone is a fools errand. If it is too late to stop any hand we had in it, we are better to be read to face the consequences. A good warning to serve us, should be the calamity that has befallen thus far through mudslides, floods, famines, and sea level rises of various countries around the world.
We should¬†start working on relocations, sea walls, changes to irrigation, and plans for emergency, all in addition to any attempt to curb the effects we suspect we have on the climate. Our attempts to phase out fossil fuels should be driven by passion for innovation, not fear. Fear slows things down, and even causes us to make mistakes. This is no time to be afraid. That comes later.

text: ¬†@tchevrier¬† Well there are certainly better ways to respond to the situation that can garner immediate action without the problem of what is currently going on. As it is, the reaction to climate change has been one of negativity and opportunity through inconvenience. I believe a better path forward would be to observe beneficial changes to make in adjusting to the ever changing climate in developed nations, then advocating those changes down to lesser developed countries. The¬†problem with stopping or solving climate change is that it cannot be stopped or solved, because it is ever occurring since the beginning of ¬†climates themselves. A motive spread in greed is greatly more powerful than fear in my opinion, and in my opinion, if marketed properly would be much more effective in achieving the kind of results the fear campaign has sought after. Climate change is inevitable. The degree to which it changes can be manipulated through greed in the right direction. Much easier to convince than fear. Especially so, when not everybody shares the same fear, as¬† evidenced by the fact of deniers, corporate interests, and subtle disagreement on cause variations. Even the producers of "It's Okay To Be Smart" could not mount an argument proper enough to quell dissident on climate change through the fear motive. Clearly there is a difference of viewpoint on rationale. If they would only approach the issue in a different direction, this would not be such a big issue as it is. It is not only the United States suffering from climate change denial, which is also a troublesome matter, since the USA isn't the only place being dramatically affected by it. author: Juan Valadez

text: +Juan Valadez Antarctic ice is different from Arctic ice. The Arctic is an ocean covered in ice,¬†mostly surrounded by land. The Antarctic is mostly land covered in ice surrounded by ocean. The Arctic has a regular freezing thawing cycle because the ice is in direct contact with the ocean. The Antarctic had a much smaller version of the thawing freezing cycle until the climate started changing at an increased rate. Fresh melt water ran into the southern ocean lowering relative salinity just a little and as you know fresher water freezes at a higher temperature than salty water. So in the Antarctic winter the less saltier surface water froze in larger area's because of the melting the previous summer. It took the scientists a little by surprise until they figured out what was happening and why. The extra Antarctic ice in no way invalidates the overwhelming evidence for CO2 driven climate change. In fact when you understand how it happens the extra ice actually reinforces the theory.
