¬†@hettygreene¬† Then I'll explain explicitly. No one disagrees that climate changed in the past. Both the rate and underlying reasons it is changing now present a concern when you look toward the future. So "it's changed in the past" doesn't take into account why the current situation is concerning.

No one disagrees that CO2 is a small part of the atmosphere, either. That doesn't forego an effect; temperature changes due to GHGs are subject to a positive feedback loop that magnifies their effect.

In other words, everything you're saying is already being taken into account by those with whom you disagree.

author: Patrick Merkel

text:
True, all the records of rising temperatures and sea levels and wild weather patterns could be completely fabricated, but I've actually been experiencing a lot of climate change where I live - like warmer summers and colder, rainier winters - and that's obviously climate change. Whether or not the climate change that I'm experiencing is spurred by global warming is another matter, but it's undeniably a change in the climate.
Also, back to my original point, from the research that I've looked at, the average global temperature has risen by 2 degrees celsius in the past century. The ozone layer has been depleting. The great barrier reef is not quite as great as it used to be. The Arctic ice has been slowly but undeniably melting. Sure, I've never been to antarctica and I don't have my own personal satellite, but if it makes me narrow-minded to believe the statistics that I've seen as opposed to assuming that climate change is some sort of hoax cooked up by the government for god-knows-what reason, then doesn't that make you a conspiracy theorist?

text:
Here's the biggest problem in the fight of climate change. Apathy. There is a strong resistance to change in the human mind. We like things to be predictable and steady, we like a routine. And the idea that we are changing things drastically is unpopular.

But an even bigger problem is defeatism. "I know that things are bad, but what can I do to stop it? I'm just one person, and one person never makes a difference." Well that might be true, but it you don't at least try, you definitely WON'T. We are the system and if we want to change the system, we need to change ourselves.

Bizarrely, the third threat to fighting climate change is annoyance. Within the past twenty years, going green has been the trend. Nowadays if you're not eating organic, grass fed, free range beef, people make you feel like a villain. Like you and your Big Mac and Coke are directly responsible for the death of the polar bears. We get nagged at so much in the modern world to be green that it is sometimes having the opposite effect. Instead of saying, "Oh crap, California is experiencing a drought of epic proportions that threatens the lives of millions!" the badgered Big Mac eaters say, "Screw California! If you don't like the weather there you can move somewhere else!"

text:
Ever since the whole global-warming fracas began, the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) has been fudging and faking evidence and statistics in order to give the illusion that there was proof of human-caused global warming.

This is well known, though unmentioned by our monolithic true-believer media, whose science coverage has become a mere church choir in the religion of eco-puritanism.

The IPCC have performed illegitimate and unjustified statistical manipulations; they have reworded reports after scientists signed off on them, and without their knowledge.

These are the kinds of things that you only do when you know that the evidence does not make your case. Nobody steals an election they've actually won.

Through all of this, they have insisted that human-caused global warming is a fact, and that anyone who resists it is in the same category as creationists and holocaust-deniers.

This namecalling is another confession that they haven't got the data to make their case. If you have the data, you don't have to call names. The science speaks for itself.

One reason they have been able to get away with this is the lack of data to contradict them. That is, the data we have had up to now did not say what they claim it said -- but it didn't say anything else, either.

That's because everything was based on computer models, and computer models are only as good as the data that is fed into them. The people running the simulations were all True Believers, and so they always came up with "results" that mirrored the biased data they had been fed.

But finally there is real data to feed into the computers. In a Dec. 18th Wall Street Journal essay, Matt Ridley reports on a conversation with Nic Lewis, one of the educated people keeping tabs on the global warming science issues for those of us who don't have access to the latest reports.

If it weren't for people like Lewis, we laypeople would have no choice but to believe the deceptions of True Believers like the IPCC. Lewis is part of the reason we know about the previous lies and manipulations by the IPCC, but no one denies that the deceptions took place.

Now, however, because Lewis is an honest observer, he reports that real data shows that there is a genuine statistically probable effect from atmospheric carbon emissions.

What genuine scientists, faithfully reporting their actual findings, now report is that the mechanisms claimed to cause global warming may in fact contribute to a rise in temperature -- but they do so at a rate FAR, FAR LOWER than that assumed by the True Believers.

We are finally getting a pretty good idea of the actual effects of carbon dioxide emissions. Comparing global temperatures over the past 100-150 years with the fluctuations in carbon dioxide emissions from human activities gives us -- at last -- a reasonable basis for estimating how sensitive global climate is to changes in carbon dioxide levels.

Keep in mind that carbon dioxide is far from being the major greenhouse gas. Methane is far more important, and the most important, water vapor, has such unpredictable effects that it is left out of all the models.

That's because water vapor, besides being a greenhouse gas, also forms clouds, which by their high reflectivity, bounce sunlight out of the atmosphere without converting it to heat. Storms also funnel heat from near the surface up to the higher atmosphere.

We have no way of predicting or modeling how much the albedo and storm effects balance with the greenhouse effect, nor even to what degree global warming would increase cloud cover.

As Ridley says in his article, "As one Nobel Prize-winning physicist with a senior role in combating climate change admitted to me the other day: 'We don't even know the sign' of water vapor's effect -- in other words, whether it speeds up or slows down a warming of the atmosphere."

Says Ridley, "Climate models are known to poorly simulate clouds, and given clouds' very strong effect on the climate system -- some types cooling the Earth either by shading it or by transporting heat up and cold down in thunderstorms, and others warming the Earth by blocking outgoing radiation -- it remains highly plausible that there is no net positive feedback from water vapor."

This matters a great deal -- the global warming alarmists' warnings absolutely depend on the idea that carbon dioxide's warming, if real, will then be greatly amplified by water vapor increases. But this remains entirely a matter of faith. For all we know, increased water vapor may be the ecosystem's natural way of damping down the effects of global warming -- whether that warming is astronomical or human caused.

We can now calculate with some reliability just what a doubling of the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere would do to global climate. "Given what we know now," said Ridley, "there is almost no way that the feared large temperature rise is going to happen."

Ridley quotes Lewis as saying that, assuming a doubling of CO2 -- the IPCC's worst-case scenario -- and even assuming "another 30% rise from other greenhouse gases by 2100, we are likely to experience a further rise of no more than" one degree Celsius.

Says Ridley, "A cumulative change of less than 2O C by the end of this century will do no net harm. It will actually do net good -- that much the IPCC scientists have already agreed upon in the last IPCC report. Rainfall will increase slightly, growing seasons will lengthen, Greenland's ice cap will melt only very slowly."

Historical evidence shows that global temperatures have been warmer than they are now, following natural cycles alone, in historical times. There seems to be a regular warming-and-cooling cycle, with cooling represented by the Little Ice Age of 1350 to 1850. In 1000 a.d., global climate was warmer than it is now.

The same cycle seems to have corresponded with the collapse of agriculture and population during the cooling phase in the late Roman Empire and through the Dark Ages -- a plague-ridden era like the Little Ice Age.

The historical evidence suggests that eras of global warming are natural, that they are beneficial, that they can best be called "good weather."

When you add to this the fact that all of human history has taken place in a ten thousand year lull in the great Ice Age that has dominated the last million years of Earth's climate history, and I, for one, wish that we could control and warm the climate through mere carbon dioxide emissions -- because when the major astronomical cycles bring back the Ice Age, our descendants will very much wish for a means of causing global warming on a vast scale.

Meanwhile, keep in mind that there is nothing unnatural about the carbon dioxide we release into the atmosphere. All the carbon in the coal and oil and natural gas that we dig or pump up from under the surface was once atmospheric carbon dioxide.

Carbon dioxide is fertilizer for all plant life. For millions of years, the coastal jungles of the dinosaur era sequestered natural atmospheric carbon dioxide and kept it out of circulation.

In effect, we have starved for CO2 for millions of years because all those plants selfishly drank up all the atmospheric carbon they could and then thoughtlessly died without returning it to the atmosphere.

We're only putting it back where it started.

And every serious climate scientist has to admit this fact: Whatever else our carbon dioxide emissions might be doing, they are definitely fertilizing forests and grasslands all around the world. Where humans are involved, that means orchards and grainfields.

If we really did reduce our CO2 emissions, it would cause a worldwide decrease in crop yields. That's a fact, not a computer model.

The real limiting factor should be this: The supply of oil and coal is finite. It was larger than the alarmists of the 1970s and 1980s supposed, but that doesn't mean that we will never run out. It is quite possible that in a mere two centuries of fossil fuel consumption, we will use up the entire supply of accessible sequestered carbon.

That, not groundless fears of global warming, is the reason we need to find other means of generating energy. Instead of worrying about carbon emissions, we need to search desperately for a means of powering our transportation and heating and cooling our habitations that does not depend on a resource that, once it runs out, is gone forever.

My fear is that because of all the lies and deceptions, all the oppression of dissent and nastiness of the global warming alarmists, the general public, once free of those delusions and lies, will think that all warnings and dangers are false.

In other words, we have been through three decades of massive wolf-crying about a nonexistent wolf, so that people won't believe in the need to deal with the real wolf of depleting resources.

We have a responsibility to future generations to leave them with the resources necessary to sustain a modern society. It is a sin to burn it all up when we don't have to. CO2 is a non-issue and always has been -- only the eco-puritans took it seriously and then foisted it on laypeople who trusted in "science."

The net effect of their falsehoods will be a loss of trust in real science, and that's a crime. Because there are dangers to the environment, and serious consequence from burning up resources that can never be renewed. And thanks to the global warming clowns, I fear that nobody will pay attention.

text:
There's so much malarkey in this video, it's hard to know where to start. Let's take something simple. We don't have any global temperature measurements before, at best, the 1980s. No one has any accurate global temperature measurements before that time, so any assertion to that effect is completely wrong. My proof? Well, if you can find the temperature measurements in Perth, Australia from the 1800s, let me know.¬†
In addition, the video makes no mention of the "Little Ice Age" which occurred from the 1600s and ended in the 1900s. So, when your measurement starting point is low, then it is not surprising that you will see a general rise.¬†
Even the C12 versus C13 is bogus. Why? Because almost 99% of all carbon on Earth is C12. Thus, it's not surprising that you find C12 in the atmosphere.

text:
2:15 -- The idea that our contribution of carbon dioxide is unprecedented in the last million years is fallacious. ¬†Proxies that go back a million years and beyond don't measure CO2 on century-wide intervals, and the smoothing put on the data would prevent it anyhow. ¬†We have no idea if there are any spikes in CO2 over that period of time.

Using proxy data like this is simply bad science. ¬†You cannot compare modern data measured over years and decades to paleoclimate data which is measured in thousands of year intervals.


2:30 -- Again, comparing paleoclimate data to modern data when there are different intervals and smoothing techniques is improper statistical analysis.


3:20 -- Natural simulations use models that were already built to hindcast CO2 and aerosols.  Obviously, if you take CO2 out of the equation of models that assume CO2 is the cause of most climate change, you'll get warming.  But, this is without just cause.  We've had much more forcings to do with warming, such as the continued prolonged high period of solar activity greater than at any point in 11,000 years (Solanki), as well as very high El Nino indices.


4:15 -- Oceans have risen 8 inches, but very little of that is due to human activity.  Sea level has been steadily risen for thousands of years.


4:35 -- Of all of the scare tactics for the oceans, this is the most incriminating of all.  People who believe in global warming refuse to accept much more viable alternatives for the lowering of surface ocean pH (which is NOT called "acidification" because there's nothing acid about the oceans).  Water pollution is a much more viable explanation for changes in ocean pH.  Additionally, ocean warming counteracts increases in atmospheric CO2 with it being less soluable in the warmer oceans.


5:20 - -"Yeah, we're just gonna have a bad time."  That is language for "I don't have a scare talking point for you."  The fact is that mass extinctions are related to cold periods and not warm periods, with one exception (P/T event), which was caused by enormous changes in temperature that even the scariest predictions don't go near.

text:
¬†@Brian Stuart¬† "We don't have any global temperature measurements before, at best, the 1980s."


That's just wrong, and I won't repeat what you can read here: http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/paleo/globalwarming/instrumental.html


About the Little Ice Age, what I would recommend is to go look at a graph of estimated temperatures from around 1000AD to 1800AD, and figure out how fast the rate of temperature change was before the little ice age minimum. As I recall it's no more than -0.2C/century. The trend in the last 40 years is about 1.5C/century. What we're seeing is about an order of magnitude faster than a typical natural shift in the climate.


Indeed, I could easily hypothesize that the "little" part of the little ice age is an anthropogenic result.
author: Jose S

text:
¬†@Jose S¬†¬†Okay, please tell me the temperature in London on June 2, 1850. What's the temperature in Perth, Australia, 1913?¬†

You don't know because there are no accurate records of it.¬†

So, how in the world can you tell me the global temperature in 1850 when you have only records of an extremely small area? According to the article you linked, they only had measurements in the 1800s (debatable). Only an extreme narcissist would think that encompassed the entire world.¬†
author: Brian Stuart

text:
¬†@Brian Stuart¬†¬†I get the sense that you think you need temperature stations in every remote location of the world, in order to build a proper record. That's not correct. You do need a good quantity of stations, to average out local noise (maybe hundreds of stations), and you do need reasonable global coverage.¬†

See, the exact temperature doesn't matter too much in analysis, but the observed changes in an aggregate of stations. I can't go over the math in a youtube comment, but there's a well-known methodology that works.
author: Jose S

text:
¬†@Jose S¬†¬†Well, your sense is wrong. The early 80s is when we started getting measurements from satellites. Those have been shown to be a lot more accurate than any ground based temperature reading.¬†

I almost laughed when I read your comment that "the exact temperature doesn't matter too much in analysis". Really? When climate dogmatic followers are talking about a less than a 1 degree increase per year, I am confused how you can assert that exactness isn't necessary. ¬†
author: Brian Stuart

text: ¬†@Brian Stuart¬†¬†It's not. Different stations can have thermometers that are not exactly calibrated in the same way. What matters is the changes from day to day, month to month. These are matched across many stations. You can get an idea of the Earth's temperature (~ 14 C) from station data, but that's not precise by any means. However, a 1C rise from a reference is quite precise. How do I know this? (I've done this, btw.) You can sample half the stations, and do the analysis, then repeat with the other half. The match will be very precise.
author: Jose S

text:
¬†@Jose S¬†¬†No, it's not accurate. You just admitted as much. If you don't calibrate your tools the same way, you won't get the same measurements. You can't just get an "idea" of the measurement, it has to be exact. That's how science works.¬†
When they build nuclear power plants, they don't just "get an idea" of calibrations. They are exact. When astronomers talk about stars, they try to get as precise as possible.¬†
Yet, you're saying that this doesn't have to be accurate? Why? Does meteorology have some sort of special status where "close enough" works?¬†
author: Brian Stuart

text: ¬†@Brian Stuart¬†¬†I think what I said was pretty clear. As a way to estimate Earth's temperature, it's not very precise. I don't know what the error is, but it could easily be in the order of 1C. As a way to estimate temperature change relative to a reference, it's very precise, and this can be confirmed statistically as I outlined.
author: Jose S

text: ¬†@Brian Stuart¬† The only malarkey is found in your outdated and long-debunked climate denial talking points. Please put a modicum of effort toward understanding actual reality by perusing peer-reviewed scientific literature instead of industry-funded blogs and Fox news. Really, just spend a few hours looking for actual information--not confirmation of your paranoid beliefs--and you'll quickly realize how things actually are in actual reality, where real things and events are happening.
author: Ryan M

text: ¬†@Ryan MacFarlane¬†¬†Wow. You're awfully arrogant. First, I have reviewed the so-called peer-reviewed literature. For the most part, it's unconvincing and full of confirmation bias. Second, being skeptical is a sign of good science. You who just accept whatever is tossed at you are the ones who who deny reality and events happening.
author: Brian Stuart

text: ¬†@Brian Stuart¬† No, I am correct. If you are unconvinced by the scientific literature, it is because you do not understand the scientific literature. The scientific literature is abundantly clear: the climate is changing, and anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are the primary cause. There are virtually zero qualified voices that disagree with this. There are many unqualified voices that do disagree with this.
author: Ryan M

text:
¬†@Ryan MacFarlane¬†¬†The fact that you assert that anyone who disagrees with you is "unqualified" illustrates your arrogance and ignorance. According to you, there is no room for disagreement. To illustrate how this is both arrogant and ignorant, let me provide an example. We have developed nuclear bombs and power plants based on Einstein's theory of special relativity. Yet, there are scientists who are right now trying to disprove it. That's how science works.

Not with your blinkered view that no one should ever disagree with you.¬†

Now, you assert that no "qualified" scientist disagrees with you. Despite the fact that the predictions based on your theory have not to pass (hey, look, there's ice in the Arctic), no one can explain the relatively lack of increase in global temperatures for the past decade, and the fact that it's been shown that supporters have repeatedly fudged data to get the results they want.¬†

Lastly, before you start blathering about 97%, the American Meteorological Society conducted a survey of it's members. Only 39% agreed with your hypothesis. I suppose the 61% of the AMS are "unqualified."¬†

You express a typical view of those who follow a dogma. Rather than enter a reasoned debate, anyone who disagrees with you must be a heretic.
author: Brian Stuart

text:
¬†@Brian Stuart¬† No, it's not that anyone who disagrees with me is incorrect, it's that anyone who disagrees with the facts and the evidence is incorrect. My opinion doesn't matter. Your opinion doesn't matter. The facts and the evidence matter. The facts and the evidence indicate that the climate is changing, and that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are the primary cause. When you disagree with the facts and the evidence, you are wrong, because the facts and the evidence are true regardless of your private perceptions.

In actual reality, where real things and events happen, 97% peer-reviewed scientific publications taking a position on climate change acknowledge anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions as the primary cause. The number of publications aligned against this position has never exceeded 0.2%. If you disagree with this, you are wrong, because to disagree with what's true is to be wrong.

Meteorologists are not required to take a course in climate change. Understanding climate change is not part of the NOAA/NWS certification requirements, and university programs do not require any relevant coursework. The opinion of meteorologists thereby doesn't matter. These people are weathermen; they understand cloud dynamics and pressure systems, and they predict local weather. They are not authorities on climate science. If you think they are authorities on climate science, you are confused.

Claims made against the overwhelming body of meticulously gathered evidence must be substantiated by equal or greater evidence. When it comes to climate change, this evidence is not forthcoming. It is certainly not forthcoming from you. That's just how things are.
author: Ryan M

text:
¬†@Ryan MacFarlane¬†¬†Well, if you rely on facts and evidence, then you'd have to admit that it is, at the very least, uncertain. The predictions and models are coming true and most of you climatistas cannot explain things like the pause or the increase in ice in the Antarctic. Then, as I pointed out, we have the NOAA fudging the data to make things work.¬†

Your so called "97%" has been debunked over and over, to the point that it's a punch line. The Wall Street Journal ran and expose on this and it's clear that the 97% is faked and circular.¬†

Also, consensus isn't science. The Steady State Universe was the consensus until about 1961. Even Einstein believed in it.¬†

Lastly, I must point out since you're making the claim, you have to prove it correct, which you cannot. I don't prove it incorrect.¬†

Nonetheless, it is clear that you bought into the dogma and regard it as a religious truth, like the firmament of the Earth.¬†

Good luck with that religious dogma.¬†
author: Brian Stuart

text:
¬†@Brian Stuart¬† The facts and evidence are not uncertain, they are as certain as scientific certainty can be. The scientific consensus has not been debunked, it has been confirmed by several other meta studies. Stop listening to the Wall Street Journal and start listening to the scientific literature. No investigative committee without a conflict of interest has found any evidence of forged or manipulated data. It has not happened in actual reality, where real things and events happen. Stop listening to industry-funded climate denial mouthpieces, and start listening to peer-reviewed scientific publications.

Claims made against the overwhelming body of meticulously gathered evidence must be substantiated by equal or greater evidence. When it comes to climate change, this evidence is not forthcoming.
author: Ryan M

text:
¬†@Ryan MacFarlane¬†¬†Stop listening (reading acutally) to a highly reputable news agency? Why would I do that?¬†

As to the facts being uncertain, is that why NOAA is constantly "adjusts" its numbers? Because those numbers are "certain?" Sorry, that dog ain't gonna hunt.¬†

Yes, real things have happened (or more accurately, not happened). For example, the Arctic is supposed to be free of ice. What happened? It still has ice. We weren't supposed to get snow in Washington, DC. Woops. We're supposed to have more hurricanes. Hmmm. We seem to have fewer.¬†

author: Brian Stuart

text: ¬†@Brian Stuart¬† Actually, we do have long-term global data. You're right in one way; we have better instruments now than before 1979 and before we relied on ground stations. But all the new ways of measuring , including satellite data (and learning to reconcile it with ground data) and paleoclimatology show that global temperatures have steadily climbed since the Industrial Revolution, and¬†the three warmest decades on record are, in order, the 1980s, 1990s and 2000s. Don't be surprised if 2010s are a new record.¬†The video also¬†referenced data since well before¬†the last major ice age (about 125,000 years ago) and indeed¬†referenced data going back¬†800,000 years. This easily encompasses the Little Ice Age, also known as the 1600s.¬†Also, yes C12 is the most abundant Carbon¬†isotope, but that is not what the video is saying. C12 and¬†C13 are the two most stable carbon isotopes so they are the easiest to use in earth science. They¬†can even used to measure and identify the¬†presence of ancient and more unstable carbon deposits, such as C3 and C4, showing the kind of environment it was created in. The amount (C12 is about 98%, C13 is a little more than 1%) is not¬†what is¬†in question, but the proportions in the atmosphere. And yes, C12 levels, normally stable, are rising.¬†No¬†single data point establishes global climate change. It's the agreement of¬†the various models,¬†the different ways we measure climate data from atmospheric radiation, hydrology, oceanography, paleoclimateology, organic chemistry, fluid dynamics and yes, historical meterological data.
author: Zeupater

text:
¬†@Brian Stuart¬†¬† You should stop listening to news agencies--reputable or not--because news agencies are not peer-reviewed scientific publications. You should start listening to peer-reviewed scientific publications because that is where real information is found. The world's peer-reviewed scientific publications agree with virtual unanimity that the climate is changing, and that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are the primary cause. That is how things are in reality.

NOAA and other scientific organizations adjust their figures according to the data. As new data comes in, it is incorporated into the broader analysis, returning new figures for publication. As this scientific process carries on, our insight into climate systems increases in sophistication, and our understanding of their behaviour becomes more certain. Utilizing this data, i.e., evidence, the conclusion of NOAA and all other major scientific organizations is that the climate is changing, and that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are the primary cause. That is how things are in reality.

Arctic ice is declining. Record lows are recorded year over year, and have been for decades. The process is not linear--some years will see more ice recovery in the winter, and less ice loss in the summer--but the overall trend remains down. Because of this reality, an ice-free Arctic in the summer is not only expected, but inevitable. That is how things are in reality.

Over and over again, the predictions of climatologists are proven correct, or they are proven to be underestimations as opposed to overestimations. Projections in CO2 concentration and its correspondent temperature rise have closely paralleled observations. Projections in Arctic sea ice decline fell far short of observations. Most notably, observed sea level rise between 1993 and 2007 far exceeded projections rendered by the 1995 and 2001 IPCC synthesis reports. If anything, the scientific community has been too conservative in their projections, and the climate is changing more abruptly than they anticipated. That is how things are in reality.

The bottom line is this. If we fail to act on climate change, hundreds of millions of people will be displaced, and hundreds of thousands will die. Food and water security will collapse in many parts of the world, and enormous populations will suffer under it. Conflicts will erupt as a result. If we do act on climate change, and if we do implement carbon neutral technologies which already exist and can be deployed at once, we can solve our energy problems without depriving anyone of anything, instead increasing the security of people around the globe. That is how things are in reality.

All of this as a response to a proven fact: anthropogenic climate change. You, in your ignorance and bias, would have us ignore the facts, to embrace industry rhetoric, and to idle on the most pressing issue of our time. It's because of your line of thinking that there is a disagreement between public opinion and scientific evidence, and it's because of this disagreement that much needed action remains idle. That is how things are in reality.

Make no mistake: you are on the wrong side of history. Every time large financial interests have tried to fight scientific evidence, they have failed, and the consequences of their distortion has been human security, life and liberty. That is how things are in reality.

text:
¬†@Dee Jay¬† If flaws were found in the data or the technique used to analyze it, absolutely. It would be dishonest not to. You see, scientists are always trying to prove themselves and each other wrong, and to find flaws in their own work. Entire careers are made out of that, and indeed it's what drives all scientific inquiry. It's through establishing what's not true that what is true is ascertained and refined.

Our ability to accurately assess data and render projections today is contingent upon the reliability of data gathered yesterday. Constant scrutiny is applied to decades-old data because this is how we increase the sophistication of our methods and our insights today. Indeed, apart from this scrutiny and refinement there would be more bias in today's observations, not less.

Which is more likely: that tens of thousands of career-dedicated scientists over the past century have been wrangled into a monolithic intergenerational conspiracy to dupe the world into accepting a global carbon dictatorship, or that a handful of extremely wealthy corporations have invested a tiny portion of their assets into a disinformation campaign with the aim of protecting their already-existing market dominance?

The latter scenario is not only more likely, but also supported by actual evidence.¬† Read The Climate Deception Dossiers: http://www.ucsusa.org/sites/default/files/attach/2015/07/The-Climate-Deception-Dossiers.pdf
author: Ryan M

text: ¬†@Ryan MacFarlane¬† So thermometers in the past always measured too high, and thermometers in the present always measure too low..  Interesting, and convenient!
author: DJ

text:
¬†@Dee Jay¬† Yeah, global temperature data is not gathered using drug store thermometers. The process is quite a bit more sophisticated than that. To understand what the climate is doing, it is necessary to measure air temperatures at different altitudes (including the high atmosphere using satellite sensors), at the ocean surface, ocean depths, ground temperatures, subterranean temperatures, and so on and so forth. This enormous body of data has to be gathered, assembled and meticulously analyzed to derive averages and trends. It has been an international effort involving thousands and thousands of individual scientists. Are you saying that thousands and thousands of scientists have thrown away their integrity to participate in a nefarious conspiracy? Why would they do this? To pay their mortgages?

Or is it more likely that five or six of the world's largest and most powerful fossil fuel companies have commissioned a handful of cranks to confuse the public and stall legislative action in order to preserve their multi-trillion dollar oil businesses? After all, we've seen that before: a five or six of the world's largest and most powerful tobacco companies commissioned a handful of cranks to confuse the public and stall legislative action in order to preserve their multi-billion dollar tobacco businesses. Indeed, some of the same people involved in yesterday's tobacco disinformation campaign are involved in today's climate disinformation campaign: http://www.ucsusa.org/sites/default/files/legacy/assets/documents/global_warming/exxon_report.pdf (Page 40, Table 3).

If it is your contention that the planet is not warming at all, and that all the data showing otherwise is fabricated, you have a lot of catching up to do. Even the most obstinate climate deniers have now accepted that the planet is in fact warming. They have accepted it because it has become impossible to ignore, and because it makes them look like idiots when they deny something that is obvious to everyone.

¬†@Dee Jay¬† When a given data analysis technique is found to be imprecise, and a superior technique refines the accuracy, correcting the values is both honest and necessary.

Climate denying mouthpieces gesture toward these corrections as dubious behaviour, and they get away with it because many people are too scientifically illiterate to understand how data is gathered and processed, or too married to their conspiracy theories to be receptive to actual information.

Previous measurements of Pluto taken from multiple vectors of analysis concluded the planet to be 2301 km in diameter. When a superior vector of analysis was achieved with the New Horizons probe, the value was corrected to 2326 km. That's how science works: findings are continuously updated and corrected as methodologies increase in sophistication.

text:
¬†@Dee Jay¬† Temperature data from ten years ago is accumulated from thousands of measurement devices all over the world. The data is gathered, analyzed, and averaged to yield the results and trends. When flaws are found in the manner in which the data was gathered, analyzed, or averaged, correcting those flaws produces new results, and the figures are corrected accordingly.

The IPCC 5th assessment report used data gathered from thousands of sources all over the world to find that the rate of warming had apparently slowed down. Just this year, NOAA found flaws in the methodology by which that data was gathered and analyzed, and their corrected values showed that indeed it had not slowed down.

text:
¬†@*****¬† For global temperatures to rise as much as they have over the course of a single century is outside the breadth of naturally-occurring climate change.¬† Naturally-occurring major climate shifts require hundreds or thousands of years to unfold on the global scale.

The "global warming hiatus" doesn't exist.¬† Studies published in June of this year have found errors in the data published in the 5th IPCC report. The IPCC report showed that warming trends had slowed to a rate of 0.039¬∞C per decade, leading to speculation about a "hiatus" or "levelling off" of temperature rise. In reality, data indicates that temperatures have been rising at a rate of 0.116¬∞C per decade since 1998, which is three times faster than previously thought, and entirely in line with earlier projections.

Studies reported by the IPCC in 2013 had suggested that global warming slowed or paused during the period of 1998 to 2012. More thorough research shows the global warming "hiatus" likely never happened, but instead was caused by a failure to account for cooler temperature readings collected by ocean buoys, whose presence in the oceans had increased during the same period. http://earthsky.org/earth/global-warming-hiatus-never-happened-study-says

Are you going to adjust your view to accommodate new and updated data, or are you going to cling to the old and outmoded data because it supports your existing beliefs?¬† It's up to you.

text:
Some people deny climate change and others realize that it's a reality, yet do nothing about it.It is true that most of the globes resources are used up by the minority living in developed welfare states, who are also responsible for most of the pollutants and the environmental damage caused. As thus it seems only reasonable for developing countries to demand some compensation. HOWEVER, this does not mean they do not have to make an effort for environmentally sustainable industry. They say that future generations learn from the mistakes of the previous ones; let's not make a repeat of what happened and is happening following the European industrial age.

There are 7.3 BILLION people on the globe!¬†It's the small things every individual can do that count. Here are a few simple things that EVERY one can do for the sake of the planet that's our and our children's home:

- Live in a city? Why not commute by public transit, even if its only a couple of times a week? Helps create jobs and saves big time on car expenses.
-Going shopping? Take a few reusable bags to carry your goods back home. Canvas or even the old plastic bags you used last time will do.
-Groceries? Make an effort to favor seasonal goods, especially in the produce section. Thing grown and produced nearby are often much more cleaner and you support the local community at the same time, even if you don't buy organic.
-Have a heater? Try dropping the temperature down a bit. Even a drop of one degree is significant and will definitely show in your next electricity bill.
-Or air-conditioning? Give the machine a break and throw open the window. The outside air is often times more cleaner than the recycled air flowing through your vents. ¬†
-Turn of the lights when you don't need them. Prefer natural light during day-time: it's much healthier for both your eyes and mind.
-Throwing out the rubbish? Try sorting your trash, even if its only between biodegradable(food stuffs and the sort) and mixed rubbish. Sorting out glass and paper helps with recycling.
-Got old furniture? Make a trip to the recycling center. One man's trash is another one's treasure, after all.
¬† ¬† ¬†¬†

text: While he is right that there has been a slowing in rising temperatures, he isn't right that it means climate change isn't occurring. These anomalies occur pretty frequently during any climate trend, and can be due to anything from variable solar output to a decrease in volcanic eruptions and to wind currents, and any number of factors. The fact is that human CO2 output is higher now than it has ever been, and even though the climate hasn't risen as dramatically as before for 17 years, we still have far higher temperatures now compared to 30 years ago. The pause in global warming is simply a temporary plateau that could be due to any number of reasons, and doesn't change the overall global trend.

An example of a theory is "Human Activity is causing a large amount of Climate change.". This is supported by the data, as we see that CO2 in the atmosphere is trapping huge quantities of heat, and we are the only ones producing enough CO2 to explain the amount in the atmosphere. text:
+Mandroid321

"Since the mid 1990's there has been no increased warming ti'll today, yet the Co2 concentration has nearly doubled. Explain that to me?"

Stop making stuff up.

There's been global warming over the past couple of decades, as observed in ocean warming, surface warming, warming of the upper atmosphere, and Earth's energy balance (i.e. comparing the amount of energy the Earth takes up vs. the amount of energy the Earth releases):

Atmospheric warming: 
"Sensitivity of Satellite-Derived Tropospheric Temperature Trends to the Diurnal Cycle Adjustment"
"Assessing atmospheric temperature data sets for climate studies"
"Comparing tropospheric warming in climate models and satellite data"

Surface warming: 
"Global Temperature in 2015" http://mahb.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/20160120_Temperature2015.pdf
"On the definition and identifiability of the alleged ‚Äúhiatus‚Äù in global warming"

Surface warming / ocean warming: 
"Possible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus"

Ocean warming: 
"A review of global ocean temperature observations: Implications for ocean heat content estimates and climate change"
‚ÄúAssessing recent warming using instrumentally homogeneous sea surface temperature records‚Äù 
http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WG1AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf ["Ocean warming dominates the increase in energy stored in the climate system, accounting for more than 90% of the energy accumulated between 1971 and 2010 (high confidence).[...] On a global scale, the ocean warming is largest near the surface, and the upper 75 m warmed by 0.11 [0.09 to 0.13] ¬∞C per decade over the period 1971 to 2010."]

Energy balance:
"Anthropogenic and natural warming inferred from changes in Earth‚Äôs energy balance"
"An update on Earth‚Äôs energy balance in light of the latest global observations"


This has led to many scientists saying that there's been no "pause" or "hiatus" in global warming:

"Has there been a hiatus?"
"Debunking the climate hiatus"
"Change points of global temperature"


Michael Mann himself feels uncomfortable with the term "pause", since it leads to denialists pretending AGW has stopped, when it actually hasn't. Mann also admits that global warming has continued:

"The rate at which the earth‚Äôs temperature has been rising eased slightly in the past decade, but temperature is still increasing; calling the slowdown a ‚Äúpause‚Äù is false."
http://www.meteo.psu.edu/holocene/public_html/Mann/articles/articles/MannSciAmApr14.pdf

"Making sense of the early-2000s warming slowdown
[...]
We do not believe that warming has ceased [...]
A point of agreement we have with Lewandowsky et al. 26 concerns the unfortunate way in which the recent changes have been framed in terms of GMST having ‚Äú'stalled', 'stopped', 'paused', or entered a 'hiatus'‚Äù. Just exactly how such changes should be referred to is open to debate. Possible choices include 'reduced rate of warming', 'decadal fluctuation' or 'temporary slowdown' ‚Äî all try to convey the primary mechanism involved, which in the recent example is likely to be internal decadal variability."
https://courses.eas.ualberta.ca/eas570/warming_slowdown.pdf

author: Joshua Feil

text:
You ask why facts aren't enough and answer it in a separate video. I disagree with your answer. The truth is that facts are NEVER enough for any conclusion on any topic. Logic dictates that a valid conclusion can only be drawn when sound reasoning bridges the gap between facts and your conclusion. Presenting facts and jumping to a conclusion is a fallacy.

I'd like to see a video where you offer logical reasoning instead of plain facts. It would be easy for someone to present as many facts as you did and reach the opposite conclusion, which is why your video isn't convincing. Can you weigh the opposing sides for why oceans are rising? Can you offer an explanation of how it may be caused by humans, how it may be caused by not humans, and why the explanation for "by humans" is more reasonable than "not humans"?

author: Juli Townsend

text: This video is likely to lead to cognitive overload for most people. Even for those with a strong scientific background, who are well-versed in climate science, there's a lot to digest in a short time frame. Also, the "transmission model" is well-proven to be ineffective for conceptual change. More effective conceptual change strategies involve getting learners to reflect on their own ideas in depth and use them to make testable predictions, so that they become aware of the shortcomings. "Did it change any minds?" "Are facts enough?" - unfortunately the answers are likely to be "no, and no". "Why do so many people continue to not believe in climate science?"... it is very likely that misinformation and lack of knowledge contributes (although it's likely not the only factor) but in order to be effective, education needs to target specific misconceptions. One. At. A. Time.

text:
This video fudges the facts. Sea level rise began long before our supposed "tampering" with climate. According to empirical scientific research, we're on pace to have about six more inches of sea level rise by the end of this century. The sea level rise needs to accelerate to agree with the hypothesis that greenhouse gases are causing catastrophic climate change. An empirical scientific test, and the hypothesis failed.

Temperature rise, according to data, halted about 15 years ago, as greenhouse emissions continued to rise. Another failure of the hypothesis when empirically tested.

Hurricanes, according to the hypothesis, should become both more intense and more frequent with the rising ocean heating. The empirical test results? Again, the hypothesis failed. Hurricanes (typhoons) have neither become more frequent, nor more intense.

There are plenty more tests that the hypothesis fails, these are but the tip of an iceberg.

text:
So much bullshit gets slung by the paid professionals in the Church of Catastrophic Anthropogenic Global Warming that one needs supersized muck boots to wade through it. ¬†Not to be outdone by the pros there are legions of followers who declare their faith, chant their catechisms and demand their pound of flesh from any who would truck with apostasy. ¬†What a revolting scourge this is, what a stain on the reputation of Science and Western Civilization that a cesspool dweller like Michael Mann is seen as a shining light of Enlightenment. ¬†Give me a f'ing break. ¬†And to give us all a break from the nausea created by these scientific hacks I give you the esteemed Matt Ridley.

"As somebody who has championed science all his career, carrying a lot of water for the profession against its critics on many issues, I am losing faith. Recent examples of bias and corruption in science are bad enough. What's worse is the reluctance of scientific leaders to criticize the bad apples. Science as a philosophy is in good health; science as an institution increasingly stinks.

The Nuffield Council on Bioethics published a report last week that found evidence of scientists increasingly "employing less rigorous research methods" in response to funding pressures. A 2009 survey found that almost 2 per cent of scientists admitting that they have fabricated results; 14 per cent say that their colleagues have done so."

"Last week, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a supposedly scientific body, issued a press release stating that this is likely to be the warmest year in a century or more, based on surface temperatures. Yet this predicted record would be only one hundredth of a degree above 2010 and two hundredths of a degree above 2005 ‚Äî with an error range of one tenth of a degree. True scientists would have said: this year is unlikely to be significantly warmer than 2010 or 2005 and left it at that.

In any case, the year is not over, so why the announcement now? Oh yes, there's a political climate summit in Lima this week. The scientists of WMO allowed themselves to be used politically. Not that they were reluctant. ¬†To squeeze and cajole the data until they just crossed the line, the WMO ‚Äúreanalysed‚Äù a merger of five data sets. Maybe that was legitimate but, given how the institutions that gather temperature data have twice this year been caught red-handed making poorly justified adjustments to ‚Äúhomogenize‚Äù and ‚Äúin-fill‚Äù thermometer records in such a way as to cool down old records and warm up new ones, I have my doubts."

"When a similar scandal blew up in 2009 over the hiding of inconvenient data that appeared to discredit the validity of proxies for past global temperatures based on tree rings (part of "Climategate"), the scientific establishment closed ranks and tried to pretend it did not matter. Last week a further installment of that story came to light, showing that yet more inconvenient data (which discredit bristlecone pine tree rings as temperature proxies) had emerged.

The overwhelming majority of scientists do excellent, objective work, following the evidence wherever it leads. Science remains (in my view) our most treasured cultural achievement, bar none. Most of its astonishing insights into life, the universe and everything are beyond reproach and beyond compare. All the more reason to be less tolerant of those who let their motivated reasoning distort data or the presentation of data. It's hard for champions of science like me to make our case against creationists, homeopaths and other merchants of mysticism if some of those within science also practice pseudo-science."

Truly despicable behavior from PhD's in Official Science. ¬†That is, those responsible for communications and journal articles, those who are appointed heads of organizations and those who interface with government.Ôªø

text:
¬†@eagleriver elder¬† Furthermore, it is equally ridiculous to suppose that tens of thousands of climate scientists are uniformly caught in the same confirmation bias, or that they've all got the science wrong in exactly the same way. If there were even a slight discordance between the findings and the reality, this would manifest as an upheaval in the scientific discourse. This upheaval just doesn't exist -- except from a handful of loud-mouthed contrarians, 100% of whom just happen to be on the payroll of the oil & gas industry and its vested interest in distorting public opinion about climate change.

It is correct to point out that science is not a consensus-driven process. Science is an evidence-driven process. When the evidence is overwhelming, however, scientific consensus naturally orients around it. For example, the evidence indicates that life is evolving, and that random mutation plus natural selection is the primary cause. There is an overwhelming scientific consensus around this fact, because the evidence supporting it is proportionately overwhelming. Similarly, the evidence indicates the climate is changing, and that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are the primary cause. There is an overwhelming scientific consensus around this fact because there is an overwhelming body of evidence to support it. When a consensus is supported by evidence, both the consensus and the evidence are extremely likely to be correct.

The only voices arguing against evolution by natural selection are those with something to lose: those receiving tax-free cash donations (i.e., government subsidized income) from congregations. The only voices arguing against climate change by anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions are those with something to lose: the corporations receiving massive government subsidies for oil & gas development, not to mention the massive profits accrued from the ongoing extraction and consumption of fossil fuels.

author: eagleriver elder

text:
¬†@eagleriver elder¬† That is not correct. Any decrease in pH constitutes acidification, and any increase in pH constitutes alkalinization. While environments below neutral pH are correctly described as "acidic", and those above neutral pH are correctly described as "alkaline", it is not correct to say that a decrease in alkalinity is something different from an increase in acidity or vice versa.

Ocean acidification describes any adjustment of ocean pH toward the lower end of the pH scale.

As the oceans absorb more and more carbon dioxide emitted from fossil fuel consumption, a process correctly described as ocean acidification (i.e., a decrease in alkalinity) occurs. This acidification encourages the formation of carbonate ions, and this subtracts from the availability of calcium carbonate to calcifying species, disrupting their biology and the food chain as a necessary consequence.

Ocean acidification means more CO2‚àí3 and HCO3‚Äì, which necessarily means less CaCO3, and fewer numbers of those species dependent on it.

http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/co2/story/What+is+Ocean+Acidification%3F

Of course, linking to NOAA--a credible scientific institution--is not likely to elicit either your reading or understanding of factual information, because in your world any source which doesn't align with your views is part of the so-called conspiracy. Others who read this thread will witness the robust immunity toward facts that's endemic to climate deniers, however, and this will serve to further subtract from their already diminutive credibility.

As for the desert/flooding analogy, it is plainly erroneous. The pH scale precisely describes the concentration or action potential of hydrogen ions in a given solution. The term "flooding" loosely relates to the saturation state of soil. There is no analogous relationship between soil saturation and solution neutrality. That you would suggest such a thing indicates a profound scientific illiteracy.

author: jl7986

text:
¬†@jl7986¬† The amazing irony is that those special interest groups have convinced him that the entire scientific community is itself a special interest group, and that he doesn't see the laughable implausibility of wrangling many thousands of career scientists across multiple generations and under dozens of national flags into one diabolical agenda.

To see that as plausible, and to conceive a handful of massively wealthy oil & gas companies investing in a PR campaign to exploit scientific illiteracy and generate distortion in the public conversation as somehow implausible -- it's baffling. Not only is there abundant evidence indicating this has actually occurred, it also has abundant historical precedent: business interests fought against medical science over tobacco, against materials science over leaded gasoline, against atmospheric science over CFCs, and so on and so forth.

It's similar to the manner in which creationists deny evolution, decrying the evidence-supported facts as implausible, and then asserting that a magic ghost creating the universe in six days somehow qualifies as a plausible and satisfactory explanation for the origins of life. The confusion required to think along these lines is just astonishing.

When it comes to evolution denial, very little harm comes from that belief alone. At worst, creationists will attempt to have that nonsense taught in public schools, and a generation of children will have their development delayed until they're older. When it comes to climate denial, however, a poorly educated and unaware population has major ramifications for the whole of civilization, an invites planet-wide economic, material, and human adversity that will persist well into the coming centuries.

Beliefs have consequences. When the beliefs of large numbers of people cause them to reject climate science, it has serious consequences for today, tomorrow, and for generations to come.

That is why I feel it's time to pass legislation against fraudulent science denial. When somebody denies scientific evidence in the media without furnishing equal or greater evidence to support their claims, and when it can be established they are doing this in the service of financial interests, it should be deemed an act of fraud and prosecuted according to the severity of its consequences.

Asking him to disprove your contention is asking him to prove a negative, and is a logical fallacy thereby. In the course of incorrectly identifying an ad hominem (no such fallacy occurred), you deployed a logical fallacy of your own. This kind of rhetorical collapse is all too common among climate deniers, and indicates a deficit in critical thinking skills.

Earth is round. Anthropogenic climate change is occurring. These statements are true, and do not require further debate. We know these statements are true because the evidence indicates they are true. When somebody disagrees with the evidence, they are incorrect, because their statements are not congruent with what's true.

text:
¬†@eagleriver elder¬† You are referring to the long-debunked Oregon Petition, which could be signed by anyone with a bachelors degree in an unrelated science, and contained signatures of individuals whose existence cannot be verified. It contained several names of deceased individuals, proponents of intelligent design, veterinarians, mining prospectors, and many other unrelated fields. 0.1% of its signatories had any background in climatology at all, and even fewer had an advanced background. The petition was organized and published by the George C. Marshall Institute, which is funded by Exxon Mobil. The formatting of its publication plagiarized that of the National Academy of Sciences in order to manufacture an appearance of credibility. Its cover letter was authored by Fred Seitz, a big-tobacco lobbyist who argued that the carcinogenic effects of tobacco were not a settled science.

There are not 30,000 members of the scientific community who reject the reality of anthropogenic climate change. In actual reality, where real things and events are happening, 97% of climate scientists identify anthropogenic causes as the primary source of present day warming. This real information comes from the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, the group which saw its publication formatting plagiarized by the Oregon Petition.

Because your ideas are unsupported by facts and evidence, you resort to the shill gambit and ad hominem fallacies. Because your ideas are not congruent with reality, you default to accusations and insults. It is the childish behaviour of someone who does not think or perceive correctly.

Everybody knows the climate has changed before, and everybody knows that it will change again with or without anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. This does not alter the fact that today's warming trend is anthropogenic, and that its continuation has major repercussions for the security of human civilization. This is the conclusion of virtually the entire scientific community, as supported by evidence and observation.

Even if it were true that today's warming trend is only marginally anthropogenic, and that other forcings are the major driver today (this is not the conclusion supported by the evidence), still it would be urgent for us to begin rapidly scaling back our greenhouse gas emissions. We know this is true because the laws of physics are such that more atmospheric CO2 and CH4 means greater heat retention in the lower troposphere, such that any naturally-occurring warming trends will be amplified by these and other greenhouse gases.

text:
+Robert Johnson 

"NONE of his 24 points explains why centigrade has LEVELED OFF for 15 years in a row even though CO2 is indeed going up."

There's been global warming over the past couple of decades, as observed in ocean warming, surface warming, warming of the troposphere (with the associated stratospheric cooling typical of greenhouse-gas-induced warming), and Earth's energy balance (i.e. comparing the amount of energy the Earth takes up vs. the amount of energy the Earth releases). Radiative forcing from CO2 has continued, as it did during earlier periods of global warming:

Atmospheric warming (tropospheric warming ans stratospheric cooling): 
"Comparing tropospheric warming in climate models and satellite data"
"Sensitivity of Satellite-Derived Tropospheric Temperature Trends to the Diurnal Cycle Adjustment"
"Evidence for an earlier greenhouse cooling effect in the stratosphere before 1980 over the Northern Hemisphere"
"Assessing atmospheric temperature data sets for climate studies"

Surface warming: 
"Global Temperature in 2015" http://mahb.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/20160120_Temperature2015.pdf
"On the definition and identifiability of the alleged ‚Äúhiatus‚Äù in global warming"

Surface warming / ocean warming: 
"Possible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus"

Ocean warming: 
‚ÄúAssessing recent warming using instrumentally homogeneous sea surface temperature records‚Äù

Chambers et al in a 2012 Geophysical Research Letters paper reports the presence in the long term records an oscillation with a period of 60 years, further recommending caution in using instrument records (meaning satellite altimeter and individual tide gauge) that do not cover at least 2 complete cycles of the oscillation.

In another 2012 paper, Boretti reported that even the satellite altimetry shows a deceleration in the sea level rise, consistent with a fluctuation as opposed to any acceleration. None of the empirical evidence shows an acceleration of sea level rise, let alone the impending catastrophe alarmists are shouting about.

text:
¬†@Aanthanur DC¬† "because for you, scientists giving scientific sound explenations are not reasonable."

Not at all.  But just because some PhD wrote a paper that was published in a peer review journal I don't genuflect to it granting it 'truth' based on those two facts.  I actually read the paper and pay attention to what it has to say.  From that, one can form an idea of its truth value.  Do you have any idea how much 'shit' gets published that is junk, that has very little truth value?  Every paper I've read that was given to me as 'proof' of CAGW has turned out to be 1.  Not read or read poorly by the referrer.  2.  Not saying what the referrer thought it was saying and 3. Not one of them offered proof of CAGW.  There is something that stands in for what you and yours do that should throw light on this.  Gavin Schmidt is an 'expert' in Climate, at least some say so.  He's affiliated with both NOOA and NASA.  He, through those institutions, released a press release stating that 2014 was the hottest year evuh!!  This was taken up by the press and touted with great fanfare offering 'proof' of the CAGW meme.  Even if it was the hottest year EVUH! that would NOT constitute PROOF of the CAGW meme.  But I think you and yours take it to be proof which suggests you and yours don't understand science and the notion of proof any better than a dim witted jr HS student in spite of your professed fealty to the principles of science.
But it wasn't true and Schmidt was forced to withdraw that statement a few days later.  Any honest scientist, that is, any scientist with a shred of intellectual integrity and any fealty to scientific principles would not have done what Schmidt did.  When you see that the numbers showed a temperature that was 5 times less than the error bar for the measurement, any good scientist would have declared that noise, and either made no statement, or the statement would be, 'our measurements fall below the error bars so we must conclude that the plateau continues.'  But that won't do for a True Believer like Schmidt.  One has an obligation to feed the useful idiots, to push the meme, to fight for the cause, to give fodder to the minions.  Every time I push on you YouTube CAGW warriors, this is what I get.  My skepticism remains intact despite the efforts of faux scientists, and 'experts' like Schmidt simply reinforce that skepticism.

"you must think somehow the experts around the world are [sic]conspired to lie about AGW."

Not at all...as I've said at least a 1000 times, most conspiracy theories reveal a type of intellectual laziness, and make assumptions that are unrealistic about other people's intelligence and their ability to coordinate.  No conspiracy theory required to understand how majorities can form around bad ideas nor to understand that your construction of the idea is sloppy at best.  The takeaway from your construction is that ALL 'experts' agree that not only is the planet getting warmer but that the driver is aCO2 and that the results will be catastrophic.  This is false.  Except to the True Believers.

'how come there is not even one scientific institution on this planet that rejects AGW?'

Rejects AGW?  Again, for one who insists you grasp the science your constructions are worse than a Freshman in HS.  That's really sloppy.  AGW.  Anthropogenic Global Warming.  What does that mean?  Do you realize that on a cool spring day if you fart you've just contributed to Global Warming.  How can you doubt that?  But once you accept that do you then go on to say 'everyone accepts AGW?'  Meaning everyone excepts CATASTROPHIC global warming being driven primarily by aCO2?

There is at least one institution that does reject the idea of  CATASTROPHIC global warming being driven primarily by aCO2 whose leadership tried to put out a statement in support of that notion until the members had the courage to stand up and tell the leadership to knock it off.  Again, you profess a belief in science and yet your thinking is as sloppy as someone who graduates with a degree in Women's Studies.  Have you read the statements of everyone of the scientific institutions on this planet?'  Do you know what they say?  Do you know how that statement was arrived at?  Do you know if they polled their membership?  These statements written by these institutions are not worth the paper they are published on nor the ink used to publish them.

And again, people who resort to references to authority are revealing how they process the world more than they are about the reality of that world.

text:
Both content and graphics are superb! As a science writer in paleoecology, I have one question with your pt #7. 400 ppm is the highest in more than 2 million years (as inferred from pollen data in Siberia and ocean sediment isotopes). The 800,000 years you show on your chart is simply as far back an ice record we can get by drilling in Antarctica -- so that is the oldest direct measurements. But paleoecologists reliably infer 400 ppm was during the Pliocene. Back then, there were conifer trees in what is now Siberian tundra and there were camels on Baffin Island. ¬†I produced a youtube video on this. Go directly to the section on Julie Brigham-Grette. The video title is "Hot Climate Women Scientists in Cool Places."

Keep up the great work -- and I am eager to watch how you handle part 2 of the climate issue: the psychological framework as to why people will not accept the science.

author: Matthew Linus

text:
¬†@Matthew Linus¬†¬†You don't get it, do you?
First some facts:
- Everything radiates black body radiation with a peak in different wavelengths depending on its temperature. Things also absorb energy depending on its albedo. (How much of the incoming radiation that gets reflected)
- Different things are transparent to different wavelengths of electromagnetic radiation (light). Water vapor for example lets through most visible light but not that much infra red light.
- When a planet has an atmosphere energy will be trapped inside the atmosphere due to the greenhouse effect (this is a good thing, since it would be cold and we would die if it didn't)
- The greenhouse effect can a bit simplified be explained as: When visible light goes through the atmosphere (since it is transparent in the visible spectra) and hits a surface of a planet it gets absorbed heating up the surface. The surface then release energy (cool) due to black body radiation. This black body radiation will usually have its peak in the infrared, and since the atmosphere is not as transparent in the infrared part of the spectrum, the IR-light gets scattered down again and heat up the surface again. ¬†
- Energy trapped inside the atmosphere will heat the planet. And if more and more gets trapped it will heat up more and more.
- The worst greenhouse gas is not CO¬≤... Water Vapor contributes a lot more.. That is the reason that our infrared telescopes are placed outside of earths atmosphere. (for example)

So what is the problem then?
The problem is that earth has a lot of water and when water gets heated it becomes water vapor. So the warmer the planet becomes , the more water vapor there will be. And the more water vapor there is, the more the earth heats.
This have been quite stable as long as the earth have been able to cool of in a fast enough rate, but if the CO¬≤ gets added in to the atmosphere, the stability shifts and and the planet heats faster. At the same time the albedo shifts when the ice (that reflects a lot of the light) melts.
So basically it wont be as easy as to "just get rid of the CO¬≤ and everything will be fine again".

An example of a planet where the greenhouse effect have went wild is Venus. That atmosphere have become around 100 times as thick as on the earth with a lot of greenhouse gases. I sugest that you think for a while if that atmosphere is something that you would want here on earth.

(This post might be a bit simplified. There is a lot going on with the albedo of clouds for example that might save us, but in general things are BAD!)

author: thewindowforest

text:
I'll talk off my elbows for a second here, and suggest that what we need to do is to find a way to shift the whole discussion around the main culprit for climate change. I suggest:

For us to stop trying to yank people off their addiction to fossil fuels and instead, find ways to make them addicted to renewable energies.

Because I think that we're¬†trying to replace fossil fuels for the wrong kind of reasons...

Right now, any new source of non-fossil energy presents itself as either a solution to climate change, or as a handy replacement for when fossil fuel reserves run out.
This wind turbine can replace this coal plant! With this electric car you replace that gas car! With this solar panel you don't need to worry about the sun running out soon! And so on.

But are these the right arguments one should make to convince people to leave fossil fuels?
Aren't we dreaming a little too small with those ideas?
Because by continuously framing things like this, renewable energies keep looking, at best, like a replacement for fossil fuels, and at worst, as an inefficient but necessary replacement for them. Something that we have to use we like it or not.
And so the solar panel/wind turbine/whatevs looks expensive, primitive, and as enjoyable as brushing your teeth or going to the doctor. It looks like "a¬†backup", a desperate solution, a resource you will be forced to use for when everything else fails.

And that's no way to sell the future to people.

So let us imagine, just for a moment, and just for the sake of argument, that renewable energy had been presented to us, not as a "replacement" for fossil fuels, not as a way to "save the planet" or "fight climate change", but rather, as an improvement beyond our good' ol gas engines.
Imagine if we thought of it as methods to obtain energy (and therefore, to get shit done) that not only does what fossil fuels do right now, but which can do even more than they could ever dream of.
And before you slam me about how renewable energies are "not there yet", let me tell you the kicker:
We've already done this.
There was a time when a new kind of technology appeared which depended on unreliable sources of energy, which was expensive and technical and which was barely able to do what your old technology did with ease. Yet it became the default source of energy for centuries:

Fossil fuels.

People didn't replaced farm animals for machinery because machinery was "necessary" or good for the environment. People didn't began using cars instead of horses because horses were a "bad habit" or because cars were "saving the world". People switched to fossil fuels in the first place because they were better. Because they allowed you to build, move and produce faster, bigger, and on a scale unimaginable at the time.

And I think we're missing the same kind of opportunity here.
So forget about how renewable energy competes with gas or coal, forget about how expensive or technical it is in comparison to what you're used to, forget the initial investments or the mountains of research still to be done. These were all the same kind of problems people had to deal with when selling gas or coal engines in the first place. And they won by framing it like this:
What do the new source of energy does that the old one cannot do? What does it allows you to do as a person, or as a society, that you were unable to do before?
What do renewable energies posses that will make fossil fuels looks not only obsolete, but barbaric?

Find THAT pitch, find that unfair advantage in renewable energy, and you can finally stop selling it like the backup or compensation prize that it feels like right now.
Find the unique characteristic that differentiates it from the rest. Stop competing with the old one, change the discussion and give people something they didn't know they needed before.
And as a bonus, we get to the save the planet.

author: John Prime

text:
I resisted my urge to unsubscribe, and decided instead to air some of my thoughts on the matter.¬† I am not looking the argue the merits of global climate change as a done deal, just show why someone like me doesn't care much about it.¬† I pasted the following from the notepad in which I wrote it. It was not proof-read. I didn't want to find myself re-wording and re-toning what came off the top of my head:


Hmm, why do people have trouble with the facts about climate change? Let's see, since the 1970s I have heard these predictions presented as though they were a fact. To name just a few:

1) We will be in the next ice age within 20 years (1970-72 global freezing)
2) The human population is now unsustainable, starvation will kill off most of our population in the next 20 years (around 1974)
3) "The oceans will be dead in 20 years" (Ted Dansen psa around 1990)
4) We will flat run out of oil in 10 years (around 1972 during the gas rationing crunch)

There are many others I haven't listed. Much of it fueled by the same human drive for recognition many people yearn to have, and a driving need for the media to be the first with bad news. And credibility in the global climate area of science has suffered to an embarassing degree. Right now, it sucks.

I love science. I enjoy reading layman's books by physicist and cosmologist, even geologist. I favorite all-time book on science is "A Short History of Nearly Everything" by Bill Bryson, a non-scientist but exacting author. In spite of that, I find the global weather alarmist community suspect.

Consensus means squat. It used to be a concensus that black holes were black, emitting nothing. It was a consensus that the universal expansion was slowing due to gravitational effects.¬† That there were four dimensions, one universe, or that the UCLA Bruins basketball team could never lose.¬† Consensus changes as facts continue to accrue. Global climatologist keep jumping the gun with pronouncements that don't come true.

Al Gore writes a book for profit on the subject, then helps design and carbon credit system to primarily make him richer.¬† People gripe about it from the comfort of their air-conditioned houses, on their electric-powered computers and global internet system.¬† They drive their cars, mow their lawns, consume whatever they want, and yelp that someone needs to do something.¬† The global weather science is caught on email fudging facts to keep the worry factor high (nothing to do with chasing grant money I suppose). Even the term "global warming" had to be replaced with climate change to give more room for error.

Yes, climate change may be coming more rapidly than ever before, but what are you personally going do about it?¬† High human population is the problem, right?¬† Are you going to give up all your conveniences and live down on a subsistence farm?¬† Are you going to demand that wealthy politicians do the same?¬† Will you eat at a near starvation level? Never drive an internal combustion vehicle again? Give up all plastics and other oil-derived products? Or any of the endless other self-depriving solutions?

Will you volunteer to give up your life to reduce the over-population?

I personally won't change my ways, but I really don't care about the potential problem. My life is nearing the end and it won't really affect me.

Is it even a solvable problem?¬† The human race has reach the current level of success by cleverly manipulating the evironment for it's own betterment.¬† At first it was a survival trait that helped make the species more persistent than it's competitors. Eventually that trait has become the drive to comfort.¬† Can we change to dump this behavioral trait? Is it genetically hard-wired into our behavior overall?¬† Maybe, just maybe, we should start considering the possibility that the human species, like all other species, has a limited life span too. Just saying.
