author: Aleks Myrene

text:
This is probably the best presentation of the issue I have ever seen. Neither treated like an idiot, or have someone speak with such a thick dialect of science (that is a dialect, try reading their papers on university level, makes no sense to mere mortals). But...¬†I need more data, to do anything about it though...

It would be nice to know if I eat 300 grams of beef (if there is a significant difference between countries/regions of origin, then put all the data and make it easy to search), or used one kWh of power made from coal and other sources (so I can make a localised calculation), or used 1 litre of petrol in my car, how does that translate into warmer temperatures? And this has to include production released gasses as well (example: refining oil to petrol and the chemicals etc. there are used to get the oil out of the ground).

I know this might be 10^-X kelvin (where X is maybe around 15-20?) crazy small stuff, but if I am ever going to change any pattern in my life until I have data to do cost benefit analysis with. No one ever just gives up everything bad, but most will make concessions based on informed non-forcefull options.

Also there needs to be more information on indirect sources of green house gas emissions. A random example (that might not have anything to do with reality): If I buy beef from Brazil, what are the impacts of supporting Brazilian agriculture, on driving people to turn the rainforest into farmland, since the rainforest eats CO2...

The only way to do anything about green house gasses is to inform consumers in a non-emotional way with data. If 2 products are equally good for the same job, but one hurts the environment more, then only an idiot would buy the product that does most harm, but the data and meta-data on this that I can find, is either useless or written in a dialect of science that no non-scientist would ever be able to read.

Driving a car full of people can often be better for the environment than using public transportation. But 1-3 people driving is a lot worse than public transportation (depending on the car). Hybrids are often challenged to meat more challenging requirements, which means they are far from always the solution.

We need to stop this good-and-bad-for-the-environment argument and tell people exactly how bad something is. Even if it take 10 years before it makes sense to them. Getting people to care is a long and slow process, and has to be done respectfully based on presenting useful and relevant data and not emotions (if you were emotionally invested in this, then you would already be convinced).

The value of something in raised temperature is something we need to introduce or nothing will ever really change.

author: SGlitz

text:
It is somewhere around this point in the discussion that the whole "talking off my elbows" starts to become evident, ¬†¬†@SGlitz¬†¬†, but I'll try to argue anyway just to give some answer to your comment.
My main idea is to take some inspiration from the times when fossil fuel engines (first coal to power steam engines, later oil to power gas engines) became a thing in the first place.
It is easy to imagine that this technology started off as perfectly engineered and efficient as they are today, but in fact, they were messy, highly inefficient machines when it all first started. I don't know if they were exactly 400% more expensive than a farm animal or a group of people pushing things together (the alternatives at the time); but I'm willing to bet early engines were, adding all the complications of these early prototypes, very, very expensive for the "little" work they could do in comparison to proven muscle-technologies of the time.

Right now we complain about how you need hectares of solar cells or wind turbines to replace a single gas generator, but such kind of complain reminds me of those days when people complained that you needed gas stations, roads, training and mechanical skills to own a car.
No new technology begins as efficient as the previous one. None. But they all hold something that the previous one lacked and which people required at the time. Cheapness and efficiency come later, not first.

So what is that "special something" about renewable energies? I'm not entirely sure. Maybe there isn't any. Or maybe there is and the time is simply not right yet for us to see how glaringly obvious it had been all along.
¬†¬†
But all and all, I find it it erroneous to think that renewables can compete with fossil fuels on a one-to-one match. They shouldn't even try to. Their advantages may lie beyond "simple" things like cheapness and efficiency.

At any case, it is not as if a different approach may hurt their already difficult case. I am, after all, just wondering here if we haven't approached this whole issue from the wrong end of the line.

author: Arturo Gutierrez

text:
A lot of people I have talked to that are climate change deniers tend to already see renewables as a superior improvement to non-renewables, but dislike incentives and funding from the government, claiming that climate change is not urgent and any programs surrounding it are fraudulent. I would argue that we are already trying to convince people the correct way; the primary source of false information is from news outlets. The reason this false information is continually being spread is due to a combination of confirmation bias and funding directly or indirectly from companies that have interests in fossil fuels. In many cases, there are unfounded and heavily biased attacks from all sorts of media on groups revolving around renewables. In addition, it seems that conservatives in the US are more politically oriented against climate change, which gives them a reason to fight against it, since people are willing to choose and support almost everything one of the only two available parties in the US. I believe this is because people are treating political parties like teams, and they would like the opposing team to loose, rather than for the correct action to be taken.

I like your analysis, but there are few people that would be dissuaded from their opinion from just explaining those things. Often times I find that after convincing somebody that climate change exists or that the advancement of renewables should be supported and funded by government, some time later they will completely forget and switch back to the opposing stance. So the issue seems much more entrenched in confirmation bias and the proliferation of new incorrect information that regularly seems to be generated among anti-renewable media figures, politicians, and professionals that are highly regarded, but have no expertise or knowledge about the climate.

text: "I believe this is because people are treating political parties like teams, and they would like the opposing team to loose, rather than for the correct action to be taken."¬† Yes, you are correct especially when it comes to the Democrats whose idea of "bi-Partisan" is "BY-Partisan" and they must have 100% of what they want and you compromise by giving it to them. text:
We can reduce our impact by implementing a cap and trade system of emissions to encourage the implementation of efficiency upgrades, especially if those upgrades are cheaper than a licence to pollute. Or we can introduce hard caps and fine violators (not ideal), or tax carbon emissions (also not ideal, but better than hard caps...bear in mind, none of these ideas is ideal, but some are better than others).

We also need to build more wind turbines, solar power plants, and find ways to reduce our overall power consumption. Of course, it'll still trend upwards, but if we slow the trend we'll do less damage in the long run.

We also need to push for upgrades in automobile fuel efficiency. Ultimately we need to get off of petroleum for automobiles, but in the short term adopting diesel engines and pushing fuel efficiency will reduce our impact.

We need to implement better land use ideas, including better management of grazing land so that the grassland's ability to absorb carbon isn't compromised. Reducing livestock methane emissions would go a long way too (yeah yeah, cow farts, go ahead and giggle).

There's a lot of things we can do, but it's ultimately up to citizens and lawmakers to decide what we're going to do and how we're going to do it. How fast we're going to do it and how much money we're willing to spend on it, is a question for policymakers.

Or groups of people will have to organize, like ranchers and farmers, and commit to more sustainable land use, and probably more profitable land use too. But those groups tend to be conservative, and for good reason, because if your harvest fails you're likely to default on the mortgage and lose the farm (and in previous generations, you'd starve). But if you can demonstrate that these methods are both effective and cheap, you'll get people on board. Those people will convince their neighbours and before you know it, everyone will be doing it.

Population growth in the third world is actually having a negligible effect on the climate. It's the 1 billion humans living a first world lifestyle that are driving the climate into a tailspin. But, it's possible to live a life as good as ours sustainably, we just need to convert our economy to use more sustainable methods of giving us the goods and services we require for that lifestyle. At least, that's what I believe.

text:
This didn't change my mind. It failed in a few ways (though I'm still a fan of the show as a whole!)

Correlation is not causation. Causation has not been proven, only correlation, but even then it has been 1400 years, according to this video, since the Arctic was so small. Were human beings burning fossil fuels then? No. Did the Earth (and humanity) recover? Yes. Was the world hotter 65m years ago in the reign of the dinosaurs? Yes. Were there significantly higher levels of CO2 then? Yes. CO2 is required to make plants grow. Animals were bigger then due to this, and the vegetation was lush. Eventually, the earth cooled, and many species died, but that is the course of the circle of life. Did humans cause the Earth the dinosaurs inhabited to be so hot with so much CO2 by consuming fossil fuels? I really don't think so.

The Earth will always be here. Species come and go as this occurs. Survival of the most adaptable. The earth goes through changes. Something I did find interesting in this video was the argument about the Sun not warming the uppermost layer of the atmosphere, and it being the lower layers getting warmer (where CO2 might accumulate). That is some intriguing information. Yet this video fails to address other planets in our solar system also getting hotter, and some scientists attribute that to the sun. Whether they're correct in that attribution is irrelevant -- sun activity is diminishing afterall -- but the fact remains that they are also getting hotter. Are humans burning fossil fuels on Earth causing that?

There's as much evidence for climate science as against. Climategate was a big deal. People did lie, for financial incentives and with political motivations. To chide "conspiracy theorists" and make fun of them early in the video, while funny, is a bit immature, not to mention an extreme display of sophistry. I understand YouTube videos need to be short, but the shortcut of telling us global warming evidence is overwhelming rather than proving it is lazy. Making a statement is not proving a statement. Then making fun of real people with real reasons for their real beliefs... that's low. Sophistry is not fact. It's just sophistry.

In short, this video suffers from: causation != correlation; sophistry; straw man fallacy; and many other logical, rhetorical, and philosophical blunders. If you're going to attack people, risking isolating a portion of your fan base, at least wear your big boy panties.

In the end, even if global warming supporters are 100% correct, we are not saving the planet. The planet will still be here, will adapt, change, and grow, whether we're here to witness it or not. This is all about saving humanity, selfish motivations out the wazoo. Carbon taxes... hmm... that seems like a great idea to reduce pollution. Money will certainly clean our air... wait, no it won't. Throwing money at a problem won't fix it. All the money in the world won't protect us from global warming (if it's true). At best, a carbon tax solution as proposed at present reduced the number of people consuming fossil fuels to only those who can afford it. That rate is adjustable, and thus the number of people at any given time consuming fuel is adjustable as well. This is not conspiracytardedness but rather an honest analysis of a proposed policy. But if only a small percent of the rich elite have access to fossil fuels... what happens to the rest of us in today's modern world, especially those of us in suburbs or rural communities?

text:
The important note is that sea ice is temporarily growing. It is due to complex short term whether phenomenon which will go away at some point and then we'll see the sea ice levels drop. All this is beside one very important point though: while the sea ice is growing (which is no longer true, it has decreased since this time last year¬†http://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/) the land ice (aka. ice sheet) is the important statistic. And that is what is actually decreasing (primarily in West antarctica but also incredibly rapidly in Greenland). The antarctic ice sheet is primarily going down although east antarctica is mildly bucking the trend for some reason, not nearly enough to compensate for losses.
[sources]
http://nsidc.org/cryosphere/quickfacts/icesheets.html
http://www.skepticalscience.com/antarctica-gaining-ice.htm

And another interesting note, the reasons currently given for the increase in sea ice are as follows:
i.) wind patterns from an anomalous strong low-pressure pattern
ii.) warmer waters melting deeper ocean ice, inhibiting mixing of different density water and fueling sea-ice growth conditions.

text:
Part of the problem, and I agree wholeheartedly with John Oliver, is that every time there's a debate, we give equal (or more) time to the opposition as we do the proponents. It creates a false air of uncertainty about the issue, when in fact most scientists know climate change is real and caused by humans.

Another factor is the current trend of extremism. Left vs. Right, Men's Rights vs. Women's Rights, Apple vs. Android. We live in a time where people tend to take one extreme and demonize the other instead of realizing that each side makes valid points. These people are unwilling to entertain ideas that might fall out of line with the rest of their group think, and they're unwilling to change their mind lest they be called a "flip flopper," admit they were wrong, or be seen to not have any conviction.

This channel poses the statement "It's okay to be smart," and that's fine. But being smart alone doesn't cut it. We need to realize that it's okay to be wrong, and it's okay to change your mind.

text:
¬†@paytontech¬† 


"There's no effort to cut to the root of the veracity of the arguments to draw out who's is most complete and authentic!"


There shouldn't be.  People should be able to draw their own conclusions instead of having the orthodoxy tell them "this is what you must believe."  An advocate will always claim that every statement he makes is unquestionably true and that his opponent should just be ignored.  And, indeed, this is what you indicate you want.


I am the audience.  I don't trust anyone.  If I detect that you want your opposition silenced, I will conclude that what you say has no merit.  And what I will find most convincing is if I can test your proposition myself.


If you tell me there is a consensus, you have committed a fallacy.  Truth does not care about the popularity of a proposition.  If you turn to say "peer reviewed," you should remember that any work produced by a religious orthodoxy is similarly "peer reviewed."  The keepers of an orthodoxy review to keep out heresies.  And I find it not the least bit surprising that a religion would don a lab coat and masquerade as "science."
author: John Undefined

text:
The problem is that people get their information from somewhere. Also, unfortunately, the education in the U.S. in particular (whether public or private) does not educate people to be able to analyze things honestly or comprehensively.

Claims are coming from different directions about different things. Any media outlet even pretending to be honest needs to make the effort to bring out the significant variables, mechanics, and dynamics concerning an issue. Bring out the "Left" and "Right" crap and calling it a day doesn't do it justice.

If you happen to believe most people are informed, or trained well enough to "figure it out on their own" then you're not well grounded in the reality on the ground.

As for your argument about science and peer review, it's a dead end straw man. How about this indiscriminate "truth" you speak of? How about some basic physics, chemistry and biology? How about actual science that addresses the actual science presented in this video?

Just because you may be able to "win" a debate doesn't make what you say true.
author: Kimoto

text:
¬†@paytontech¬†

"If you happen to believe most people are informed, or trained well enough to 'figure it out on their own' then you're not well grounded in the reality on the ground."

To the extent that people can't "figure it out on their own," you are only able to push forward just another religion. ¬†If people cannot come to a conclusion themselves, the only agreement you can possibly get from them is blind faith.

"As for your argument about science and peer review, it's a dead end straw man."

Calling it a straw man doesn't make it so. ¬†Do you dispute my observation that religious orthodoxies review works in order to exclude heresies? ¬†Do you dispute my observation that this is, in fact, a peer review?

"Just because you may be able to 'win' a debate doesn't make what you say true."

I'm not calling on anyone to believe something on the grounds that I said it. ¬†I am stating things that everyone here has already observed. ¬†It may be an inconvenient truth that you are only telling people to trust your review process, while denouncing the self-serving nature of the review processes of other groups. ¬†But we on the outside have no means of telling them apart, and no reason to trust yours.

The video starts off with the claim "this is what you need to know." ¬†I see that as a giant red flag. ¬†And if you can't see why, you have no hope of convincing me. ¬†And throughout the video, I can see that I am being called on just to believe. ¬†The biggest problem is that true believers won't even recognize that they are calling for blind faith. ¬†They just complain that people "aren't swayed by facts."
author: John Undefined

text:
Frankly, I don't care to convince you of anything, as it's obvious that there isn't anything that can "convince" you. You have your ego and identity built into this. The blindest man is the man who doesn't want to see.

I'll sustain my central requests: Give us your actual science. Address that. Give us YOUR scientific facts, not your semantics and pointless philosophical arguments.
author: Kimoto

text:
¬†@paytontech¬†

"The blindest man is the man who doesn't want to see."

Perhaps. ¬†But you are wrong in your claim that I have my ego and identity built into this. ¬†I have not been convinced by anyone's "side." ¬†I do not claim to know the actual reality behind the claims. ¬†Everyone who has claimed to "know" whether global warming is man-made has called for blind faith. ¬†I will, however, accept your assertion that you are blind because you don't want to see.

My observation is that there is no actual science involved. ¬†And you are just trying to "win by default." ¬†If I am correct demonstrate that you would not attempt to saddle my claim of "not proven" with "show me YOUR science."
author: John Undefined

You're here calling the science into question so I'm asking your for science. If you don't have any, then that's all the answer anyone needs. You claim there's no actual science involved, huh? OK, then what's the scientific basis for that claim?

You give nothing because you have nothing.

Since I actually acknowledge the facts in the video, my science is sitting right there above this little discourse. Bon appetit.

I am. ¬†More specifically, I am saying that no one is presenting science and that everyone is saying "trust me." ¬†However, since I do not take a stand on whether global warming is human-caused or not (only noting the tactics of the advocates) it is meaningless to call on me to demonstrate "my" science.

"Since I actually acknowledge the facts in the video,"

The video gives the dogma that you endorse, so you call it "facts." ¬†If I can't test it for myself, I will not be convinced. ¬†But you are going with "we say so" = "science."

The family itself is only 200 million years old.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garfish

Or maybe this 'Gar':

"Gars (or garpike) are members of the Lepisosteiformes (or Semionotiformes), an ancient order of ray-finned fish; fossils from this order are known from the late Cretaceous onwards."

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gar

There's only seven living species in the family.

"The goblin shark (Mitsukurina owstoni) is a rare, poorly understood species of deep-sea shark. Sometimes called a "living fossil", it is the only extant representative of the family Mitsukurinidae, a lineage some 125 million years old. "

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goblin_shark

"Living fossil" doesn't mean "completely unchanged".

"Tuatara are reptiles endemic to New Zealand and which, although resembling most lizards, are part of a distinct lineage, the order Rhynchocephalia.[2] The two species of tuatara are the only surviving members of their order, which flourished around 200 million years ago.[3] Their most recent common ancestor with any other extant group is with the squamates (lizards and snakes). For this reason, tuatara are of great interest in the study of the evolution of lizards and snakes, and for the reconstruction of the appearance and habits of the earliest diapsids (the group that also includes birds, dinosaurs, and crocodiles)."

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuatara

"¬†many species of ants and flies, fleas,"

Together with the four species of echidna, it is one of the five extant species of monotremes, the only mammals that lay eggs instead of giving birth. It is the sole living representative of its family (Ornithorhynchidae) and genus (Ornithorhynchus), though a number of related species have been found in the fossil record."

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Platypus

"The nautilus (from the Latin form of the original Greek ŒΩŒ±œÖœÑŒØŒªŒøœÇ, 'sailor') is a pelagic marine mollusc of the cephalopod family nautilidae, the sole extant family of the superfamily nautilaceae and of its smaller but near equal suborder, nautilina. author: Arvind Raj

text:
It's not that the planet won't be able to sustain life, or even human life. ¬†It's not that there's some risk of permanent 'damage to the planet'. ¬†It's not that the climate isn't supposed to change.
¬†The actual threat is this: ¬†Humans food production is heavily affected by the climate, the natural rate of change can be easily adapted to, rapid climate change can result in sudden shifts of weather patterns that has the potential to cause sudden and devastating loss of crops. ¬†Humans could do fine in a climate like that of the cretaceous, but the transition could be horrific.
author: skevoid

text:
¬†@STDrepository¬†¬†This might come as a surprise to you, but we're not dinosaurs and we're not plants. Really, you can tell by the lack of green in your skin.

Look around you. Humans have made a global network of trade to make sure we have a relative average of food and water. We are HEAVILY dependent on the stability of climate to keep this up. If this stability falls away, as we see happening, then the prices will rise, shortings will be more frequent and the spread of disease and hunger will follow.

It might not be the end of humanity, but it will be the end of life as we know it.¬†

text: I don't think climate change is necessarily going to throw humans off the planet. ¬†However the changes are so fast and dramatic they are already effecting planting seasons and water levels. ¬†So for me the issue isn't "will there be any humans" it is "Will there be modern civilization". ¬†These effects will cripple economies in ways that are not easy to counter. ¬†As Miami sinks into the ocean (if this goes on unabated) where will those people go? ¬†As farmers find that they can't grow the crops that they once did, how do we get farmers to move north to areas where the crops will grow? ¬†As droughts get worse, wars will be fought over water. ¬†These things are already happening, and are projected to get worse. ¬†This is why the defense dept lists climate change as a major threat to the US. ¬†I don't think climate change will kill us, we will do it to ourselves because of climate change.

author: Djorgal

text:
It's not the volume of CO2 or the average temperature that's the problem. After all, lots of plants and animals live in the desert and in the polar regions. The problem is the speed at which the climate is changing. In the past, these changes would take millions of years. The industrial revolution happened, what? 200 years ago? It doesn't give plants and animals any time to adapt. Find new food sources, find new places to migrate to, develop the genes for different coats and colourings, etc.

Add to that there are 7 billion mouths to feed, and changing climate means growing food, which is already difficult, becomes a big problem.

author: noctbot

text:
Only the ice-core data suggests the current CO2 level is 'unprecedented' but the ice-core is most likely not an accurate representation of ancient CO2 levels. There are a host of problems with the ice-core that can lead to the ice-core misrepresenting past CO2 levels such as fractionation processes like gravitational compression which can force CO2 up to the surface, the formation of clathrates which explode like tiny grenades when the ice-core is decompressed which create micro-cracks that can potentially taint the original air, different solubility coefficients of gases with CO2 being absorbed by frozen water in the ice-bubbles at a disproportionately greater rate than other gases, and measurements that have been inappropriately adjusted after the fact. The original ice-core measurements from the likes of Neftel 1982 showed CO2 as high as 500ppmv but these measurements were later arbitrarily deleted from the recorded as explained by Jaworowski presumably as to align with Callendar's interpretation. Other paleo-climate data such as stomata shows that atmospheric CO2 is highly variable over millennia and is not 'static' as the ice-core suggests but varies continually in accordance with a host of environmental parameters such as temperature and biomass. Stomata shows CO2 as high as 459ppmv. Also we have over 90,000 chemical measurements complied by Georg Beck showing CO2 reaching 440ppmv as far back as 1880 and these direct CO2 measurements correlate nicely with changes in temperature as would be expected with Henry's law. I am not meaning to suggest that the ice-core data is useless, but I think it would be unwise as to interpret it as a reliable representation of past CO2 levels, especially when it is in direct conflict with other data and has obvious flaws.

This video has been uploaded by people who have not really investigated this subject thoroughly and are just mindlessly parroting the same old fashionable memes it seems to me.

Third, look back at 800,000 years ago when things were this CO2 heavy. What do you not see? That's right, human infrastructure! If a massive hurricane sweeps through an area when there's no humanity, the animals might lose a few in number but they just go right back to doing animal things. Humans, however, lose infrastructure and systems of support, we lose stored food, we lose services, we have much tougher periods of recovery right along with financial losses out the wazoo.

Sorry I thought that was mentioned in the video, but was only in a roundabout way. Chlorofluorocarbons also deteriorate the ozone layer along other gases that react with O3. author: Max Mitchelson

text:
¬†@Max Mitchelson¬†¬†That's incorrect (mostly). CO2 does not directly react with O3 (ozone). CFC's and HFC's do break done ozone for long periods of time, but CO2 does not.

It does have an indirect effect in vast quantities, in the lower atmosphere it slows the creation of ozone, but in the upper atmosphere it actually increases the production of ozone by preventing NO2 from breaking down the ozone.

AND, ozone is a greenhouse gas, so reducing the amount of ozone in the atmosphere would actually slow down global warming. It would also make incidences of skin cancer sky-rocket and there isn't nearly enough ozone to have a meaningful effect should we scrub it.

But yeah, there is very, VERY little correlation between CO2 and ozone, and zero when you try to compare them both to climate change.

text:
No matter how much we (humans) mess up, life will almost certainly find a way. Whether it's climate change or nuclear war or whatever catastrophe you can imagine, life on Earth has survived worse: many species will go extinct, many others will survive and evolve and fill in the niches that were left vacant by the extinct species.

One of the reasons climate change is a big deal is that current climate (or rather, pre-climate change climate) is rather convenient for most current life forms here. But if we change it, we may need to ask ourselves how appropriate it is to modify the temperature of an entire planet, which would result in the extinction of many species. People who argue that humans are still part of nature have a good point, but as sapient agents, it's necessary to question how 'good' it is to do this.¬†

text:
The climate changes, yes it does. The Earth is warming, yes it is. CO2 is a greenhouse gas, it definitely is. Humans have been emitting CO2, yes we have. Human activity has an effect on climate, most assuredly.¬†

However...

Talking about the consequences 100 years in the future is pure nonsense. Such predictions assume "if this goes on", and the one thing we know absolutely is that things do not go on without changing. With the rest of the world industrializing, the price of fossil fuels is going to be rising, and rising a lot; that is basic supply and demand. As those prices rise, alternative energy becomes price competitive. It is already the case that a homeowner in the US will save money by installing a solar system for electricity. As people switch to those alternatives, economies of scale kick in which make them even less expensive. Technology improvements compound this effect. It is highly likely that within 20 years, solar power and other alternatives will be SO much cheaper than coal, that nobody will be using fossil fuels for much more than plastics. And that puts to bed the scaremongering of what will happen in 100 years.

Ocean iron fertilization could quite easily pull the excess carbon out of the atmosphere and convert it to marine life, not incidentally also thereby reversing the acidification. Concerns about resulting harmful algal blooms can be mitigated by not concentrating the iron fertilization but dispersing it much more, drone balloons lightly dispersing atmospherically for instance.

Cloud seeding could easily reverse any short term warming spikes... Etc..

The problem with the global warming enthusiasts that the deniers rebel against is that the issue has been largely hijacked by people with a political agenda that runs counter to what they hold quite dear. Their reaction is motivated by the emotion that engenders. The global warming enthusiasts exhort that we must restrain human ambition, that we must curtail the industrialization of the third world and roll back our own, that in essence we must grant the state even greater power to impoverish us. Given that their reaction is emotional, it is not surprising that often their statements are irrational. But portraying them as solely tin foil hat loons to be mocked, as does this video, is frankly insulting.

The ecology lobby does NOT have the last word, they do NOT have the right answers, there IS another side to all this.

What should we do? We should invest in the science of things like cloud seeding and ocean iron fertilization, which right now is being actively opposed by those very ecologists who are sounding the alarm bells (remember what I said about a political agenda). We should be spending at least as much pushing the R&D of energy alternatives as we are spending doing military R&D. The budget for E-ARPA is less than 10% of that of DARPA. Bumping E-ARPA to DARPA levels would cost less than what we spend on peanut butter, and would have vastly more effect on the future than global carbon taxes or attempts at legislating industrial curtailment.

text:
Good video-

Just one clarification, since the point about lower atmospheric warming (but no warming in the "upper atmosphere"- by which you mean the stratosphere and higher) is not quite correct. We do indeed observe tropospheric warming and stratospheric cooling, but it's not because greenhouse gases are confined to the lower atmosphere. For a well-mixed gas like CO2, the mixing ratios are fairly uniform with height up into the stratosphere (of course the total number of molecules in a volume goes down, just like with any other gas, because density goes down with height). But CO2 is increasing aloft as well. Because of this, the upper layers become more efficient at emitting energy to space, while receiving less infrared flux from lower down, where absorption is going up. This is a critical signature of an enhanced greenhouse effect.

Doublespeak is language that deliberately disguises, distorts, or reverses the meaning of words. Doublespeak may take the form of euphemisms (e.g., "downsizing" for layoffs, "servicing the target" for bombing), in which case it is primarily meant to make the truth sound more palatable (Like "affordable care act"). It may also refer to intentional ambiguity in language or to actual inversions of meaning (for example, "climate Change" Oh no! not that!). In such cases, doublespeak disguises the nature of the truth. Doublespeak is most closely associated with political language.
All Hail the Ministry of Truth! :)

author: Nichan M. Neto

text:
I don't doubt human caused global warming, but still, three things you said jumped out at me...

1) You said the upper layers of the atmosphere remain cool.
2) You said the sun's output of heat has been dropping.
3) You said computer models of the climate which focus only on natural factors predict global cooling.

So, it sounds like what you're saying is that our CO2 emissions over the past century have actually spared us from the disaster of a global cooling event. And that would make sense, given that the Human race came up in what may have been only a brief warm period of the Pleistocene ice age... which may not actually be over yet.

Who's to say all this won't even out in a century or two, if this natural cooling trend were to ramp up in tandem with our human-made warming trend?

But even if it doesn't, I'd much rather live in a world with higher sea levels, and higher summer highs, than in one where you have to go to the equator to get away from snow flurries in July and August, and brutal, endless winters.

Also, Why bother at this point, trying to get everybody to believe in human caused global warming when it obviously has too much momentum for us to stop or even slow down even if we eliminated all CO2 emissions forever tomorrow?

People will move inland, and toward the poles as soon as things on the coasts and closer to the equator become sufficiently intolerable, and not a day sooner. ¬†But after they do this, we'll presumably be fine... at least climate wise.

author: IstasPumaNevada

text:
I understand your confusion...but it is confusion.¬†

There are natural cycles, observed over many decades, that impact temperatures in the short term (not climate...which, by definition, is about long term trends).

For example, El Nino / La Nina which is a transference of heat between the lower atmosphere and the oceans (one gets warmer, the other gets cooler) impacts temperature in a given year.¬†Solar flares which change the amount of solar energy (heat and light) that is directed down to earth can impact temperatures as well.

The point is, DESPITE these short term cycles pointing toward what SHOULD be a cooling climate in the short-term, we're seeing warming in the short term...and an overwhelming amount of evidence that there will be more warming in the long term. And the kind of warming that NASA, NOAA, MIT and many climate scientists are predicting doesn't sound pretty.

There's no reason anyone has identified to expect cooling in the long-term that we need to "fight" with more warming in order to remain in balance.¬†
author: Adam Levy

text:
¬†@iamihop¬† I think you are confusing knowing what technology is needed and actually having the tech. Sure, we know for large parts how to survive on the moon. But even if we fast track it, it could be over a hundred years of R&D before we have a stable colony, anywhere.

And what I am trying to hit home is that ocean life is dieing. The increased acidity is dissolving the shells of animals that need calcium. We know this is a problem, but people dont seem to like it because it wont directly effect them. People* are lazy and only want to do something if it directly benefits them. Sadly, not drowning to death, or starving, are succumbing to tropical diseases in a temperate area of the world dont count as direct benefits.

The main reason why scientist say: "this and that could supposedly happen..." is because we are charting unexplored areas. We dont know what is going to happen, but pretty much 100% of our scientists, the best and brightest of humanity, agree that it isn't going to end well if we do nothing.

No, I dont like fear mongering. But we should be afraid of this very real and very direct threat. I could tell you of all the things that could happen. But from a strictly scientifically point, I would have to claim it as a possibility and not a certainty, even if it is very likely.
But I can tell you, it won't end well if we keep going on.

I myself was very skeptical of the imminence of the danger. It was only until last September when we started investigating the oceans for our Geochemical Cycles course that the facts really started to sink in. Our whole class, usually a very joyful and friendly bunch, couldn't and cant stop talking about it.
Learning of the importance of the oceans was, for me, the turning point. And I am still trying to find words to best emphasize their importance.

PS: sorry it got a little long, really just find it important to explain this.


*: I am describing an average behavior of people, not a specific one for everybody.
author: Azivegu

text:
¬†@iamihop¬†
¬†boy do I feel silly now. I revised my text like three times to make sure it was understandable to someone who isnt in geology xD.
The real concern for me is the stability of gas methane hydrates (GMH) in ocean sediments. It only takes a slight¬† temperature change to make the crystal unstable and dissolve. There are two lighter sides (if you look at it in a very obscure way): the rising temperatures wont affect deep or intermediate ocean right away of course. So that could give us an extra 100 to 500 years. And the increase of sea level increases the pressure too.
That not so fun side is that basically the USGS has done (ballpark estimate) 80% of the research on GMH's. When we made a Stella Model, we didnt have good numbers for anything.
When we tried to calculate the production of GMH there was only 1 article that we could find that gave us something we could use. And even that was with a wide margin.
(for the article, look for: F. S. Colwell, S. Boyd, M. E. Delwiche, D. W. Reed, T. J. Phelps and D. T. Newby, ‚ÄúEstimates of Biogenic Methane Production Rates in Deep Marine Sediments at Hydrate Ridge, Cascadia Margin‚Äù Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 2008, 74(11):3444. DOI: 10.1128/AEM.02114-07.)

But killing of 8 billion people would be hard. But loss of coastal lands, degraded farming (droughts, flooding, soil depletion, saltification), ocean dead zones and acidification increased temps, water scarcity and go on and on. We are seeing deaths from climate stress (climate factors and social unrest due to climate) which could probably kill off 70 to 90% of humanity (again, a ballpark estimate). Wouldnt be everything, but it wouldnt be hard to end human life on earth. We will probably be hit by an asteroid we where no longer looking for. That would be a kind of dark humor.

My real concern is that we just dont know enough, and that when we do, it will be too late. Maybe a bit outdated, but if I where to have kids, I don't want them to live in an Interstelleresque kind of world, where starving to death, or the black lung are legitimate causes of death.

PS: Also maybe important, I am in my second year of Earth Sciences. Not an expert yet, but University does like to grind new information into you.

author: Azivegu

text:
¬†@iamihop¬† I'm sorry, but I have to interject on the very first statement you made, regarding "we currently have the technology to survive on the moon". I must say that is completely false. I study aerospace engineering, specifically astronautics. One of the many scientific reasons why the world has not returned a human to the moon or elsewhere since 1972 is primarily due to both solar and cosmic radiation. In fact, Apollo 16 just missed a coronal mass ejection when they returned to Earth. The Apollo astronauts were lucky, plain and simple. The entire surface of Mars (once similar to Earth, with flowing water) has been BLEACHED by these charged atomic particles traveling at light speeds over billions of years due to Mars' lack of a magnetic field (unlike Earth). Can you imagine what this constant stream of particles would do to tissue and DNA, when we are pondering an indefinite lunar base? The ISS (although still shielded by Earth's magnetic field) has been such an asset in the testing of new technologies and materials that would protect astronauts for future long-term deep space voyages. However, there is still no current technology that can positively shield astronauts from cosmic radiation, and this is one of the primary reasons NASA refuses to send more manned moon or Mars missions in the near future. 


This is but one of the MANY concerns regarding long term space missions, let alone indefinite. While water has in fact been found on the moon, it is so minute that it would take enormous effort to harvest enough to sustain a permanent human foothold. You also have to find a way to get around the enormous lack of gravity when compared to Earth. Our bodies are designed for Earth, that is to a specific pressure and force being exerted from all angles. When you are in space or on any other surface with anything but EARTH's specific gravity, your bones and tissue will deteriorate! This is why any proposed deep space mission must CREATE artificial gravity (such as Mars Direct). What about food? What about healthcare? Wouldn't you want some sort of entertainment on the moon if you are living there forever, to prevent insanity?¬†


Bottom line. We aren't ready for manned long-term deep space voyages. There are just too many risks and dangers associated with it. However, will we be in the future? I have no doubt that humanity will colonize other worlds - that is if humanity doesn't destroy itself first.

text:
Aside from the well known example of Rapa Nui there have certainly been other civilizations that have died out due to their own actions (the possible disappearance of cannibalistic cultures due to prions, or the agricultural contribution to the downfall of Hopewell culture come to mind). Then there are the countless peoples who have been wiped out by war (internally or with neighbours). We humans cull our numbers expertly. More interestingly and to the point, humanity as a whole seems to have nearly vanished due to famine roughly 150,000 years ago. If our numbers are sufficiently reduced it won‚Äôt matter whether or not the entire planet is inhospitable to us (which was the initial point I was making).¬†

As you‚Äôve noted, rising sea levels could definitely become a problem for humans. But if a large enough portion of humanity were wiped out due to an inability to cope with extreme weather (plus famine and civil instability/violence), then you‚Äôre right, the remaining humans could easily move inland with other populations there. However, massive influxes of refugees is a bit of a hard thing to deal with in the best of times. Some projections put the number of displaced people as high as 1 billion due to sea rise. There will be no accommodating that many migrants.¬†

Again, I‚Äôm not saying I think humanity is screwed. Effects of climate change can be mitigated, and there are still many variables that we do not fully have a handle on. Our current level of technology and social organization is unprecedented and this could be enough to save us. But I think it‚Äôs a dangerous hubris to ever dismiss the possibility of humans going extinct.

I found this section on the wikipedia page on Human Extinction to be interesting: ‚Äúwiki/Human_extinction#Observations_about_human_extinction‚Äù¬†
And you may be interested in the wiki page on ‚ÄúSocietal Collapse.‚Äù

Next week: Asteroidal impacts and super volcanoes!
author: Centregeist

text:
I never claimed humanity would go extinct from climate change. My original statement in reply to another's comment about the acidification of the oceans was that, "much of the human world as we know it will end before the world becomes too inhospitable for us" and that we would "end our own world" (by which I did not mean a complete biological extinction). I later stated that its hubris to think humans won't go extinct and noted that this has already almost happened.

I do agree with you that our large and wide-ranging population is a huge factor in our survivability. This point falls right in line with the unprecedented levels of technology and social order that I mentioned.

Regarding rising sea levels I never implied a situation of masses of screaming people racing away from 100m waves or anything. Crumbling infrastructure and social disorder would lead to the migration. Of course the sea level isn't going to rapidly shoot up over night. But imagine more situations like Hurricane Katrina with even less social support. Repeated cases of that will definitely unsettle things. And yes, increase in severe weather is an anticipated outcome of climate change.

I should mention that I had to learn about disaster mitigation and climate change in courses at my university as part of a program in public planning. The material I had to know, drawn from leading experts all indicated something very different from your suggestion that we can expect to "out-build" increasing frequency of natural disasters. The "food riots" and mass migrations are scenarios that are taken seriously.

BUT, ultimately, if I'm asserting anything concrete, I'm only asserting these things:
1) Humanity is not certain to last forever,
2) and we could die off without climate change,¬†
3) but I don't think climate change helps our odds.

Again, I am not saying that we WON'T survive climate change (to whatever degree it occurs). I'm saying we can't ignore it as a real threat.

author: Ken John

text:
It's not a poll. It's called a meta study. A study of studies, if you will. It goes like this:
Climate scientists conduct studies of the factors that contribute to climate change.
Some other scientists come in and conduct a study OF THOSE STUDIES. That's the study that gives you your 97% figure.

Something else to note: The scientific definition of "theory" does not mean the same thing as your definition of the word "theory." Anyone who disagrees with the Universal Theory of Gravity is invited to step off a cliff to validate their claims.
author: Justin P

text:
+Ken John

"5 studies come up with a 97% consensus? Did the 5 studies start with the 97% as a target? One has to ask what is the odds that 5 studies come up with 97% Not 99, not 75 but exactly 97% I smell a rat."

If you stopped being intellectually dishonest and actually read the research in question, then you'd know that not all the studies came up with exactly 97%. This was due to differences in the methods of each study. Sometimes the percentage was 96.7%, sometimes 96.7%, sometimes 100%, etc.

Seriously, read the paper I cited to you.

"He won't read any of the papers. He's satisfied getting all his 'news' from fake producers and sticking with his false information, rather than allowing himself the opportunity to conceive that he might have been wrong all this time."

Yup. I'm used to it at this this point.



"Hell, Brendan Nyhan and Jason Reifler's paper 'The roles of information deficits and identity threat in the prevalence of misperceptions' provides some interesting findings on how conservatives are resistant to facts when they oppose their strongly held views."

Thanks for pointing that out. There are ideological forces on the right that have led to a stronger rejection of science on the right than on the left? Basically religiously-based/socially-based conservativism led to denialism on evolution, embryonic stem cell research, etc. And fiscally-based conservativism led to denialism on anthropogenic climate change, the health risks of smoking and second-hand smoke, the role of CFCs in depleting the ozone layer, etc.

For further discussion, see the discussion (and empirical testing) of Chris Mooney's ideas in:

"Politicization of Science in the Public Sphere: A Study of Public Trust in the United States, 1974 to 2010"
http://probeinternational.org/library/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/Apr12ASRFeature1.pdf

author: Sergio Vera

text: The issue is that clouds don't just form in moist air, they form in saturated air, so it's not self-evident that a moister atmosphere becomes a cloudier one. What's more, as Azivegu mentioned, clouds have competing effects on the planet's energy balance. The distribution of clouds, both in the vertical and in latitude, matter a lot, in addition to other issues like whether you have ice particles or liquid, etc. So it's complicated.
author: Chris Colose

text: to add to what other people are saying, phase changes in water (liquid to gas in this case) are different when there is stuff dissolved in it, since ocean water contains a lot of dissolved minerals and gases (the latter of which is increasing) it takes a lot more energy to make it evaporate.

author: Aundalius

text:
Here's your problem. Water evaporating does NOT guarantee clouds. Clouds need very specific circumstances to arrise. You have to evaporate off the water and then rapidly cool it as it ascends in order to get cloud formation. The types of clouds you get are affected by a number of different variables, most of which I no longer remember but that's digressing.

The bigger issue is, water vapor is ALSO a potent green-house gas. So you pump CO2 into the air which traps more heat. This increased heat generates more water vapor through evaporation. This increase in water vapor in the air traps even more heat. And you cannot guarantee cloud formation from it.

So I see what you were hoping for, but it doesn't necessarily pan out. We asked that same question of our climate science teacher, so it was a good guess!

And as to your last part, the fact of the matter is that CO2 is what we have the most control over. Whether or not you're tired of the arguments about CO2 is irrelevent because that's where the argument is. The other greenhouse gasses certainly matter, but CO2 is what we are most responsible for.

I have a science degree majoring in biology and minor in botany. Before I did my degree I was in the army and also worked in construction with my two brothers who are carpenters. text:
¬†@zach korinis¬†¬†People breathing has absolutely nothing to do with AGW. Nor does what people eat have anything to do with AGW. You are displaying a complete ignorance of the biological cycles, of which carbon cycle is a small part.

What you eat and what you breathe is simply cycling carbon. Cycling carbon doesn't cause AGW. What causes AGW is throwing that carbon cycle out of balance by disrupting the leg of the carbon cycle back into the soil.

See you are confusing the very real effect agricultural production models have on climate with what the consumer eats. Production models that lead to soil degradation are the problem, not the consumer eating the food. Change the production model and restore the soil carbon and you can actually eat your way to mitigating AGW. In fact since it is scientifically proven that increasing soil organic matter increases agricultural productivity, you could even support more people eating even more food. The key though is changing the production model to one that maximises the carbon cycle back into the soil. In fact do it on enough land and it will even offset fossil fuel emissions.

text:
¬†@Erik¬†¬†Hi, I am a geocosmochemist graduate student. I study meteorite geochemistry and cosmodust. I have researched core samples oxygen isotope records on both poles and seen the frequencies of 18oxygen isotope to 16base oxygen. I have assisted with paleoclimate analysis of hard shell calcium carbonate temperature sensitive marine organisms. I have reviewed probably over a hundred papers on various proxy climate records. For my undergraduate thesis I analyzed tree rings and C14 analysis in sedimentation of vast bodies of preserved prehistoric organisms. On top of that I have looked at micromarine sediments in peatlands on elevated regions; heavy igneous rocky mountains. I have a plethora of experience in this field although I am not working in it (my work is far more complex) I can understand it.

Unfortunately in any good science paper you will hear the OTHER story. That is, if you aren't trying to disprove what you are trying to prove, you are just trying to prove something. This holds ZERO countability and reliability in the science realm.

I also don't care what other scientists do, what I care about is the science and if you would like to talk about that, I would love to share my passion. Those articles discuss hottest on record but don't talk about El Nino; post RRR atmospheric activity deflecting westerly winds. They don't talk about axil tilt or solar cycles. They don't discuss flaws in ground system thermometers or how we analyzing a system so complex that we can't even monitor reliability through our mounts of ignorance. As well..where is the discussion of 200 of years of data (roughly 70 yrs of good data accumulation) on a 4.56 billion year rock? How on earth can we conclude anything?
NASA talks about acidifying oceans? We are talking about a .03/1.0 trace gas that is going to make a 8.1 (+1/-1) alkaline hydrosphere go basic? I am going to look into the math but I don't think we have enough CO2 molecules in our UNIVERSE to do this, let alone our atmosphere. NASA talks about shrinking poles? I have NEVER heard this, every paper I have read says the opposite beside one small part of Antarctica which has been breaking off due to glacial expansion and harsh solar linear activity (dating preindustrial revolution). ¬†

author: Erik

text:
The proof that man-made CO2 is causing global warming is like the chain of evidence in a court case. CO2 keeps the Earth warmer than it would be without it. Humans are adding CO2 to the atmosphere, mainly by burning fossil fuels. But maybe as importantly, by degrading the ecosystems responsible for returning that CO2 back into the earth/soil. And there is empirical evidence that the rising temperatures are being caused by the increased CO2.¬†

One way of measuring the effect of CO2 is by using satellites to compare how much energy is arriving from the sun, and how much is leaving the Earth. What scientists have seen over the last few decades is a gradual decrease in the amount of energy being re-radiated back into space. In the same period, the amount of energy arriving from the sun has not changed very much at all. This is the first piece of evidence: more energy is remaining in the atmosphere and/or being reflected back..
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2011GL048794/abstract
http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v410/n6826/abs/410355a0.html
https://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg1/WGIAR5_SPM_brochure_en.pdf

For our next piece of evidence, we must look at the amount of CO2 in the air. We know from bubbles of air trapped in ice cores that before the industrial revolution, the amount of CO2 in the air was approximately 280 parts per million (ppm). In June 2013, the NOAA Earth System Research Laboratory in Hawaii announced that, for the first time in thousands of years, the amount of CO2 in the air had gone up to 400ppm.
http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/gr.html
http://www.climatecentral.org/news/co2-400-ppm-global-17485

Now that is pretty secure, because it is directly measurable. CO2 is rising, and the Earth is retaining more heat from the sun than emitting. However, while the basics are secure, there is some room for debate as to why. Obviously CO2 emissions are coming from fossil fuel emissions and a few other things.But that's happened before. Why wouldn't the plants just suck it right back out. After all increasing CO2 generally makes plants grow a bit faster. That's more complicated. See about 40% of the planet land surface is affected by agriculture. Most the "prime agricultural" land is already in production. So to understand why the ecosystems that typically would have sucked that CO2 right back out, we really need to study agriculture. For example, we know the great tallgrass prairie of North America no longer exists at all. ~98% destroyed, mostly to grow corn and soy. Similar situations can be found all over the globe. So how does this effect climate? Well, the answer is, it depends really. First you lose the natural ecosystem function, then you add the artificial agricultural ecosystem that replaces it, and compare. In some cases certain agricultural practises might improve carbon sequestration over the natural ecosystems they replaced, but as a general rule MOST agriculture has been done in such a way as to reduce the carbon sequestration potential of the land. Even cutting emissions to 0 wouldn't work because the sinks are damaged.
http://blogs.uoregon.edu/gregr/files/2013/07/grasslandscooling-nhslkh.pdf
http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2005/12/1209_051209_crops_map.html
http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/only-60-years-of-farming-left-if-soil-degradation-continues/
http://www.grazingbestprac.com.au/research/grazing/AGEE3851%20Grazing%20management%20impacts%20in%20north%20Texas%20v12011.pdf
http://sri.cals.cornell.edu/conferences/IRC2014/booth/SRI_climate_smart_rice_production_%20handout_2014.pdf
http://www.thesolutionsjournal.com/node/1261

So while the issue really is a complex one, a few things are immediately obvious. 1) We are burning fossil fuels which adds to atmospheric CO2. 2) We have largely destroyed the most productive ecosystems on the land surface which are carbon sinks, and replaced them with artificial agricultural ecosystems that function much differently, usually reducing the carbon sink potential. 3)There are alternative artificial agricultural system that can function as sinks, even bigger sinks than natural ecosystems.

So if currently we are adding CO2, and reducing the amount of the CO2 sink, but we know how to increase the sink, why aren't we doing that? Why the ultra leftist campaign against fossil fuels when we have a solution to the extra fossil fuel emissions already? (change agriculture to a bigger sink than even the natural ecosystems they replaced)

Denialism gets you nowhere but planet earth on slow boil. But you don't have to submit to the extreme leftists either. Impossible for their solutions to work anyway. The only real solution that saves civilization is change agriculture.
author: Red Baron Farm

text:
Yeah I don't necessarily believe all the 'doom and gloom' hype surrounding climate change. The 'greenhouse effect' science is dead-simple to understand - I learned about it in my 3rd grade science class back in the late 80s. What isn't so clear is what the long-term effects will be, and honestly I think the apocalyptic predictions are just as much about marketing and scare-mongering as religious apocalypses are.

It seems very obvious and easy to understand, to me, how an increase in greenhouse gasses leads to an increase in trapped heat on a global scale. CO2, water vapor, methane - it is trivial to verify, personally, that these are indeed greenhouse gasses - so trivial a child could put together an experiment that proves it. It is also trivial to understand how our use of fossil fuels correlates to an increase in atmospheric CO2 when you come to understand combustion products - another 3rd grade science topic. When you burn something containing carbon, you oxidize it - and that carbon has to go somewhere. Since there's none left in the remaining ash, it must have escaped in the form of gas. This is trivial. I don't understand how people don't get it.

text:
¬†@Erik¬† I am not sure how to conduct this conversation. 130years and an average of 1.5d F in temperature. This is well within natural variability. I think the issue with where I am sitting is that I am submerged in research. I am aware of the uncertainties in research. For many people who aren't scientists or haven't conducted research, they often look at scientists and their papers as factual. The thing is, it isn't and that is my whole point. I don't believe in the factual basis that is being thrown around right now. You either believe that our industrial by-products are the leading cause of the current climate variability or you are a baboon. This case is absurd. 

I don't even know where to begin because it is extremely hard for me to believe data. You can link me a heavily cited ice core record paper and I will at it and see -70/+70y variability with spill over (that can't be accounted for in data variability analysis). You can link me a geochemical analysis of surface water levels in Australia and I will see concentration bias via secondary factors that were not looked at (because of funding publication e.g. deep sea gas expulsion). You can link me a chart on carbon ratio concentrations in lower atmosphere which points to an archaic atmosphere and I won't even care. Because a) so what? b) this proves nothing & c) what is the chemistry of a notch higher atmosphere and why wasn't this accounted for? 

Heck you could link me a paper on glacial melt and I will ask a) why is glaciers growing (on average) b) why would their breaking have to do with temperature vs surface area pressure & c) if they are breaking because of temperature i) how do you know this ii) show me your experiment iii) how do you know the heating was due to human activity? 

My point being, as a skeptic and as an objective scientist I don't like interpretation.Singularities are my game. So when I see climatologists who smooth graphs and make strong conclusions based on their data..I have to do a face palm. But it is even stupider as they win awards, get more grant money and policy is built on their research. Let me tell you, geometric secular variation in ionosphere storm nucleation..not as pretty sounding as "humans are fucking up the earth, eh." But anyways, my point is..I am skeptical and when you ask me for "evidence" of human activity not causing the currently climate well......my evidence is my skeptical opinion based on issues with conclusions of the scientists own lab data

text:
I'm glad that some scientist is challenging it here. With any bold claim (such as AGW), the first response must be "Prove it". Proof is not "we know all these fancy things, trust us". That is statistically invalid, with confirmation bias being primary. Proof is "I have this equally bold prediction - do you agree how different this is from the null hypothesis?" Then everyone tests said prediction and is forced to accept the result as strong evidence. This has not happened (the major predictions have all been way off the mark), which to me is strong evidence that these leading "scientists" have NFI. Then you factor in things like unannounced revisions of raw data - see https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/feb/08/no-climate-conspiracy-noaa-temperature-adjustments-bring-data-closer-to-pristine - this is what I consider to be a Data Science Crime. There is no excuse for altering raw data - but you are very welcome to publish an additional "improved" series. It all looks much the same as Economic "Science", whose predictive power is best demonstrated by the whole "no-one saw this coming" of the GFC. But don't worry, both Climate Scientists and Economists will continue making bold predictions!

One day I'll have a bucket of funds from my endeavours, and I'll ensure that actual science is performed on a bunch of important subjects. I like science and scientists, and I strongly dislike salesmen in labcoats who call themselves scientists. My ideal team would have a believer, a denier and several who don't know but really want to discover the truth.

author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text:
+Paul Stringini

"So yes, a debate in which 97% of scientists agree can be a very hot debate."

Nope. It's a manufactured controversy, where people pretend that there's more scientific debate occurring then there actually is. This is a typical tactic of denialists, whether they be AIDS denialists, creationists, or anthropogenic global warming (AGW) denialists:


"This article examines three cases that have been identified by scholars as ‚Äúmanufactured‚Äù scientific controversies, in which rhetors seek to promote or delay public policy by announcing that there is an ongoing scientific debate about a matter for which there is actually an overwhelming scientific consensus. The comparative study of argumentative dynamics in the cases of AIDS dissent, global warming skepticism, and intelligent design reveals the deployment of rhetorical traps that take advantage of balancing norms and appeals to democratic values."
https://muse.jhu.edu/article/440840

"The opponents of evolution and global warming face a formidable challenge: to convince the public and decision-makers that there is significant dissent among scientists in two fields where in reality a strong consensus exists. "
http://reports.ncse.com/index.php/rncse/article/viewFile/71/64

"Further, deniers exploit the sense of fair play present in most scientists, and also in the general public, especially in open and democratic societies. Calling for a fair discussion of dissenting views, independent analysis of evidence, and openness to alternatives is likely to garner support, regardless of the context."
http://journals.plos.org/plosmedicine/article?id=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040256

"I want first to identify and contextualize what I call pseudoskepticism, as opposed to scientific skepticism.
[...]
In contrast to the cases above, the form of science denialism I wish to explore below is what I refer to as pseudoskepticism.
[...]
When scientific consensus is rejected by *non-experts who naively consider themselves more scientifically astute than the collective scientific community*, it is appropriately labeled pseudoskepticism."
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/tops.12179/full

"Accounting for the Appeal to the Authority of Experts
[...]
The account of expert/citizen communication starts by acknowledging the general (if ambiguous) norm: it is imprudent for the nonexpert to go against the expert view (Goodwin 1998). When a local tells a tourist that a road is dangerous, or a doctor advises a patient that smoking is harmful to her health, or a climate scientist tells the rest of us that the world is warming because of our activities*, then the tourist or patient or we would be dumb keep going along regardless. ‚Äò‚ÄòOnly the *fool would not want some expert advice in technical matters‚Äô‚Äô (Fischer 2009, p. 139); ‚Äò‚Äòother things being equal, we ought to prefer the judgments of those who ‚Äòknow what they are talking about‚Äô‚Äô‚Äô (Collins and Evans 2007, p. 2)."

Now, I don't really get into climate conversations often, I think this video is my first.  This is not my subject.  But we are being asked to make major changes to essentially avert a disaster.  This consensus demands action.  This is not like the consensus over evolution.  Outside of science and education, the consensus over evolution does not make demands of society.  The consensus over climate makes demands.  And it makes threats.  And if people outside climate science start to question climate science, one can hardly be surprised, they are not merely asking us  to take their findings as authoritative.   They are asking us to act on their predictions.  And whatever one wants to say about climate science, the predictions are still non-specific enough to cause me to believe they really don't know what the effect of climate change will be, and that their science is still quite primitive.

author: W. Hoffman

text:
+W. Hoffman

"1.  Do you think there's no way a poll could yield such results without bias?"

Yup. Just like a poll could yield a 99% consensus on human evolution among PhD, research biomedical scientists. For example:

http://www.pewinternet.org/2015/07/23/an-elaboration-of-aaas-scientists-views/

This is because experts in a scientific field are more likely to know about evidence in that field, how to reason in that field, etc. So if there's solid evidence in that field, a consensus will usually form among the experts. This consensus might not extend to non-experts, since the non-experts are more likely to be ignorant of the science, not understand how to reason about that scientific field, etc. That point applies to evolutionary biology just as it applies to climate science.



"2.  If it were truly 97%, could you not imagine the questions were framed to leave no chance?"

The results have been replicated by independent research groups, using different questions framings. You'd know this if you bothered to read any of the sources I've been citing to you for months. This is shown in:

"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"

Figures 88 (v043) and 2 (v007) of "The Bray and von Storch 5th International Survey of Climate Scientists 2015/2016"
https://www.hzg.de/imperia/md/content/hzg/zentrale_einrichtungen/bibliothek/berichte/hzg_reports_2016/hzg_report_2016_2.pdf

The ~90% consensus attributing recent global warming to humans, as shown on page 49 of:
"Model, manifestation and attribution of climate change"



"3.  Aren't you the least bit suspicious of a survey of "climate scientists" whose livelihood depends on their beliefs?"

No, because that's just a silly, paranoid conspiracy theory you have. Scientists don't just en masse make up conclusions to match their funding sources. Otherwise, most scientists would have stopped citing evidence of AGW under AGW denialist, politically conservative administrations; yet that didn't happen. And if AGW research was just a money-motivated conspiracy, then you would not expect such as broad scientific consensus to hold across scientists from different political/governmental systems; yet such a consensus did arise:

"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"

Nor would you expect the scientific consensus to be supported by multiple lines of evidence, including from evidence from non-government-funded studies, studies that were done before there was much of a political rationale for funding climate science research, and studies that lack a politically-motivated funding rationale; yet we do have such lines of evidence.

It also makes no sense to claim that these scientists are just lying for the sake of funding, or because their field depends on it. After all, climate science is an old field (dating back to the 1800s) that includes more than anthropogenic climate change, just like oncology/cancer is a field that includes more than smoking-induced cancer. So scientists can get funding to study non-anthropogenic climate change, just like oncologists can get funding to explore cancer that isn't caused by smoking. Thus, it makes little sense to claim that climate scientists are all lying to prop up their field, just like it makes little sense to claim that doctors are all lying (to prop up their field) when they claim that smoking causes cancer. To claim otherwise, is to show that you ignorantly believe that climate science is just about anthropogenic climate change.

Furthermore, you seem to have little understanding of how grant funding is awarded. It isn't awarded based on researchers guaranteeing that their research will support an accepted, pre-determined consensus conclusion. In fact, the research that gets the most attention, prestigious prizes (ex: Nobel prizes), etc. is research that overturns accepted conclusions or breaks new ground, as opposed to just supporting the consensus position. 

Grant proposals may offer hypotheses to test, but the proposals typically leave open the possibility that the hypotheses will not be confirmed and instead a novel conclusion may be supported. For example, they might propose testing one of the predictions of AGW theory. Those sorts of studies are often funded. And they often end up getting evidence that supports the predictions of AGW, even though it wasn't it was always possible for them to have disconfirmed the predictions.

Anyway, grant funding is awarded based on things such as the proposal writers previously publication record (to show that you can do published research, when given money), preliminary data presented in the proposal, how well the proposal writers know the field (as displayed in their grant proposal), whether the proposal writers have access to the equipment/tools needed for their proposed project, etc. You'd know this if you'd ever bothered to apply for a research grant, spoken with scientists who'd applied for such grants, looked up the grant proposal guidelines (which are freely available on the NIH website, NASA website, etc.), or spoken with grant reviewers. I've done all four of these. Trying doing those 4 things some time.



"4 [...]"

Your questions 4 - 6 are silly red herrings based on you not grasping the difference between an evidence-based scientific consensus vs. topics like politics, business, etc.



"7.  Of the 97%, what part is involved in the fundamental physics of AGW, do you think?"

The 97% consensus includes the following claims:

A1) There has been global warming since the mid-20th century.
A2) Humans (largely via anthropogenic greenhouse gases) caused most of this recent warming.
A3) Most of the recent (or near future) climate change is (or will be) caused by humans.
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

And just so you know, Jesuits are not just priests who have faith.  Jesuit studies take 12 years and are as tough as many military academies, and then some go on to earn Ph.D.s.
