author: W. Hoffman

text:
+W. Hoffman Yes, I read your entire post. There wasn't much beyond your weird non sequitur. Sorry, I was in a hurry and wasn't prepared to precisely qualify my position on AGW, especially as I've already done so a few times in this 200-comment-long thread. Alas, no, I don't expect anyone to read through this entire monstrosity, but repeating myself gets tiring,

I still don't understand what you were trying to say with the '2+2 = 4 therefore AGW' thing. It's pretty clear by your tone that you think I'm a moron. Are you suggesting that I'm simply taking the claims I hear at face value without doing some fact checking?

As for 'keeping the faith' - I don't keep faith. I threw that out a long time ago along with dogma and superstition. Further, I try very hard not to tie my identity to my beliefs, and so generally don't have as difficult a time changing beliefs as others might. This was a difficult skill to acquire, and while I still haven't quite mastered it (I'm only human) I think I do pretty well these not to get upset when my erroneous beliefs are corrected. I try to be open to all the evidence, not just that which comports with my already established views. (Key word: try. It's hard work and echo chambers are just so easy to belong to.) If you've got something to share that add to the discussion, then please share it. 

The science on greenhouse gasses is, as I mentioned earlier in this thread, elementary-school-level. A 3rd grade child could demonstrate the greenhouse effect with a variety of gasses as well as quantify each one's specific contribution - in fact, I along with the rest of my 3rd grade science class back in 1989 did exactly that. (Our control was vacuum - needless to say, the teacher handled that apparatus for us.)

CO2 is not the only greenhouse gas, nor is it (by unit) the most potent. Methane is a really bad one, and water vapor (the most abundant greenhouse gas in our atmosphere) is up there too. I think the reason CO2 is discussed so much is because our contribution to worldwide CO2 levels is massive and easy to notice on a graph. Quantifying global CO2 isn't exactly grade-school science, but it's straightforward and easily understood by your average educated layman. I don't really see any reason to doubt the measurements that have been taken, by multiple independent parties - error bars notwithstanding.

The thing about climate change is that there is no one cause. Humans play a role, as well as a myriad of other systems in our lovely biosphere. Nothing exists in a vacuum, and everything we do has consequences of some sort.

As far as the specific consequences of our involvement in mucking with global climate; I'm taking all predictions with the appropriate amount of salt. We are notoriously bad at predicting the behavior of complex systems, and climate is a beast to model with any sort of accuracy. I will say that the general theme - bad times ahead - is probably accurate, although to what degree is anyone's guess.

Personally, I've been on-board with reducing humanity's carbon footprint long before climate change became a hot-button issue. Fossil fuels are so 19th century. 

Oh, and - I don't know why, but Youtube flagged your two most recent replies as spam, and is not allowing me to undo that. Dunno what's up.
author: Erik

text:
+KoreyRB "That is a immature response." - Snarky, perhaps, but not immature.

"Just google" - No, that's not how this works. Firstly, as science and reality are not determined by consensus, the existence of lack thereof of "the 97%" is and irrelevant red herring.

Secondly, while I know I didn't specifically ask you for your source: When you make a claim and are asked for the source material, "just google" is not sufficient. You can "just google" and come up with ample nonsense to back up literally any claim you'd like to make. The point of asking for sources is so that I can evaluate your source to determine whether I think it's credible. If you have a specific source, please present it so that I can do this and make up my own mind.

"your a dumbass sheep" - How precious.

author: Erik

text:
+Erik  On the basis of what you wrote in the post starting with (E:): "Yes, I read your entire post.", I don't see all that much to disagree on.  Mostly, you are talking about choices we humans may make, and truth be known, I'd rather see o&g reserves used for medicine, building materials, plastics, adhesives and the whole panoply of constructive products they make possible, than simply burning them up.

I also favor moving to a nuclear energy production system, and eventually a fusion-based economy (with hydrogen for transportation).

What I won't put up with (and the entire thrust of all my posts on the topic, both here and on my own channel, is based on this) is being bullied by people selling a fear, cloaked in scientific terms.  Not only is it fundamentally dishonest, but if we can be sold scientific error in the name of the "greater good", we can be sold anything.  I don't see you doing this, but it is behind most of the AGW anxiety, so I made myself clear.

WH: "1+1=2; therefore AGW is true" is not meant to suggest you or anyone else is a moron.  It is only to suggest that if you consider the foundation of the AGW theory, and find it flawed (which 1+1=2 is not), then everything built on it is fragile, suspect.  Your comment that you did an experiment in 3d grade that showed warming suggests you had some version of Fourier's experiments recreated by your teacher.
Since this brings the discussion back to science, I'd like to pursue it.  Realizing it was now 28 years ago, I don't suppose you recall the details, but can I ask what it was about it that convinced you that "anthropogenic global warming" was well modeled by it?  Have you reexamined it, now knowing what you have learned in the intervening years, or do you regard it as bedrock, on which all else is built?

I ask because sometimes we get shown things, and even by good teachers, the things are wrong...no intention to misguide implied...simply error.  I will use a concrete example that ultimately has relevance to the whole climate, and if you don't mind, I'll do it with a question related to 3d grade science class.  Do you know why there are high tides on both sides of the earth at the same time?

BTW, I don't think YT marks anything as "spam".  Someone who didn't like my comments was trying to game the YT system.  Life goes on.
author: W. Hoffman

text:
W. Hoffman - "What I won't put up with [...] is being bullied by people selling a fear, cloaked in scientific terms." Damn right. That kind of behavior harms not only the people who are deceived by it, but the entire scientific enterprise by turning what is supposed to be a tool for discovery and enlightenment into a malicious weapon that serves only greed. If you have some evidence that the current state of the AGW hypothesis is informed by this kind of thinking, then I absolutely want to see that.

"not meant to suggest you or anyone else is a moron." That was kind of a knee-jerk reaction and I apologize; a lot of people like to be rude on the internet, but that doesn't give me license to assume. I understand what you mean now - although I'll remind you that "1+1=2" is only axiomatically true, and thus only as solid as the axioms upon which it is laid. =P

I'm not a climate scientist, so I don't know really know whether the AGW hypothesis is flawed or not. I tend to outsource the knowledge-gathering to field experts, and I tend to trust those experts regarding their findings. I think that most people do this, whether they profess a distrust of science in general or not. I'm aware of bias and deception, but I think that most professionals are decent, honest people who are as interested in understanding reality as I am. Optimistic, perhaps, but that's just where I'm at with all this. When I do find evidence of bias or deception, naturally I adjust my internal models appropriately - but I'm not going to preemptively distrust scientists or their findings. I'd be stuck in the dark ages if I did that consistently.

As far as the details regarding the experiment my science teacher had us perform - alas, no, I don't remember very much at all aside from the results I personally gathered. I'd like to be able to describe the setup in detail, but I only have very vague visual memories from then. It was a long time ago and those memories have been stepped on a lot in the intervening years - but that's what I get for trying to record data into meat and fats. =P I'll do some research into the experiments you mentioned and see if any bells ring.

"what it was about it that convinced you that "anthropogenic global warming" was well modeled by it?" - Eh, I wouldn't say that. The purpose of the experiment was only to demonstrate and quantify the greenhouse effect on a small scale, not to model climate change. If you're asking me why I'm convinced that AGW is well modeled in general, well I wouldn't say that either. I would say that my level of certainty here is maybe 70%. If I was more directly informed on the topic, I could revise that probability estimate, but alas, there are only so many hours in a day, and I don't really find climate science to be very fulfilling of a field, personally. I'm more into astronomy, chemistry, and physics although I'm not a professional in any of these fields.

As far as why I think AGW is more likely than not a factor in climate change - well I think I covered that in my previous reply, but I'll restate: nothing lives in a vacuum, and the things we do as a species affect our environment on a global scale. Specifically, the carbon in the fuels we burn at gigaton levels annually has to go somewhere, and since there's none left behind after combustion (ideally), that 'somewhere' can only be the atmosphere. It isn't a very big leap to go from 'CO2 is demonstrated to be a greenhouse gas' to 'increasing the amount of global CO2 in the atmosphere will result in a commensurate increase in the global greenhouse effect.'

To be clear, I don't think that humans are the only causal factor - far from it - and I'm still unsure just how much impact we really have in the grand scheme of things. Complex systems are difficult to model and predict, and I am pretty much entirely out of my depth when it comes to climate models. But I do trust the experts who we rely on to investigate these things.

"I ask because sometimes we get shown things, and even by good teachers, the things are wrong..." - If you're implying that my teacher used this experiment as a comment on climate change, I could be wrong but I don't think this was the case. My memory is pretty foggy here but I don't think climate change was even discussed, or if it was it was more hypothetical than anything else. You are correct, however, in that sometimes well-meaning authorities allow ideological biases to impact their work. We are all human, and nobody is immune to bias. All we can do is correct for our biases when we spot them, as best we can.

"Do you know why there are high tides on both sides of the earth at the same time?" - If this was covered in any of my science classes (and it's likely that it was), I don't remember. However, I have seen several differing pop-sci explanations, none of which I can recall the details for at the moment - but this is the kind of factoid that I tend to outsource to google for remembering. I haven't been interested enough in the question to really dig into any of the explanations I've heard to suss out what's true, though. You've got me curious though; where are you going with this? =)

"Life goes on." That it does, that it does. Thank you, by the way, for the conversation so far - it's rare to hold an intellectual discussion in youtube comments on a hot-button issue without it devolving into ad hominems and general asshattery. =P

author: Pamela Lopez

text:
+Never going straight
I'm not really the right person to ask the first or second questions to, unfortunately - I don't have a lot of personal experience with solar power or electrical vehicle manufacturing, so I don't know the specifics. It's true that the environmental impact of manufacturing green'energy often goes overlooked by green energy advocates, and this is definitely a problem that deserves more scrutiny.

Really, it's the same deal with your second question, just in a different domain, although it seems by the way you phrased your question that you already have a good start on answering it yourself. I will say though that my intuition tells me that unless some electric vehicle manufacturer was being excessively dirty in their process, EVs are probably guaranteed to be cleaner in the long run than their gas burning counterparts - but I don't know how to quantify this.

Regarding your third question: can we ever stop man-made climate change? Yes, I think it's possible, but only if we all collectively leave the planet behind and go find a new environment to live in - and then we'll just start changing that climate, simply because we're active agents in a (somewhat) closed system. Every action we take as a species has consequences for ourselves and everyone sharing our space. Beyond that, I think it will be possible to modify our contribution to the changes our climate is undergoing, but I don't think it'll ever be possible to stop contributing altogether.

However, I think 'doomed' is probably an overreaction. Change is inevitable, regardless of whether it's human-caused or not, but change doesn't necessarily mean chaos, turmoil, or suffering. I also think some of the hype regarding the consequences of climate change are overly dramatic at best and downright misleading at worst, depending on who you're listening to for your apocalypse forecast. My advice, if you're anxious about such dire predictions, is to consider that the human species has survived very dramatic climate shifts during its short existence, and while things might get difficult for us for a while, it very likely won't be anywhere near as bad as the media is saying it's going to be.

Lastly: You're 14 and you're asking questions that adults three times your age don't bother asking. The fact that you're actively seeking answers to those questions (instead of just passively hoping someone else will come along to hand them to you) is just incredible, and the fact that you're actually allowing new information to change your mind - well it's people like you that give me hope for my species. Hold on to that skill - it will serve you very, very well in life.

+W. Hoffman - I am also curious to see your answers to these questions, especially since I wasn't really able to give any decent answers. =)
author: Erik

text:
+Never going straight  Many people confuse the idea of anthropogenic global warming with thoughtless pollution.  They are not the same at all, and my best way to say it is that your exhaled breath in a day contributes more CO2 than all your cell phone usage, and probably more in a year even counting the additional CO2 to manufacture the cell phone.  [..and I say that even while stating that CO2 does not make the Earth warm, nor does more CO2 make it still warmer].
You are in balance simply because your biology as a human is that of the Earth, and even to the extent you ski, you do more to the snow by skiing on it than you do by breathing.  Just don't go burning forests down (and even that is not "irreversible").

"Polluting" by careless release of wastes other than carbon, on the other hand leads to different issues, including spoiling views, making others clean up after them, and things that interfere with others enjoying their lives, but I frankly don't see how a 14-year old can be negatively active in that area, and yet showing the concern you have for our environment.

So be of good cheer and be confident that in your person there is no harm created to the environment, and if there is any sort of influence, it is of a type the Earth has handled for millions of years.

author: Relo

text:
There are solutions, the trouble is implementation. Implementation is a problem because much of the world is a democracy and therefore policies that are good for the people but do not have the consent of the people are hard to pass. This is why it is important for people to understand and acknowledge climate change.

There are, of course, other problems with policy solutions. These policies often, at least in the short run, curb economic growth by taxing or limiting pollution. Because pollution is a result of physical capital production, reducing the pollution allowances temporarily reduce the economy's ability to produce physical goods. That reduces the number of jobs, especially in poorer areas that rely on the production of physical goods.

So policies need to also exist that aid those that will be negatively affected by the temporary economic downturn.

In short, environmental policies are expensive and unpopular, but are (at least eventually) necessary. We can only reduce the cost of the policies by enacting them sooner rather than later, and we can make them less unpopular by educating the public.
author: Grimm

text:
¬†@relo999¬†
Don''t forget waste incineration. It has the same energy conversion efficiency as oil (33%), recycles waste materials, and is a waste disposal method. They are also creating ways to reduce waste to energy incinerators CO2 emissions (which are already lower than coal and oil and some natural gas power plants).

My problem with what you said is that, if the government paid 25% of a "green" car, my taxes would go way up. I think CO2 taxes would work better.

A subsidy on a car would only benefit me if I then went and bought that car, otherwise it would just increase my taxes even if I sold my car and bought a bike (which is even more favorable than any kind of car). A tax on the pollutant allows the consumer to make the choice of what they buy while also providing the government with more funding for additional programs.

Individuals may even be indifferent to the tax if policy changes included a reduction in taxes elsewhere. If we reduced income tax and raised carbon taxes such that people were paying the same amount of taxes if they continued their current consumption habits, people would be indifferent to the tax increase because we would have effectively given them more money to spend. However, because they now saw the price of gas go up and their wallets grow and slowly drain as they continued driving their big car, they may be more inclined to change their spending habits.

There are other policy options that exist beyond these mentioned that cost very little from the government but still change consumer behavior.

text:
¬†@iamihop¬†
These scenarios are exactly where government intervention is reasonable. Even Adam Smith believed the governments ought to intervene in market failures. When the private cost of production does not reflect the total (social) cost of production, the market tends to over produce, causing a market failure. This is precisely the case with pollution from production today. When you buy a gallon of gas, a portion of the cost is paid by you (about $3 where I am) and another portion is paid in environmental damages that negatively affect others. Because I do not incur the total cost of that gallon of gas, I will purchase more gasoline than is socially optimal.

Governments have a role here is correcting prices. This scenario could use a per unit tax on CO2 emissions that will correct the price of gasoline to reflect the total social cost of production (private costs+environmental costs+health costs= social costs).

In the case of taxes that serve to change consumer behavior it is important for governments to provide alternative options so that consumers do not lose utility from the tax. In this case, the government could reduce income tax by the same rate that they will increase the CO2 tax rate such that tax revenue remains the same if consumers do nothing to change their behavior. This will both increase the cost of gasoline, but then give consumers enough money to afford cheaper or equivalent alternatives such as "green" vehicles and maybe a really nice bicycle.

This does not give the government more power. It is a fair and intended use of government power. This is the most capitalistic method to reduce pollution: getting the prices right.

Green energy is quite efficient. I live for a goo 50% of windmills and the other largely on nuclear (which is also extremely clean, at least when done in modern facilities). So I can safely say it's really efficient. Not to mention in most places you can build hydroelectric dams. And considering how most people use their cars, using electric would be still be quite functional. Not to mention hydrogen would be a full replacement without much, if any, loss.

And of course their are positives. But they don't outway the negatives.
Polar bears can fish more in winter but malaria (and other tropical diseases) also spread more and of course other species hurt more. Then we have rising of sea levels which comes hand in hand with flooding. The acidity is getting more off which hurts ocean life not to mention more oxygen starved areas (which is already suffering due to overfishing). Because that article you shown only uses almost anecdotal points to show his view, but it isn't remotely hard to think of any flip side of the thing he names in other locations.
author: Relo

text:
¬†@relo999¬†¬†Wind is very inefficient. The cost, not only in land, but in poor energy delivery. It's not economical at all yet.

Nuclear is great, and here in the USA it's the government that is blocking more of them. That's hilarious. Instead of them forcing a green agenda on us, they're preventing people from freely choosing to go that way.

Was the government that shut down their prototype liquid thorium reactor.¬†

It doesn't solve portable energy though.¬†

Electric cars draw their power from the grid, which isn't very clean right now because of the government. They also pollute a lot purely in their fabrication. They are also not practical for larger transport and shipping vehicles/boats/planes.¬†

Portable energy is the real issue, and moving away to greener energies is not wrong or bad, as long as it is gradual and done without force. It's not possible in poorer countries. They need the cheapest energy possible to get work done, to get energy available.¬†

The main point of the article to is to demonstrate that climate change is not a doomsday end of the world catastrophic nightmare that demands we give up all of our freedom to fight it, as the media would portray it.

It's a minor concern, possibly a minor benefit for the next few decades (there is no scientific consensus on this part) and something that should be thought of carefully, not recklessly.¬†
author: UnknownXV

text:
¬†@UnknownXV¬†¬†In regards to wind it really depends on where you live and how big the grid is. Great for, what they would call local, in america.¬†

BTW what a bloody idiots they are for blocking nuclear. It's like they still live in the 70's...

But Hydrogen is a good alternative even for transport, granted expensive to implement. And fabrication of such cars is also polluting, but most of that can be solved by making the power grid cleaner.

And I agree that climate change isn't a doomsday scenario in the near future. But at the end of the day I trust nature to keep itself in balance for more than I do people, even if there wouldn't be a consensus.

And I'm not saying everybody should be forced to go green or some shit like that. I'm saying that the government should make the green alternative more attractive than the more polluting actions. And of course take steps to make the green alternative more available.
author: Relo

text:
¬†@relo999¬†¬†Some areas are more efficient for wind, but it's usually quite variable and just not effective enough right now. Similar to hydro power, though where that is viable it is very efficient. I live in Quebec, electricity here is very clean and very cheap. It's great. Maybe it could improve, and I'm all for researching into new technologies to get there, both privately for business and through crowdsourcing. I don't believe in government funded research., People shouldn't be forced into supporting research they disagree with. Moreover, why should we let stuffy, dusty old politicians decide what gets funded?

At least we can agree they are idiots for blocking nuclear energy.

Hydrogen cars? I don't know much about that. You can make an engine based on this that is as energy dense or more than gasoline? What about the cost?

I guess we won't agree on government action. I am all for moving towards a greener world, I just don't believe in using force to get there. If I am unable to convince people, it is my own failure. I will not resort to the lazy and immoral method because I've failed.¬†
author: UnknownXV

text:
¬†@UnknownXV¬†¬†Well do you think private/corporate research isn't as biased as you claim? Do you think ExonMobil cares for green energy more than money? I'd say government research, at least non US and other countries heavily reliable on oil, are the most trust worthy.

Hydrogen is actually more efficient (NASA used it for the space shuttles, when they still did those). The only real downside of it is compared to gasonline is that it's less fuel eficient than most post mid-90's cars per liter. Currently they are trying to get them in some places, but only iceland (being a island with small population) has hydrogen tanking spots as common as gas.

I'd hardly call government action immoral. How I see it it's more is saving people from themselves if need be by disincentivising certain actions. Most places already have such a system in place to a certain extend.
author: Relo

text:
¬†@relo999¬†¬†I think a business is focused on profit, so if there is money in green energy they will pursue it. If on the other hand it is not economically viable yet, they won't, that's where crowdfunded research is important.¬†

I'll look into hydrogen, it sounds interesting. It's entirely clean?

Government is force. That is literally all it is. To force my agenda on others, even if I am convinced I am right, that I view as immoral. I also have no desire to save people from themselves.¬†
author: UnknownXV

text:
¬†@UnknownXV¬†¬†But remember if a company makes it money with oil, they would be really hard pressed to say oil is bad.

If you burn hydrogen it becomes water. So yes, as far as I know it's entirely clean.

And that is where we differ.¬†
author: Relo

text:
¬†@relo999¬†¬†Water vapor is a potent greenhouse gas though is it not? Pretty sure I read that before. Might be in some other format though.

I don't care if a company says oil is bad or not though, I just care about what is practical. The only problem is if big oil companies lobby the government to prevent new technologies from coming in. Similar to how the taxi lobby tries to block Uber and Lyft.¬†
author: UnknownXV

text: ¬†@UnknownXV¬†¬†To some extend yes, but it doesn't hang around like CO2 does. Watervapor will turn into clouds (which block a good chunk of solar radiation) and will turn rain.
author: Relo

text: ¬†@relo999¬†¬†Yeah I figured it wasn't as bad in the long-run. Certainly better to breathe water vapor.¬†

text: ¬†@UnknownXV¬†¬†Not to mention the car related suicides going down. Hahahaha.

text: ¬†@relo999¬†¬†Huh, you went there? I guess I have to chuckle a bit.¬†
